column2: 'Europe'];"The principality of Andorra is sandwiched between France and Spain in the eastern Pyrenees. The sixth-smallest country in Europe
column3: with an area of 180 sq miles (468 sq km)
column4: it is smaller than every English county apart from Rutland. Landlocked
column5: and lying entirely above 840 metres (2
column7: the climate is
column8: as you would expect
column9: mostly continental and alpine. Because Andorra lies on the southern
column10: Spanish side of the highest peaks
column11: which run along its northern border
column12: it is more sheltered and drier than locations on the French side. Winters are fairly cold
column13: dry and sunny
column14: with as much as five hours of daily sunshine in January and February. Winter temperatures in the capital
column15: Andorra la Vella
column16: are mostly a few degrees above freezing and precipitation is mostly low – just 160mm (6.3in) from December to February. However
column17: heavy snowfalls can occur
column18: especially when fronts sweep in from the Atlantic to the west. In Soldeu
column19: at an altitude of 1
column20: 800 metres (5
column22: temperatures are much colder throughout the year
column23: staying below freezing from December to March. Temperatures rise rapidly from May onwards
column24: with average daily maxima of the mid-20s Celsius (high 70s Fahrenheit) in the summer months; pleasantly warm but rarely very hot. The wettest months are usually May and June
column25: when there are regular thunderstorms. Rainfall is low and fairly regular for the remainder of the year.";https://www.theguardian.com/news/2022/jan/04/weatherwatch-andorra-continental-alpine-climate

column10: 'Black British culture'];"Shortly after Margaret Thatcher became prime minister in May 1979
column11: Eddie Chambers made an artwork called Destruction of the National Front. Then a 19-year-old student in Wolverhampton
column12: Chambers reconfigured the union jack as a swastika
column13: before tearing it into fragments across four panels. The image stands as a defiant rebuke to a resurgent far right
column14: evoking the anger many Black Britons felt at the time. The work was emblematic of the Blk Art Group
column15: a radical association of young Black artists founded by Chambers in 1979. The group
column16: stylised as Blk and pronounced “Black”
column17: aimed to combat racism with work that focused on the experience of being Black in Thatchers’ Britain
column18: while promoting a distinctly Black British political identity. Although short-lived – it only lasted for five years – the group casts a long shadow over British art
column19: through its influence on subsequent generations of Black artists and its impact on contemporaries such as Lubaina Himid and Sonia Boyce. More than 40 years on from the group’s foundation
column20: Keith Piper
column22: still looks every inch the artist in his red flannel shirt and goatee. Malta-born and raised in Birmingham
column23: he now lives in London
column24: though his accent is still unmistakably Brummie. Piper met Chambers in 1979 while studying at Lanchester Polytechnic
column25: Coventry
column26: now known as Coventry University. “I overheard him talking about a show
column27: ” he says
column28: referring to Black Art An’ Done
column29: held at Wolverhampton Art Gallery. “I thought
column30: ‘He’s very serious.’ But we had a lot in common because we were the only two Black students on the course.” Chambers quickly set about recruiting Black students from West Midlands’ art schools and soon their ranks grew. By 1982
column31: Dominic Dawes
column32: Claudette Johnson
column33: Wenda Leslie
column34: Ian Palmer
column35: Donald Rodney and Marlene Smith had joined. “Eddie was a great organiser
column36: ” says Piper
column37: “but we all had our own specific creative concerns.”

column1: The group’s work features prominently in a new exhibition at Tate Britain
column2: Life Between Islands
column3: which focuses on the work of British artists of Caribbean heritage. Life Between Islands was co-curated by the director of Tate Britain
column4: Alex Farquharson
column5: and David A Bailey
column6: an artist and contemporary of the Blk group. You can see how their work influenced subsequent generations
column7: not least the Black YBAs Chris Ofili
column8: Yinka Shonibare and Steve McQueen. Chambers
column9: now professor of art history and African diaspora art at the University of Texas at Austin
column10: epitomised Blk’s political approach. How Much Longer You Bastards
column11: from 1983
column12: directly challenged the activities of Barclay’s bank in South Africa at a time when Margaret Thatcher was refusing to impose sanctions on the apartheid regime. The collage features the bank’s logo alongside pages from the Financial Times and a widely publicised image of parents carrying their dead child after the 1976 Soweto uprising
column13: to illustrate British complicity in the inhumanity of apartheid.

column1: Piper
column2: in turn
column3: incorporated text into pieces such as 1983’s The Body Politic in order to articulate complex narratives of dehumanisation and torture
column4: for which he took inspiration from the work of Gavin Jantjes and Rasheed Areen. The work features two naked and headless bodies – a white woman
column5: a black man – with identical text alongside each figure: “To you I was always (just) a body.” Piper says: “I needed the audience to understand the hostile scrutiny Black bodies came under from the white majority.” The group’s work was always rooted in the politics of the era. “Wolverhampton was one of a number of places to be decimated by the experiment Thatcher was undertaking
column6: ” says Piper. “It was the usual tensions of the 1980s – the far right on the rise
column7: anti-apartheid
column8: Greenham Common
column9: policing
column10: the New Cross Fire. It was a very politicised time – and that was core to my perspective as a young Black man.” This febrile atmosphere was evident in the reception the group received. They were immediately polarising: a breath of fresh air in some quarters
column11: an unwelcome source of aggravation in others. “We were surrounded by a lot of reactionary forces
column12: people who were openly hostile
column13: ” says Piper. At a 1983 showing of The Pan-Afrikan Connection at the Herbert in Coventry
column14: complaints from a security guard about the exhibition’s subject matter forced the gallery to erect a warning notice outside the entrance: “Not suitable for people under 18.” Even on the left
column15: the group’s work was largely dismissed. A note left in the visitors’ book read: “Angry. Too angry … more Marxist approach needed.” In the Guardian
column16: Irene McManus wrote: “Their work is really just a collection of political posters.” But some Blk members are now considered innovative. Donald Rodney was a leading figure
column17: who died in 1998 at just 36. “Donald was a very active and energetic person
column18: ” says Piper
column19: who shared a Nottingham flat with the artist in the early 1980s and is now a trustee of his estate. Completed shortly before his death
column20: In the House of My Father is a closeup photograph of Rodney’s hand. In his palm is a tiny sculpture of a house made of pieces of his own skin. Rodney suffered from sickle cell anaemia
column21: an extremely painful blood condition that is particularly common in people of African or Caribbean heritage.

column1: The artist and curator Marlene Smith was 18 when she joined the group and believes they shared a vision. “We were very coherent
column2: both in terms of our pan-Africanism but also in wanting to make Black lives visible. There was a lot of protest in the work but what’s overlooked sometimes is the humanity.” Pan-Africanism – the idea that African peoples and diaspora share a common history and identity
column3: often symbolised through the colours red
column4: gold and green – was a guiding principle for the group. “We wanted to illustrate the connection between Victorian colonialism and the struggle that we had as teenagers to find our place
column5: ” says Smith. “We were all children of Windrush but
column6: for me
column7: pan-Africanism wasn’t just about making sense of the world but also about making sense of me.” The movement could only provide limited answers
column8: however. “Pan-Africanism really fed me but it couldn’t help me understand the role gender played in my identity. We were devouring books in an attempt to make sense of that time.” She mentions Ain’t I a Woman: Black Women and Feminism
column9: by bell hooks
column10: who died last month
column11: as well as the work of Toni Morrison and Alice Walker. Smith’s 1985 sculptural installation Good Housekeeping depicts a Black woman beneath the words: “My mother opens the door at 7am she is not bulletproof.” The work was a direct response to the police shooting of Cherry Groce
column12: who was left permanently paralysed by the incident that incited the 1985 Brixton Uprising.

column1: Smith remembers the first meeting of Blk at Chambers’ parents house: “Claudette Johnson did an absolutely jaw-dropping job of showing her work in relation to the canon – Picasso
column2: Rubens
column3: Manet’s Olympia. She showed us how Black women were seen as decorative in art history
column4: either as exotica
column5: or evidence of how wealthy someone was.” In a statement for The Pan-Afrikan Connection
column6: Johnson wrote: “While the black woman experiences oppression on the grounds of her sex
column7: sexuality and race
column8: there is not yet a word that describes the specific and deliberate nature of this oppression.” As she says now: “The word ‘intersectionality’ didn’t exist at the time.” Johnson’s career stalled in the 1990s but has restarted in earnest. Last month she presented a solo exhibition
column9: Still Here
column10: at Hollybush Gardens in London. “The oppression of black women was a hot potato. It could be seen as divisive. People would ask me where I was putting my energy in terms of fighting for change: are you black
column11: or are you a woman?” Johnson’s 2017 work Reclining Figure was emblematic
column12: she says
column13: of “the subtle and dramatic difference that occurs when the person doing the gazing was a black female herself.” This almost lifesize image depicts an exhausted Black woman lying horizontal. “My mum used to adopt a similar position on the sofa after she’d been on her feet all day. I had in mind that poignant moment when she finally wasn’t doing something for someone else.” Of Blk
column14: she says: “In the 1980s
column15: we were seen as people passing through – so much of our work was about making the point that we were here to stay.” Sonia Boyce was a contemporary
column16: as was the future Turner-prize winner Lubaina Himid. Smith and Johnson both mention The Thin Black Line
column17: a show curated by Himid at the Institute for Contemporary Arts in 1985
column18: as the high-water mark of Black British art in the period. The show featured key works from 11 Black female artists
column19: including Johnson
column20: Smith and Boyce
column21: along with Himid herself. “That show was like storming the citadel
column22: ” says Johnson. “Lubaina had gone to the Royal College and was trying to find black artists – she curated
column23: she wrote
column24: she was like a magnet gathering different artists together. In terms of persuasive power
column25: she was very similar to Eddie Chambers.”

column1: Blk’s members were not only defined by their youth (at 25
column2: Johnson was the oldest when the group disbanded) but also by their art school education. “Blk wasn’t outsider art
column3: ” says Johnson. “We were full of hope that we could change things – that our art could mobilise black people and inspire white people to see us differently. We were trying to bring in a new audience that hadn’t been served by those galleries before.” Beyond Blk
column4: 1980s Britain was fertile ground for a thriving ecosystem of Black artists. Now 74
column5: Tam Joseph was both a forerunner and a contemporary of Blk. Sitting in his paint and dust strewn studio
column6: he explains how his childhood in Dominica lends his work a different emphasis. “I am Windrush
column7: ” he says. “I didn’t experience growing up as a Black child in England.” By way of explaining his approach
column8: he says: “I love taking the mickey.” And he points to a bubble-wrapped painting of Jimi Hendrix as Frans Hals’s Laughing Cavalier. “Hendrix looks more like a cavalier than a fat white man
column9: ” he says. Another painting
column10: 1982’s The Spirit of Carnival
column11: encapsulates the legacy of police aggression towards British Caribbean communities. The image features a carnival masquerader
column12: alone in a sea of British police; Joseph was inspired by his experience at the 1976 Notting Hill carnival
column13: where a riot broke out after police clashed with revellers. Debates around education
column14: housing and the police were central to the work of many Black artists in the 1980s. Joseph’s 1983 work UK School Report depicts the passage of a Black child through the British education system in three portraits captioned: “Good at sports”
column15: “Likes music” and “Needs surveillance”. The director and artist Steve McQueen has mentioned the work in reference to his Year 3 photo series.

column1: While at art school
column2: Denzil Forrester was charged with using insulting language after he was apprehended outside a jewellery shop in London. “They thought I was casing the joint but I was just drawing it. They came over to see what I was doing and my expensive college camera attracted their attention!” Forrester frequently painted nightclubs in his early career and says he “only started painting about the police after my friend Winston Rose was killed in 1981. I could never have done Three Wicked Men without my knowledge of what happened to Winston. I really had to work hard to capture the darkness of that London street.” Born in Grenada
column3: Forrester moved to Britain aged 11. “Everywhere was dark and grey
column4: ” he says. “I never painted in the West Indies but I studied painting because my school in Stoke Newington had an art room. It was the only time you were allowed to do what you want. Once I got into art school
column5: I knew there was no stopping me.” The Blk Art Group disbanded shortly after the second National Black Art Convention in 1984. Most left the West Midlands after their art degrees concluded
column6: primarily heading to London for gallery work or postgraduate study. “It was Eddie’s founding impulse that brought us all together
column7: ” says Piper. “When he lost that impulse
column8: we went our separate ways.” “The YBAs took the DIY strategies we used in alternative spaces and applied them in some of the biggest institutions
column9: ” says Marlene Smith. “We were the AYBs – angry young Blacks
column10: ” she jokes. Picking up on this theme
column11: Johnson says: “We wanted to be more political than previous generations of Black artists. We used the N-word and were unafraid to reference violence
column12: lynchings and slavery in our collective resistance to the Thatcher government. Sometimes I’m surprised the work still seems to speak to people more than 30 years later
column13: but then the struggles we were articulating are the struggles of many still.”

column1: Says Piper: “We were serious about seizing space and time in the venues that had previously only been open to white artists. But we were also just young kids
column2: egging each other on and having a good time. We were supposed to be talking about the logistics of shows but we’d mostly fight about politics and music – mainly Reggae
column3: Mod
column4: Ska-revival and 2-Tone in those days … It was a bizarre and multilayered era but a very important one in terms of the consolidation of Black communities in this country.” Looking back
column5: Piper thinks it was remarkable how fully formed the group’s vision was at the outset: by the time Chambers applied for degree courses
column6: Destruction of the National Front was already under his belt: “I remember him working away in his room
column7: marking up these flags and tearing them to pieces. It’s mad to think he was turned down with that in his portfolio. Now it’s part of the national collection at the Tate.” • This article was amended on 4 January 2022. Piper met Chambers in 1979 while studying at Lanchester Polytechnic
column8: Coventry
column9: which is now Coventry University. An earlier version said the institution was “now Wolverhampton School of Art”. Keith Piper’s major solo show is at the New Art Gallery Walsall
column10: West Midlands
column11: from 14 January. Marlene Smith features in Cut & Mix at New Art Exchange
column12: Nottingham
column13: until 8 January. Tam Joseph’s new exhibition
column14: The Face: Portraits
column15: is at Felix & Spear
column16: London until 9 January. Life Between Islands is at Tate Britain
column17: London
column18: until 3 April.";https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2022/jan/04/blk-art-group-angry-young-blacks-keith-piper-tam-joseph-claudette-johnson

column1: 5720;5720;Airbnb blocks Oregon hosts from seeing guests’ names in push against racial bias;2022-01-04T06:00:08Z;['N/A'];['Airbnb'
column2: 'Oregon'
column3: 'US news'
column4: 'Race'];Airbnb rental hosts in the state of Oregon will no longer be able to see guests’ names before approving their bookings
column5: according to a new plan announced by the company. The policy update is specific to Oregon
column6: for now
column7: and was born out of a lawsuit in which three Black women from the Portland
column8: Oregon
column9: area alleged the rental site’s use of names and photographs allowed for racial discrimination
column10: violating the state’s public accommodation laws. The suit was settled in 2019
column11: and starting on 31 January
column12: Airbnb announced this week
column13: hosts in Oregon will only see a guest’s initials until their booking is confirmed
column14: only after which their full name will be visible. The update will be in effect for at least two years
column15: the company said. “As part of our ongoing work
column16: we will take any learnings from this process and use them to inform future efforts to fight bias
column17: ” the company added. Complaints about discrimination on Airbnb aren’t new. In 2015 and 2016
column18: the hashtag #AirbnbWhileBlack circulated
column19: highlighting racism experienced by some of the platform’s users. Many Black users discussed being denied bookings until they changed their names online or used generic profile photos. Some even found that using photos of white individuals could game the system. A study conducted by Harvard Business School researchers in 2016 affirmed these stories through data. After studying 6
column20: 400 Airbnb listings in five American cities
column21: the study concluded that “requests from guests with distinctively African American names are roughly 16% less likely to be accepted than identical guests with distinctively white names”. Advocates called the Oregon policy change a good start
column22: but cautioned that the adjustment shouldn’t be heralded as the end of racism on Airbnb. “We believe that measuring discrimination is crucial to eliminating it
column23: and we think all tech companies should take responsibility for that
column24: ” said Johnny Mathias
column25: deputy senior campaign director at the racial justice organization Color of Change. In order to know if changes are meaningful
column26: Mathias continued
column27: companies should measure the outcomes and be transparent with their findings. In other words
column28: making a gesture without numbers to back up its efficacy is not useful. “I’m glad that Oregon has specific public accommodation laws that provided for this suit
column29: ” he added. “But whether this specific change is the most important change to ensure [they’re] addressing discrimination on the Airbnb platform
column30: we’ll only know if we see the research.” As with most emerging tech platforms
column31: rules and regulations are often playing catch-up with the technologies they’re supposed to govern. In their study
column32: the Harvard researchers noted that anti-discrimination housing laws that hold sway over traditional landlords – such as those renting large apartment buildings – are often lost on the smaller-scale landlords who use Airbnb. Airbnb has resisted doing away with names and photos altogether
column33: arguing that they add to the sense of community on the site. But the company has taken some steps to fight the bias on its platform. In 2018
column34: it announced that it would hide guests’ profile photos until after their booking was accepted. It also requires that all hosts and guests to agree to the Airbnb Community Commitment
column35: “which requires everyone who uses Airbnb to treat others without discrimination and with respect”. And in 2020
column36: Airbnb launched Project Lighthouse
column37: an initiative created to measure bias on its own platform
column38: with Color of Change and other civil rights organizations.;https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/03/airbnb-race-oregon-names-discrimination

column6: 'World news'];"Although
column7: mercifully
column8: still rare
column9: there are signs that wild animal attacks on humans are increasing. Research from the scientific journal Nature found that
column10: as our urban areas further expand into the territories of carnivorous animals
column11: attacks on pets
column12: livestock and sometimes humans have been on the rise. In Kashmir
column13: local wildlife departments have been reporting a marked increase in attacks
column14: with almost 200 people killed and more than 2
column15: 000 others wounded in man-animal conflict in the region since 2011. From a British citizen attacked by otters in Singapore
column16: to monkey attacks in Thailand
column17: squirrel attacks in New York
column18: and a man who fought off a crocodile with a pocket knife in Queensland
column19: these encounters capture our imaginations. But how does it feel to survive such an ordeal – and how does it affect your life?

column1: ‘I tried to punch the mountain lion in the face’ – Anne Hjelle
column3: Orange County
column4: California One day in January 2004
column5: I texted my biking friend Debi to see if she wanted to meet for a ride. I live in California and wanted to do a 45-minute loop at Whiting Ranch
column6: which was only a 10-minute drive from my house. I left my groceries on the counter at home. It was about 3.45pm when we started. I was coming around a blind corner and saw a man in the middle of the trail with another bike propped up against the bushes. I slowed down and asked if everything was OK. He said he had found an abandoned bike and was looking for the owner. Debi and I continued
column7: trying to pick up speed. A minute later
column8: I came to a twisty section
column9: bordered by thick brush and a slope down to a ravine. In my peripheral vision I suddenly saw this flash of reddish-brown fur. I knew it was an animal
column10: but my first assumption was that it was a deer
column11: since they would sometimes bound across the trail. In the next second
column12: the animal leapt and grabbed me. There’s only one animal that would attempt that; I knew it was a mountain lion. It latched on to my shoulders and tried to bite down on the back of my neck. It felt like getting hit by a truck. I was slammed to the ground and it knocked the wind out of me; I could not believe this was happening.

column1: The cat started to drag me down into the ravine. It had me by the back of the neck and I tried to punch its face but it didn’t have any effect. It dragged me several feet and then readjusted its grip to over my left ear and then the left side of my face. I realised that it was working its way around to the front of my neck. At this point
column2: I was trying to scream for Debi and I saw her – she was screaming
column3: too
column4: and in a tug of war with the cat over me. It had me by the head and she grabbed me by my calf to try to keep it from pulling me down into the ravine. Meanwhile
column5: it closed its grip on the left side of my face and pulled my cheek away. It was like a hot knife through butter. I started to say goodbye to Debi as it tried to grab the front of my throat. Within a matter of seconds
column6: things began to go black. I was convinced this was the end of my life. I just felt peace. But Debi’s screams had brought other riders over to us. One went back to call the emergency services and two others started throwing rocks at the cat. They hit it three times – and when one landed on its head
column7: it let go of me. Shortly after that
column8: I came to. I remember being very shocked that I had woken up – and that the cat was gone. I was choking on my own blood and it felt as if I was drowning. The left side of my face felt like someone had stapled a steak to it. My next concern was whether I could see out of my left eye. When I realised I could
column9: that was the first moment I thought I was going to be OK. It took 19 minutes from the 911 call until the paramedics arrived. When the helicopter was flying overhead
column10: the pilot saw the cat crouched down
column11: waiting for another chance. The sheriff’s deputies later found a body that was identified as Mark Reynolds. He was killed earlier by the cat – the abandoned bike was his.

column1: Without Debi stepping in
column2: I would not be here. Mark was a high-level athlete and he did not survive because he was by himself. People have no clue how powerful these animals are – it was like being mobbed by 10 people. That night
column3: I went into surgery for six-and-a-half hours. My trauma surgeon later said that my injuries were the worst he had ever seen. But I was lucky – out of the 20 deep puncture wounds I sustained
column4: none hit my trachea
column5: oesophagus
column6: voice box or carotid artery. My doctors said it was a miracle. I got back on a bike only four months later. I got friends together and went to ride that same trail. Either I let the fear control me or I take control; I wanted to check it off the list and move on. I’ve had zero issues with nightmares or PTSD since the attack. I am just so thankful to be alive. I don’t let this attack define me. I now have a daughter
column7: who is eight
column8: and I try to be strong and set an example for her.

column1: ‘I grabbed the shark in a bear hug to stop it biting me’ – Rodney Fox
column3: Adelaide At 22
column4: I was the winner of the South Australian spearfishing championships
column5: holding your breath and spearing a variety of fish under a time limit. I was trying to regain my title in 1963
column6: off Aldinga beach. After three or four hours
column7: I needed to catch some special species
column8: so I swam a long way offshore
column9: where none of the other competitors had been
column10: and dived to the bottom. I was just about to pull the trigger on a really prized fish when a huge crash hit me in the side. It knocked the gun out of my hands and the mask off my face and I was dragged through the water faster than I’d ever swam before.

column1: I initially thought I’d been hit by a submarine
column2: but then I realised it had to be a giant shark – a great white. Fortunately
column3: I had been talking to a guy who had been bitten on the leg a year earlier
column4: and we had worked out that the most vulnerable spot on the shark was its eyes. So I gouged around its head trying to get the shark to let go of me. And it did. I fell out of its mouth and I instinctively thrusted away with my hand
column5: but that went into its mouth and tore on its teeth. I then grabbed the shark in a bear hug around the belly because I knew it wouldn’t be able to bite me there. I was 30 or 40ft underwater and I realised I was going to drown if I didn’t move. So I let go and kicked up to the surface
column6: then I looked down through the blood red water and saw this big set of white teeth coming back towards me. I kicked as hard as I could at the shark but I only just touched it. Instead
column7: it turned and swallowed the float that I had tied my fish to. That float was connected to my lead belt by a rope and that caught on the shark’s teeth. It dragged me underwater again. I knew I had to find the quick release for the belt
column8: but my hands were all cut up. I was within split seconds of drowning when the shark pulled
column9: the line snapped and I managed to thrash to the surface. Miraculously
column10: a boat was on its way over to have a look at all this red water and the people on board pulled me in. The fear of dying overrides pain. It was only when I was lying down on the boat that the waves of pain arrived. I knew I had done my best – now it was up to my rescuers to try to save me. In those days
column11: there was no microsurgery
column12: so they put 29 stitches in my lung to close up the pleural sac
column13: and every rib on my left side was broken. I had 462 stitches in my chest in total
column14: since all of my organs were exposed and my torso was ripped open. Doctors said it was the worst shark attack they had seen. Just seven months after the attack
column15: I was at Adelaide zoo looking at a lion’s cage. I had this idea that I could build a cage underwater and reverse the roles. I would look at these sharks and try to understand them
column16: and then see if I wanted to go back to diving. In 1964
column17: I managed to organise an expedition with two other shark-attack survivors. The sharks were more interested in the bait than us
column18: and I started to realise that maybe the sharks weren’t going to attack us every time we went in the water. A lot of people would say the best sharks are dead sharks
column19: but I knew there was already lots of blood in the water from the speared fish
column20: so I don’t blame the shark for coming and biting something. Over the years
column21: it’s been a huge battle trying to get people to understand sharks better. We have to learn not to kill them from fear. A year and a half after the attack
column22: I entered the Australian spearfishing championships and came first in several events. I’m 81 now and it hasn’t given me any real problems
column23: except that I have a tight feeling in the left side of my chest to remind me how lucky I was. I’ve been running expeditions for people to watch sharks in their habitats ever since.

column1: ‘The otter kept torpedoing underwater to bite my legs ’ – Leah Hiller
column3: Minnesota My dad owns a cabin in a remote area on Island Lake
column4: Minnesota
column5: where we would often spend holidays. In July 2012
column6: when I was 31
column7: I was staying there while training for the USA Triathlon National Championships. My husband and two children
column8: who were four and two at the time
column9: were with me. One morning
column10: I went for my usual mile-long swim. I’d done it 100 times before and my dad was going to take my kids out to follow me on his pontoon boat. Everything was going great until my kids said they wanted to be taken back to eat some snacks. I told my dad it was fine for him to go
column11: since there was no boat traffic. In Island Lake
column12: the water is the colour of dark rum
column13: so when your hand passes into it
column14: you can’t see past your elbow. You don’t know what is beneath. I circled the island in the lake and was on my way back to shore when I was bitten on the heel. It was a really sharp pain. At first
column15: I thought it was a muskie
column16: which are these huge fish that populate the lake
column17: but they’re not known to be violent. Then I was attacked on the calf. Something grabbed my leg and just started biting. I was in real pain and my mind was in shock. About 20ft away
column18: a head popped out to look at me and I realised it was an otter.

column1: I’m an animal lover and had never thought otters would attack anyone. Over the next 10 minutes
column2: I was yelling and calling for help. The otter kept torpedoing underwater to bite my legs and then it would come up
column3: track where I was
column4: and attack again. I knew I couldn’t outswim it
column5: so I just had to brace for the bites and try to protect my neck because
column6: if it hit me there
column7: I would have drowned. These sharp
column8: searing bites were coming from every angle and it bit me 25 times. Some of them were two inches deep and one pierced my ankle bone
column9: while another went through my calf muscle. But I am no stranger to adversity. When I was 18 I survived a car crash where I was sent flying through the windscreen. I spent six months in the hospital and had to have multiple surgeries. When I was 23
column10: I was diagnosed with thyroid cancer and had to have my lymph nodes removed. I believe these experiences helped me – I knew I had to fight. I kept on screaming and eventually my dad heard me. He was so panicked he flooded the motor of the pontoon boat trying to start it. He had to get to his other boat
column11: which luckily did start
column12: and he made it to me and pulled me out of the water. He couldn’t leave my kids alone
column13: so they were in the boat
column14: too
column15: and my daughter was bawling at seeing her mum covered in blood. Even though I was in pain
column16: I switched into mum mode and was comforting her. I knew
column17: now I was out of the water
column18: I would be fine. It must have been 10 to 15 minutes before my dad got out to me
column19: and without him it could have gone on for a lot longer because there were no other boats nearby. My wetsuit was a saviour – that quarter inch of neoprene took a lot of the scratches and it was shredded. The blood was streaming under it. We went straight to the hospital where the doctors were worried that the otter might have rabies. Since I had 25 open wounds
column20: I had to get a rabies shot in each of them – it was so much medication that I threw up everywhere. The first thing I asked when I stopped vomiting was
column21: “When can I get back in the lake?” The doctors thought it was crazy
column22: but I knew that if I could not get back in the water and face my fear
column23: I would never want to again. I was given a two-week course of antibiotics and after that I was told I would be good to go. There was a triathlon happening about two weeks later and I knew that would be my way to get back in. I did it in a wetsuit that said “otter girl” on the back. I still swim now. I’m proud of that otter attack story because it showed me how mentally strong I can be. That otter still lives
column24: too. No one knows why it attacked me
column25: but the doctors guessed that it must have been a mother otter protecting its babies. My dad would see it swimming around for years afterwards – I just don’t think anyone else swam in that spot again.

column1: ‘The grizzly bear carried me 30ft in its mouth’ – Colin Dowler
column3: Vancouver Island In summer 2019
column4: I was exploring potential hiking routes to climb Mount Doogie Dowler in British Columbia. I was cycling down a narrow logging path when I came around a corner and spotted a grizzly bear. I had seen two or three black bears before and
column5: usually
column6: if you make some noise
column7: they move away. But this was the first time I had seen a grizzly – and it was staring at me. I got off my bike
column8: since it wasn’t moving. I was peering out of the corner of my eye and noticed it slinking towards me
column9: until it was only a couple of feet away. It had almost cleared past my bike – until it made a 180-degree turn towards me. I spun around to put the bike between us and got my hiking pole out as it moved closer
column10: placing it between its eyes. It pushed back a little and that seemed like a decent stalemate until it rolled its head
column11: bit on to the pole and tossed it away. I took off my bag and threw it to the side – I thought it would go for the food in there instead of me. It took a sniff but then started prodding me with its paw. Each poke got a little more aggressive until it lifted its paw high. I thought it would inflict some serious damage so I threw my bike at it.

column1: It lunged forward and sank its teeth between my ribs and hips on my left side and soon I was in the bear’s mouth as it carried me 30 or 40ft towards a bush. I was in crushing pain. It put me down and I tried to gouge at its eyes but I couldn’t reach. I was thrashing while it pinned me and started biting and tearing at my thigh. It was so painful it felt like my hip was going to dislocate. It excavated into my thigh so far I could hear its teeth grinding against my femur like a dog chewing a bone. I started saying goodbye to my wife and kids in my head and felt guilty that I’d even taken this trip in the first place. Then I realised I had a pocket knife. I had to use both hands while I was still pinned down but I eventually managed to get it out. The blade was under three inches long but I gave the bear a stab in its neck with all the energy I had. When I pulled the knife out
column2: it lifted its head up and a big gush of blood splashed on to my waist. It got off me and walked to my bike
column3: sniffed at it for a while and then stood back at the bush where it had stepped out from. I knew I had to move fast otherwise I’d bleed to death. While the bear was still watching
column4: I cut the sleeve off my shirt and made a tourniquet for my left leg. I looked over again and the bear had gone. It was 12.01pm and I knew there wouldn’t be any loggers here until later in the afternoon. So
column5: I dragged myself to my bicycle
column6: gathered my wits and started pedalling with one leg for about 45 minutes until I finally saw a loggers’ cabin. The door was open and I crashed into their stairwell
column7: yelling for help. Thank God there were five guys there who seemed panicked but got their first aid kits out and called 911 while patching my 60 puncture wounds up. One wound was so big that my kidney was visible. An air ambulance came about an hour later; they gave me two pints of blood on the cabin floor and then flew me to hospital for six-and-a-half-hour surgery. The next day
column8: I began 40 days of recovery at Vancouver general hospital. They had me back up and walking 24 days after the attack and
column9: by January 2020
column10: the specialists were seeing some nerve regeneration in my left leg. By February
column11: I began jogging on a treadmill. In September
column12: I ran a half marathon. Mentally
column13: it was a lot harder than I thought it would be getting back into the woods. I made a conscious effort to walk in the bush behind my house as soon as I could so I wouldn’t be overwhelmed by fear. I used tactics to help me
column14: like playing music in headphones to drown out the noise of critters moving around. I have since bumped into a few black bears on the trails
column15: too
column16: but I yell and they get out of the way.

column1: ‘The hippo was thrashing me around like a toy’ – Kristen Yaldor
column3: Odessa
column4: Florida My husband
column5: Ryan
column6: and I decided to go to Victoria Falls for my 37th birthday in 2018
column7: and take a canoe trip down the Zambezi River on the day itself. The weather was great and the temperature was perfect. As far as safety was concerned
column8: the guides just said that if you fall out
column9: swim to shore as fast as you can. We brushed it off – we’re from Florida and are used to being on the water
column10: so we didn’t think we’d fall out. There were three canoes in total – the first one had a guide and another tourist
column11: the second canoe was myself with Ryan in the back
column12: and the third was another guide. We were only around the corner from where we had launched when a guide told us that he had seen a group of hippos ahead
column13: so we should head to the bank. We were paddling left and I glanced over to look for them. I saw one submerged – and as we paddled a few more strokes
column14: it came under our canoe. It leapt up and forced us out
column15: bending the canoe with a big thud.

column1: I fell forward towards where the hippo was and Ryan fell backwards towards the bank. We had lifejackets on so I quickly popped back to the surface. I started swimming
column2: but after a few strokes it grabbed my leg and pulled me straight down. I was only about six strokes from the shore. My first instinct was to reach for the sky to see if my hands would break the surface and when I just felt more water
column3: that’s when I went into survival mode. Just before I went down I had instinctively taken a deep breath and I told myself to hold it and stay calm. As soon as the hippo dragged me to the bottom
column4: it started thrashing me around like a toy. I bunched up around its snout and tried to pry its mouth open. I knew I wasn’t strong enough to
column5: but it must have got freaked by me grabbing it
column6: or my staying still made it think I was dead
column7: since it then
column8: surprisingly
column9: let go. Because I was wearing a lifejacket
column10: I popped back up to the surface
column11: but I couldn’t swim. I couldn’t kick my leg and I thought I had broken my knee. I yelled to everyone on the shore and started back stroking with my arms before reaching for the guide’s paddle
column12: and was pulled out. I think the whole episode only lasted about 45 seconds but
column13: from Ryan’s account
column14: when he came up to shore and looked back
column15: he saw nothing. Even though I was being thrashed around underwater
column16: there was no surface movement
column17: I was just gone. My entire trouser leg and the skin on my thigh and knee were ripped apart. I could see my muscle
column18: and a chunk of it was sitting on top of my leg. We waited 45 minutes for a helicopter to come and take us to the local hospital. They prepped me there and then we waited for an emergency flight to take us back to the trauma centre in Johannesburg. My femur was broken and I also needed a skin graft. I spent two weeks in the Johannesburg hospital before taking a medical flight home to finish the remaining procedures. I have had 21 surgeries to date and I don’t know if it’s because nerves were severed
column19: but I have had hardly any pain throughout. I’m very determined. I didn’t ever think I wouldn’t be able to walk again. My husband signed me up for a charity 5k run when I wasn’t even able to walk
column20: knowing that I’m goal-oriented. I told him that if I was able to achieve it
column21: he would need to dress up as a hippo and come with me. Even though I couldn’t run
column22: we took part in 2019. After that
column23: we signed up for a 10k
column24: which we completed in November
column25: and in January we’re doing a half marathon. The attack was so instantaneous that I didn’t properly see the hippo. I haven’t been haunted by PTSD. My struggle has been to get over the muscle loss and to walk again. I’m almost there now
column26: and I’ve just finished physical therapy. I know I’m going to be working on it for the rest of my life but that’s OK. At least I’m still here and doing the things that I want to do. I just won’t go back canoeing on the Zambezi again.";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/04/saw-big-set-of-white-teeth-coming-towards-me-people-who-survived-wild-animal-attacks

column5: 'Silicon Valley'];"Elizabeth Holmes
column6: founder of the blood testing company Theranos
column7: has been found guilty on four charges of fraud – a verdict that will probably land her in prison and have major implications for Silicon Valley. Holmes was acquitted on three charges relating to patients who received inaccurate test results but found guilty on four charges
column8: including one count of conspiracy to defraud investors and three counts of wire fraud against investors. The jury remained deadlocked on three of the charges.

column1: The split verdicts are “a mixed bag for the prosecution
column2: but it’s a loss for Elizabeth Holmes because she is going away to prison for at least a few years”
column3: said David Ring
column4: a lawyer who has followed the case closely. It also marks a milestone for Silicon Valley – an industry that has for years evaded accountability in its pervasive culture of “fake it till you make it” that encourages founders to make big promises
column5: often with little proof. “Silicon Valley has thus far been famously been resistant to much prosecutorial activity because its business model assumes you are going to take an aggressive
column6: optimistic view of your product or service to attract investors
column7: ” said Jack Sharman
column8: a white-collar defense lawyer at Lightfoot
column9: a law firm in Alabama. “And if that product or service succeeds
column10: you’re not a fraudster
column11: you’re a visionary
column12: ” he added. Theranos sold a promise to improve health with tests on one drop of blood – a claim that despite having little scientific proof raised hundreds of millions of dollars and attracted big-name investors such as the media mogul Rupert Murdoch and the former secretary of state Henry Kissinger. The Theranos verdict could cause startups to tread more carefully in the future
column13: said Neama Rahmani
column14: a former former federal prosecutor and president of West Coast Trial Lawyers. “In Silicon Valley
column15: this conviction will resonate with the big law firms that advise startup companies
column16: ” he said. “Attorneys are going to be advising their clients to be more careful
column17: especially in what they say to investors.” The Silicon Valley investor Jason Calacanis
column18: who was an early backer of major firms like Uber and Robinhood
column19: said the verdict was a “reminder to founders”. “Never lie
column20: never bend the truth
column21: always be honest about where you are at with your traction
column22: especially when raising money
column23: ” he tweeted. Greater whistleblower power The verdict could also mark a new era for workers in technology
column24: who are increasingly speaking out against their powerful employers. Throughout the trial
column25: former employees of the company testified they long suspected Theranos could not deliver on its promises
column26: but felt they could not raise questions. Tyler Shultz
column27: a witness in the trial and early Theranos whistleblower
column28: said on Monday he hoped the verdict encouraged others to speak out against corporate wrongdoing. “This has been a long chapter of my life
column29: ” he said. “I am happy that justice has been served and that this saga is finally in my rearview mirror.” He also highlighted Erika Cheung
column30: another whistleblower and former employee at Theranos who spoke out against the company’s deceptive business practices. “Proud of the impact that Erika and I had
column31: ” he added. “Hope to inspire other young professionals to hold their leaders accountable.” Experts said the verdict showed that the decision to put Holmes on the stand – a major gamble made by the defense – did not play in the founder’s favor. This could set a precedent for fraud cases in the future
column32: said the Los Angeles criminal appeals attorney Matthew Barhoma. “This jury did not fall for it and ultimately that points to why it’s generally best for defendants to avoid testifying in their own defense
column33: ” he said. “If a master manipulator like Holmes can fail to convince a jury
column34: what chance does the average defendant have?” What happens next for Holmes? A hearing has been set for next week during which the prosecutors will reveal whether they plan to retry Holmes on the three charges the jury could not decide. Such a retrial is “not very likely”
column35: Sharman said
column36: as the convictions already carry considerable sentencing time. “I would expect them to declare victory
column37: ” he said of prosecutors
column38: noting that Holmes was already decisively convicted on hundreds of millions of dollars of fraud charges. Holmes walked out of the courthouse on Monday after parties agreed she would not be taken into custody until her sentencing hearing. That date will be set at the hearing regarding the retrial next week. With no prior convictions
column39: Holmes is unlikely to face the maximum prison time her charges carry
column40: which is 20 years
column41: said Rahmani
column42: and she will probably face just several years in prison and more on probation. Still
column43: Holmes is almost certain to appeal. “She’s not someone who is going to want to do even five months in prison
column44: much less five years
column45: ” he said. The Associated Press contributed reporting";https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/04/elizabeth-holmes-verdict-analysis

column9: 'Global economy'];"Tesla has opened a new showroom in the capital of Xinjiang
column10: a region at the heart of years-long campaign by Chinese authorities of repression and assimilation against the Uyghur people. Tesla announced the opening in Urumqi with a Weibo post on 31 December saying: “On the last day of 2021
column11: we meet in Xinjiang. In 2022 let us together launch Xinjiang on its electric journey!” The post was accompanied by photos of the opening festivities including people holding placards which read “Tesla [heart] Xinjiang”. The US has enacted a range of sanctions and regulatory and other measures against China over its continuing human rights abuses in Xinjiang
column12: including restrictions on US business dealings with local operators and suppliers.

column1: President Joe Biden last month signed the Uyghur Forced Labor Prevention Act
column2: and the US government intends to conduct a diplomatic boycott of the upcoming Beijing Winter Olympics. Uyghur rights groups criticised the opening of the showroom
column3: reportedly Tesla’s 211th in China. The Council on American-Islamic Relations urged its immediate closure
column4: and the cessation of what it alleged “amounts to economic support for genocide”. “No American corporation should be doing business in a region that is the focal point of a campaign of genocide targeting a religious and ethnic minority
column5: ” said the council’s director of national communications
column6: Ibrahim Hooper. Human Rights Watch’s Australia researcher
column7: Sophie McNeill
column8: said: “Beijing and businesses have long banked on a global willingness to put profits ahead of human rights
column9: even in the face of crimes against humanity
column10: but we must not allow this to continue in 2022. “Elon Musk and his Tesla executives need to consider human rights in Xinjiang or risk being complicit.” Tesla has been contacted for comment. Tesla’s decision drew some support on Chinese social media
column11: and followed revelations a week earlier that US tech company Intel had requested suppliers not to source goods
column12: services
column13: or labour from the region. One commenter welcomed Tesla’s support for “the development and construction of Xinjiang
column14: unlike some other companies”
column15: an apparent reference to multinationals seeking to reduce business links with Xinjiang over the rights abuses. Last month Intel was accused by state media of offending the Chinese market after it wrote to suppliers requesting they avoid using “any labor or source goods or services from the Xinjiang region”
column16: citing restrictions imposed by multiple governments. After a backlash the company published a letter to “deeply apologise for the confusion”
column17: saying the request was a matter of compliance with US law and didn’t represent its stance on Xinjiang.

column1: Commercial operations in China have become fraught as international brands come under increasing pressure to cut ties with Xinjiang suppliers if they can’t guarantee the absence of forced labour or other abuses. Companies including H&M and Intel have been widely criticised or threatened with boycotts in China over their decisions to distance the brand from Xinjiang labour and products. Case studies of such mass online reactions have found the nationalistic backlash is often driven or amplified by Chinese state media and state-linked social media accounts. Xinjiang is the site of a long campaign of forced assimilation by Chinese authorities against ethnic minorities including Muslim Uyghurs. As many as one million people are estimated to have been detained in mass detention and reeducation centres
column2: and the broader population subjected to suppression of religious and cultural activity
column3: intense surveillance and policing
column4: alleged forced labour programs and enforced birth control. Governments including the US have declared the campaign to be genocide
column5: while several human rights and legal groups have said the actions amount to crimes against humanity. Beijing denies all accusations of human rights abuses
column6: and says its policies are part of anti-terrorism efforts and poverty alleviation programs.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/tesla-criticised-for-opening-showroom-in-xinjiang-despite-human-rights-abuses

column12: 'Newspapers & magazines'];"Chen Kun was living in Indonesia with his wife and daughter when he learned from his brother Mei’s boss that he had been “taken away for investigation” by Chinese police. He immediately suspected it was to do with his brother’s website
column13: a citizen news project called Terminus 2049. Since 2018 Mei
column14: his colleague Cai Wei
column15: and Cai’s partner – surnamed Tang – had been archiving articles about issues including #MeToo and migrant rights
column16: and reposting them whenever they were deleted from China’s strictly monitored and censored online platforms. It was April 2020
column17: and for the last few months Terminus 2049 had been targeting stories about the Covid-19 outbreak and response. In an interview with the Guardian from his home in France
column18: Chen recalled warning his shy but passionate younger brother about setting up such a website
column19: but thinking the worst case scenario was that Mei would be “invited to drink tea”
column20: a euphemism for interrogation by security agencies
column21: not arrested. Instead Mei and Cai spent almost 16 months in detention. Tang was released in May
column22: when the other two were convicted at a trial which Chen said lasted just 100 minutes. Mei and Cai were sentenced to 15 months jail and released in August on time served. Mei is potentially still under surveillance. The group is on a growing list of journalists and others who have been arrested and detained by Chinese authorities
column23: often without trial
column24: in a crackdown that appeared to escalate during the pandemic. In December a report by Reporters Without Borders (RSF) detailed a worsening “nightmare” for journalists under the rule of Xi Jinping
column25: with 128 known to be behind bars or disappeared. More than 70 are Uyghur journalists
column26: and at least 10 people were arrested for reporting on the Covid outbreak and lockdown in Wuhan. Chen said it was a sign of how sensitive Chinese authorities were and remain about the pandemic and its origins. “I’m sure the reason why my brother was arrested was because of Covid
column27: ” Chen said. “Before his arrest … they didn’t encounter any problems.” ‘A war on independent journalism’ Mei was formally arrested for “picking quarrels and provoking trouble”
column28: a vague and ubiquitous charge frequently levelled at dissidents
column29: activists and journalists
column30: and sent to residential surveillance in a designated location (RSDL) – China’s increasingly utilised form of secretive and solitary detention where the accused can be held for up to six months and interrogated without charge
column31: or access to lawyers or family. The rights group Safeguard Defenders estimates between 45
column33: 000 people have been sent to RSDL
column34: including about 15
column35: 000 in 2020. Among them have been Mei
column36: the Australian CGTN anchor Cheng Lei
column37: the journalist Sophia Huang Xueqin and the activist Wang Jianbing. Mei and his Terminus 2049 colleagues were freed in August
column38: and he is living at home in China. Chen is still advocating for those still detained
column39: particularly Huang
column40: and says that neither his brother nor their parents are aware of his campaigning.

column1: As well as reporting on the #MeToo movement and the Hong Kong protests – the latter for which she was detained for three months in 2019 – Huang had also interviewed Chen and written about Mei. “She was always trying to record the stories and experiences of a lot of people like my brother
column2: about defenders
column3: ” Chen said. The independent investigative journalist has not been seen since she and Wang were arrested in September on the eve of her planned departure to study in Europe. In October her parents were told she had been formally arrested for “subverting state power”. Also subject to human rights campaigns is Zhang Zhan
column4: a former lawyer turned citizen reporter
column5: who last Christmas was sentenced to four years in jail over 122 videos she posted online and interviews she gave to foreign press during 14 weeks in Wuhan. Deep into a lengthy hunger strike
column6: which no friends or family can convince her to stop
column7: Zhang is close to death
column8: her family says. While human rights observers
column9: legal groups
column10: and media organisations maintain she should never have been convicted in the first place
column11: an international campaign is urgently calling for her release on any grounds possible
column12: to save her life.

column1: Feng Bin
column2: who like Zhang broadcast reports on YouTube from Wuhan
column3: has not been seen since his arrest in February 2020
column4: and Li Zehu
column5: who broadcast the police chase which led to his arrest around the same time
column6: was detained for two months. Chen Qiushi
column7: a former human rights lawyer turned citizen journalist
column8: reported from Wuhan’s hospitals interviewing families

column11: posted on Facebook that she and her friend Haze Fan
column12: a Bloomberg news assistant
column13: had been unsuccessfully lobbying to report from Wuhan. In August Cheng was detained and later charged with “illegally supplying state secrets overseas”. Fan was detained in December. Both remain in detention more than a year later. Cedric Alviari
column14: RSF’s east Asia bureau director
column15: said the 128 detained journalists and press freedom defenders is the biggest count in five years. It includes 71 Uyghur journalists
column16: and at least 10 who face impending death if not immediately released
column17: according to RSF. Alviari said the crackdown is driven by Xi
column18: who has “declared a war on independent journalism” after tightening controls on traditional media. “Everything he and the CCP have been doing over the past eight years … has been to suppress independent voices.
