column3: more than I have ever seen before ;2022-01-04T05:30:07Z;['Mark Cocker'];['Environment'
column4: 'Rural affairs'
column5: 'UK news'];"A moist airstream surging through the cold massif of the Peak District deposited ground fog over mid-Derbyshire. Just to the west
column6: however
column7: at the county boundary with Staffordshire
column8: and before the world fell away to mist-enshrouded flatlands about Leek
column9: there was a band of high country held in piercing sunlight. What little warmth fired down at this place then rebounded off the bare gritstone ridges
column10: so that the air around the Roaches actually felt hot. Perhaps it was these conditions
column11: in a context of otherwise absolute winter stillness
column12: that gave rise to the day’s wildlife drama. For in the fields
column13: and in an eddy of slow-rising warmth drifting toward the hill known as Hen Cloud
column14: there unfolded a remarkable abundance of spiders. Initially I noticed it as strands of white wafting thread
column15: wound around the roof edge
column16: walls
column17: gates and fence posts near the cafe at this spot. Then I began to feel strands of cottony stuff in my eyes. Looking down
column18: I could see a million silvery pixels glistening in wavy lines among the fields.

column1: There were spiders everywhere: on fence tops
column2: on stone figures in the cafe garden
column3: on dead plants
column4: bushes
column5: running through my hair and across my cheek. On one post I counted 15. But the deepest insight into overall numbers came when I ran binoculars from the ground into the middle sky. The air had become a visible fluid made almost liquid by snaking
column6: lifting lengths of silk. I’ve never seen anything like it. There must have been millions of money spiders
column7: probably in the family Linyphiidae
column8: dispersing in response to their high densities at source in a technique known as “ballooning”. The drag of air through the silk is greater than the weight of its maker
column9: and the spider is carried aloft to pastures new. Who knows where it might settle? Silk strands have been recorded at elevations of 6
column10: 000m. When Krakatoa erupted in 1883 and punished the whole world with a summer of ashy skies and plunging temperatures
column11: the first to plant a flag for life on that dead volcano was a spider on its magical silk carpet. • Country Diary is on Twitter at @gdncountrydiary";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/04/country-diary-money-spiders-everywhere-more-than-i-have-ever-seen-before

column1: 5727;5727;New Zealand Covid experts take legal action against employer over alleged failure to protect them from abuse;2022-01-04T05:21:56Z;['Helen Livingstone'];['New Zealand'
column2: 'Asia Pacific'
column3: 'World news'
column4: 'Coronavirus'];Two of New Zealand’s most prominent Covid experts are taking legal action against their employer
column5: the University of Auckland
column6: over what they say is its failure to respond adequately to “harassment from a small but venomous sector of the public” that is becoming “more extreme”. Siouxsie Wiles
column7: an associate professor of medical science
column8: and Shaun Hendy
column9: a professor of physics
column10: have filed separate complaints to the Employment Relations Authority
column11: which last week ruled that they should proceed directly to the Employment Court due to the “high public interest” in their Covid commentary. According to the ruling
column12: the scientists say that as a result of their work they have “suffered vitriolic
column13: unpleasant
column14: and deeply personalised threats and harassment” via email
column15: social media and video sharing platforms which has had a “detrimental impact” on their physical safety as well as their mental health. The determination also noted that Wiles had also been the victim of doxxing – in which personal information is published about a person online – while Hendy has been physically confronted at his university office by a person who threatened to “see him soon”. The pair say that they are expected to provide public commentary as part of their jobs and that it is “consistent with the principle of academic freedom” but that the university had “failed to take proactive action to protect them” from abuse and that it had “failed to take all reasonable steps to provide a safe working environment”. Wiles
column16: who is known for her trademark pink hair
column17: was named New Zealander of the Year last year for her work on explaining the science behind the Covid-19 pandemic
column18: including everything from how the virus spreads to how vaccines work. Her collaborations with cartoonist Toby Morris for The Spinoff website were widely shared and resulted in work for the World Health Organization. Hendy’s expertise in data-modelling has been credited with shaping the country’s pandemic response. The Employment Relations Authority determination said the issue of their safety had first been raised in early 2020 shortly after the pandemic began but Wiles and Hendy claim the steps taken to protect them were “inadequate” and not consistent with the university’s contractual and statutory obligations and had resulted in “ongoing unjustified disadvantage”. The scientists
column19: who say they had been asked by both the university and the prime minister’s office to provide Covid commentary
column20: claim that in a letter sent in August
column21: the university urged them to cut back on their public comments and suggested they take paid leave in order to“minimise any social media comment”. The university denies unjustifiably disadvantaging the scientists or breaching its statutory obligations and said they were neither expected or required to provide comment on Covid as part of their jobs
column22: adding that much of their public commentary had been undertaken in a private capacity. It also said that it had responded “appropriately” to Wiles’ and Hendy’s concerns and denied telling them to keep their public comments to a minimum. It said it had “merely advised the applicants that doing so is an option they may want to consider”. The Employment Relations Authority said the matter should be resolved as quickly as possible by the court – rather than going through the authority’s sometimes lengthy and potentially more costly process – due to the high public interest in their commentary. It also noted
column23: “the authority is concerned about the uncontested evidence that the harassment is escalating and is expected to continue to do so. The issues associated with the vaccination of children aged 5-11 years of age is already a topic that has stirred up increased vitriol towards the applicants.”;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/new-zealand-covid-experts-take-legal-action-against-employer-over-alleged-failure-to-protect-them-from-abuse

column1: 5728;5728;A crisis of faith in South Africa: ‘People have given up on the state’;2022-01-04T05:00:06Z;['Jason Burke'];['South Africa'
column2: 'Africa'
column3: 'World news'
column4: 'Coronavirus'];"One evening a week
column5: Natasha Msweswe and Zanele Madasi leave their children at home and set out to patrol the streets of Thembokwezi. They return at midnight. This is potentially very dangerous but they feel they have little choice. “It can be scary but we want to protect our community
column6: ” said Madasi
column7: 31. “We want to make a difference.” Thembokwezi is a neighbourhood of Khayelitsha
column8: a sprawling
column9: overcrowded township overlooked by Table Mountain that has long been infamous for high levels of gang violence
column10: drug abuse and unemployment. South African police are stretched very thin and so a network of neighbourhood watch organisations play a key role in fighting crime here. Thembokwezi is more prosperous and safer than much of the rest of the township
column11: and those who live here want to keep it that way. “We work with the police of course … but if we fold our arms as a community
column12: the criminals will run amok
column13: ” said Phindile George
column14: the leader of the Thembokwezi neighbourhood watch
column15: which counts 50 volunteers including Msweswe and Madasi among its members. Across South Africa
column16: tens of thousands of people are making similar resolutions. Some teach
column17: secure reliable electricity supplies
column18: organise vaccination drives
column19: repair roads
column20: deliver protective gear to hospitals or distribute water. Many work almost alone
column21: others in NGOs or for wealthy businesses that are now setting aside large sums for philanthropic work.

column1: What all share is an almost total lack of faith in South Africa’s government to provide any kind of a solution for their problems. “People have given up on the state as a protector … There is a massive loss of faith. It’s a tragedy
column2: ” said William Gumede
column3: a respected analyst and academic in Johannesburg. The retreat of the state from everyday life in the continent’s most developed country has widespread consequences
column4: changing the way people think
column5: behave and interact
column6: especially in a time of crisis. The death of Archbishop Desmond Tutu
column7: who was almost universally revered
column8: provided a moment of paradoxical hope as well as grief: reminding many South Africans of what they have in common after many months where circumstances have conspired to drive them apart. Most South Africans were suffering even before Covid struck
column9: and discontent with the ruling African National Congress (ANC)
column10: in power since the end of the racist
column11: repressive apartheid regime in 1994
column12: has been growing for years. Economic growth was already slowing even before the nine-year rule of Jacob Zuma
column13: the populist president ousted in 2018 amid widespread corruption allegations. Despite the good intentions of the current president
column14: Cyril Ramaphosa
column15: a former labour activist turned tycoon
column16: there has been little to celebrate since. The pandemic has delivered a series of crushing blows to the economy. Rolling power cuts shut down businesses and factories for weeks on end
column17: while the public healthcare system has been lethally undermined by mismanagement and corruption. The government claims 90
column18: 000 South Africans have died from Covid
column19: but reliable excess mortality figures suggest the real death toll is between two and three times higher. Depending on the definition
column20: unemployment could be as high as 46.6%.

column1: In July
column2: in the worst breakdown in public order for decades
column3: hundreds of shopping malls were looted
column4: warehouses torched and key infrastructure targeted across a swath of South Africa. Much of the violence appears to have been instigated by renegade factions within the ruling party
column5: angered by the jailing of Zuma on contempt of court charges. This shook faith in the state too
column6: and a few people turned to vigilante violence. The neighbourhood watch in Thembokwezi aims to reinforce official efforts
column7: but in a rougher part of Khayelitsha a community has come together to confront local authorities. When a strict lockdown at the beginning of the pandemic in 2020 led to widespread illegal evictions
column8: hundreds of homeless people occupied a patch of wasteland and built homes of tin and wood. “For years the politicians said they would use this land for homes for us. They failed to fulfil their promises … So we decided to take it over and do it ourselves
column9: ” said Mabhelandile Twani
column11: a community leader.

column1: Despite efforts to evict them anew
column2: this neighbourhood has thrived. Now more than 15
column3: 000 people live in rows of shacks on the sandy soil. Electricity is diverted from better-supplied streets nearby. Twani calls it “people’s power”. The neighbourhood is known as Lockdown Village. There are many other such settlements born of the misery inflicted by Covid in a country unable to afford the expensive support offered to individuals and businesses in Europe
column4: the UK or the US. In Khayelitsha
column5: there are now settlements called Sanitiser
column6: Quarantine and Social Distance. “Now things are so difficult. We don’t get help from the government. We try to help ourselves
column7: ” said Nondwebi Kasba
column9: who helps to run a communal vegetable garden set up by neighbours in Khayelithsa’s Illitha Park to help the poorest among them. Seven hundred miles to the east
column10: in Graaff-Reinet
column11: a small and conservative town in the Karoo desert
column12: there is also a new struggle for the basics that the state once provided. In the townships on Graaff-Reinet’s outskirts
column13: drug dealers steal water tanks from schools and hawk their contents alongside cannabis and methamphetamines. No one bothers to tell the police
column14: expecting that they will not come. Jobs are rare. So too are the means by which young people could gain the skills to allow them to escape. Khanya Mbaile
column15: a 31-year-old office administrator
column16: hopes to start a coffee shop and internet cafe that would provide a safe meeting place for young people in the township where she lives. She has already sourced six computers from an NGO. “We are all exhausted but there is a glimmer of hope
column17: ” Mbaile said. Louise Masimela
column19: who runs a community school for young children in a township just south of Graaff-Reinet
column20: is another of South Africa’s perpetual problem-solvers. The former journalist has no permanent premises for her students
column21: scarce water and no funds to pay teachers. “It’s tough
column22: really tough … but we want to give our kids an education that will allow them to go out into the world
column23: not get stuck here
column24: ” said Masimela. So she has found solutions: a church offers a space during the week
column25: and seven volunteers teach. Water comes from The Gift of the Givers
column26: now one of South Africa’s biggest NGOs. Funded entirely by private donors
column27: mainly businesses
column28: it distributes 400m rand (£20m) of aid annually. In Eastern Cape province
column29: the NGO works in hospitals
column30: providing much-needed PPE
column31: medicine
column32: oxygen delivery devices
column33: food for patients and even goody bags to motivate healthworkers. Elsewhere in the province
column34: one of South Africa’s poorest
column35: it has provided seeds
column36: fodder and food for orphanages
column37: trucked water into poor communities and even dug boreholes. “There are a lot of good people in government who want to do the right thing … and I can see things changing. It’s not massive change but people want to fix things
column38: ” said Dr Imtiaz Sooliman
column39: the NGO’s founder. “We have to fill the gap but by filling the gap we are putting on pressure. People are asking why we are doing what the government should do.” Recent local elections have been seen by many analysts as a cause for optimism. The ANC was punished by voters
column40: losing 8.3% of its vote share and just under 1
column41: 000 council seats. The party was forced to share power in many small towns – including Graaff-Reinet – and its grasp on cities such as Johannesburg and Pretoria slipped further. In several towns
column42: local communities joined together to create political alternatives that frequently won support. “A lot of this is hopeful … It shows a desire for a new inclusive project
column43: ” said Gumede. Many see a need for political options that offer an authentic alternative to the ANC but also escape the toxic legacy of South Africa’s traumatic past. The dominance of the ANC at national level means the most important political battles occur within the organisation.

column1: Judith February
column2: an analyst
column3: wrote for the Daily Maverick website in December: “From the insurrection in July to the shambles which is our intelligence services
column4: [from] an increasing … anti-vaxx position to a commitment to coal
column5: the tensions within the party are … at odds with the country’s best interests. Ramaphosa’s grip on power appears reluctant and tenuous.” Farmers say the relief provided by rain that has broken a five-year drought has helped the agricultural sector offset losses elsewhere
column6: but the key industry of tourism has been badly hit by the pandemic
column7: with huge losses of income and jobs. “It has been a disaster
column8: a total disaster
column9: ” said 59-year-old Kobus Potgieter
column10: who runs a farm guesthouse outside the town of Oudtshoorn
column11: on the spectacular R62 road that was once busy with tourists. After 16 years he is thinking of closing for good
column12: or at least downscaling.

column1: In Franschhoek
column2: a centre of fine dining and wine-making amid mountains and vineyards an hour’s drive from Cape Town
column3: the absence of overseas visitors has forced top restaurants to close
column4: hotels to shut for months
column5: and led to the loss of thousands of jobs. As elsewhere
column6: the national vaccination campaign has lacked resources
column7: offering minimal opportunities for local people to get jabbed and almost no information that might help overcome very widespread hesitancy. To convince would-be visitors that the town was safe
column8: Franschhoek’s tourist office sought to organise its own vaccination drive
column9: supported by crowdfunding
column10: big businesses and the local administration. By November
column11: 85% of those working in the hospitality industry were jabbed. But just as the tourists began returning
column12: the identification of the Omicron variant in South Africa brought new travel bans. “It was devastating
column13: ” said Ruth McCourt
column14: a marketing manager.

column1: In a country with some of the highest levels of inequality in the world
column2: some have been able to weather South Africa’s economic and political storm better than others. Even its residents admit Franschhoek is a “bit of a bubble”. Khayelitsha is not
column3: and its half a million inhabitants have little protection from the forces buffeting the country. “It will be a bitter
column4: black Christmas
column5: ” said Twani
column6: the community leader in Lockdown Village
column7: interviewed in mid-December. “My fear is that here in South Africa we are living in a timebomb. People are angry … Eventually
column8: anything can happen.” • This article was amended on 4
column9: 6 and 7 January 2022 to correct misspellings of Franschhoek
column10: Oudtshoorn
column11: and the surname of Kobus Potgieter.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/a-crisis-of-faith-in-south-africa-people-have-given-up-on-the-state

column1: 5729;5729; ‘No worries’: how America came to banish Australia’s go-to phrase;2022-01-04T03:45:00Z;['Ann Ding'];['Australian lifestyle'
column2: 'Life and style'
column3: 'Australia news'];"A list of “banished words”
column4: published annually by Michigan’s Lake Superior State University
column5: has this year included the unmistakably Australian “no worries”. LSSU’s tongue-in-cheek list has been compiled every year since 1976 from submissions on terms deemed “familiar but problematic”. This year’s list also includes
column6: among others
column7: “asking for a friend”
column8: “circle back” and “wait
column9: what?” for elimination. While the list takes submissions from around the world
column10: executive director of marketing and communications at LSSU
column11: Peter Szatmary
column12: said “not a single of the many nominators of ‘no worries’ came from Australia. All nominators of ‘no worries’ listed their addresses as in the US”. But how did this Australianism get there?

column1: “The same way anything does: use
column2: contact
column3: and time
column4: ” says Tiger Webb
column5: a language researcher and chair of the ABC’s English usage committee. The first use of “no worries” goes back to a 1965 edition of Sydney’s Oz magazine
column6: according to the Oxford English dictionary. The expression probably received a boost in popularity from Australian cultural exports such as Crocodile Dundee
column7: which Webb says contains six instances
column8: as well as the Sydney Olympics and Steve Irwin. “‘No worries’ is a victim of its own success
column9: and has since become naturalised in America
column10: that is
column11: stripped of specific Australian connotations.” Webb says one American lexicographer and writer on usage
column12: Bryan Garner
column13: dates the shift to naturalisation to about the year 2000. Examples of “no worries” in the wild
column14: “with no accompanying Australiana”
column15: begin to appear around then
column16: such as this New York Times article from 2000
column17: “No Goals
column18: No Complaints
column19: No Worries for US National Team”
column20: or this 1999 Rolling Stone article
column21: which begins: “No worries: Basement Jaxx makes the world’s happiest dance music.” Google’s Ngram viewer
column22: which allows users to look at the frequency of a word or phrase’s occurrence in a corpus of books
column23: also shows that beginning in the 90s
column24: the term starts to become more frequent in American English
column25: shooting up sharply after 2000.

column1: Lauren Sadow
column2: a postdoctoral fellow at Macquarie University’s school of education who has a background in linguistics
column3: guesses that more recent influences in popular and social media have likely helped to spread “no worries” even further
column4: with Australians such as Margot Robbie
column5: Rebel Wilson and the Hemsworths rising to fame. On top of this
column6: the phrase has been popularly memed in recent times.

column1: It’s not the first time this little expression has been noticed
column2: either: a 2014 Quartz article looks at how it might have “infected” US English. In the UK
column3: decades of Neighbours have helped it to become commonplace – in a 2007 ninemsn article
column4: linguist David Crystal said an uptick in “no worries” had been noticed in the preceding 10 to 15 years. Webb also mentions the phrase hakuna matata
column5: from Disney’s 1994 movie The Lion King: “Hakuna matata is translated as meaning no worries
column6: which suggests the phrase was not alien to US audiences.” As for why it’s been nominated for banishment this year
column7: LSSU’s entry for the phrase says it “incorrectly substitutes for ‘You’re welcome’”. The list quotes one submission as saying: “If I’m not worried
column8: I don’t want anyone telling me not to worry.” It adds: “If I am upset
column9: I want to discuss being upset.” “The description given in the list misunderstands the phrase’s usage
column10: at least in Australian English
column11: ” Sadow says. “In Australian English
column12: although it is used in the same place as ‘you’re welcome’
column13: the meaning is quite different.” “It is the speaker saying that they feel ‘no worries’
column14: and that they think the listener should have ’no worries’.” Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: Webb is a little less restrained. “In my view the compilers of the Banished Words list at LSSU are idiotically mistaken to view ‘no worries’ as misused
column2: overused
column3: or incorrect.” Those who object to being told not to worry are “misunderstanding on two fairly fundamental levels”
column4: he says. “In this context
column5: ‘no worries’ indicates that the person being thanked went through no trouble or difficulty; it is not an imperative from the person being thanked that the person doing the thanking should not worry. “Even if it were
column6: that would still probably be fine: a lot of small talk is what’s known as phatic
column7: that is
column8: there for the purposes of social interaction rather than information transfer
column9: ” Webb says. Sadow says: “It wouldn’t be used in a situation (as one commenter said) where either party would actually have worries. It would be completely inappropriate to say ‘You broke my leg!’ ‘No worries’.” She points out that it is “very similar to the US English ‘no problem’”
column10: another expression that might qualify as phatic. “I would say that its usage has been misunderstood by people who do not have it in their own idiolect
column11: ” Sadow says.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/04/no-worries-how-america-came-to-banish-australias-go-to-phrase

column1: 5730;5730;Morrison government warned about lack of rapid antigen tests in September
column2: AMA claims;2022-01-04T03:35:18Z;['Sarah Martin'
column3: 'Michael McGowan'];['Health'
column4: 'Coronavirus'
column5: 'Australian politics'
column6: 'Scott Morrison'
column7: 'Australia news'];"The Australian Medical Association warned senior executives in the federal health department of the need to develop a national strategy for procuring rapid antigen tests (RATs) in September last year. But the AMA’s vice-president
column8: Chris Moy
column9: said that he was told in the meeting that the government did not want to intervene in the private market. “I asked the question of them because I knew what was happening in other countries
column10: and we needed to transition
column11: so what was the plan?” Moy told Guardian Australia. “We needed to get a lot of them [RATs]
column12: and we needed a really clear strategy to transition
column13: it was so bloody obvious. “They have been caught short because of Omicron and the number of cases
column14: but the bottom line is if you are going to rely on the private market in a health emergency you need to make pretty damn sure that they are ready.”

column1: The chair of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission
column2: Rod Sims
column3: warned retailers on Tuesday the watchdog would not hesitate to “name and shame” companies engaging in “unconscionable conduct” over the pricing of the tests. “The ACCC is obviously acutely aware of the concern over the pricing of rapid antigen tests [and] we’re in the process of writing to both the suppliers and the retailers of these rapid antigen tests to find out what their stock levels are
column4: their predictions of stock levels and most importantly what their costs are
column5: what their pricing is and how that’s evolved over time
column6: ” he said. “I’d like to see
column7: if any retailers are pricing as high as $45 for a test when they’re normally supposed to be a third of that
column8: that they would immediately take notice of what we’re saying today and take those prices down.” Sims told reporters the ACCC had begun investigating reports of price gouging following a request from the federal treasurer
column9: Josh Frydenberg
column10: and had already seen reports of “excessive pricing” particularly on individual-sales sites such as Gumtree and Kogan. Sims said the watchdog had received more than 100 reports of potential “unconscionable” or misleading conduct over the products and he urged people to contact the ACCC if they encountered examples of the price of tests being unreasonably inflated. He said the ACCC would also be examining claims the current pricing levels of rapid antigen tests were due to challenges in obtaining supply of the tests. The government is under growing pressure to provide free rapid antigen tests across the community as case numbers in Australia reach record highs
column11: while testing clinics remain overwhelmed. But Sims stopped short of criticising the federal government
column12: saying that while “clearly demand is outstripping supply”
column13: it was unclear what was causing the shortages. “The pricing of these is not something I’m going to comment on
column14: obviously you can see both sides of that argument
column15: ” Sims said in response to questions about whether the tests should be provided free.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: New South Wales and Victoria registered record daily case numbers. NSW had 23
column3: 131 new cases
column4: while Victoria recorded 14
column5: 020. Queensland registered a record 5
column6: 699 cases
column7: while South Australia had 3
column8: 246 new cases
column9: the ACT 926
column10: Tasmania 702 and the Northern Territory 75. The prime minister
column11: Scott Morrison
column12: has said the government will not make the rapid tests free for everyone
column13: but is in the process of finalising concessional access with state and territory leaders. National cabinet is expected to sign off on the details in a meeting on Wednesday. Regardless of the cost
column14: supplies remain constrained in the private market across the country
column15: with frustration growing that the tests cannot be found on chemist and supermarket shelves. The Queensland health minister
column16: Yvette D’Ath
column17: said Queensland would distribute 500
column18: 000 RATs to public testing clinics from Wednesday
column19: but supplies remain constrained across the country. “This is happening across the country. We are as prepared as we can be
column20: but have a look at what is happening around the world
column21: ” she said. “This is not unique to Australia. There is not one country
column22: there is not one state who can say that we don’t have lines
column23: that you won’t have to wait for tests now.” Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: She said RATs needed to be “heavily subsidised” or made free to ensure equity of access. “We do want to make sure they are affordable
column2: we do want to make sure people have easy access to them and we don’t want to become a society where only those who can afford it get it.” She said she had also appealed to the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) to fast-track any outstanding approvals for test kits
column3: including those made in Australia. The Queensland chief health officer
column4: John Gerrard
column5: said the Omicron virus had changed the pandemic landscape
column6: with each infected person now infecting between seven and 10 people. “The Omicron strain really has changed everything – I know it sounds like a cliche
column7: but that has completely changed all the planning
column8: ” Gerrard said.

column1: The federal Labor leader
column2: Anthony Albanese
column3: said Morrison was ultimately responsible for the lack of supply. “It’s about time the prime minister took responsibility for something himself
column4: for doing his job. And his job is to ensure supply
column5: just like it was his job to secure supply of the vaccine
column6: ” Albanese said. But the opposition leader fell short of saying the tests should be made free. “We think that if someone needs a rapid antigen test
column7: and they can’t afford it
column8: they should get one. Everyone should have access to a rapid antigen test. It shouldn’t be dependent upon your income.” However his NSW counterpart
column9: Chris Minns
column10: went further
column11: saying on Tuesday that the NSW Labor party believed the state was facing an “urgent situation” and that the tests “need to be free of charge”. “This is what is happening in other jurisdictions around the world. It’s happening in the UK
column12: it’s happening in the USA
column13: it works
column14: ” Minns said. “The minimum the government can do for the citizens of this state
column15: is ensure that they’re providing the services so that they can test whether they’ve got Covid or not
column16: that’s the smallest and minimum thing the government can do on behalf of the citizens of New South Wales. “Now
column17: at the end of the day
column18: it’s a difficult set of circumstances and we know that we have to live with Covid. But that doesn’t mean we can live without a government.” The Nationals senator Matt Canavan said the TGA was to blame for the hold-up
column19: and said making the tests free would exacerbate demand. “The hold-up was at the feet of the TGA
column20: ” he told Sky News on Tuesday. “We should have been better prepared for this.”";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/04/morrison-government-warned-about-lack-of-rapid-antigen-tests-in-september-ama-claims

column1: 5731;5731;Queensland Covid update: people queuing for seven hours as private testing site closures cause chaos;2022-01-04T02:13:58Z;['Ben Smee'];['Queensland'
column2: 'Health'
column3: 'Coronavirus'
column4: 'Australia news'];"More than a dozen Queensland Covid-19 testing clinics were unexpectedly closed on Tuesday
column5: creating chaos and waiting times of up to seven hours at other sites. In the 24 hours to 7pm on Monday
column6: Queensland recorded 5
column7: 699 new Covid cases
column8: another daily record and up by more than 1

column1: Testing sites were thrown into chaos as people arrived to find private clinics shuttered

column1: People were turned away from an open drive-through testing site at Murrarie due to traffic congestion. “There [are] very long lines at our testing clinics across the state

column5: 'Infectious diseases'];"For Krisinda Merhi
column6: recovering from Covid while isolating in her bedroom felt like “exhausting nothingness”. “You’re tired from doing nothing
column7: because you both can’t and don’t have the energy to
column8: ” she says. The 25-year-old Sydneysider contracted Covid after a trip to Melbourne in November. It started with “slight congestion and a persistent cough”.

column1: After receiving a positive PCR result
column2: Merhi instantly relocated to her bedroom
column3: where she stayed isolated for a week. Luckily
column4: her family of five
column5: who isolated inside the home as close contacts
column6: all remained negative. As daily Covid numbers surpass 21
column7: 000 in New South Wales
column8: and “worst case” Covid modelling suggests 200
column9: 000 cases a day nationwide by late January
column10: Prof Jayashra Kulkarni says isolation inside the home as either a Covid-positive person or close contact is becoming “a common experience now”. Kulkarni is a professor of psychiatry from Monash University
column11: and has isolated in her home as a close contact of a Covid-positive family member. She says “it is helpful to know you are not alone”. “Once a family member is detected to be positive
column12: the immediate response is to be anxious
column13: ” she says. But Kulkarni reminds us that “human beings are designed to cope with crises”.

column1: Here’s what to do if you test positive and need to isolate. The environment Once you receive a positive diagnosis
column2: positive cases should “immediately isolate yourself at your home
column3: or other accommodation”
column4: according to Queensland Health. “Isolate means you need to stay away from other people as much as possible so you don’t give the virus to someone else. “People living in your house can quarantine at home in a separate area to you. It is still important that you isolate as much as possible from these people so that you don’t give them Covid-19 if they haven’t already caught it
column5: ” the advice states. If you cannot safely isolate in your home
column6: public health departments in all states and territories offer special health accommodation in some circumstances. Health authorities advise Covid-positive cases to use a separate bathroom if available
column7: or clean a shared bathroom after each use. Wearing a mask inside your home is also important
column8: especially when entering a room you are sharing with others
column9: according to NSW Health. Ventilating common spaces
column10: such as by opening windows
column11: can also reduce the risk of transmission.

column1: The rules On 30 December
column2: national cabinet agreed to new isolation rules for positive Covid-19 cases. Under the new arrangement
column3: a confirmed case must isolate for seven days from the date they took the test swab that confirmed their infection. They should not leave isolation if they are still symptomatic. The supplies Public health advice stresses the need to organise for your food and medication supplies to be delivered to you without contact
column4: whether that be from a friend
column5: family member or delivery service. The government recommends widely available painkillers for treating mild symptoms
column6: such as paracetamol or ibuprofen. Kulkarni’s shopping list for a week of Covid isolation inside the home includes disposable gloves and surgical masks. She recalls “feeling really exhausted
column7: and not knowing why you’re exhausted”. “So take hot showers
column8: drink lots of tea
column9: and get lots of rest.”

column1: Dr Jenny H Martin
column2: a practising physician and clinical pharmacologist of the University of Newcastle
column3: says “staying well hydrated” is helpful to manage symptoms and discomfort. “People find it difficult to drink water
column4: so Hydralyte is helpful.” Kulkarni says organising the “bits and pieces” of receiving grocery deliveries
column5: or care-packages dropped off by friends
column6: is another consideration. Watching physical health Care guidelines are changing as states and territories respond to the Omicron outbreak
column7: but public health advice is fairly consistent. According to Queensland Health
column8: the general rule is that people who are well or have mild symptoms should stay at home for their illness. “Only call Triple Zero (000) or go to an emergency department if you have severe symptoms
column9: ” the authority recommends. In a person with underlying
column10: compromising health conditions
column11: symptoms may be more severe. According to the federal government’s healthdirect website
column12: these are the more severe symptoms you should watch for
column13: that indicate you need to go to the hospital: your oxygen level is 92% or less when you test using the pulse oximeter
column14: even if you feel okay worsening shortness of breath or difficulty breathing blue lips or face pain or pressure in the chest cold and clammy
column15: or pale and mottled
column16: skin fainting or collapse being more confused becoming difficult to wake up little or no urine (wee) output – less urine than usual
column17: even though you have been drinking lots of fluid coughing up blood Kulkarni also suggests close contacts who may share the home with a Covid-positive person “keep an eye on transmission” with rapid antigen tests “for peace of mind”.

column1: Remembering mental health “A person in isolation can feel totally cut off
column2: ” Kulkarni says. “The cleanliness factor gets hyped up
column3: and it needs to be. But looking after mental health is important.” She says keeping up communication while in isolation is “really critical”. To feel connected to people while in isolation
column4: Merhi video called with friends and watched movies over the phone with her partner. She says she was “lucky” to have a balcony. “It made it a lot easier to self-isolate. I could actually get fresh air. It was easier on my sanity.” Martin suggests making a list of friends and family to get in touch with
column5: and “working through that list of people each day”. “Some people do yoga
column6: others make at-home gyms with milk bottles filled with water
column7: ” she says. “The isolation seems like the hardest thing – just sitting in your room
column8: counting down the hours. “So it doesn’t really matter
column9: you just have to be engaging in something.” The aftermath After the infectious period has ended
column10: “do not disturb the room or bathroom for a day”
column11: Martin says. “Let it settle. Then wear a mask and gloves
column12: and clean all surfaces with disinfectant.”

column1: Kulkarni says that
column2: amid a time of “consideration and changes”
column3: it is important to keep abreast of health rules in your state. “We are in some ways in a middle ground
column4: ” she says. “Omicron appears to be a milder illness
column5: particularly in those vaccinated. That is encouraging.” At the same time
column6: however
column7: people remain concerned. “Particularly when you see stories from overseas of long Covid
column8: and events need to be cancelled.” Critical to balancing this
column9: she says
column10: is getting “focused and practical” about a Covid positive result
column11: and being prepared for isolation.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/dec/31/the-covid-isolation-guide-how-to-prepare-for-a-positive-result

column1: 5734;5734;Theranos verdict: five key moments from the trial that shook Silicon Valley;2022-01-04T00:40:32Z;['Kari Paul'];['Theranos'
column2: 'Technology'

column4: 'Law (US)'
column5: 'US news'];"Elizabeth Holmes
column6: the founder of blood testing company Theranos
column7: was found guilty of four charges of fraud on Monday
column8: ending a closely followed saga that could have major implications for the tech world. Over the course of several months
column9: federal prosecutors laid out a case to the jury that Holmes knowingly scammed investors and patients
column10: artificially inflating the value of Theranos and lying about the capabilities of its technology. The trial has been nearly as spectacular as the rapid rise and fall of the company
column11: which at its height was hailed as a game changer and attracted hundreds of millions in investment. Here are five key moments to remember in the case that shook Silicon Valley.

column1: High-profile investors takes the stand Holmes managed to woo billionaire investors and assemble a board of directors comprising former US cabinet members spanning from the Nixon to Trump administrations. While most of these early Theranos players did not appear in court
column2: one did make an appearance: James Mattis was called to testify by the prosecution in the early days of the proceedings. He stated he personally invested $85
column3: 000 in the company
column4: finding the technology “pretty breathtaking” but lost faith after the Wall Street Journal reporting.

column1: “There came a point where I didn’t know what to believe about Theranos any more
column2: ” he said. Former employees speak out The prosecution paraded a number of former Theranos employees as witnesses during the trial
column3: including three different lab directors. Former Theranos lab director Kingshuk Das testified that Holmes seemed reluctant to acknowledge any criticisms of the Theranos technology
column4: giving “implausible” excuses for apparent failures in the company’s tests. “I found these instruments to be unsuitable for clinical use
column5: ” he said of the company’s proprietary Edison devices. Other lab directors Lynette Sawyer and Sunil Dhawan said the job required “minimal” in-person work and that they spent the majority of their time doing paperwork
column6: not testing the actual hardware used in blood analysis. More key testimony came from Erika Cheung
column7: a former Theranos employee
column8: who took the stand for three days to detail shortcomings of the company’s blood testing processes. She said she was very concerned about the accuracy of the technology and occasionally refused to run patient samples on the devices. Patients “don’t know the fact that behind closed doors we’re having all these problems and they think they’re getting correct results”
column9: Cheung said. “It was starting to get very
column10: very uncomfortable and very stressful for me working at the company.” Holmes defends herself
column11: alleges abuse Perhaps the most shocking moment in the trial came when Holmes herself was called to the stand by her defense team to testify. The risky move allowed her to make her own case to the jury
column12: potentially garnering more sympathy ahead of deliberations. But it also opened her to cross-examination from the prosecution
column13: during which attorneys grilled her for several days about inconsistencies in her story.

column1: Holmes claimed on the stand that she trusted statements from her scientists that Theranos technology was working as planned and that she did not purposely mislead anyone. She also laid out bombshell allegations that her former business partner and lover
column2: Sunny Balwani
column3: abused her
column4: influencing her to commit fraud. The two met when Balwani was 38 years old and Holmes was only 18. She said Balwani wanted her to “kill the old Elizabeth”
column5: controlling what she ate and who she spent time with so that she could become a successful CEO. “He had taught me everything I thought I knew about business and he was the best business person that I knew
column6: ” Holmes said. “I didn’t question him in the way that I otherwise would have.” The ‘smoking gun’: pharmaceutical logos One integral piece of evidence prosecutors frequently returned to was that Holmes doctored documents sent to potential investors. The Walgreens CFO
column7: Wade Miquelon
column8: said during his testimony that Holmes had implied the pharmaceutical firms Pfizer and Schering-Plough had validated the company’s blood-testing technology. He said Holmes shared with investors and potential partners a document carrying the Pfizer logo
column9: purportedly showing the drug company’s support. But the document had been forged
column10: the prosecution claims. “Pfizer did not write this
column11: ” prosecutor Robert Leach said in opening arguments for the trial. “Pfizer did not put its logo on this. Pfizer did not give its permission to put its logo on this. Pfizer did not make the conclusions in this report.” In her testimony
column12: Holmes admitted to personally manipulating those documents
column13: saying she did so not to imply that the companies had vetted the technology but “because this work was done in partnership with those companies and I was trying to convey that”. “I wish I had done it differently
column14: ” Holmes told jurors.

column1: Evidence offers window into Holmes’s life Submitted into evidence
column2: amid the thousands of pages of dense laboratory tests and scientific data
column3: were a handful of documents that offered a window into Holmes’s mindset as she stood at the helm of one of Silicon Valley’s buzziest companies. “I do everything I say – word for word. I am never a minute late. I show no excitement
column4: ” one strict handwritten note to herself said. She obsessively tracked her food
column5: drinking a daily green juice and avoiding sugar. “ALL ABOUT BUSINESS.” “I am not impulsive.” “I do not react.” “I am always proactive.” “I know the outcome of every encounter.” “I do not hesitate.” “I speak rarely. When I do – CRISP and CONCISE. I call bullshit immediately. My hands are always in my pockets or gesturing
column6: ” the note read. Also in evidence were hundreds of pages of text messages between Holmes and Balwani
column7: many amorous and others business-like. In some they referenced a bird they owned together. Also in evidence: an aerial photo of a home they owned together in Atherton. “You are the breeze in desert [sic] for me – my water
column8: and ocean
column9: ” she texted Balwani in May 2015
column10: according to a recent court filing. “OK
column11: ” he replied. The two frequently used the phrase “hmfr” which Holmes said references an Arabic phrase that translates roughly to “this too is my God’s glory”. In her journals and texts with Balwani
column12: Holmes referenced a spiritual connection and a belief that God put Balwani in her life for a higher purpose. “Love you
column13: ” one message from Balwani reads. “I prayed from the bottom of my heart for you. I have never prayed with this intensity in my life for anything.” “I love this
column14: ” Holmes replied. “My nirvana.”";https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/03/theranos-verdict-five-key-moments-from-the-trial-that-shook-silicon-valley

column1: 5735;5735;Theranos jury says it remains deadlocked on three of 11 fraud counts;2022-01-04T00:04:40Z;['Kari Paul'];['Theranos'
column2: 'Silicon Valley'
column3: 'US news'
column4: 'Technology'
column5: 'Law (US)'];"The jury weighing fraud charges against Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes has told the court it is unable to reach a unanimous verdict on three of the 11 criminal counts she faces. Jurors in the high-profile Silicon Valley trial had been deliberating for seven days after a trial that chronicled the missteps of the now-defunct blood testing startup. Over the course of 15 weeks
column6: federal prosecutors called 29 witnesses
column7: outlining missteps and alleged fraud Holmes committed during her 15-year reign as CEO. In a dramatic turn of events
column8: US jurors returned a note to the judge on Monday morning saying they were deadlocked on three charges. In response to the note
column9: US district judge Edward Davila gave the jury what is called an Allen charge
column10: encouraging them to deliberate further. But jurors returned to the court several hours later
column11: saying they remained unable to move forward. Davila then sent jurors back to the jury room to fill out a verdict form. It’s not yet clear whether the jury will render its remaining verdicts on Monday.

column1: Holmes faces nine charges of fraud and two charges of conspiracy to commit fraud. It is not clear on which of those charges the jury was unable to come to an agreement. If the jury is unable to come to a conclusion
column2: it may under federal rules deliver a partial verdict. Such a conclusion would
column3: however
column4: leave Holmes open to be re-charged with the remaining three charges at a later time. Holmes founded Theranos after dropping out of Stanford at the age of 19
column5: promising a revolutionary technology that could run hundreds of health tests on just a drop of blood. A charismatic character known for her blonde hair
column6: uniform of black turtlenecks and low voice
column7: Holmes quickly rose to fame in and outside the tech world
column8: gracing the covers of major magazines
column9: headlining conferences
column10: and drawing comparisons to Apple’s Steve Jobs. As Theranos grew
column11: the company attracted big-name investors including the former secretaries of state George Schultz and Henry Kissinger. At its height
column12: Theranos was valued at more than $9bn. But Theranos ultimately fell short of its ambitious pledge. Wall Street Journal reporting in 2015 revealed that the company’s in-house tests had massive inaccuracies
column13: and that the company was performing other tests using traditional blood drawing methodology and outside labs. During the trial
column14: prosecutors painted a picture of Holmes as a strict
column15: power-hungry leader willing to go to any lengths to save her company’s image
column16: repressing internal and external dissent and manipulating the press. Taking the stand in her own defense
column17: Holmes argues she made decisions in good faith and did not knowingly commit fraud.";https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/jan/03/elizabeth-holmes-theranos-verdict-latest

The stamp duty holiday – which ended on 30 September 2021 in England and Northern Ireland – has been credited with fuelling a boom in the market. First-time buyers already benefited from stamp duty relief on the first £300
column28: 000 of the purchase price

column1: 5737;5737;UK government extends powers to intervene in foreign takeovers;2022-01-04T00:01:00Z;['Rob Davies'];['Mergers and acquisitions'
column2: 'Business'
column3: 'Politics'
column4: 'UK news'];"Ministers have greater powers to block foreign takeovers of British firms after new rules came into effect on Tuesday giving them more scope to unpick deals that have the potential to harm national security. The National Security and Investment Act
column5: which enhances existing powers
column6: is described by the government as the “biggest shake-up of the UK’s national security regime for 20 years”. Ministers have already been able to intervene in deals where a foreign-led takeover could affect economic stability
column7: media plurality
column8: the UK’s pandemic response
column9: or national security. However
column10: the act builds on the government’s ability to deploy the national security rationale for “calling in” a takeover. It identifies 17 areas of the economy that warrant greater scrutiny when overseas investors seek to make an acquisition. In addition to defence and military technology
column11: ministers will be able to examine deals in a wide range of sectors such as advanced robotics
column12: artificial intelligence
column13: the civil nuclear sector
column14: transport and quantum technology. Officials will be notified that a deal is worthy of examination when a buyer takes its stake above three trigger points: 25%
column15: 50% and 75%. The government can block these transactions and even unwind them restrospectively if they were completed on or after 12 November 2020
column16: the day the bill was introduced to parliament. The business secretary
column17: Kwasi Kwarteng
column18: said: “The UK is world-renowned as an attractive place to invest but we have always been clear that we will not hesitate to step in where necessary to protect our national security. “The new investment screening process in place from today is simple and quick
column19: giving investors and firms the certainty they need to do business
column20: and giving everyone in the UK the peace of mind that their security remains our number one priority.” The act is viewed by some as a response to concern about Chinese takeovers of strategically important technology businesses
column21: with some of the deals already being pored over by officials under existing rules. They include relatively small deals
column22: such as the sale of the semiconductor manufacturer Newport Wafer Fab to a Dutch company owned by China’s Wingtech
column23: which is partially backed by the state. Newport Wafer Fab has multiple contracts with the UK government
column24: including defence-related projects. The government funding body UK Research and Innovation has suspended grants to the company
column25: while a consortium of British investors is reportedly ready to submit a £300m bid if the deal is blocked. Much larger foreign buyouts by US companies also came under the microscope in 2021
column26: owing to concerns about national security or intellectual property. Takeovers of the defence suppliers Ultra Electronics and Meggitt attracted government scrutiny
column27: as did the $75bn (£56bn) takeover of the world-leading chipmaker Arm by its rival Nvidia – a deal that is the subject of competition investigations in the UK
column28: US and Europe.

column1: Plans to expand the government’s remit to examine such deals have divided opinion. It will apply regardless of the size of a company by revenue
column2: or where the prospective acquirer is based
column3: even if it is in the UK. Business groups have warned that the breadth of criteria could result in unnecessary meddling in a large volume of deals
column4: deterring investment in the UK and bogging down officials in needless paperwork. The government has said that while up to 1
column5: 800 deals a year would be notifiable under the new powers
column6: fewer than 100 would be called in for a full review. Reviews are intended to last a maximum of 30 days
column7: faster than is typical at the moment
column8: thanks to a new investment screening unit.

column1: Kwarteng has also faced criticism
column2: including from the Henry Jackson Society thinktank
column3: for reducing the equity threshold at which deals can be examined from 25% to 15%. The Department for Business
column4: Energy and Industrial Strategy has insisted that the act will not lead to ministers “arbitrarily” intervening in takeovers. “The vast majority of acquisitions will require no intervention and will be able to proceed quickly and with certainty in the knowledge that the government will not revisit a transaction once cleared unless false or misleading information was provided
column5: ” the department said on Tuesday.";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/04/uk-government-extends-powers-to-intervene-in-foreign-takeovers

column2: 'Darts'
column3: 'Sport'];"Eyes moist
column4: red mohican sparkling in the lights
column5: scalp painting glistening with sweat
column6: Peter Wright won his second PDC world championship in one of its tensest and most absorbing finals. He did so not by outscoring Michael Smith but by outlasting him
column7: not by blowing him off the board but simply by resisting
column8: holding his nerve and holding his throw against one of the heaviest and most relentless treble-hitters in the sport. As an exhausted Wright celebrated a 7-5 victory
column9: Smith stood at the back of the stage: distraught
column10: disconsolate
column11: destroyed. He looked up at the lights
column12: down at his feet
column13: off to the side. He buried his face in his shirt. He turned and stared at the blue sponsor’s backdrop. Anything to avoid glancing at the Sid Waddell Trophy that was being placed on a plinth in front of him
column14: the trophy that has now twice eluded him at the final hurdle.

column1: He believed it was his time. We all felt it
column2: too. He had beaten the defending champion Gerwyn Price
column3: the dangerous James Wade
column4: the breakthrough star of the year in Jonny Clayton. When he is on song and in rhythm
column5: when the 180s flow from his fingers like piano music
column6: there is barely a player on the planet who can live with him. And perhaps
column7: ultimately
column8: only a player like Wright could have thwarted him. Late in the game Smith was 5-4 up with a break of throw
column9: an advantage that felt decisive. Instead Wright endured
column10: much as he has been enduring his whole career. Darts never came easy to him. Life never came easy to him. Even in his moment of triumph
column11: the boos from an uncharitable Alexandra Palace crowd continued to sting his ears. But here he was
column12: the last man standing and now legitimately one of the greats of the sport. Long before a dart had been thrown in this final
column13: Alexandra Palace was already a heaving hive of fervour and festivity
column14: as grown men bellowed their viral load across the Palm Court arena and the old songs were revived with relish. You were reminded again just what a befuddling challenge it must be to throw pinpoint darts in this environment
column15: amid the pounding music and the hollering of the referee and the ambient smell of lager and takeaway. Many wither on the big stage. For those who succeed
column16: it must be akin to performing open heart surgery on a nightclub dancefloor. But both men had been here before. Wright had broken his duck by winning the title two years earlier
column17: and at 51 years of age was somewhere near the peak of his powers. An introvert dressed as an extrovert
column18: Wright is a creature of paradoxes and contradictions: the showman with a chronic shyness
column19: the court jester who throws with a sniper’s precision
column20: the relentlessly consistent scorer who changes his darts between tournaments
column21: between matches
column22: sometimes even – as here – in the fifth set of a world championship final.

column1: Three years earlier
column2: Smith had been demolished on this stage by Michael van Gerwen
column3: breaking a hand midway through after punching a door in frustration. And for a while it felt like the experience might be a terminal one. His scoring had always been peerless. But in times of stress the arm would tense and the doubles would drift. As if he couldn’t quite take the final step. As if he was finally being forced to contemplate what it meant to win. Such was the fate that befell him here. He has now reached seven major televised finals
column4: and lost the lot. The action was as loose and easy as ever
column5: but the body language looked a little strained
column6: the gaze a little pained. The canny Wright was taking his time between visits
column7: forcing Smith to think as much as possible. The contrast between them was stark. Smith flings his darts as if they’re laughing emojis: one
column8: two
column9: three
column10: who cares? Wright
column11: by contrast
column12: throws them as if he’s trying to construct the three parts of a perfect sentence. The first two sets were scrappy
column13: and Wright won them both. But as Smith settled
column14: his sheer weight of scoring began to impose itself. He swung himself back into the match with a sumptuous 167 checkout. Two-all became 3-3 became 4-4 became 5-5. One hour became two. Even the crowd seemed to tighten a little
column15: as if aware that the time for frivolity had passed. On the stage
column16: both players were betraying barely a flicker of tension or nerves
column17: even as they knew – as we all did – that they were fooling absolutely nobody.

column1: And finally it was Smith who cracked
column2: missing a crucial bullseye to hold throw in the 12th set. Wright checked out 81 for a 12-dart finish
column3: and before long the last rites were being administered. Smith had recorded a higher average (99 to 98). He had hit 24 180s to Wright’s 17. But as the old truism goes
column4: darts is not simply a game of scoring but of timing. And as Smith blinked into the Palace lights
column5: pyrotechnics lighting his face
column6: he could be forgiven for wondering when his time might come again.";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/03/peter-wright-edges-out-michael-smith-to-secure-second-world-darts-title

Dad fell ill at the worst possible time: just as GPs were going on holidays

column27: headache

column5: 'Pacific islands'];"On the morning of Monday 27 September
column6: a crew member on board the Hsinlong 1 fishing vessel went to fetch his friend Arnold Latu for breakfast. Latu
column7: in his mid-30s
column8: was the monitoring officer of the Chinese-owned
column9: Fiji-flagged vessel
column10: employed by the Tongan government to check that the amount of fish caught on its three-week voyage was legal and correctly recorded. The Hsinlong 1 had almost completed its work and was berthed close to Pangaimotu Island
column11: off the shores of Nuku’alofa
column12: awaiting the OK from local authorities to berth at the Tuimatamoana fishing wharf.

column1: “We were just about to have breakfast and get ready for the vessel to go in to the wharf to berth and one of the crew members had gone to call Latu to come and have breakfast
column2: ” said a senior crew member onboard the vessel at the time
column3: who did not wish to be named. “The crew member shouted to us that Latu was not responding to his calls and was lying on his bed. We went in and touched his body which was already cold. We were shocked and did not know what to do.” Latu’s friends remember him as a hard worker
column4: a friendly person who got along with everyone
column5: and a “good listener and one who is always keen to help anyone”. He was also described as a “marine man” who loved the seas and his job at Fisheries.

column1: His longtime friend Benny Jagroop
column2: who was not on the vessel
column3: described him as a “little brother” who came from a tough neighbourhood
column4: but worked with a local group called Falepiliki (brick house) to try to support young men to stay in school
column5: and stay out of trouble. “Latu’s death is still a mystery for us
column6: ” said Jagroop. “So if you ask what [is] the speculation around Arnold’s death
column7: for real I have no idea.” After they found him dead
column8: crew members alerted the ship’s captain
column9: and Tongan police were contacted. But nearly three months later and despite calls for a transparent investigation from international bodies
column10: there are no answers about what caused the apparently healthy man’s death
column11: and neither police
column12: nor the government of Tonga were willing to speak about the case. Dr Tuikolongahau Halafihi
column13: chief executive of Tonga’s Ministry of Fisheries
column14: said they were not able to release any information because the case was still being investigated by Tonga police. “I won’t be able to give you any information about this case as we are still awaiting the report from police and health. We are still after this report but it’s still with the police
column15: ” he said in an email response to questions from the Guardian. Tonga police did not reply to requests for comment. Despite calls from non-government organisations like WWF and the Association of Professional Observers (APO)
column16: the cause of death and results of the postmortem examination have not been revealed by authorities. The WWF wrote about Latu in its December position paper
column17: saying that there had been no report of the cause of death
column18: nor was there any information to “suggest he was sick or injured” before his death. Bubba Cook
column19: WWF western and central Pacific tuna programme manager
column20: called for transparency and a thorough investigation of any reported deaths or incidents involving fisheries observers. “In the case of any missing human
column21: from a vessel
column22: [if] there’s a death of anyone
column23: whether it’s crew member or a fisheries observer
column24: there should be an investigation into that fatality. And it should be a thorough investigation and the information about that should be made public
column25: ” he said. Hsinlong Fisheries Ltd
column26: the owner of Hsinlong 1
column27: did not respond to detailed questions from the Guardian. Nor did Tonga police. ‘If you’re not protecting all
column28: you’re not protecting any’ There is no evidence of foul play in Latu’s death
column29: however the uncertainty as to how he died has attracted the attention of the WWF and the APO
column30: which monitor the safety of fishing observers around the world. Being an observer
column31: which involves monitoring fishing practices and catches to make sure boats follow the rules
column32: is a dangerous job that can put observers in conflict with the crews on the vessels on which they are working – often hundreds
column33: or even thousands
column34: of kilometres from the nearest port. According to the Association for Professional Observers
column35: there have been more than a dozen cases of observers dying on the job since 2009 alone
column36: including a number from the Pacific. Eritara Aati Kaierua from Kiribati died onboard a fishing vessel in 2020. His family have serious concerns about the investigation conducted into his death. Antin Tamwabeti
column37: also from Kiribati
column38: died on another boat in May 2019
column39: in circumstances which have not been reported
column40: though his case was ruled a suicide. According to the company that hired him
column41: he was harassed and threatened by the crew of the Taiwanese-flagged boat he was on shortly before his death. The WWF has argued that Latu’s death has “exposed a significant potential weakness in regional observer safety and security measures related to jurisdictional ambiguity”. Because Latu’s deployment was classified as a national trip and the vessel was fishing in Tonga’s waters
column42: Latu was not given safety equipment that he would have been given if the trip had been in international waters and had fallen within the context of a Regional Observer Programme trip. But the WWF says this should not matter. “We’ve made good advancements to addressing the safety issues with observers … but they didn’t go far enough
column43: ” said Cook. “And I think that’s evidenced by Arnold Latu’s situation
column44: because he was on a national trip
column45: there was some jurisdictional ambiguity around who was responsible
column46: on what rules are subject to with respect to safety. And our position is
column47: if you’re not protecting all of the observers
column48: you’re not protecting any of them.” In a document shared with the Guardian by the Association for Professional Observers (APO)
column49: Samuela Bulimetuira
column50: the manager of safety compliance and response at the Maritime Safety Authority of Fiji
column51: wrote that since Latu’s death occurred in Tongan waters
column52: Tonga was responsible for investigating. Tonga and the company that owned the vessel “have an obligation to report all incidents especially deaths onboard to the Flag State Authority [Fiji] as soon as is practicable”. Bulimetuira did not respond to questions from the Guardian.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/04/its-a-mystery-for-us-the-puzzling-death-at-sea-of-a-tongan-fisheries-observer

A line in the joint statement saying that “nuclear weapons – for as long as they continue to exist – should serve defensive purposes

column4: 'UK news'];"The family gatherings have disbanded

column10: the prime minister’s decision not to impose lockdown-style restrictions before the holiday period may be vindicated. Johnson is correct that peak Omicron
column11: when it comes

column13: and roughly two weeks later

column1: In London

column5: compared with 450 the day before
column6: and 511 the day before that. “We would guess
column7: based on what case numbers are doing in London
column8: that the peak in hospital admissions should be this week
column9: and nationally
column10: maybe a week later
column11: ” Ali said. This is roughly in line with the scenarios outlined in modelling studies
column12: which suggest Omicron cases will peak in early-mid January. However
column13: the magnitude of the peak appears to be significantly lower than some of the worst case scenarios predicted. For instance
column14: according to modelling data published by the University of Warwick on 30 December
column15: hospital admissions should by now be approaching about 5
column16: 000 a day in England. Yet
column17: according to the latest figures
column18: the number of Covid-19 patients admitted on 1 January was 1
column20: down from 2
column21: 370 three days earlier.

column1: This does not necessarily mean we should disregard such models
column2: as some hawkish MPs have suggested. Ali said: “Modelling
column3: post-vaccination has become extremely difficult. And trying to predict people’s behaviour
column4: well
column5: they don’t even try to include that in the models
column6: so
column7: inevitably
column8: they’re not going to be able to predict what’s going to happen. “Instead
column9: they give a variety of scenarios
column10: which are necessary because we have to have some idea of the range of possibilities. But when the range is so wide
column11: it doesn’t really help policymakers
column12: because the difference between 100 deaths a day and 6
column13: 000 deaths a day is just so huge.” Although the gloomiest predictions may have not come to pass
column14: experts caution that we are not out of the woods yet. Some of the slowing could be a reflection of altered behaviour in the run-up to Christmas
column15: when concern about escalating Omicron cases and a desire to spend the festive period with older relatives prompted many to scale back social activities and behave more cautiously. They may also have been less likely to get tested in the run-up to Christmas – assuming they could access a test. Now Christmas is over
column16: some of us may have relaxed our behaviour. Whether we will see a surge in cases as a result of new year’s celebrations will not become apparent for about another week
column17: as it takes five to six days on average after exposure to the virus for symptoms to develop
column18: and then a further couple of days for people to seek a test and receive the results.

column1: The return of children to schools this week – many of whom remain unvaccinated – may also lead to a surge in cases owing to increased mixing. Paul Hunter
column2: a professor in medicine at the University of East Anglia
column3: said: “The Warwick model suggested that cases would peak early January. But it is still impossible to say. We will probably only really know in retrospect a couple of weeks later. “What we can say is that the rate of increase has slowed dramatically for early mid-December
column4: otherwise we would be seeing several millions of infections a day by now and that would have been impossible.” “Taking all this together
column5: I don’t think we have peaked yet
column6: but I think we are not that far away – or at least I hope so
column7: ” he added. A further fly in the ointment is that younger age groups accounted for the majority of Omicron cases during early-mid December

column9: because Omicron is better at infecting people who have been vaccinated than Delta
column10: proportionately more vulnerable older people are likely to fall ill.

column1: The good news is that most of these people have now received a booster dose
column2: and their levels of immune protection should remain high for a few months yet – though we will not yet know whether they will require yet another dose. The ramped-up booster programme has been under way for several weeks
column3: meaning many younger individuals should also soon have additional layer of immune protection
column4: if not already. The combination of this vaccine-induced protection and so many people having been infected means we will eventually we will hit peak Omicron

column7: the global death toll from Covid will continue to rise

column8: 'US politics'];"Democrats are seizing on this week’s anniversary of the deadly US Capitol riot to renew a push for voting rights legislation to safeguard democracy.

column1: Majority leader Chuck Schumer announced on Monday that the Senate will vote on changing its own rules on or before 17 January
column2: the federal Martin Luther King Jr Day holiday
column3: if Republicans continue to obstruct election reform. The deadline appears part of a concerted effort to use Thursday’s commemorations
column4: marking a year since a mob of Trump supporters stormed the Capitol
column5: seeking to overturn Joe Biden’s election win
column6: to give fresh impetus to the long-stalled legislation. In a letter to Senate Democrats
column7: Schumer argued that the events of 6 January 2021 are directly linked to a campaign by Republican state legislatures to impose voter restriction laws. “Let me be clear
column8: ” the New York senator wrote. “6 January was a symptom of a broader illness – an effort to delegitimise our election process
column9: and the Senate must advance systemic democracy reforms to repair our republic or else the events of that day will not be an aberration – they will be the new norm. “Much like the violent insurrectionists who stormed the US Capitol nearly one year ago
column10: Republican officials in states across the country have seized on the former president’s Big Lie about widespread voter fraud to enact anti-democratic legislation and seize control of typically non-partisan election administration functions.” Sweeping voting rights reforms have stalled in the evenly split 50-50 Senate
column11: repeatedly blocked by a Republican-led filibuster
column12: leaving Democrats unable to find the 60 votes needed to advance. Schumer went further than before in calling for a filibuster exception for voting rights. “We must ask ourselves: if the right to vote is the cornerstone of our democracy
column13: then how can we in good conscience allow for a situation in which the Republican party can debate and pass voter suppression laws at the state level with only a simple majority vote
column14: but not allow the United States Senate to do the same? We must adapt. The Senate must evolve
column15: like it has many times before.” He added: “We hope our Republican colleagues change course and work with us. But if they do not
column16: the Senate will debate and consider changes to Senate rules on or before 17 January
column17: Martin Luther King Jr Day
column18: to protect the foundation of our democracy: free and fair elections.” Although Schumer’s words were ostensibly aimed at Republicans
column19: there is little prospect of any members of that party shifting their position. On Monday
column20: Republicans swiftly condemned what they described as a threat. Senator Mike Lee of Utah said: “Senator Schumer’s rash
column21: partisan power grab should be seen for what it is – desperation and a failure to do what Joe Biden and Democrats ran on: unify. “If this rule change were to pass
column22: the people of Utah and the United States would suffer immeasurably as the Senate devolves into a strictly majoritarian
column23: Lord-of-the-Flies environment. Senator Schumer and his disastrous plan must be stopped.” But Schumer’s true target
column24: amid blanket media coverage of this week’s anniversary
column25: is likely to be Democratic holdouts Joe Manchin and Kyrsten Sinema
column26: who have resisted abolishing or changing the filibuster. The senators from West Virginia and Arizona contend that if and when Republicans take control of the chamber
column27: they could use the lower voting threshold to advance bills Democrats oppose. Schumer’s announcement is likely to set up 6 January vigils and Martin Luther King Jr Day events as rallying points for voting rights activists who have criticised Biden and the party in Congress for failing to prioritise the issue. But the president has become less cautious and more direct. Last month
column28: he told ABC News: “If the only thing standing between getting voting rights legislation passed and not getting passed is the filibuster
column29: I support making the exception of voting rights for the filibuster.” Schumer’s announcement was welcomed by Martin Luther King III
column30: son of the civil rights activist and chairman of the Drum Major Institute. “There is no better way to honor my father’s legacy than protecting the right to vote for all Americans
column31: ” he said.

column1: “The King holiday is historically a day of service
column2: and we hope the United States Senate will serve our democracy by passing the Freedom to Vote Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act. “We applaud Senator Schumer for his commitment to expanding voting rights
column3: but we won’t halt our plans for action until legislation has been signed.” Also on Monday
column4: the US Conference of Mayors sent a letter signed by 146 bipartisan mayors to Schumer and the minority leader
column5: Mitch McConnell
column6: urging them to act this month. It noted that in the past few months alone
column7: 19 states passed 34 laws that made it harder to vote. The mayors wrote: “American democracy is stronger when all eligible voters participate in elections. Yet voting rights are under historic attack and our very democracy is threatened. “These bills would stop this voter suppression. They would create national standards for voting access in federal elections that would neutralize many of the restrictive voting laws passed in the states.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/03/schumer-senate-democracy-voting-rights-election
