column14: 'Economics'];At the core of Boris Johnson’s Brexit is a conflict between ideology and geography. The purpose of the project is divergence – a competitive leap away from Europe into other markets. But that impulse to move is thwarted by the permanence of Britain’s location. No matter how much sovereignty the Eurosceptics claim over national regulation
column15: governing a medium-sized power 30 miles from the coast of France will always require some accommodation with the interests of neighbouring states. EU membership was not the only possible way to manage those relationships
column16: but it worked better than anything that had been tried in the preceding centuries
column17: and nothing has been arranged to replace it. The Brexit withdrawal deal offers only a technical framework for economic partnership
column18: and even that is unstable
column19: as is clear from the ongoing negotiations over customs checks for Northern Ireland and operating licences for French fishers in UK waters. The two issues are not equivalent in scale. Much more is at stake on the island of Ireland
column20: given the history of sectarian violence. But they flow from a common Brexit delusion
column21: which is the belief that “taking back control” is a unilateral assertion. In reality
column22: borders have two sides. The folly of ignoring that strategic geometry has been routinely demonstrated
column23: most recently in a silly exchange of recriminations over migrant boat crossings in the Channel. The Home Office
column24: being unable to stop the vessels
column25: has tried blaming French authorities for failing to stop embarkations. France replies that the draw factor is lax British labour regulations that act as a magnet for refugees seeking a new life. French agenda Tensions on that front predate Brexit. The UK was not part of the Schengen common travel area
column26: and policing of the Anglo-French border is governed by the bilateral Le Touquet accord. But the capacity for escalation is higher now that Britain has no seat around the EU table where other continental leaders meet. As it happens
column27: France sets the agenda at that table for the first six months of 2022
column28: as holder of the rotating council presidency. That means also that President Emmanuel Macron’s hawkish view of Britain’s obligations to uphold the Brexit agreement it signed will set the tone in Brussels. Since Mr Macron is seeking re-election in April
column29: his attention will be more than usually focused on domestic matters. To the extent that those issues overlap with Brexit – as in the fisheries dispute – there will be pressure to take a hard line with London. There is a tendency in Downing Street to see Mr Macron’s stance as punitive to the point of spite. The Tory Eurosceptic view is that France
column30: affronted by the temerity of Britannia in choosing freedom
column31: is determined to prevent her from enjoying its benefits. That analysis contains a truth
column32: filtered through a jaundiced lens. Mr Macron
column33: in common with other EU leaders
column34: understands that Brexit is a deliberate strategic challenge to the European project
column35: based on the false premise that Britain could retain benefits of proximity to continental markets while using deregulation to outcompete EU businesses. Plainly
column36: it is in the economic interests of member states for that not to happen. It is also in the interest of politicians who are committed to the logic of supranational solidarity that Euroscepticism be seen as a strategic cul-de-sac. Mr Macron is less patient than some of his continental counterparts for that point to be proven. As German chancellor
column37: Angela Merkel took the view that British noses should not be rubbed too hard in the folly of Brexit
column38: lest they be put out of joint. She feared Britain sliding even deeper into populism. Her successor
column39: Olaf Scholz
column40: is closer to Mr Macron’s position. Anglo-French relations are not helped by the low opinion that the French president has of Boris Johnson. He has been quoted describing the prime minister as “un clown”. He believes Mr Johnson is a deceitful and unreliable partner. A run of poor judgments and conspicuous dishonesties have made that assessment of Mr Johnson’s character indisputable. column6: 'World news'];Jonathan Freedland is right to say we fight shy of the “why” question when faced with extreme acts of cruelty or abuse (The Ghislaine Maxwell case raises a question some may think naive: why? 31 December). column5: 'Culture'];"A proposal to insert a statue of the first woman in the world to earn a PhD among the 78 dedicated to notable male figures on a prominent square in northern Italy has stirred controversy. Elena Lucrezia Cornaro Piscopia received her doctorate degree in philosophy from the University of Padua in 1678. But she was not included when Padua officials devised a project in the late 18th century to erect statues in Prato della Valle – the largest square in Italy – dedicated to illustrious historical figures who were either from the city or had links to it. Originally there were 88 statues adorning the central island of the 90
column6: 000-sq-metre square
column7: all paying tribute to men
column8: including the Italian scientist Galileo Galilei
column9: the sculptor Antonio Canova
column10: and several popes. But 10 statues dedicated to Venetian doges were destroyed by Napoleon’s army after it conquered the republic of Venice; eight were later replaced by obelisks
column11: while two of the pedestals remained empty. Although a statue honouring Piscopia already exists at the University of Padua
column12: two local councillors
column13: Simone Pillitteri and Margherita Colonnello
column14: proposed celebrating her with another on one of the empty pedestals at Prato della Valle. “Perhaps it is not so well known that the figures to whom the stone effigies are dedicated are all
column15: without exception
column16: men
column17: ” the pair wrote in a motion presented to the city’s council. The suggestion came after Mi Riconosci
column18: an association of professionals working in the cultural heritage sector
column19: undertook a census of all statues of Italian figures erected in public spaces across the country and found that only 148 were dedicated to women. Federica Arcoraci
column20: an art historian with Mi Riconosci
column21: said Prato della Valle’s male-only line-up had “an impact on our lives and collective imagination”. She said: “The Prato della Valle regulation of 1776 forbade having statues of saints
column22: living people and people with no ties to the city
column23: but never prohibited the representation of women. “Obviously
column24: that was the result of a particular trend in history. But today it is possible to create a project that is connected with the history of the square in its entirety.”

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the proposal immediately sparked debate
column3: with detractors arguing that placing a statue of Piscopia in the square would be “out of context” with its history. Carlo Fumian
column4: a history professor at the University of Padua
column5: said the “expensive and bizarre” idea was “a bit trendy
column6: but culturally inconsistent”. “Moving monuments as if they were Lego is a dangerous and unintelligent game
column7: ” he told the local newspaper
column8: Il Mattino di Padova. “Instead
column9: we should help people discover the original [statue]
column10: triumphantly seated at the university.” Art historian Davide Tramarin said the two empty pedestals should remain empty as they represented a symbol of the historical destruction by Napoleon’s troops. Fabrizio Magani

column5: 'US politics'];"Only free and fair elections in which the loser abides by the result stand between each of us and life at the mercy of a despotic regime – one we had no voice in choosing and one that can freely violate all our rights. So everything is at stake in the peaceful transfer of power from a government that has lost its people’s confidence to its victorious successor. It was that peaceful transfer that Trump and his minions sought to obstruct and almost succeeded in overthrowing when Joe Biden was elected president. A year has passed since Donald Trump’s attempted coup and his supporters’ violent storming of the United States Capitol on 6 January 2021
column6: in a nearly successful effort to prevent Congress from certifying Trump’s decisive loss of the election to Biden. Watching the images that day of the seat of US democracy overtaken and defiled
column7: it was impossible not to viscerally feel the grave danger that confronted the republic. In the tumultuous year since
column8: the immediacy of that sensation has waned – and the magnitude of the stakes has receded from memory. In the rubble of the insurrection
column9: the sheer shock of the moment jarred loose hints of long-lost bipartisanship and national unity and rekindled an appreciation of why a successful coup would have meant the end of all we care about. The House of Representatives expeditiously moved to impeach Trump for his role in fomenting the attack and 57 senators

column9: peering in. The Gurus’ tour manager is a large man and he’s struggling. I’m talking him through it when another crew member arrives and we stand
column10: peering in
column11: together. “I want one thing
column12: ” says the tour manager trapped in the lift. “Just get her away from me now.” I thought my counselling skills were good but they are not on this day; somehow
column13: they elude me this day. Back in the foyer
column14: Clyde Bramley
column15: bass player with the Gurus
column16: demands that something be done. Where is that firetruck that was called 20 minutes ago? Clyde is maddened. The crew in the lift are disturbed. The foyer is a mass of competing energies – the staff calming

column1: Clyde is done. He picks up an enormous pot plant and smashes it to the ground. “Get them some help

column3: hurtling down the stairwell

column5: the Gurus’ manager
column6: catching Clyde in a headlock

column8: the Go-Betweens’ bass player
column9: whispers to me: “I know what that feels like?” I ask: “What do you mean?” He replies

column11: early mornings
column12: hurry up and wait

column14: I know how Clyde feels.”";https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/04/the-go-betweens-lindy-morrison-ill-never-forget-playing-roskilde-when-chaos-hit-the-hoodoo-gurus

column4: 'Life and style'
column5: 'Australian lifestyle'];"Back pain is the most common form of chronic pain
column6: with about 4 million people living with it in Australia. The most effective way to manage chronic back pain is with a multidisciplinary approach
column7: of which exercise is a key component. “Any single treatment in low back pain is never enough by itself
column8: ” says Associate Prof Michael Vagg
column9: a pain medicine physician and dean of the faculty of pain medicine at the Australian and New Zealand College of Anaesthetists. “But exercise is a fundamental part of recovering from low back pain and managing it if it becomes persistent.” But people who have suffered from back pain for a long time might feel fearful of moving. Dr Matthew Bagg
column10: a physiotherapist and pain scientist at Curtin University
column11: says the first big challenge for people with chronic back pain is understanding that pain is not an accurate indication of the robustness of their body. “Regardless of how they feel
column12: they are not broken
column13: damaged or falling apart.”

column1: “If it hurts to do something
column2: people are likely to do less of it
column3: ” Vagg says. But those who remain active tend to have better outcomes in the long term. “Even when we experience back pain
column4: it doesn’t mean that we shouldn’t be moving.” “Pain itself isn’t an issue
column5: ” agrees Dr Rob Laird
column6: a musculoskeletal physiotherapist. But increasing pain during and after exercise is a red flag
column7: he says. “Exercise should reduce
column8: not increase
column9: pain.” There is limited evidence to suggest that one type of exercise is better than another when it comes to chronic back pain. “The best exercise is one that you will keep doing and enjoy
column10: ” Vagg says. Laird says physical activity for chronic back pain should include three domains: strength
column11: mobility
column12: and cardiovascular fitness. Consulting a GP or a physiotherapist before starting an exercise routine for chronic back pain is strongly recommended. But here are some practical tips that can help you stay active. The class: pilates In a study published in October in the Journal of Physiotherapy
column13: Bagg and his colleagues conducted a statistical analysis that combined the results of multiple clinical trials of exercise therapies for people with long-term back pain. They found some evidence suggesting that pilates exercise might have the most significant effects on pain intensity. Pilates classes include a series of exercises that focus on the stability and mobility of the body
column14: particularly the spine
column15: core and pelvic area. It emphasises the “neutral spine position” – the natural curves in our spine that provide stability and mobility for taking on the weight and pressure of our bodies. Pilates exercises also help strengthen legs and gluteal muscles
column16: shoulders and arms. The move: single knee squat Laird advises strengthening lower limb and gluteal muscles because these are the muscles we use when we bend or move from sitting to standing. “If they are underdone
column17: the back muscles have to work harder.” Because exercising legs and glutes does not involve excessively recruiting back muscles
column18: he says
column19: most people feel safe doing it. Laird suggests beginning with the classic pilates roll down and progressing to single knee squats. To start a roll down
column20: imagine standing against a wall
column21: then think of peeling your spine off the wall one vertebra at a time
column22: beginning by tucking the chin in
column23: rolling the neck and slowly going down to the pelvis. Your knees are slightly bent
column24: and you might feel some pressure in your hamstrings. To come back up
column25: roll the pelvis first
column26: then the spine
column27: one vertebra at a time. Neck and head come up last.

column1: The second part of the exercise targets the gluteus maximus. Roll down again one vertebra at a time
column2: place one hand on a chair to balance and lift one foot off the ground. Bend the knee of the standing leg
column3: then push through the heel and come back up. Aim to five to 10 repetitions and change side. Reduced mobility of the spine has a poor impact on back function
column4: Laird says. A simple exercise that can help improve back mobility is the cat-cow stretch. Start in a four-point kneeling position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Breathing in
column5: allow your stomach to drop down slowly and tilt your pelvis forward. As you exhale
column6: arch your back up by tucking your tailbone in and pulling your belly button in towards your spine. The activity: walking
column7: cycling
column8: swimming Laird says brisk walks
column9: cycling or swimming are great ways to include cardiovascular fitness in your training. These are all activities most people with chronic back pain can do
column10: he says. “Cardiovascular fitness is essential. If you are not fit enough to walk around the block easily
column11: you are going to struggle with life in general
column12: and pain is still going to be a real problem.” The hard pass: running Laird does not encourage taking up running. “Running is not recommended at the start of a recovery plan but can be used in younger patients towards the middle to end of their recovery plan
column13: ” he says. “It’s less useful in older patients – over 60 approximately
column14: although there are always some exceptions – because of the impact loading when there is significant degenerative change already present.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/04/how-to-move-with-chronic-back-pain

column3: 'Life and style'
column4: 'DIY'];"Getting caught in the rain is depicted on screen with near-comic frequency. From make-out scenes in Nicholas Sparks film to the drama of Shawshank Redemption and Point Break
column5: stormy skies have long been a marker of heightened emotions
column6: desperate declarations and a willingness to well
column7: get wet. With La Niña weather patterns already making this a particularly wet Australian summer
column8: on the upside
column9: we can plan grand romantic gestures with a little more oomph. But this doesn’t mean our clothes have to suffer. Here’s how to care for your outfit after that dramatic downpour pash. The 101 When you get home after being caught in the rain
column10: assess what you’re wearing and how drenched it is to determine what to do next. Corey Simpson
column11: a communications manager for clothing company Patagonia
column12: says: “Some material may not need any care after being caught in the rain; others
column13: like natural fabrics
column14: may need to be dried.”

column1: Garments like coats and jackets that have natural water resistance can just be shaken out or wiped off
column2: while t-shirts
column3: jumpers and pants that have absorbed rainwater will require more attention. Once you’ve taken wet clothes off
column4: it’s best not to leave them sitting in a pile or inside a clothes basket
column5: as this can result in mildew and smells. Damp clothes should be hung on a rack to dry or washed straight away. If you’ve been particularly adventurous (or unlucky) and your clothes are dirty as well as wet
column6: Simpson says to “wipe off chunks of mud and debris” first
column7: “then wash the garment according to the manufacturer’s instructions”.

column1: For delicate fabrics like fine wool and silk
column2: a trip to the dry cleaner may be in order to prevent water stains. Re-upping repellence Simpson says synthetic fabrics coated “with a durable water repellent usually fare best in the rain” but they also require special treatment to maintain their performance. Unfortunately
column3: water repellence doesn’t last forever. It can be affected by dirt
column4: your skin’s natural oils
column5: sunscreen and smoke
column6: so it’s important to keep your raincoat or puffer jacket clean. Simpson says: “Be sure to wash and dry your garment often – this helps remove oils and anything that can hinder the performance of your puffer or raincoat.”

column1: Check the care instructions
column2: but most nylon or polyester rain jackets and waterproof shells are machine washable. Use a performance wear-specific cleaner (Simpson recommends Grangers). Proper drying is also important to maintain water-repellent properties. Raincoats should be run through the dryer on medium heat for at least half an hour
column3: he suggests. If care instructions permit
column4: ironing can also improve water-repellent properties
column5: but this should be done over a towel on a very low heat to avoid melting your jacket.

column1: For less technical rain garments – like waxed cotton parkas or poly-cotton trench coats – it is best to follow the care instructions on the label. Ironically
column2: some rain-repellent trench coats can be dry clean only. Puffer jackets should be washed with a down-specific detergent
column3: and can take a long time to dry. They should be left to drip dry for between 24 to 48 hours
column4: while being given the occasional fluff to prevent the down from clumping. When almost dry
column5: put the puffer in the dryer on a low heat with some dryer balls to completely break up any remaining clumps. If the water-repellent properties of your outerwear have diminished after a few years of wear
column6: the good news is you can apply a fresh layer. Patagonia recommends the wash-in or spray-on products from Nikwax – which also work on waxed cotton. Special care for shoes

column1: Getting caught in the rain is the number one reason to waterproof your shoes and sneakers when you first buy them. Jenny Velakoulis
column2: the owner of Evans Leather Repair
column3: says to apply three coats of a waterproofing spray to your leather shoes
column4: then reapply every six months. The same goes for sneakers. Eugene Cheng
column5: the founder of Sneaker Laundry
column6: a maintenance service in Melbourne
column7: says the first and most important step is protection. A waterproofing spray will form a barrier around the sneaker
column8: making it easier to care for. If the rain has already got to your shoes
column9: before drying them out
column10: make sure they’re clean. Use a material-specific shampoo to prevent dirt from drying into the shoe
column11: then place leather shoes somewhere dry
column12: away from heaters and out of direct sunlight to dry off. Once dry
column13: apply a balm to nourish the leather. For sneakers that have been soaked
column14: take out the laces and insoles and leave them outside in the sun. Cheng warns that sneakers can get mouldy if they’re put in closets or left indoors while wet.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/04/home-and-dry-what-to-do-with-clothes-that-have-been-caught-in-the-rain

column6: 'World news'];"Human bodies have a second line of defence against Covid that offers hope in the global fight against the Omicron variant
column7: Australian researchers say. University of Melbourne research
column8: done in conjunction with the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
column9: has found T-cells should be able to tackle the virus. Omicron has a higher number of mutations than other variants
column10: which means it can sometimes slip past the antibodies produced by vaccination or infection. But if it does enter the body
column11: the T-cells – white blood cells that originate in the marrow – will attack. • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: The research has just been published in the peer-reviewed journal Viruses. Co-leader of the research
column2: the University of Melbourne’s Matthew McKay
column3: said while it was a preliminary study
column4: it was “positive news”. “Even if Omicron
column5: or some other variant for that matter
column6: can potentially escape antibodies
column7: a robust T-cell response can still be expected to offer protection and help to prevent significant illness
column8: ” he said. “These results overall would suggest that broad escape from T-cells is very unlikely. “Based on our data
column9: we anticipate that T-cell responses elicited by vaccines and boosters
column10: for example
column11: will continue to help protect against Omicron
column12: as observed for other variants. We believe this presents some positive news in the global fight against Omicron.” The team studied fragments of Covid’s viral proteins – called epitopes – from patients that had been vaccinated or infected. Among the epitopes that had the Omicron mutation
column13: more than half were predicted to still be visible to T-cells
column14: HKUST research assistant professor and study co-lead Ahmed Abdul Quadeer said. “This further diminishes the chance that Omicron may escape T-cells’ defences
column15: ” he said. The paper’s authors warn that T-cell responses alone do not block infection and therefore prevent transmission. However
column16: the T-cell immunity provides hope of a protection against severe disease. Dr Stuart Turville
column17: from the University of New South Wales’ Kirby Institute
column18: has been studying samples from people infected with Omicron. He said T-cells represent a “pretty good backup” in the immune response. That response is multi-factorial
column19: he said
column20: as both T-cells and B-cells (which produce antibodies) develop a “memory” of the virus that attacks the body.

column1: “At the beginning
column2: what gives them that memory is the primary encounter
column3: ” Turville said. “If you’re lucky
column4: it’s a vaccination; if you’re unlucky
column5: it’s the first time you’re infected.” University of Sydney’s Prof Robert Booy
column6: who is also a director of the Immunisation Coalition
column7: said T-cells were an “important backup” to antibodies because they recognise different parts of viruses to produce a response to entire cells
column8: not just their proteins. Australia has a long history of T-cell research
column9: he said. Prof Peter Doherty – the patron of the Peter Doherty Institute
column10: which has been providing Covid modelling – won the Nobel prize in 1996 for his work on T-cell-mediated immunity. Booy also pointed to world-first work being done at the Westmead Institute for Medical Research on how long-term immunity to Covid works
column11: and the possibilities of a T-cell vaccine. The new University of Melbourne research also adds to existing international work that shows the importance of T-cells. South African researchers have found that T-cells can robustly protect against Omicron after it has evaded antibodies. A small South African study that has not yet been peer-reviewed also suggested T-cells have a role to play.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/04/t-cells-can-fight-omicron-when-antibodies-fail-to-australian-researchers-say

column2: 'Food'
column3: 'Waste'];"While 5 million Australians go hungry each year
column4: an estimated 7.3m tonnes of food is wasted. In Australia
column5: up to 25% of all vegetables produced never leave the farm
column6: often because they are too oddly shaped for the grocery store. All the while

column1: Though the numbers sound overwhelming

Buying a subscription box of imperfect groceries may just be the most convenient way to simultaneously offload your weekly shop for fresh produce and reduce waste.

column1: Good & Fugly

column3: delivers boxes of fresh produce direct from the farm. Each box includes staple ingredients – such as potatoes
column4: onions and leafy greens – as well as a variety of changing seasonal produce. A small box of fruit and veg
column5: feeding two people for up to five days
column6: sells for $39. A larger box
column7: feeding five people for up to five days
column8: sells for $59.

column1: Farmer’s Pick
column2: a Melbourne-based service
column3: has found a home for more than 100 tonnes of fresh
column4: oddly bent and sometimes blemished produce. Straight from local farms
column5: the produce varies week-to-week
column6: and subscription options cater to single and family households
column7: with boxes starting at $35. The service also partners with Alex Makes Meals
column8: donating up to seven meals to Victorians facing food insecurity for every box sold. Harris Farm
column9: the family-owned NSW market chain
column10: offers their own imperfect produce service at a discount of up to 50% off on fresh produce through their Imperfect Picks range online. Or
column11: if you want a curated box to save you the trouble of adding to your cart
column12: buy their Imperfect Picks Value Box for $40. Give the strangely-bent carrot or bumpy potato a try and you’ll support local farmers
column13: reduce your contribution to a growing volume of wasted food each year
column14: and you may just find you consume more fresh produce than ever.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/04/easy-wins-imperfect-produce-the-perfect-solution-to-food-waste

column8: 'Australian politics'];"This is not a unique story. I’m trapped in a house with my husband and two teens
column9: and we’re all sick. My 19-year-old son was the first to go down on Tuesday
column10: 28 December. In the morning he developed stomach cramps
column11: vomiting
column12: a migraine and a high fever. I bought him the last rapid antigen test at the local servo. It came up as positive. And so began our efforts to be included in New South Wales’ latest Covid figures. A week later and we are still not part of that count.

column1: I live in northern NSW and last Tuesday was a public holiday. I rang three public hospitals to find out which testing centres were open and learnt that every testing centre was overrun and our chances of getting in were Buckley’s. I was undeterred. My son had severe asthma as a child. Would Omicron trigger his asthma? I’m probably an anxious mother
column2: but I wanted an official diagnosis in case he needed hospital care. I also believe that the state and federal governments need to chart the spread of infection because it’s their job to deliver resources to hospitals and tighten pandemic restrictions to slow infection. I was determined for us to be included in the Covid count.

column1: On Tuesday afternoon we drove to the Byron drive-through testing clinic – the security guard said they couldn’t test any more people. We then headed to Ballina only to be turned away. Lismore and Casino’s drive-throughs were also closed. We went home. My son’s temperature was above 38C that night despite the Nurofen and Panadol. The headaches also started for me. At 6am on Wednesday
column2: my feverish son dragged himself out of bed and I drove him back to a drive-through testing clinic. It was almost 20C
column3: but he wore a hoodie
column4: and brought a blanket and box of tissues. By 9am we’d crawled to the front of the drive-through queue. I told the nurse he had a positive RAT and a history of severe asthma. She said his results would be fast-tracked and back in 50 hours. I was surprised that 50 hours was considered fast
column5: but still grateful he was a priority. We drove home from the testing centre and into the twilight zone. The whole family became unwell
column6: and days of high temperatures
column7: strange dreams
column8: headaches
column9: dizziness and exhaustion followed. Since the summer influx of visitors to the northern rivers
column10: one member of my family has received a Covid exposure site alert every second day. It has been like playing dodgem cars with Covid. We got hit.

column1: Our region is popular with tourists so they add to rapidly increasing case numbers
column2: but it also has a high percentage of elderly and First Nations residents and a limited number of ICU beds. I hope our health system holds in coming weeks. NSW premier Dominic Perrottet has told journalists: “We will tailor our response to the situation that comes. If evidence changes
column3: we will have targeted restrictions in place.” For seven days
column4: we have been trying to contribute to “the evidence”. Yesterday – 122 hours after being swabbed – my son and I received our positive results so I anticipate we will be in today’s figure
column5: exactly a week after he became sick. My husband and daughter will surely be added to the numbers having also been tested. The questions I keep coming back to now are: is the testing system so slow because labs are under-resourced
column6: and the state government did not plan for a contagious new variant and Christmas travel and celebrations causing a surge in cases? Or are numbers rising so quickly it’s simply impossible for labs to keep up? Should we consider Victoria’s lead and look at allowing people to upload RAT results? What is clear though is the latest numbers being given out by government clearly do not reflect daily infection rates. I’ve come to think of the NSW Covid-19 figures as being like a Hubble space telescope – reporting back what happened light years ago.";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/04/i-spent-a-week-trying-to-be-counted-as-a-nsw-covid-case-ive-only-just-succeeded

For more: The band’s entire catalogue is worthy of your time. Just dive in. Augie March – Clay For fans of: Holly Throsby

column1: Wilsn – You Know Better For fans of: Amy Winehouse

column1: 5792;5792;Telehealth changes ‘devastating’ for psychiatry patients in regional areas;2022-01-03T16:30:06Z;['Tory Shepherd'];['Health'
column2: 'Australia news'
column3: 'Medicare Australia'
column4: 'Greg Hunt'];"Australians in regional areas with severe mental health problems will go without help
column5: after “devastating” changes to the telehealth system
column6: psychiatrists warn. Recent federal government reforms removed a 50% loading for some rural psychiatric services
column7: meaning some types of consultations providers will no longer be able to bulk-bill. They will have to absorb the costs or pass them on to patients. • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: Dr Vivienne James
column2: a psychiatrist at Sydney’s Gordon Clinic
column3: says she is “devastated” and her patients will be “distressed” about the changes
column4: which came into effect on 1 January. “It is simply not financially viable for us to continue seeing these patients
column5: ” she said. “This will leave many patients distressed and
column6: dare I say it
column7: suicidal
column8: as some of these people are extremely isolated and have little support. They will not be able to pay to see us and will have to be discharged back to their GPs. “Personally
column9: I am devastated by these changes.” Grahame Gee
column10: a credentialed mental health nurse
column11: said it was “unethical” that he and his colleagues were “blindsided” by the changes
column12: which were announced a couple of weeks before Christmas. His patients have complex mental health needs and many also have histories of physical and sexual abuse and intimate partner violence. “Most have limited financial means and struggle to pay gap fees
column13: ” he said. “Their recovery depends upon access to this service … I had patients in tears … Others said they would have to cancel their appointments.” On 13 December the federal health department announced $106m to make telehealth a permanent part of primary healthcare. On 16 December it announced changes to the Medical Benefits Scheme
column14: including two new telehealth items
column15: 17 amended items and the scrapping of 128 items
column16: which included item 288 for video psychiatric consultations through GP referrals. Guardian Australia revealed how other changes would affect patients
column17: particularly those with cancer.

column1: Assoc Prof Vinay Lakra
column2: the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists president
column3: said most of the reforms were welcome
column4: but that fixing some gaps meant others appeared. “People living in a rural area couldn’t afford to see a psychiatrist
column5: but [the rural loading] allowed them to see a psychiatrist without paying a gap. If you’re bulk-billing and that loading is removed
column6: some providers will pass on the cost to the patients and patients might cancel their appointment.” The rural loading was introduced about 10 years ago to encourage the use of telehealth in country Australia
column7: an incentive the health department says is no longer needed. Lakra said that before Covid
column8: the psychiatric community wanted it phased out rather than removed and only phased out if there was another system in place to ensure affordability and accessibility. Covid “hasn’t gone”
column9: he said
column10: and the college wants the MBS item extended for another year. “Twelve months is enough time to prepare a plan … With item 288 there was not enough time
column11: ” he said. In a statement
column12: the health department said the new arrangements consolidated telehealth into a single national program
column13: “ensuring universal and equitable access”
column14: and that rural patients will have access to other bulk-billing options.

column1: The loading was to encourage the take-up of video consultations and help practitioners adopt new technologies. But according to the statement
column2: there are about 10 times more telephone consultations than there are consultations that attract the loading and more than twice as many video consultations that do not attract the loading. “This is about improving access to video and telephone services provided by GPs
column3: medical specialists and other health professionals that reflect clinical best practice and provides greater flexibility in the healthcare system
column4: depending on the services required
column5: ” the statement said. “It is backed by an additional $106m over four years and part of a $308.6m investment by the government to support Australia’s primary care system.” • Crisis support services can be reached 24 hours a day: Lifeline 13 11 14; Suicide Call Back Service 1300 659 467; Kids Helpline 1800 55 1800; MensLine Australia 1300 78 99 78; Beyond Blue 1300 22 4636";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/04/telehealth-changes-devastating-for-psychiatry-patients-in-regional-areas

column1: 5793;5793;Can Britain really learn to live with Omicron? This week we’ll find out;2022-01-03T16:30:05Z;['Gaby Hinsliff'];['Coronavirus'
column2: 'Boris Johnson'
column3: 'Conservatives'
column4: 'Hospitals'
column5: 'Schools'
column6: 'Education'
column7: 'Politics'
column8: 'Society'
column9: 'UK news'];"The roulette wheel is spinning
column10: the ball already rattling towards its final destination. Boris Johnson has bet the house on his Omicron gamble and now there’s no going back. The bullishness of ministers insisting over the weekend that they see no case for further restrictions glosses over the fact that it may now be too late for that anyway
column11: given an estimated one in 25 people in England already had the virus before New Year’s Eve. Double or quits it is
column12: then
column13: as a country drags itself back out to work and school after the Christmas hibernation period. We’re about to find out exactly what it means to experience unprecedented levels of Covid infections
column14: but from a strain that may be less dangerous
column15: at least in the fully vaccinated. Once again
column16: a virus we thought we’d got to know has abruptly shapeshifted and once again
column17: history isn’t necessarily a reliable guide to the present. We’re all back on the seesaw
column18: lurching between hope and fear
column19: never knowing quite what to expect. The novel threat this time is not death on the biblical scale forecast during the first wave – although sadly there will be too many deaths
column20: hospitalisations and cases of long Covid disabling people for months to come – but knock-on chaos and disruption caused by the potential mass infection of key workers
column21: leaving them unable to do their work. We’ve entered an unpredictable world of people who have heart attacks waiting for well over an hour for an ambulance
column22: critical incidents being declared by hospitals that can’t maintain safe staffing levels and large organisations being warned to plan for up to a quarter of their people being off sick or self-isolating. Now imagine what that worst-case scenario might do to the everyday grind of supermarket deliveries
column23: bin collections and bus timetables
column24: let alone to policing or critical infrastructure such as the power and water industries. Education ministers have meanwhile vowed to keep schools and nurseries open wherever possible – rightly given the profound impact we now know closures had on poorer children’s education
column25: and on a vulnerable few who are sadly safer with their teachers than with their parents – but are simultaneously letting heads know they can send year groups home if they have to. For secondary schools in England and Wales hit by serious staff shortages
column26: in practice that would probably mean prioritising GCSE and A-level classes for pupils who need to sit their mocks this term but switching to home schooling for other years if necessary
column27: something already happening in some parts of the country before Christmas as Omicron hit. Nurseries and primary schools catering for pupils too young to be vaccinated will meanwhile be flinging windows open to the January air and crossing their fingers
column28: knowing that (at least according to the Office for National Statistics) about one in 15 children aged between two and 11 had Covid before Christmas. Since many key workers are also parents who can’t easily do their jobs if their child gets sent home sick
column29: we’re probably about to be reminded that childcare is the fourth emergency service
column30: without which the other three would struggle very quickly. In other words
column31: it’s time to prepare ourselves at least for the possibility of things getting messy; of everyday life becoming harder and more volatile as Covid jams its spokes into wheels that in good times you barely even notice turning.

column1: With luck
column2: that upheaval could be mercifully brief. But any country that nearly ground to a halt overnight thanks to a temporary post-Brexit shortage of fuel tanker drivers and a panicky stampede for petrol should probably have learned by now not to get cocky. Over and over again this virus has reminded us of just how much happens unseen beneath the surface of a functioning society; of how complex our just-in-time modern lives with all their endlessly interconnected moving parts have become
column3: but also how fragile
column4: dependent on things and people we mostly take for granted until brutally reminded not to do so. And that’s why learning to live with this or any other virus
column5: the mantra of those who never want their liberties restricted by government diktat again
column6: doesn’t mean quite what some hope it does. It’s not about ripping off your mask and gleefully forgetting that any of it ever happened
column7: but about building in resilience and learning from the weaknesses exposed by Covid. Rubbing along successfully through what might hopefully be the tail end of a pandemic should mean investing not just in vaccines and antivirals but in more hospital beds and people to staff them
column8: creating enough slack in the system to absorb seasonal Covid surges without having to throw up tent wards in NHS car parks. It’s going to mean well-honed contingency plans for critical industries
column9: better ventilation in schools
column10: and more imaginative answers to the question of protecting people who are shielding or clinically vulnerable than are so far forthcoming from lockdown sceptics bellowing that it’s time everyone was left to get on with their lives. But it may also take something of a shift in national attitudes. Living successfully with Covid-19 will require not just a virus obliging enough not to mutate in more lethal ways but the maturity to self-police sometimes – as plenty did last month by voluntarily side-swerving parties or the pub so they could have Christmas with their families
column11: and as Swedes have always quietly done in what was the unsung element of their country’s no-lockdown policy – and the resilience to live with a degree of unpredictability in life
column12: which is infinitely easier said than done for some. Low-income families especially are likely to need help absorbing the sudden shocks and disruptions this virus is still capable of delivering
column13: even as it hopefully burns itself out. The silver lining to the Omicron cloud is
column14: of course
column15: that it could pass relatively quickly. It’s risky reading too much into data collected over the Christmas holidays when reporting was potentially patchy
column16: but all hopes are now pinned on Britain following the same path as South Africa
column17: where infections seemed to peak relatively quickly before falling back. A rocky few weeks
column18: so the cabinet’s argument goes
column19: beats months of economic and personal misery; better to rip the plaster off and get it over with. Whether that gamble was uncharacteristically shrewd or lethally reckless will become clear enough in the next few days as Omicron spreads from London to the rest of the UK
column20: with hospitalisation rates doubling already across much of the north of England. But right now
column21: the wretched roulette wheel is still spinning
column22: and all most of us can do about it is hold our breath. Gaby Hinsliff is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/britain-live-omicron-boris-johnson-roulette-wheel

column1: 5794;5794;‘My heart sank’: Covid returns to Newmarch House as aged care sector fears new crisis;2022-01-03T16:30:05Z;['Royce Kurmelovs'
column2: 'Michael McGowan'];['Aged care'
column3: 'Coronavirus'
column4: 'Australia news'
column5: 'Royal commission into aged care quality and safety'
column6: 'New South Wales'];"A positive Covid case has been recorded at the Newmarch House aged care home in Sydney
column7: where 19 people died during an outbreak in 2020
column8: amid growing concern at the strain on the sector’s workforce. As of Monday
column9: there were 1
column10: 180 active Covid-19 cases in aged care homes across Australia
column11: with more than 550 each in New South Wales and Victoria. In the past seven days
column12: the NSW health department has reported the deaths of eight aged care home residents as a result of coronavirus infections acquired inside the facilities. Federal government data suggests a rise in deaths in aged care has coincided with the move by most states to relax restrictions. In 2021 91 people died with Covid in aged care across Australia up to 22 October. By 17 December that figure had more than doubled to 206. At the same time the workforce in NSW
column13: which has experienced record-breaking case numbers
column14: has come under increasing pressure.

column1: The Guardian spoke to three aged care workers in the state
column2: all of whom did not wish to be named out of concern for their employment situation. Those in metropolitan areas described a feeling of “desperation” and burnout
column3: with workers in some facilities pulling 16-hour shifts to cover gaps in the workforce and nearby hospitals refusing to take new Covid-positive patients unless “absolutely necessary”. One worker at a regional facility in the state’s north said six staff had quit due to low pay and burnout
column4: leaving them woefully unprepared in the event of an outbreak. “I think we’re going to get Covid in the facility
column5: ” they said. “I think we’re going to lose more staff. I think the current staff who are willing to stay are going to burn out and get sick themselves. I think we’re going into a state of disaster. People will die.” On Sunday the operator of Newmarch
column6: Anglicare
column7: notified residents’ families that a staff member had tested positive for the virus after a “community exposure”. Newmarch said another member of staff and a resident had been identified as close contacts
column8: but that no further positive cases had been identified as yet. “Our highest priority is the safety and wellbeing of residents and staff
column9: while providing the best possible care to residents in the home
column10: ” Newmarch said in its email to the families. “As a further precaution
column11: PCR testing of [the] staff and residents will take place today.” The case has put the families of residents on high alert
column12: prompting memories of the devastating outbreak in which 37 residents tested positive and 19 died after a staff member worked a shift while infectious in April 2020. At the time it was the deadliest outbreak of the pandemic in Australia. “My heart sank
column13: it really did
column14: ” Elizabeth Lane
column15: whose mother is a resident at Newmarch
column16: told the Guardian. “My mum is at the end of life and the idea that there could be another outbreak and I wouldn’t be able to see her or be with her if she passed away
column17: nothing would break my heart more.

column1: “I don’t know if people realise the impact of what happened on the residents there
column2: the decline in a lot of the older people. Because of the lockdown and everything that has happened
column3: you go in there and the atmosphere is just so quiet.” Gerard Hayes
column4: the national president of the Health Services Union
column5: said he believed the situation was going to get “dramatically worse” around the country over the next few weeks. “I would usually have an optimistic view that if we apply this or apply that
column6: we can manage through. I don’t have an answer this time
column7: ” Hayes said. “This problem manifested itself some time ago [and] we chose to do very little about it. “Both the government and opposition have been talking a big game on aged care until it’s come to now. What are [the] Labor and Liberal [parties] going to do for the people who actually built this country
column8: who put us in a position we are in today? “I need answers – from both sides of government. At the moment all I’m hearing about in the federal sphere is nuclear submarines and bullet trains.” Hayes said the low pay in the industry
column9: with a base rate of $23 an hour
column10: was not enough to attract and keep new workers under normal conditions
column11: let alone during a time of crisis. Paul Sadler
column12: the chief executive of Aged and Community Services Australia
column13: said pay was one of a number of issues that had not been addressed since the royal commission and the first wave of the pandemic. “What we are seeing now is federal and state governments warning all businesses they could be losing 10 to 25% of their staff
column14: to a period of time when they’re Covid-positive and can’t come into work
column15: ” Sadler said. “I think our members feel like it’s an impossible situation on a daily basis for the moment. They’re trying to balance the risk; they’re trying to enable residents to have the best life possible; they’re trying to keep out a deadly disease; they’re trying to manage staff rosters when there’s immense pressure on the availability of staff.” “It’s the toughest time aged care services have ever been through.” • Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: A spokesperson for the federal health department said it was working closely with states and territories to provide surge workforce support when needed. “As soon as the department is notified of a case in an aged care worker or resident
column2: a case manager will be appointed to support the facility
column3: ” the spokesperson said. “This includes facilitating access to commonwealth programs and supports such as PPE and surge workforce. “In addition
column4: surge workforce support continues to be provided to supplement aged care providers’ strategies. This includes access to dedicated nursing staff and support from agency workers
column5: as well as agreements with private hospitals to provide support if states seek to utilise this resource.” The federal government changed guidelines on Saturday to allow employees who are close contacts to return to work earlier from isolation where a lack of staff was having a “high impact” on services. A national cabinet meeting on Wednesday is expected to address the issue of staffing in aged care.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/04/my-heart-sank-covid-returns-to-newmarch-house-as-aged-care-sector-fears-new-crisis

column2: advocates say;2022-01-03T16:30:05Z;['Sarah Martin'];['Disability'
column3: 'Religion'
column4: 'Coalition'
column5: 'Australian politics'
column6: 'Australia news'];"Disability groups say the Morrison government’s proposed religious discrimination bill will erode the rights of people with a disability and allow legally protected “hurt and humiliation”. In a submission to the parliamentary joint committee on human rights
column7: more than two dozen disability support organisations have urged the Coalition to abandon the bill in its current form
column8: saying there is widespread concern about its “harmful impacts”. “We support religious freedom as essential to a thriving democracy
column9: but not at the expense of the rights and freedoms of others
column10: ” the group’s submission states.

column1: “The religious discrimination bill will encourage prejudice
column2: stigma
column3: denigration
column4: division
column5: and discrimination against people with disability
column6: and undermine all efforts to build and sustain an inclusive Australia.” The organisations – which include peak advocacy groups People With Disability Australia and the Australian Federation of Disability Organisations – raise particular concern about the bill’s controversial statement of belief clause. This part of the proposed legislation says “statements of belief” do not breach discrimination laws
column7: giving legal protection to statements of religious belief or “a belief that the person genuinely considers to relate to the fact of not holding a religious belief”. Examples given in the submission include a person with a disability being told they are suffering a “punishment from God” for their
column8: or their parents’
column9: sins. Or being told they may be “healed” by prayer or by “living virtuously”. Disability advocates say this clause
column10: which would override existing state legislation aimed at protecting people with disability
column11: will result in more discrimination. It warns that a “power imbalance” already exists between people with a disability and the large proportion of disability support services that are faith-based and control the delivery of personal care
column12: housing
column13: community access and emergency relief. “We are concerned the religious discrimination bill will allow people with disability to be demeaned by statements of religious belief that are permitted under this bill
column14: creating an unsafe and harmful environment
column15: ” it states. A separate submission from Disability Voices Tasmania says the proposed bill
column16: which was first promised in 2018 and is now in its third iteration
column17: “introduces the right to discriminate in the name of religion”. “People with disability constantly experience ridicule
column18: offensive assumptions
column19: bias
column20: and intimidation. It does not matter whether this arises from hate
column21: prejudice
column22: misguided assumptions
column23: and attitudes towards disability
column24: or because of religious belief – or one person’s interpretation of religious belief
column25: ” the group’s chair
column26: Michael Small
column27: said. “What matters is the hurt
column28: humiliation
column29: and long-term impact we experience as a result of it.” Small said the legislation would override the Tasmanian Anti-Discrimination Act which prohibits conduct that a reasonable person would anticipate would offend
column30: humiliate
column31: intimidate
column32: insult
column33: or ridicule another person on the basis of disability. The proposed overriding of state and territory anti-discrimination laws has also been criticised by equality advocates
column34: who fear protections for the LGBTQ+ community would also be undermined
column35: including state laws banning conversion practices.

column1: The Equality Australia chief executive
column2: Anna Brown
column3: told federal parliament’s human rights committee in December that the proposal to override state laws would weaken equal rights. “It’s anathema to our democracy that state laws could be overridden in this way and that these hard-fought-for protections that have existed for decades
column4: in many cases
column5: could be unwound and overridden and undermined by this bill.” The proposed legislation is being scrutinised by two parliamentary inquiries due to report by 4 February – shortly before the scheduled resumption of parliament. The government was unable to pass the legislation in the final sitting of 2021 given deep divisions within the Coalition party room over the bill. Labor is reserving its position on the legislation until the inquiries are completed. But the opposition leader
column6: Anthony Albanese
column7: has said any new religious discrimination laws should not come at “the expense of discriminating on the basis of other people’s characteristics”.";https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/jan/03/coalitions-religious-discrimination-bill-will-erode-rights-of-people-with-disability-advocates-say

column1: 5796;5796;Covid-positive nurses are working in NSW hospitals due to severe staffing shortages;2022-01-03T16:30:05Z;['Elias Visontay'];['Health'
column2: 'New South Wales'
column3: 'Sydney'
column4: 'Coronavirus'
column5: 'Omicron variant'
column6: 'Australia news'];"Covid-positive nurses are being recalled to work in hospitals across New South Wales – in breach of state health protocols – as hospital managers resort to desperate measures to staff facilities buckling under the Omicron outbreak. Guardian Australia has been contacted by multiple nurses working across several hospitals in the state who are alarmed at finding themselves working alongside Covid-positive colleagues
column7: as 2
column8: 500 health workers are in isolation across NSW. The public hospitals span three local health districts in NSW and include major Sydney hospitals and smaller regional facilities.

column1: All of the nurses say they had received unofficial
column2: verbal advice from their hospitals in recent days that Covid-positive nurses could leave their mandated isolation to work
column3: provided they were asymptomatic and wore personal protective equipment. However
column4: some claimed they saw Covid-positive nurses on wards with obvious symptoms
column5: including coughing and sneezing. At one Sydney hospital
column6: the Covid-positive nurses appeared to be limited to working in Covid wards. However
column7: at other hospitals
column8: nurses said they were treating non-Covid patients and interacting with Covid-negative staff. “God help any non-Covid patient in a hospital right now. They are sitting ducks
column9: ” one nurse told Guardian Australia. “It’s like everyone has given up. I’m absolutely devastated. It’s a circus … positive nurses working with healthy staff and non-Covid patients.” Protocols for healthcare workers in NSW have been loosened in recent days
column10: including an exemption announced on New Year’s Eve to allow workers who are close contacts that should be isolating for seven days
column11: to return to work if they are asymptomatic and deemed essential by their employer. However
column12: a NSW Health spokesperson confirmed that Covid-positive nurses do not fall under this exemption. “Healthcare workers in NSW who test positive to Covid-19 are required to isolate at home and are not permitted to return to work until they are released from isolation
column13: ” they said. Nurses who expressed concern about allowing Covid-positive colleagues to return to work stressed that the advice was given in an unofficial capacity
column14: as managers were left with few other options to ensure patients could be cared for. The nurses requested their names and employers remain confidential to avoid identifying them. The revelation comes days after Guardian Australia obtained a leaked memo that revealed critically understaffed public hospitals in NSW were planning to fly in nurses from overseas. Desperate attempts also included managers begging local staff to cancel leave and offering $250 daily incentives on top of public holiday penalties. Meanwhile
column15: the western NSW LHD is offering nurses $823 a week on top of their wage to work in the region during January. The NSW premier
column16: Dominic Perrottet
column17: has said the health system “remains strong”
column18: and his health minister
column19: Brad Hazzard
column20: has also defended the system. On Monday
column21: the prime minister
column22: Scott Morrison
column23: backed up these comments
column24: insisting Australia’s health system could manage the “very different virus” of the Omicron variant. However
column25: the NSW Nurses and Midwives Association general secretary
column26: Brett Holmes
column27: accused governments of presenting an overly optimistic version of the state of the health system.

column1: Holmes said reports of Covid-positive nurses returning to work “shows the level of desperation we’ve got into our health system”. “To try and force potential sick and infectious staff into the hospitals to work
column2: that places everyone at risk.” Holmes told Guardian Australia he was “absolutely opposed” to allowing Covid-positive nurses to return to work before finishing their isolation and testing negative – but noted such a policy had occurred in parts of Europe and the United States during the peaks of their outbreaks. “There has been discussion about this here
column3: because it’s been done overseas
column4: and talk of the idea is no doubt rife amongst desperate managers looking for staff. They might well be preparing for this
column5: ” Holmes said. Holmes added the practice risked spreading Covid to vulnerable patients in hospital for unrelated reasons. “We know these types of patients can die with Covid. If nurses [are] knowingly being told to go in there and play a bit of Russian roulette as to whether their PPE is perfect all the time
column6: it’s an extraordinary expectation to work in those circumstances
column7: ” Holmes said. Do you know more about pressure in the healthcare system? Contact elias.visontay@theguardian.com. You can remain anonymous.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/03/covid-positive-nurses-are-working-in-nsw-hospitals-due-to-severe-staffing-shortages

column1: 5797;5797;Antonio Conte insists he has nothing to prove on Chelsea return with Spurs;2022-01-03T16:24:48Z;['David Hytner'];['Tottenham Hotspur'

column6: 'Sport'];"Antonio Conte says he has nothing to prove to anyone at Chelsea as he prepares for a first return to Stamford Bridge since his sacking in 2018. The manager goes back with Tottenham on Wednesday night for the Carabao Cup semi-final first leg and it is sure to be emotional
column7: given the relationships he made during his two seasons in west London.

column1: Conte won the Premier League in his first campaign
column2: seeing off the challenge of Spurs – then managed by Mauricio Pochettino – and he followed it up with an FA Cup triumph in his second season
column3: his team beating Manchester United in the final. It was not enough
column4: however
column5: to earn him a longer stay. Conte’s focus is on the cup game and managing a return of Covid cases to his squad. After the large outbreak in December that led to Spurs being forced to postpone their Europa Conference League tie against Rennes and the league fixture at Brighton
column6: Conte said the club were “checking a couple of situations about Covid” with regard to players
column7: although he was “not sure 100% that they’re going to miss the game”. Yet Conte did acknowledge the romantic side of the story that pits him against the club that gave him his first opportunity to work in England. “I spent two seasons where I created a good relationship with players
column8: staff
column9: people who work at Chelsea
column10: ” Conte said. “We did a really good job and I think in my position I mustn’t prove anything to anyone. I’m a manager that has experience and continues to have experience and do important jobs at other teams. It’ll be a pleasure for me to come back to Stamford Bridge.” Conte is acutely aware that Spurs have won nothing since 2008 but he also knows that Chelsea are at a different stage of development. “At this moment
column11: Chelsea is more ready than us to win
column12: ” he said. “They won the Champions League last season. We have a lot of space for improvement
column13: to be a team with aspirations to win. To use the verb ‘to win’ is more simple than winning because to win you have to build something important
column14: be solid
column15: have an important squad. Then you’re ready to win. Otherwise you have to hope.”

column1: On the disruption of Covid cases
column2: Conte said: “We are living with this situation – not only Tottenham but all the clubs. We have to be ready to find always the right solutions. For sure it’s not simple for any coach to change the plan you have
column3: especially when you play many games in a short time. You make a plan in your mind and sometimes you arrive and players are positive so you have to totally change your plan.” Meanwhile
column4: the Premier League confirmed that between 27 December and 2 January
column5: there were 94 new positive cases of Covid-19. This figure
column6: which came from 14
column7: 250 tests
column8: includes players and staff from the 20 clubs. It was the first week-by-week decrease in positive results for eight weeks.";https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/jan/03/antonio-conte-nothing-to-prove-chelsea-return-with-spurs-carabao-cup-covid-cases

column3: 'Spain'
column4: 'Europe'];An estimated 12 people a day died or disappeared while trying to reach Spain in 2021
column5: more than double the total for the previous year. The 4
column6: 404 refugees who perished included 205 children
column7: according to Caminando Fronteras (Walking Borders). In a report published on Monday
column8: the NGO noted that the number of deaths was more than twice the 2
column9: 170 deaths and disappearances recorded in 2020. “It’s horrible
column10: ” said Helena Maleno
column11: who leads Caminando Fronteras. “These are the worst figures we’ve seen since we began keeping count in 2007.” The report drew a direct link between the steep rise in the number of deaths and European efforts to curb migration in the Mediterranean. As a result
column12: refugees have turned increasingly to the treacherous Canary Islands route – one of the most dangerous crossings into Europe – setting off in unstable vessels that are often unfit to face the fierce currents of the Atlantic. Up until 28 December last year
column14: 200 migrants landed on the shores of the Canary Islands
column15: according to the Spanish government. Caminando Fronteras estimated that 4
column16: 016 people died or vanished along the route
column17: suggesting that for approximately every six people who make it to the Spanish archipelago
column18: one person dies or disappears. The figures compiled by Caminando Fronteras are drawn from the work it does in fielding distress calls from migrants or their families and alerting coastguards and maritime rescue services. The NGO also logs missing vessels and works with relatives to identify the missing and the dead. “The 4
column19: 404 is the minimum number
column20: ” said Maleno. “The truth is that there could be more victims that we aren’t aware of.” Boats en route to Spain often vanish without a trace
column21: in part explaining why the bodies of 95% of those who died or disappear are never recovered. People who were lost attempting to reach Spain came from 21 countries
column22: from the Ivory Coast to Sri Lanka
column23: many fleeing armed conflict or the consequences of climate change. Those who do make it to Spain
column24: particularly via the Canary Islands route
column25: are often haunted by the journey. “The waves were taller than the dinghy
column26: ” one survivor told Caminando Fronteras after a voyage in which 15 of the 58 people onboard were lost. “The waves washed people away
column27: sweeping them off the boat
column28: ” they said. Another man from Mali described spending days lost at sea as food and water supplies dwindled and nearly all of the 59 people onboard succumbed to starvation. After 19 days adrift
column29: rescuers found him and two others barely alive. He had spent much of the trip force-feeding a young boy who also managed to survive. “I would open his mouth to feed him a scrap of biscuit with the bit of water that was left and tell him to swallow
column30: ” he said. “He looked dead.” On Monday
column31: Caminando Fronteras called on the Spanish government to take urgent steps to address the rise in deaths
column32: noting that more than three decades had passed since a body turned up on the shores of Andalusia
column33: in what is believed to be the first known death of a Spain-bound refugee. “In those 34 years
column34: the idea that people can die by crossing a border has become something that people have accepted as normal
column35: ” said Maleno. “It’s not normal.” The International Organization for Migration has described 2021 as the deadliest for migration routes to and within Europe since 2018. At least 1
column36: 315 people have died on the central Mediterranean crossing
column37: while at least 41 lives were lost at the land border between Turkey and Greece. In November
column38: 27 refugees
column39: including a pregnant woman and three children
column40: drowned in the Channel while trying to cross from France to the UK.;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/03/death-toll-of-refugees-attempting-to-reach-spain-doubles-in-2021

column9: 'Wildlife'];"Some wild birds can be killed in order to protect game birds bred for shooting in England
column10: the government has ruled
column11: in an update to guidance on general shooting licences. General licences give broad permissions to shoot certain species of wild birds to protect livestock
column12: aid conservation
column13: and preserve health and public safety. The new licences have been issued for two years rather than one
column14: with government officials saying this is to provide “stability and certainty” to shooters. General licences are permissive licences
column15: meaning users do not need to apply for them but they must comply with their terms and conditions when undertaking licensed acts. There has been debate over whether pheasants
column16: partridges and grouse count as livestock
column17: as they are wild birds
column18: and so whether predators can be shot in order to protect them. The Department for Environment
column19: Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) has released a new definition of “livestock” including these birds
column20: to give explicit permission to shoot carrion crows
column21: jackdaws
column22: magpies and rooks. It reads: “‘Livestock’ is as defined in section 27(1) of the 1981 [Wildlife and Countryside] Act. For the purpose of this licence
column23: this expression also includes game birds kept in an enclosure or which are free roaming but remain significantly dependent on the provision of food
column24: water or shelter by a keeper for their survival. This does not include supplementary feeding.” A Defra spokesperson said the change was made after gamekeepers asked for more clarity about whether game birds counted as livestock. The new language makes it clear that wild predatory birds cannot be shot under this licence in order to protect wild game birds that are not dependent on food and shelter from humans
column25: but they can be shot under the licence if they are. The official added: “The new general licences have been updated to clarify when they apply and make clear when a game bird ceases to be livestock and becomes a wild bird. None of the changes alter the activities licence users are authorised to do. “We continue to work with stakeholders to ensure our licensing process is robust for wildlife and workable for users going forward.” Conservation groups raised concerns that the update could mean an increase in the killing of wild birds. The RSPB’s head of site conservation policy
column26: Kate Jennings
column27: said: “If this update to the livestock general licence goes beyond a reclassification of terminology and implies that it will lead to an increase in the killing of wild birds to protect game bird interests
column28: then given the nature and climate emergency we find ourselves in
column29: this would be a massive backward step for nature conservation in this country.” The general licences have been challenged by wildlife groups including the BBC presenter Chris Packham’s Wild Justice. His group has challenged the legislation and in 2019 managed to get it suspended. Wild Justice has since managed to secure changes including removing all gull species
column30: and the places they can be used no longer include sites of special scientific interest and other nature reserves. • This article was amended on 4 January 2022. The headline of an earlier version inaccurately said the law had been changed; it is the guidance on licences that has changed by introducing a new definition of “livestock”. The sub-heading and introduction was also amended to clarify this.";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/03/law-change-allows-wild-birds-killed-protect-game-birds-england
