column5: 'Fashion industry'];"It’s been 20 years since pallid faces
column6: dark eyes and black clothes haunted UK secondary schools and shopping centres. While some might argue that they never left
column7: merely retreating into the shadows
column8: the consensus for 2022 is that goth style is returning to mainstream culture with a vengeance. There are some differences this time. The modern goth is more likely to take inspiration from ultra-glam “hot goth girlfriends” such as Kourtney Kardashian and Megan Fox and the fashion world darlings Rick Owens and Yohji Yamamoto than the Marilyn Manson-loving self-proclaimed outsiders of the early 2000s. They are also more likely to integrate elements of a darker style of dressing into their wardrobes than to subscribe to a whole culture and lifestyle
column9: with shopping platforms and social media sites reporting huge increases in searches containing the word “goth”.

column1: “At one point there was an idea goth was ‘strange and unusual’
column2: but it doesn’t feel that way any more. I wouldn’t like to say it’s mainstream
column3: but it’s much more visible
column4: ” said Catherine Spooner
column5: a professor at Lancaster University who specialises in gothic culture. Andrew Groves
column6: professor of fashion design at the University of Westminster
column7: sees the new goth style as a reaction to the preening
column8: gym-honed
column9: Instagram-filtered perfection of the 2010s. “It has become unappealing. Instead
column10: smudged eyeliner
column11: bitten oxblood lips
column12: and a deathly pallor have once again become enticing.” He said it’s unsurprising that people are looking for ways to express darker emotions aesthetically when “we have been overwhelmed with news about death
column13: mortality
column14: and illness” since the beginning of the pandemic
column15: while school closures have lent themselves to a mood of “romantic disengagement
column16: sullenness
column17: and introspection” among teens.

column1: The clothing resale app Depop
column2: which is popular with Gen Z consumers
column3: reported a 20% increase in “goth” and “gothcore” searches over the past three months
column4: including a 200% spike for “black corset top” in October. Sophie Daly
column5: who runs a goth clothing business on Depop
column6: said the new approach to goth style is to mix and match influences as online communities have connected previously disparate tribes
column7: united by a love for sombre palettes and dark thoughts. She said: “Visually a goth could literally be anything now. In 2022
column8: goths don’t even have to wear black.” She said videos on TikTok
column9: such as those under the #goth hashtag
column10: which has 8.8bn views
column11: are fuelling the interest in vintage goth fashion
column12: with some sellers auctioning pieces for up to £350 due to high demand. The shopping platform Lyst said searches for collections by the cult goth designer Rick Owens
column13: which feature black leather and punk details such as rips and zips
column14: have grown by 200% this year. Searches for black items have grown 169%
column15: while chokers have grown by 81% and fishnet tops by 196%. Pinterest data
column16: meanwhile
column17: points to the goth aesthetic influencing everyday life. Searches for “goth business casual”
column18: described as “Wednesday Addams goes to the office”
column19: are up by 90% this year
column20: with goth baby clothes up 120%
column21: goth decor by 85%
column22: and searches for goth pyjamas up 185%. This is echoed in the online communities building around the topic. On Reddit
column23: the r/Goth community has grown by 35% over the past year to reach 101
column24: 000 members
column25: while r/GothStyle had a 136% increase to 115
column26: 000 members. The focus this time around has been on personal style and the way it has inspired and been lifted from high fashion
column27: with cyber goths haunting the runway in Balenciaga’s spring-summer 2022 show
column28: Givenchy showcasing 90s teen goths
column29: and Olivier Theyskens taking inspiration from gothic brides.

column1: There is also a goth influence on culture more broadly. Taylor Swift’s latest album references folk horror
column2: Willow Smith has a subversive new look
column3: and the 18-year-old singer-songwriter Olivia Rodrigo
column4: who sports a “goth princess” aesthetic
column5: references the goth-adjacent emo subculture of the mid-2000s in her songs. Daniel Rodgers
column6: a fashion and culture writer
column7: said the new goth aesthetic taps into the early noughties revival that has defined youth fashion and culture in recent years. It’s not a return of the “deathly looking goth”
column8: he said
column9: but rather a way to “gesture at subculture more generally” by drawing on a blend of earlier dark style tribes
column10: including emo
column11: punk and strands of goth such as the Camden-inspired cyber-goth look. Rodgers charts the current moment from the eboys and egirls phenomenon of the late 2010s
column12: where young gamers popularised a style that combined elements of goth and emo with Japanese anime and cosplay. He sees this and the current iteration of goth as reflecting the way culture develops in the internet. “We’re in a constant cycle of looking back and reproducing things
column13: spewing up references on to the table
column14: which is like a buffet young people can choose from.”";https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2022/jan/03/back-to-black-goths-go-mainstream-in-corsets-leather-and-lace

column1: 5801;5801;Doomscrolling: the exhibition that visualises our appetite for bad news;2022-01-03T15:30:11Z;['David Smith'];['Art'
column2: 'Art and design'
column3: 'Culture'
column4: 'Painting'];"When then US president Donald Trump caught the coronavirus
column5: Zorawar Sidhu found himself refreshing his phone for updates. Waiting anxiously for the 2020 presidential election result
column6: he was glued to flashing screen again. “My appetite for news had been increased
column7: ” the 36-year-old says by phone from New York. “Maybe it’s the frequency of it or the pace of how the information comes in or just how intense every morsel of information is
column8: where the next thing is more alarming than the previous.”

column1: We are all doomscrollers now
column2: compulsively absorbing a constant flow of negative news with untold psychological and social consequences. Sidhu and fellow artist Rob Swainston
column3: who marry historic printing processes with 21st century tools
column4: have responded with works designed to make us stop and regain our footing. Their exhibition of woodblock prints
column5: Doomscrolling
column6: interprets 18 moments between 24 May 2020 and 6 January 2021
column7: a stretch for the history books that saw the coronavirus pandemic
column8: Black Lives Matter protests and deadly insurrection at the US Capitol. The project was born after Sidhu and Swainston found themselves bombarded by images from 2020 and after Swainston took photos of an eerily deserted Manhattan under quarantine during morning bike rides.

column1: “It was a very strange sight and everything was empty and all you really saw was this very visible homeless population but everyone else was sort of hiding
column2: ” the 51-year-old recalls. “Then
column3: all of a sudden
column4: this plywood started to go up all over lower Manhattan in response to the protests. “I was photographing and I was like
column5: wow
column6: this is such an opportunity for someone who works in print media
column7: and knows the potential of woodblock prints
column8: to get this plywood somehow and use it to tell the story of 2020 on plywood that was put up to ‘protect institutions’. It just seemed so poetic.” The artists contacted various institutions asking if they could have the plywood when it came down and got several positive responses
column9: particularly from the art world. Eventually they collected around 120 sheets. It proved the perfect means of expression
column10: in part because woodblock prints have an association with social change movements going back at least 500 years
column11: in part because the distressed
column12: beaten up material could convey an inherently messy story. Sidhu explains: “In this case
column13: woodcut was the appropriate medium because these prints are made with the paper directly touching the wood
column14: which was outside during these protests and collecting graffiti and was scratched and gouged and drilled into and weathered. All this is still visible when you look up close at those prints.” To create a montage effect
column15: the artists overlaid image upon image
column16: as if scrolling through a computer screen or mobile phone. Sidhu and Swainston used art historical references such as a horse taken from Albrecht Dürer’s The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse
column17: hands from Käthe Kollwitz and heavy shadows from Edvard Munch.

column1: The 18 prints each represent a specific image or event
column2: including a 24 May New York Times front page “US DEATHS NEAR 100
column4: AN INCALCULABLE LOSS” and
column5: a day later
column6: the police murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis
column7: which sparked daily demonstrations against racial injustice in New York and other cities. Swainston
column8: who has an academic background in both art and political science
column9: recalls: “There were images that just circulated and circulated and there were some that in New York City circulated a lot among us and our friends. “I participated in some of the protests that went daily from Prospect Park to McCarren Park in Williamsburg. When the curfew happened
column10: the police started to be aggressive to anyone who was out on the street after seven o’clock and lots of images were passed around. He continues: “Some of these events were very clear that we wanted to do something with
column11: like the day in DC that the parks police gassed everybody and Trump went out and held up the Bible in front of St John’s Church. “There are some other dates that were harder: OK
column12: how do we talk about Covid? Do we look at the dates that have the largest death day? Some of them were a little more nebulous as to what the exact date was but they were feelings that were happening in the time. Social distancing
column13: hospitalisations
column14: memorial images that we just wanted to bring into the series to tell the whole story.” One print focuses on Kyle Rittenhouse
column15: who was 17 when
column16: armed with an AR-style semiautomatic rifle
column17: he shot and killed two people and wounded a third at a protest in Kenosha
column18: Wisconsin. In court
column19: Rittenhouse argued that he fired in self-defence and was acquitted on all charges. But the first piece they finished was the last in chronological order: the storming of the US Capitol in Washington by a pro-Trump mob intent on overturning the election result on 6 January. It felt like a natural bookend. Sidhu explains: “There was an urgency in that moment of January 6 so we all felt that it was time to actually do something about it. For us
column20: as artists
column21: that first thing that we could do was to take that imagery and just get it out
column22: try to do something with it.”

column1: Many people
column2: including doomscrolllers
column3: have felt overwhelmed by the past two years. The artists hope to disrupt the idea of these moments as fixed and inevitable. Instead
column4: they argue
column5: their montages keep the moments alive with unfixed meanings
column6: a clue that dialogue and social change are still possible. Sidhu
column7: who was born in Ludhiana
column8: India
column9: says: “It encourages a re-examination of everything that’s happened rather than moving on as if these issues are resolved. We see Covid coming back with Omicron. With the show opening on January 6
column10: it’s already an opportunity to reflect on that date and everything that comes with it.” Swainston adds: “We hope that
column11: by putting it out there
column12: by keeping the images in circulation
column13: they continue to have possibility and don’t just become fixed in the past and we just move on from it. We are still in this moment in my mind and these culture wars that are brewing in the United States that threaten to pull us all apart. “These unresolved issues of race
column14: of gun violence
column15: all of these things we can’t put them behind us and just keep living in them. We need to start to address them and
column16: in our society
column17: it is through images that we are processing information now in a more and more significant way.” The departure of Trump from the White House
column18: and his removal from Twitter
column19: seemed to invite a little less doomscrolling in 2021
column20: but persistent crises including the Omicron variant suggest the phenomenon will not be going away soon. Still
column21: Swainston hopes the exhibition
column22: which opens at the Petzel Gallery on New York’s upper east side on 6 January
column23: can help to wean visitors off their fast food media diet. “We talk about the way that the media environments now are set up to reinforce what you’ve already seen but the way it’s happening is that images get thrown at you and they stack on top of each other
column24: and the next one resonates with the next one. We become very fast in our reading of image; we understand right away. “This is a relatively new thing. The way that humans looked at images in previous environments
column25: they were slower. We would take a long time with a painting or a photo or we would see the pieces first and then the whole. It just has consequences in the way that we look at images.” He adds: “We hope that this series slows people down. This is what you see
column26: but as you’re looking
column27: more and more unfolds
column28: more and more is there
column29: and it gives space for the viewer to continue to look and discover and make up their own mind about what these mean.” Doomscrolling opens on 6 January at the Petzel Gallery in New York";https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2022/jan/03/doomscrolling-exhibition-covid-pandemic-new-york

column1: 5803;5803;Croydon stabbing: boy
column3: charged with murder of Zaian Aimable-Lina;2022-01-03T15:19:56Z;['Kevin Rawlinson'];['UK news'];"A teenager has been charged with the murder of 15-year-old Zaian Aimable-Lina
column4: one of two boys to be killed within about an hour of each other in separate stabbing incidents in London on Thursday evening. The suspect
column5: who is also aged 15 and whom police have not named because of his age

column1: A vigil was held over the weekend at Ashburton Park in Croydon

column5: west London

column7: campaigners said efforts to tackle knife crime had been inadequate and it was now so prevalent that it was becoming normalised. “Knife crime is accepted by this generation as part-and-parcel of growing up and that’s completely unacceptable
column8: ” said Patrick Green
column9: the chief executive of the anti-knife crime charity the Ben Kinsella Trust

column1: 5805;5805;Here’s what a Tory donor and a lavish Liz Truss lunch in Mayfair tells us about British politics | Simon Jenkins;2022-01-03T15:15:03Z;['Simon Jenkins'];['Liz Truss'

column3: 'UK news'
column4: 'Conservatives'];"A woman must lunch somewhere. When the prime minister told Liz Truss to examine every road post Brexit
column5: her thoughts naturally turned to Mayfair and Hertford Street. Perhaps that nice caff at No 5. We are after all lunching with that nice American trade envoy
column6: Katherine Tai. Perhaps two measures of dry gin; three bottles of Pazo Barrantes Albariño
column7: a Spanish white wine

column10: 000 bill. Besides

column13: and buddy of Michael Gove and David Cameron. And he tipped Johnson 20 grand for his “leadership” campaign

column6: 'Society'];"The first professional trip I took was to Jersey
column7: to interview a teenage skateboarder. He was slated to win some big competition
column8: but I’m afraid I can’t tell you whether he did or what his name was. What I do remember is standing by the skate park
column9: next to his mum
column10: in this peculiar low island light
column11: while he smashed himself to the ground
column12: repeatedly
column13: and got back up again. Before long
column14: his elbow was bleeding – but this
column15: his mother assured me
column16: was an old wound
column17: so it opened up most days. He brushed it off – didn’t even appear to notice – along with every other brutal encounter with physics and gravity. “Well
column18: he’s 14
column19: ” his mum said. “They bounce at that age.” He skated into my thoughts this week
column20: while the news was ablaze with England’s back-to-school mask mandate. Educationists were (and are) justifiably upset
column21: since they received this communication – that all pupils in year 7 or above should wear masks in the classroom – long after the media had been briefed. But disgust at the absolute dishevelment of governmental standards was nothing compared with the rage of the anti-mask libertarians. It sounds like a niche group
column22: but it includes many Conservative backbenchers
column23: plus their supportive commentariat. Teenagers
column24: these anti-maskers maintain
column25: have already suffered enough. Face-coverings interfere with their learning
column26: leave them unable to communicate with peers
column27: render them insensate to life’s daily pleasures and reduce them to a state of slavery (granted
column28: I saw the last claim on Twitter
column29: where the collective 2022 resolution appears to be “be more crazy”). The thing is
column30: my house is lousy with teenagers and I have agreed
column31: stupidly
column32: to stop writing about them. But I am still allowed to make the most general observations (I think). I have seen them forget their masks
column33: try to eat through a mask
column34: pick up a mask from the street and put it on
column35: and flick each other with masks. But I have never heard any of them complain about wearing one. Please don’t walk away with the impression that this generation has stopped complaining. They bellyache constantly about stupid things
column36: such as having to spend all day in the same classroom
column37: rather than moving from one subject area to another. “What is so fun about walking down a corridor?” I have wondered aloud more than once. It’s the journey
column38: not the destination
column39: they say
column40: sagely. Corridors are where all the stuff happens. Staying put and waiting for the teacher to come to you makes it feel like primary school. Will they put up with it
column41: for the sake of public safety? Yes
column42: but they wish the management to know that it isn’t ideal. They don’t complain
column43: yet it is visible in their demeanours that it saps their life force when they have to attend school from home. They absolutely hate it when non-essential shops are forced to close. They weren’t wild about the bubble phase
column44: when they had to self-isolate after the positive test result of someone they didn’t even like. There was a brief period in 2020 when they were allowed only on certain buses; that was a veritable assault on their human rights. But they adapted to masks absolutely seamlessly
column45: uncomplainingly
column46: faster than a baby adapts to a sock. There are a load of plausible explanations for why teenagers might moan about masks less than adults. They have better hearing
column47: so they aren’t relying on lip-reading without knowing it. They tend to have better cardiovascular health
column48: so they are not constantly wondering why stairs have got harder. Fundamentally
column49: though
column50: they are just more adaptable. We talk constantly about all the ways in which the teenage brain is like an adult brain
column51: only less good – more volatile and impulse-driven
column52: less able to predict consequences – and hardly talk at all about the ways in which teenagers are superior. Their entire day is structured around life’s unreasonable demands and they just acclimatise. This unruffled resilience and psychic elasticity – or bouncing
column53: in 90s skateboarder’s-mum parlance – looks suddenly a lot more mature than what passes for maturity. Zoe Williams is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/whos-raging-over-masks-in-schools-its-not-britains-impressively-resilient-teenagers

column5: 'Science'];"Why have we had such mild weather this winter? According to the UK’s Met Office: “The extremely mild spell is driven by a flow of warm

column4: 'Horror films'];"It’s gotten rather tricky to calibrate the the annual relative quotient of tragedy. (For the future reference of misery-focused sociologists

column6: at least it’s not 2020 any more. As it becomes apparent that we will have to accept a few massive catastrophes as the new status quo
column7: assessing the quality of life turns into a matter of degrees
column8: weighing each fresh stretch of hardship against the last. It may prove some cold comfort to note that things have
column9: by sheer numbers
column10: gotten slightly better since last year. The corollary to this way of thinking
column11: however
column12: is the understanding that our circumstances can always get worse.

column1: Just take a look at the films set in the year 2022
column2: united as they are in agreement that something horrible is just waiting to happen. There’s a futuristic sheen to the number
column3: as if a robot’s stuttering while giving a readout of two
column4: that’s compelled a handful of film-makers to select this date as the point at which a major crisis comes to pass. Whether it’s a chance armageddon landing at an inopportune time or a boiling-over that our species has been building to for years
column5: the movies have marked 2022 as cursed. The only hope as we approach the beginning of another year is that whatever challenges await us
column6: they won’t have the terrible finality of the world-enders listed below. Read on for a smorgasbord of possible apocalypses imagined for the coming months

column1: Way before Carey and Chad Hayes made their name by writing 2013’s The Conjuring
column2: the twin brothers scripted this direct-to-video cult classic about a crew of astronauts venturing into a galactic no man’s land. They’ve entered the void of low orbit to repair a nuclear-arming satellite
column3: but a power failure sends them floating helplessly toward a long-defunct Nasa shuttle they board in search of aid. The game of cat-and-mouse that follows is too weird in its particulars to be dismissed as the Alien rip-off it appears to be; the reanimated corpse and the leather dominatrix robot prime us for the grand reveal that the stalker picking off the explorers is actually Satan himself. (Turns out this station is hovering above the Bermuda Triangle.) As unfortunate turns of events go
column4: this one isn’t so bad
column5: by its very nature contained and remote. If the devil does turn out to be one of next year’s primary antagonists
column6: we should be so lucky to keep him stuck in outer space. Soylent Green

column1: Soylent Green
column2: as you may already be aware through sheer cultural osmosis
column3: is people. In Richard Fleischer’s infamous sci-fi thriller
column4: the NYPD detective Frank Thorn gets the ultimate validation for his paranoia about the miracle foodstuff mass-produced by a shadowy corporation
column5: for which the magic ingredient just so happens to be the finely ground corpses of the underclass. The screenwriter Stanley Greenberg (and Harry Harrison
column6: author of the novel Make Room! Make Room!
column7: which inspired the film) was right on the money in his vision of an economy stratified by scarcity
column8: as overpopulation
column9: pollution
column10: and an eerily prescient climate cataclysm exacerbate hunger and poverty. That said
column11: we haven’t yet resorted to devouring each other – that seems to be the one taboo that’s going to hold up through any and all mounting desperation – but we’re not so far off from Snowpiercer’s future of nutrient-rich sustenance bars made from mashed cockroach. Once we’ve cleaned out the global cupboards of actual food
column12: we’ll have no choice but to turn to that which is merely edible. The Tomorrow War

column1: This past summer’s straight-to-streaming Chris Pratt vehicle didn’t make quite the splash a producer might hope for from a $200m budget
column2: but it’s built around an idea with deep resonance in the present day: that it falls to those living now to anticipate and negate the conflicts that will face the next generation. In 2022
column3: emissaries from the year 2051 materialize with a warning of an impending alien invasion twenty-six years down the road and beg for the help of the present-day armed forces to time-travel ahead so they can help beat back the extraterrestrial menace. Pratt’s Green Beret-turned-super-soldier gets the drop on the beasts dubbed “Whitespikes” only to discover that to completely purge the Earth of these hostiles
column4: he’ll have to return to his own time and act then. (It’s worth noting that the aliens were actually submerged in a glacier and released by the thaw of global warming.) Goes to show that the old saying is right – an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of full-bore military offensives. The Purge

column1: When the lucrative spec-fic horror franchise first launched with this flagship film
column2: 2022 was far away enough to allow for acclimation to an unthinkable way of life. The survival nightmare takes place after eight successful observances of the Purge
column3: the annual holiday during which all crime is legal
column4: allowing America to release its pent-up rage and chill out for 364 days of the year. Though this series has yet to realize the full disturbing potential of its ingenious premise
column5: its name has been invoked to describe real-life goings-on with greater frequency as of late. During the run-up to the 2020 election
column6: Donald Trump’s favorite scaremongering tactic was to paint a picture of Joe Biden’s America as a lawless hellscape where marauding gangs sowed mayhem with impunity. In actuality
column7: the tenor of unrest is almost the exact opposite of that articulated in the film: rather than the barely repressed bigotry fueling the Purge onscreen
column8: the demonstrations of destruction during protests were motivated by demands for justice. No Escape

column1: Martin Campbell’s juiced-up B-movie taps a peak-form Ray Liotta for the ex-marine John Robbins

column3: where the worst of the worst have been left to their own murderous devices and divided themselves into the warlike
column4: savage Outsiders and the civilized
column5: humane Insiders. The miniature revolution led by Robbins didn’t have all that much insight to shed on the carceral-state debate at the time of its release
column6: but today
column7: it looks like a comically outsized take on a real issue. Its guiding principle that inmates are robbed of their dignity by a system that treats them like easily exploited chattel holds true
column8: if anything rendered more impactful by the advances in public understanding of this sorry situation. We can only hope that we’ll have as noble a leader as the character actor Lance Henriksen to expose the treatment festering in the prison-industrial complex. Geostorm

column1: Well
column2: the good news is that we haven’t implemented the use of widespread weather-control satellites just yet
column3: so annihilation-level inclement conditions on a global scale may not be on the cards. That’s the armageddon facing the human race in Dean Devlin’s admirably dumb eco-spectacle
column4: in which the space cowboy Gerard Butler represents our last line of defense against certain death by Mother Nature. The opening salvos before the much-feared main event giving this film its title are bad enough
column5: ranging from skyscraper-drowning typhoons to torrential downpours of lightning singeing city blocks to a crisp. It’s all a bit store-brand Roland Emmerich in the awed-eyed photography
column6: but natural events of biblical ruin are growing regrettably commonplace. Even if Butler cuts a larger-than-life figure
column7: the threat he faces still speaks to a legitimate fear many of us contend with every time we open a newspaper. His character and his power to stop doomsday is a reassuring fiction
column8: the one man who can change an obliteration the rest of us are helpless to halt.";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/03/movies-films-future-2022-new-year

column7: 'World cinema'];"Romaine Hart gave me my start in the film business
column8: hiring me as an usher at the Screen on the Green cinema in Islington
column9: London
column10: when I was 18; alongside the programmer Roger Austin she taught me fundamental lessons about cinema management that inspired me through the Other Cinema
column11: Scala and later Palace years. As a teenager I had witnessed the transformation of my local
column12: the Rex cinema on Upper Street
column13: a downmarket fleapit that was part of a declining chain owned by the Bloom family (Romaine’s maiden name)
column14: to the Screen on the Green
column15: with its progressive and clever programming. It showed critically acclaimed
column16: mainly US second-run classics by day (the first double bill I attended as a 15-year-old was The Graduate and The Thomas Crown Affair). From 11.15pm the late-night cinema club showed cult films such as Performance
column17: audacious double bills featuring Chabrol
column18: Kurosawa and other greats of world cinema and obscure but daring fare like Henry Miller’s Quiet Days in Clichy. The Friday all-nighters of the Marx Brothers and Humphrey Bogart classics were usually packed to the rafters.

column1: To keep this challenging programme viable in newly gentrified Islington
column2: Romaine kept overhead costs to a minimum (I can still feel the weight of those heavy metal 35mm film cases
column3: running them up and down the narrow stairs to the tiny projection box). Sales of Kia-Ora squash drinks and boxes of Maltesers were pushed to the maximum with all of the ushers doing ice-cream breaks with a tray between films – even at 1am. It was tough in the 70s: cinema audiences were at a low ebb and the Screen was barred from showing first-run films
column4: which instead went to the Odeon Angel
column5: ABC cinema on Holloway Road and Essoldo Caledonian Road. Romaine was a shrewd
column6: incisive and – beneath the occasionally gruff but glamorous business exterior – generous person who gave me a fundamental grounding not just in exhibition but also distribution with her company Mainline Pictures. With Roger she distributed movies by Alan Rudolph
column7: Monte Hellman
column8: Billy Wilder and John Waters at a time when distribution costs were at a premium; later on I released Eraserhead with her at the Scala. Programming an all-nighter of films interspersed with live performances from the then unknown Sex Pistols
column9: the Clash and Buzzcocks was just one more brilliant coup that inspired a new generation of punk fans into the cinema. It was an unforgettable event to have been an usher at and another example of thinking outside the box against the oppressive shackles that the film industry had imposed on exhibition at that time. Romaine’s attributes are too numerous to list but
column10: as a woman in the quite frankly sluggish and male-dominated 70s British film industry
column11: her acumen
column12: good taste
column13: quick wit and infectious sense of humour stood out as a beacon of hope for so many who followed. Later I took her values with me into production – her principles of acquiring high quality or challenging films combined with reasonable budgets remain with me as a producer. I personally owe a lot to Romaine and Roger
column14: and to try to put that into words is difficult
column15: but she transformed cinema-going in that little part of London where I grew up and brought excitement back in a pre-home video
column16: pre-multichannel TV time period
column17: when most people were pronouncing the film industry as dead in the water. • Stephen Woolley is a film producer

column6: 'Culture'];"The head of the National Trust has said she received anonymous death threats during a “culture war” row over the organisation’s perceived “wokeness”. Hilary McGrady
column7: the NT’s director general
column8: said she did not report the intimidation to the police as “it comes with the territory”. The row was sparked by NT efforts to learn more about the history of its properties
column9: including a report published last year that found connections between 93 of its historic places and colonialism and slavery. Criticism of what some saw as a politicised assault on heritage spilled on to social media and the press. McGrady said the academic author of the report “had a much harder time” than she had. More recently
column10: a group calling itself Restore Trust sought to win seats on the NT’s governing council at its annual general meeting in October. The group claimed to represent grassroots opposition to what it characterised as the NT’s “woke” agenda
column11: and said it wanted to steer the trust “back to its core purpose of looking after our heritage and countryside”. Three of Restore Trust’s candidates were elected to the 36-seat council
column12: although one has denied he endorses the group’s concerns. McGrady said she suspected Restore Trust would continue its campaign despite its failure to realise its goal of six council members. “I would like to engage with them honestly and openly. What isn’t helpful is a war of words. I’m really up for having those conversations … I have to accept I can’t lead an organisation of this scale and not take on these challenges. It comes with the territory and I’m pretty sanguine about that
column13: ” she said. Some members and visitors had been “really cross and angry with us” over the issues raised by Restore Trust

column1: McGrady said the past two years had been difficult for the NT but there was “a sense of being able to draw a line” despite worries around the Omicron variant of Covid. There had been a “huge jump” in membership in the past few months

The NT had been on the verge of reaching 6 million members when the pandemic struck. “We did lose a lot of people for all sorts of reasons – financial worries or just knowing that they wouldn’t be able to use their membership – but I think we’ll be back to 6 million this coming year
column3: ” she said. The trust has ambitious plans for 2022

column5: fetes

column12: complex
column13: layered story of the history of the three countries we’re responsible for. The idea that history stands still is nonsense because you keep finding new things.” McGrady said the 2020 report was “first-stage research. The next step is
column14: property by property
column15: to [ask if] we need to do more research. And how would we weave that into the story so that we get a whole history of the place? It will take a long time
column16: to be honest.” She insisted: “No one is forcing this down your throat. No one is trying to make you read this stuff. There’s no sense that we’re trying to preach and
column17: certainly
column18: definitely not judge. We’re trying to provide layers of information; we’re taking nothing away. We’re adding to the complexity of the information available. But if [people] want to come along and walk around the garden and have a lovely cup of tea
column19: I am delighted about that. Why would I be prescriptive as to how people should engage with the National Trust?” When McGrady was appointed to lead the NT in 2018

column7: 'UK news'];"Countries that succumb to authoritarianism rarely do so with a sudden dramatic flash
column8: where one day freedom is there and then suddenly it isn’t. It is normally a process of attrition
column9: of rights and liberties eroded by stealth. The political atmosphere becomes gradually more intolerant: hysteria is whipped up against dissidents
column10: whose supposed transgressions are carefully selected to justify a new crackdown. The battle lines are defined between a law-abiding majority and an extreme fringe. This is what has happened in Hungary
column11: governed by a party that once belonged to the Liberal International and now has set up a virtual dictatorship. It is the danger facing our own country
column12: too. I spoke to 21-year-old student Louis McKechnie as he made a journey from the prison gates familiar to countless rebels before him. An activist involved with climate protest group Insulate Britain
column13: he was imprisoned for six weeks after breaching an injunction against road blockades. “I got to the point where I was more terrified of the government’s inaction on the climate crisis than I was about any repercussions the courts would give me
column14: ” he said. He was “terrified” of prison
column15: but far from deterring him
column16: his incarceration has made him more resolute. Along with eight fellow activists
column17: their imprisonment was a warning to anyone seeking to take up Britain’s long tradition of peaceful civil disobedience.

column1: Insulate Britain is not popular
column2: but then neither was Pussy Riot in Russia when they stormed a church in Moscow. Now all reasonable people would accept that Putin’s Russia is an authoritarian state – much more so than our own – and we would look to the imprisonment of those protesters as a case in point. But it is easier to recognise repression for what it is in other countries. The punitive measures deployed against Insulate Britain are an example of a country descending into an authoritarian mire. Imagine if another country introduced a law allowing the police to shut down protests for being too noisy or causing “serious annoyance”
column3: allowing stop and search without any suspicion
column4: banning specific individuals from joining protests and granting sweeping powers to the state to decide which protests are allowed. This is what the Conservatives’ police
column5: crime
column6: sentencing and courts bill in its current form allows for. Using the backlash against Insulate Britain
column7: the government has toughened up the law. It exposes the laughable claims of some commentators that Boris Johnson’s guiding philosophy “is that he will not restrict our liberties unless there is an overwhelming reason to do so”
column8: as one senior journalist put it. “It won’t stop people protesting
column9: ” as human rights organisation Liberty’s Emmanuelle Andrews put it
column10: “but many more people who go out to protest will be at risk of arrest. It shrinks our ability to make our voices heard in quite an unprecedented way.” Banning orders can bar anyone convicted of more than one protest-related offence from exercising their democratic right. Protesters who attach themselves to others
column11: the ground or an object (or who are deemed to intend to do so) face imprisonment. If a protest is thought to cause a huge public nuisance then stop and search can be used with impunity.

column1: Note the Tory MPs who have defined temporary restrictions to prevent the spread of a deadly virus as transforming Britain into a police state. Like Marcus Fysh
column2: who declared: “We are not a ‘papers please’ society. This is not Nazi Germany. It’s the thin end of an authoritarian wedge.” Or Tim Loughton
column3: who said he did not want to live in “a society in which we ask for papers and deprive people of their liberty”. Yet they backed and voted for measures that strip away hard-won rights and freedoms
column4: dramatically enlarging the ability of the state to deprive its own citizens of their liberty. The danger
column5: as Liberty’s Andrews noted
column6: is that it “changes the face of what democratic participation looks like: that only a protest ‘elite’ who are willing to get arrested” take to the streets. Insulate Britain’s Louis McKechnie may feel emboldened: but many more may be deterred. Indeed
column7: it is inevitable that those most affected will be Britain’s marginalised communities. We know that Black Londoners are up to eight times more likely to be victims of stop and search; and that the Metropolitan police were twice as likely to fine Black people under Covid rules compared with white people. It’s not all over – the House of Lords will debate the legislation in January – but the course Britain is on is clear. From the policing bill to the nationality and borders bill – which further brutalises refugees and migrants and grants power to strip millions of dual nationality Britons of their citizenship – we are coming to resemble a police state cosplaying as a democracy. How gruesome to watch rights and freedoms our ancestors fought for at huge cost stripped away with barely a murmur. Whether we decide to replicate their courage to resist is up to us. Owen Jones is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/uk-police-state-democracy-insulate-britain-conservatives-crime-bill

column11: 'Poverty'];"For many New Yorkers
column12: the inauguration of Eric Adams as the 110th mayor of New York City – and only the second Black person to serve in the position – has evoked a range of feelings
column13: from excitement at the possibility of change to confusion and concern.

column1: Adams’ rise through city and state politics was fairly typical. In addition to serving as a New York police captain
column2: he was the Brooklyn borough president and a state senator. But he remains an unconventional
column3: even enigmatic figure. There are questions surrounding his home address and curiosity about his plant-based diet
column4: but information about his actual policies remains scarce. “Where Eric Adams has thrived
column5: in many ways
column6: is in really failing to lay out a vision
column7: ” said Sochie Nnaemeka
column8: director of the New York Working Families party. “His transition has been defined by personality
column9: less [by] an agenda for the city.” Progressives and advocates working across multiple sectors have voiced concerns at the slow emergence of Adams’ plans and priorities
column10: and worry about positions he has taken including increasing the use of the heavily criticized “stop-and-frisk” policy and resurrecting plainclothes police units. Adams’ ascent comes at a crucial time in New York history
column11: as the city seeks to emerge from the pandemic and the economic and social chaos that has come with it. New York’s ballooning homelessness crisis
column12: primarily caused by a lack of affordable housing
column13: is one of the largest issues Adam must contend with. In 2020
column14: more than 120
column15: 000 people
column16: including children
column17: slept in the New York municipal shelter system
column18: with homelessness reaching the highest levels since the Great Depression. Covid presented additional challenges
column19: spreading rapidly among homeless populations. Advocates have widely supported Adams’ priority of increasing permanent
column20: affordable housing in a city which has some of America’s most expensive rents. But many have raised concerns about Adams’ main plan: converting 25
column21: 000 hotel rooms into permanent apartments
column22: noting zoning and conversion requirements many hotels do not meet. Public housing
column23: managed by the New York Public Housing Association
column24: is another area where Adams has faced pushback. Adams supports privatizing public housing units as well as selling air rights above public housing units. Activists have said such actions
column25: presented as an opportunity to raise capital for blighted buildings
column26: are ineffective and that oversight for private landlords when it comes to addressing housing issues like mold and lead paint would become even more difficult. “His focus is going to be on his big-money donors. That’s been his track record all along. That’s not a secret
column27: ” said Fight for NYCHA core member Louis Flores. “We expect him to continue down that road
column28: and for public housing that he’s going to support policies that benefit the real estate development industry at the expense of the public housing residents.”

column1: Despite ambiguities around some of Adams’ plans for addressing homelessness
column2: some experts are hopeful delays in appointments – and Adams’ reputation for flexibility – could be an opportunity for his administration to receive input from community leaders on how to address the crisis
column3: including through the creation of a deputy to oversee homelessness and affordable housing. “Having a bit more of a deliberative process is ultimately going to be more impactful than coming out on day one with an ambitious target for the number of units of affordable housing that should be created that might not actually have the impact of reducing homelessness and housing insecurity
column4: ” said Jacquelyn Simone
column5: policy director at Coalition for the Homeless. Proposed changes to policing are another point of tension. Adams
column6: who has described assault at the hands of an NYPD officer as inspiration for joining public service
column7: has faced criticism for his plans to resurrect controversial plainclothes units
column8: an anti-crime department in the NYPD involved in a number of shootings
column9: and increase use of stop-and-frisk
column10: a policy critics have condemned as racially discriminatory. While Adams and his newly appointed NYPD commissioner
column11: Keechant Sewell
column12: the first Black woman to lead the department
column13: have supported these policies and vowed to use properly trained
column14: “emotionally intelligent” officers
column15: progressives have argued that previous training attempts have failed
column16: with many officers continually excused for misconduct. “What does the emotional intelligence of an officer matter if he’s got you up against the wall
column17: patting you down
column18: ” said Kesi Foster
column19: a lead organizer with the nonprofit Make the Road New York and a steering committee member with Communities United for Police Reform. Simone said: “The ways to solve unsheltered homelessness is not through policing and pushing people from one corner to another.” Other policing initiatives Adams has sponsored have met criticism
column20: specifically when it comes to New York’s troubled jail system. While Adams has publicly supported closing down Rikers Island
column21: a jail with notoriously poor conditions where several people have died in pre-trial custody
column22: he has also promised to bring back solitary confinement to Rikers
column23: reversing a previous ban on a practice many experts have called “inhumane”.

column1: Adams has publicly opposed bail reform measures
column2: meant to curtail pre-trial detention but rolled back
column3: citing debunked claims that releases have spurred increases in crime. “Changing the bail bill is not going to achieve the outcome the mayor wants. We’re hoping that we can convince him of that during his tenure
column4: ” said Marie Ndiaye
column5: supervising attorney of the Decarceration Project at the Legal Aid Society. “Getting wishy-washy on bail reform is pretty scary because there’s a pretty linear correlation between the rollbacks and the jail population increasing
column6: ” said Sara Rahimi of the nonprofit Emergency Release Fund. In general
column7: advocates contend there is more to be learned about Adams as more appointments are made
column8: but given his comments so far
column9: many are approaching the mayor-elect with caution and timid hope of being able to advance progressive policy. “Cautiously optimistic and cautiously pessimistic all at once would be the way to go there
column10: ” said Ndiaye.";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/03/eric-adams-new-york-mayor-progressive-politics

column1: 5821;5821;‘I wouldn’t go to the park on my own now’: Plymouth traumatised by killings;2022-01-03T13:27:13Z;['Steven Morris'];['UK news'];"There are tiny but telling hints of what happened in the Keyham area of Plymouth on 12 August last year. A stretch of freshly laid pavement at the corner where Jake Davison turned his pump-action shotgun on himself after killing five people. A pile of compost in a community garden
column2: created from the thousands of flowers left for the victims and set aside to be used when memorial trees or flower beds are planted. The new bench in the park installed in memory of two victims. “Everywhere you look there are awful memories
column3: ” said Hazel Lynch
column4: a member of the Keyham neighbourhood watch
column5: one of the groups leading the recovery from that evening in late summer when Davison
column6: a 22-year-old apprentice crane operator who harboured extreme misogynistic views
column7: carried out his 12-minute attack. Lynch pointed out
column8: for example
column9: the area where the air ambulance had landed as children raced for safety and the spot where one boy sat for three whole days afterwards
column10: trying to process what happened. “He wanted to be there and to try to understand what had happened. People are still doing that.” The attack hit not just the relatives and friends of those affected but the whole community. Three hundred people
column11: many of them children
column12: directly witnessed Davison’s attack or the immediate aftermath. Children still struggle to sleep
column13: worried the “bad man” will get them
column14: while some elderly people are too frightened to leave their homes. Many hundreds of personal alarms have been handed out to girls and women and Lynch said she now carries one for the first time in her life. “I wouldn’t go to the park by myself after dark now
column15: ” she said. The city had scarcely caught its breath after Davison’s attack
column16: which began with him killing his mother
column17: Maxine
column18: when a few miles away 18-year-old Bobbi-Anne McLeod vanished from a bus stop in the Leigham area of the city in November. Her body was found near a beach three days later
column19: a second disturbing crime with a woman at its centre. Much soul-searching has been prompted in Plymouth with the launch of a commission in the city to examine violence against women and girls. While crime figures overall are down in Devon and Cornwall
column20: sexual attacks have risen. Stalking and harassment is up by 24% on 2019
column21: rape by 18% and other sexual offences by 13.5%. Since September there have been more than 200 referrals to an app that allows people to highlight areas in Plymouth where they do not feel safe.

column1: Millions of pounds are being spent to try to help make the city safer for girls and women through initiatives such as setting up new CCTV cameras
column2: boosting the number of taxi drivers after a post-Brexit drop and introducing initiatives such as bystander training to help people know how to challenge bad behaviour. Alison Hernandez
column3: the police and crime commissioner for Devon
column4: Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
column5: said a lot of work was being done but admitted girls and women were too often victims – and did not feel safe. “Although we have one of the safest force areas in the country
column6: violent crime is rising. Bobbi-Anne’s death reminds us that policing must be relentlessly focused on making our communities safer
column7: but we need to engage schools
column8: local government and our public in that effort.” She believes society needs to look deeply at problems ranging from the accessibility to young people of violent pornography to domestic abuse. “This is a problem that cannot be resolved by police officers alone
column9: ” she said.

column1: Lyn Gooding
column2: the chief executive of the charity First Light
column3: which works with victims of domestic abuse and sexual violence
column4: agrees. She told a Q&A organised by the new commission that work needed to be done in primary schools to help youngsters understand what a healthy relationship looked like. “We need to have difficult conversations with our young sons.” For Keyham specifically
column5: the Home Office has provided more than £800
column6: 000 for additional crime prevention measures and more policing and almost as much again has been made available in the area to pay for extra children’s social care workers and educational psychologists to work in schools. So many Keyham people have a sad story to tell. Olivia
column8: who lives close to the spot where Davison killed himself
column9: said she still thought often about his body slumped on the pavement. “It is still very difficult for a lot of people here
column10: ” she said.

column1: Rosemary
column2: whose teenage son witnessed one of the shootings
column3: said she feared his mental health had been compromised. “He is very confused. He finds it hard to understand what happened.” The Labour MP for Plymouth
column4: Sutton and Devonport
column5: Luke Pollard
column6: who lives half a mile from the scene
column7: warned that tragedies could lead to long-running social problems such as children struggling at school
column8: rising crime rates
column9: more people suffering from depression. “A whole community
column10: a whole city can be traumatised.” He said people were beginning to ask more questions about the gun laws and in the new year a “Keyham manifesto” setting out what the area would like to be changed is due to produced. Heather Welch
column11: the acting operations manager for Victim Support in Devon
column12: said the shock waves would be felt for many years. It has called for the experiences of survivors of the Manchester Arena attack and the Grenfell fire to learn how to help people in Keyham. “People have had to make sense of the world in a different way.”

column1: The politicians and experts are keen to flag up the great work being done by people such as Hazel Lynch
column2: who is leading the transformation of a rickety old shed on the sports field where the shootings vigil took place into a community cafe
column3: and the neighbourhood watch chairman
column4: Kevin Sproston
column5: who lives by the motto: “Let’s make Keyham as good as the people.” He is still dashing around organising the Safer Keyham programme
column6: which includes providing new security measures
column7: such as better locks and peepholes
column8: to try to make vulnerable people feel safer in their homes. Richard Baron
column9: the managing director of a double glazing company
column10: said he and his team had improved the security at 150 homes
column11: providing the materials at cost. “If we can help make people a bit safer then we’re very happy to do that
column12: ” he said. “It will take a long time for this community to heal.”";https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2022/jan/03/i-wouldnt-go-to-the-park-on-my-own-now-plymouth-traumatised-by-killings

column4: 'Men'];"When Mary moved from Bedfordshire in the UK to Michigan in the US on a Fulbright scholarship in 1985
column5: she wasn’t expecting to find love. Her mind was focused on the nutrition course she had enrolled on and her plans for a future career. In the spring of 1986
column6: she was cycling home from a meeting with her tutor when she approached a fence covered in ivy. Roy
column7: who had been pushing his bike
column8: emerged from behind the fence before she had the chance to stop. “I hit his wheel and
column9: because my hands were cold and I was wearing a backpack
column10: I went sailing over the handlebars
column11: ” she remembers. “I landed on my chin and broke my jaw on the concrete.” In typical British fashion
column12: she told him she was “absolutely fine”
column13: but Roy says it was clear she was badly hurt. “My apartment was pretty close by so I got my roommate to drive her to the university health centre
column14: ” he says. The next day
column15: Mary had to have her jaw wired shut
column16: meaning she couldn’t eat solid food for three months. “Roy came to my apartment with some juice to suck through a straw. He said that when my jaw was unwired he would make me dinner
column17: ” she recalls. Although it was an accident
column18: Roy felt “terrible” about what happened. “I was really concerned about her
column19: ” he says. Over the summer they went their separate ways
column20: with Mary returning to her home in the UK for the holidays. When she arrived back at university
column21: Roy had moved in two doors down from her. “By chance
column22: my roommate had moved home and a place turned up in Mary’s building
column23: ” he says. That September
column24: he followed through on his promise to make her dinner. They quickly hit it off
column25: and realised they had more in common than they’d thought. “He was on a PhD programme in geography and also had a Fulbright scholarship
column26: ” says Mary. “We were both vegetarians and had an interest in reading and travel. Roy had been all over the world and spoke different languages.” He was equally impressed. “I liked that Mary rode horses and had a different accent. She was the nicest person I’d ever met and was very easy to be with
column27: ” he says.

column1: Before long they were a couple. “We’d go for day trips to Lake Michigan and study together
column2: ” says Mary. “We met in such an intense way
column3: through the accident
column4: that it sort of got rid of that usual period where you get to know someone slowly.” In 1987
column5: they married in the US before moving to England. “It’s a running joke in my family that he had to marry me or I’d sue him
column6: ” laughs Mary. By the following January
column7: they had moved to Sudan for Roy’s work. He was studying the impacts of climate change in Africa
column8: and Mary took a contract with Unicef
column9: working in nutrition. “There was a coup while we were there and it became hard to get food
column10: so it was a tough experience
column11: but amazing
column12: too
column13: ” Roy says. They returned to Michigan two years later
column14: and their two children were born in 1990 and 92. Mary found a job as a dietitian while Roy became a professor at Grand Valley State University. When Mary suffered a brain bleed in 2012 and was put in an induced coma
column15: Roy cared for her. “She was in hospital for two months and it took two years to fully recover
column16: ” he says. “We kept going together and it brought us even closer.” Just as the pandemic hit
column17: they moved to St Louis to be close to their children
column18: now adults themselves. “Having kids was always a priority for us
column19: ” says Mary. “We loved having them and they were the best thing that we ever did. We share the same values and always compromise for the same reasons.” Roy appreciates his partner’s poise and calm nature. “She doesn’t jump into the fray – she’s measured. It’s easy to have meaningful conversations and there’s never any drama. We laugh together all the time.” Want to share your story? Tell us a little about yourself

column5: 'Theatre'];"When Romaine Hart transformed the Rex
column6: a 1950s fleapit cinema in Islington
column7: north London
column8: into the Screen on the Green in 1970
column9: she set a standard that would have a profound influence on the ways in which audiences appreciate first-run arthouse films. Described by Quentin Tarantino as “the coolest cinema in London”
column10: the Screen on the Green would inspire generations of future film-makers. Romaine
column11: who has died aged 88 of a heart attack after a typically fulsome Christmas
column12: rejected the fusty
column13: traditional ways of mainstream cinema management. In a blaze of art nouveau inspired branding
column14: the Screen’s opening night premiere of Downhill Racer
column15: starring Robert Redford
column16: included Laurence Olivier
column17: Richard Attenborough and Bryan Forbes among the audience. The cinema’s luxurious seats were made of purple velvet and the ushers wore hot pants. The Sex Pistols
column18: Clash and Buzzcocks played a riotous gig at the Screen on the Green in August 1976
column19: while on other occasions the cinema’s tiny foyer was filled with sand and surfboards for a beach party-themed all-nighter
column20: and Little Nell made a guest appearance naked in a bathtub to promote The Rocky Horror Picture Show. The Screen’s programmer Roger Austin had been inspired by the cinema scenes of New York
column21: Los Angeles and San Francisco. The rows between Austin and Romaine reverberated throughout the auditorium
column22: but she gave full licence to his maverick programming
column23: which suited the cinephile environments she created. The Screen on the Green made cinema-going both edgy and fun
column24: and contributed to the transformation of working-class Islington into an arty
column25: trendy borough with soaring house prices. Meanwhile Romaine divided her time between her Georgian townhouse in Highgate Village
column26: further to the north of London
column27: and a bohemian bungalow overlooking the South Downs in Sussex. As the unwieldy single screen owner-operated cinemas of previous decades gradually closed down
column28: Romaine’s company flourished
column29: opening new sites in London and the home counties. In contrast to the Screen on the Green’s punk ethos
column30: the Screen on the Hill in Belsize Park became renowned for its Saturday morning children’s film club
column31: supercharged by a local resident
column32: Tom Maschler
column33: then chairman of the publisher Jonathan Cape
column34: and featuring guest appearances by luminaries such as Roald Dahl and Michael Palin. The architects Fletcher Priest brought the allure of glass and chrome to the Screen’s chain of first-run cinemas
column35: typified by intimate auditoriums
column36: sophisticated snacks and specialising in a certain kind of must-see film.

column1: Always having to fight for the best films to show
column2: Romaine set up her own distribution company
column3: Mainline Pictures
column4: acquiring the UK rights to a diverse collection of thrilling world cinema by auteur directors. These included Barbet Schroeder’s Maitresse (1975); Paul Verhoeven’s The Fourth Man (1983); Rob Reiner’s This is Spinal Tap (1984); Stephen Frears’ My Beautiful Laundrette (1985); Tim Burton’s Pee-wee’s Big Adventure (1985); Bruce Weber’s documentary Let’s Get Lost (1988); Alejandro Jodorowsky’s Santa Sangre (1989); and Todd Haynes’ debut feature Poison (1991). Films by women were then few and far between
column5: but the Mainline catalogue included Kathryn Bigelow’s stylish co-directed debut
column6: The Loveless (1981). Thanks to the business acumen of Romaine and her small team

column11: 'World news'];The European Commission is facing a furious backlash over plans to allow gas and nuclear to be labelled as “green” investments

column18: a co-leader of the Greens

column8: 'UK news'];"The footballer Marcus Rashford’s free school meals campaign last year set off untold chain reactions across the UK In the case of Broxtowe in Nottinghamshire

column7: 'World news'];"A memoir about growing up before and after the fall of communism in Albania has won rave reviews in the west but has prompted “vicious” abuse from a vocal minority of Albanians
column8: its author says. Free by Lea Ypi
column9: a Marxist Albanian professor of political theory at the London School of Economics
column10: might seem an unlikely bestseller. But in its first full month on sale in November the memoir sold 10
column11: 000 copies. It has been shortlisted for the Costa biography of the year and will soon be available in 17 languages including Korean and Mandarin. Despite its criticisms of the disastrous impact of market changes in Albania
column12: the book received five-star reviews in the Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph
column13: and was named the Sunday Times book of the year. But in Albania the book generated such a torrent of online abuse that Ypi had to appeal to Albanians to stop sending her “offensive
column14: accusatory and defamatory” messages. She told the Guardian she usually enjoyed engaging with her detractors. But she said this abuse was different because it came from people who had either not read the book or misunderstood its criticism of capitalism and communism. The book is told from her perspective as a child in 1980s Albania
column15: when she was taught to worship the dictator Enver Hoxha
column16: and her family’s dissident views became clear only after the regime fell.

column1: “One of the most important messages in the book is that however oppressive a regime
column2: it never completely crushes human dignity
column3: ” she said. Some of Ypi’s Albanian critics have mistaken such ideas as an apology for communism and have accused her of experiencing Stockholm syndrome. This has been particularly hard for Ypi to take. “It touches you personally if you have a grandfather who spent 15 years in a communist prison to be told you are somehow trying to rehabilitate communist murderers
column4: ” she said. Some of the reaction has been sexist – in one message Ypi was told she looked “more like a showgirl than an academic”. Another dredged up an old newspaper cutting that quoted Ypi as an 11-year-old expressing a desire to help her country
column5: and accused her of turning against her former self. She said: “It’s a minority but it’s so vocal and so personal and so vicious
column6: it affects you a lot more than the other responses which have been overwhelmingly positive.” In the book
column7: she recounts being bullied as a child in part because she spoke French. “It’s exactly the same kind of people who were bullying me when I was a child that are doing it now
column8: ” she said. Ypi says much of the criticism came after she launched the Albanian version of the book at Hoxha’s former house in the capital
column9: Tirana. “For me it was like imagining Hoxha in hell
column10: having someone from a family of dissidents promote a book about the Albanian legacy. It was symbolically really powerful
column11: ” she said. But the irony of the location was lost on some
column12: who feel the property should be destroyed and suspected Ypi of trying to rehabilitate the dictator. The presence at the launch of the Albanian prime minister
column13: Edi Rama
column14: and many of his ministers was also misconstrued. Ypi said: “I’m very critical of the Albanian government
column15: but people felt I was being manipulated or appropriated by them.” Such perceptions have even fuelled false rumours that Ypi is to become the next president of Albania. She said: “If you keep repeating fake news like that it almost becomes like real news. And then it erodes constructive criticism. What should happen to Enver Hoxha’s house is a valid debate
column16: but if you start basing it on fake news and misreadings the debate never happens.” Ypi
column17: who wrote the book in parallel in English and Albanian
column18: feels that for all the negative online comments
column19: the book has succeeded in sparking constructive discussions about the merits of socialism and capitalism. She said: “Through family histories I try to engage everyone in a big conversation about freedom – my mother has one idea of freedom and my father has another. When it works it opens up big conversations not shuts them down. And there’s a younger generation who are concerned about what kind of system we live in.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/03/author-memoir-communist-albania-met-vicious-abuse-lea-ypi

column5: American workers stood up and fought back to an unusual degree. Workers went on strike at Kellogg’s

column1: Out of this comes a question that looms large for America’s workers: will this surge of worker action and anger be a mere flash in the pan or will it be part of a longer-lasting phenomenon? The answer to this important question could turn on whether all this anger and energy are somehow transformed into a larger movement. At least for now
column2: America’s labor leaders seem to be doing very little to tap all this energy and hope and to build it into something bigger and longer lasting. Yes
column3: we are seeing unionization drives at this workplace and that one
column4: but we are not seeing any bigger
column5: broader effort to channel and transform all this worker energy and discontent into a new movement

column7: that would work in conjunction with the traditional union movement. Worker advocates I speak to keep wondering: what are labor leaders waiting for? If not now

column11: union leaders have said they are eager to reverse labor’s long decline – more than 20% of workers were in unions three decades ago
column12: now just 10% are. Unless unions step up and do something bold
column13: they’ll relegate themselves to continued decline. Many labor leaders evidently think it’s impossible or improbable to turn this year’s energy and anger into a new movement or a big
column14: new group. But building a movement from scratch isn’t impossible. 350.org was founded in 2008 by several college students and environmentalist author Bill McKibben
column15: and within two years
column16: it organized a mammoth Day of Climate Action with a reported 5
column17: 245 actions in 181 countries. After the horrific shootings at Marjorie Stoneman high school in Florida in 2018
column18: a handful of students founded March for Our Lives
column19: and within five weeks
column20: their group had organized nationwide rallies with hundreds of thousands of people calling for gun control. Black Lives Matter also grew into a powerful national movement within a few years. None of these movements were one-shot or one-month affairs – they have become powers to contend with in policy and politics. So why isn’t the labor movement seizing on this year’s burst of worker energy to build something bigger? I was discussing this with friend who is a professor of labor studies
column21: and she said she thought that most of today’s union leaders were “constitutionally incapable” of building big or being bold and ambitious. She said that after decades of being on the defensive
column22: of being beaten down by hostile corporations
column23: hostile GOP lawmakers and hostile judicial decisions
column24: many labor leaders seem unable to dream big or think outside the box on how to attract large numbers of workers in ways beyond the traditional one-workplace-at-a-time union drives. But building big and outside the box isn’t impossible for labor. Just look at the Fight for $15. The strategists and SEIU leaders behind it had a vision: they wanted to push the issue of low wages into the national conversation and lift the pay floor for millions of workers. They started small
column25: with walkouts by 200 workers at a dozen fast-food restaurants in New York City
column26: and within two years
column27: they built a powerful national movement that held strikes and protests in hundreds of cities. This movement ultimately got a dozen states to enact a $15 minimum wage
column28: lifting pay for over 20 million workers. Perhaps some brilliant
column29: visionary workers or worker advocates will step forward to seek to channel this year’s burst of worker anger and energy into a new movement. Social media could certainly help build it
column30: perhaps with the assistance of groups like Coworker.org
column31: which has considerable experience engaging and mobilizing disgruntled rank-and-file workers via the internet.

column1: For many workers
column2: a big new group or movement could be a waystation toward unionizing: helping educate and mobilize workers to unionize
column3: guiding them on next steps and what their rights are
column4: and promising a pool of ready support if they seek to unionize. This new group or movement could send out bulletins telling members how they could help other workers in their community or nearby communities – perhaps help unionization drives at Amazon or Starbucks or strikers at Kellogg’s or Warrior Met Coal in Alabama or food delivery workers who are cheated out of tips and don’t have access to bathrooms. Members of this new group could be called on to protest outside the offices of members of Congress or state lawmakers about myriad issues
column5: perhaps raising the federal minimum wage or enacting paid family leave or the Protecting the Right to Organize Act. Or they could join rallies for voting rights or immigrant rights or against police abuses or to combat global warming. Working America
column6: an arm of the AFL-CIO
column7: does some of this
column8: mainly urging its members to vote and to contact lawmakers. To truly help reverse labor’s decline and capitalize on today’s worker anger
column9: much more will be needed – an organization that is far more connected to workers and does far more organizing
column10: protesting and mobilizing. America’s labor movement is terribly balkanized
column11: with many unions engaged in turf battles and upset that another union has (perhaps) stepped into its territory. As a result
column12: they too often find it hard to work together. But if America’s unions are serious about wanting to strengthen worker power and reverse labor’s decline
column13: it’s time to put past divisions behind them and figure out how to build back something bigger. There are three main reasons that America’s labor movement has declined: first
column14: corporate America’s fierce resistance to unions
column15: second
column16: the decades-long slide in factory jobs
column17: and
column18: third
column19: the Republican party’s decades-long fight to weaken unions and make it tougher to unionize. But there’s another factor behind labor’s decline that is rarely discussed – many labor leaders don’t do nearly enough to inspire workers and expand the union movement. Today’s workers could use some vigorous
column20: visionary leaders like Mother Jones
column21: Sidney Hillman
column22: John L Lewis and A Philip Randolph to lead and inspire
column23: and build something bigger. Perhaps many union leaders haven’t been hearing what I often hear from rank-and-file union members: “Lead or get out of the way.” Steven Greenhouse is a journalist and author
column24: focusing on labor and the workplace. He is the author of Beaten Down
column25: Worked Up: The Past
column26: Present
