column3: 'US news'];"As Shaka Senghor was serving 19 years in prison for murder
column4: a letter from his father gave him the strength to endure and eventually reform. “I’ll never leave your side
column5: ” Senghor’s father wrote to him
column6: after Senghor told his family
column7: in a letter written from solitary confinement
column8: that they should move on with their lives without him. Senghor explored his road to redemption in his New York Times best-seller Writing My Wrongs: Life
column9: Death
column10: and Redemption in an American Prison. At 19
column11: Senghor was convicted of second degree murder after shooting a man during a drug deal in Detroit. He was released from prison in 2010 and since then has been a MIT Media Lab Director’s Fellow
column12: delivered a TED Talk in 2016 that has collected more than 1.6m views and been featured on Oprah Winfrey’s SuperSoul 100. Now
column13: in his second book titled Letters to the Sons of Society
column14: which will be published later this month
column15: Senghor has written a collection of letters to his two sons: Jay
column16: who was born while he was in prison
column17: with whom he had a distant and fractured relationship
column18: and his younger charge
column19: Sekou
column20: who was born to a wiser
column21: redeemed Senghor who was able to be a present and attentive father. In his book
column22: Senghor
column24: wrestles with reconciling and building a relationship with his adult son who first knew him as an inmate
column25: and his second child
column26: born of a different mother
column27: who is being raised by an accomplished and liberated man. Senghor grapples with his regret over missing out on so much of his eldest son’s life
column28: battles with his own toxic ideas of masculinity and ultimately works to find a way to love both his children and engage in their lives authentically. Letters played a big role in your own redemption and transformation. Why did you decide to write this book in the form of letters versus other narrative styles? My transformation really started with letters from my dad. He is a beautiful letter writer and he would write me five to six page handwritten letters about life. We did a lot of healing and growing together and challenging ideas through our letters. And in my toughest moments in prison
column29: I would go back and reread his letters as a reminder that there was someone on the other side of the four walls who really cared about me. Someone who loved me
column30: loved me unconditionally. Through our letters
column31: we were able to really be honest and very transparent with each other. He could admit the areas where he felt he came up short and I could accept my failures and be accountable and free him from the oppressive thought that it was his fault I landed in prison. I felt like the intimacy of the letters between my dad and I were something we just don’t see: an honest and emotional exchange between Black men. I thought
column32: if I could ever write something to my sons that they could go back to
column33: the way I went back to the letters with my dad
column34: their lives would be good. You wrote Letters during a nine month period in 2020
column35: during the pandemic constraints and a moment of racial uprisings and reckonings. How did that timing influence your approach? When I began to put the letters together
column36: it was before the social unrest we witnessed globally. When I put my first proposal together
column37: it was in late 2019
column38: I was thinking about the narrative around Black men and this negative story that kept being told. We’re framed like we are America’s problem; we’re the Black community’s problem; we’re Black women’s problems; we’re everybody’s problem and nobody’s solution. It really bothered me because I know so many incredible Black men. Originally the letters were going to be addressed to different sons: my hip-hop sons
column39: my non-binary confirming sons
column40: my entrepreneurial sons. Then as I thought about it
column41: I thought
column42: “I need to write these letters to my sons because between these two worlds are the many sons I encounter.” Your oldest son
column43: Jay
column44: is 29 and your youngest
column45: Sekou
column46: is 10. How have they responded to what you’ve written? Jay does not want to read the book. He is so nonchalant and in his own world. I realized that I can’t insert myself into his life in a way that he hasn’t given me permission to do. So I make the offering
column47: and whatever he chooses to do
column48: I’m cool with. With Sekou
column49: it’s different because some of the content is more mature than where he is at. He did read some and had the best reaction ever. He was so amused that my dad once bought me some fake Jordan (sneakers). He was just like
column50: “Not the Pro Wings.” It was a special moment. Do you see this book as a parenting guide for Black boys? Or do you expect it to have a wider resonance? This is a book that white fathers and sons should consume
column51: too. Oftentimes they are in those positions that are systemically oppressive to people who don’t look like them. It’s really important for white dads to understand that Black fathers want the same things for their sons: safety
column52: well-being
column53: the ability to thrive and not just survive. The biggest thing I want (all) to take away is the power of love – the emotional accessibility that we owe ourselves and owe our sons and how impactful it is when you can open up. Love is truly our power and is the source of all things great. You wrote a letter unpacking isolation and you draw a parallel between being in solitary confinement in prison and the isolation of the early days of the pandemic. What took you there? When the global pandemic first began and people started going into lockdown
column54: I saw a lot of people struggling. Whenever people would reach out to me
column55: they’d say I feel bad because you dealt with real isolation going through solitary confinement. And I’d say: “No
column56: this is real. There is not a comparison to make
column57: but there are similar themes.” In solitary what really challenges you is this indefinite sense of not knowing. There’s never a concrete time frame of when you’ll be out. It was the same with this pandemic – we don’t know when we are coming out of it. The depression that set in for many people was familiar territory to me. I remember one day
column58: I was in my office and was getting off my fifth Zoom meeting. I had ordered food in. I felt a sense of the room closing in on me. I realized I was triggered and my mind had gone back to a previous experience – my prison experience. It felt just like when they would bring your food to the cell. And this is where you’ll be and you can’t go anywhere. And so I had to leave
column60: I can get out of here. Isolation happens in many forms. You spent about seven years combined in solitary confinement for various reasons and during that time found meditation
column61: discipline and hope. I remember writing to my dad and telling him I think I’m going to die in this place and they are never going to let me out. I want you to go on with your life and take care of Jay and the family. I wrote him an honest letter because I thought my life was over and I didn’t want to see him suffer as a result of my suffering. My dad wrote me back and told me that while he wished I wasn’t in solitary confinement he had no judgment. He told me that no matter how long I was in prison he wouldn’t leave my side and would always have my back. I read the letter so many times because it affirmed me and kept me strong on so many days. You write about trauma
column64: among other serious topics. Why did you want to broach these issues with your still young sons? Prison is designed to lay you bare. It dehumanizes you in such a way and it strips you. Once you reconcile that
column65: you can live with any truth. There are conversations that our community does not have with children. There is this old model … and we tiptoe around a lot of topics. I’m a parent

column68: they are watching everything on social media. Their conversations are hyper-mature but in a very toxic way. My responsibility is to empower my sons with my truth and that truth comes through my own vulnerability. Because I have a public life and I’ve been convicted of a very serious crime … kids could say things to my youngest son. I had a fear that someone could say to him

column71: the responsible thing to do is to speak the truth. I want to be real with both of them. [They] already know the worst thing I’ve done in my life. So for me
column72: the rest of the topics are not hard conversations to have. What does a whole Black boy look like to you? When I think of a whole Black boy the first thing that comes to mind is an image of Sekou dancing to old-school soul music. I imagine a boy who is full of joy and that is able to explore the world with curiosity and be unimpeded in his quest to learn
column75: to have agency over his body and thoughts. To be able to give love and receive love without it being filtered through a lens of trauma or skepticism. To really smile freely

column77: bring it in.” That freedom of emotional access

column1: 5843;5843;Original caretakers: Indigenous groups team up with conservationists to protect swaths of US ;2022-01-03T11:00:44Z;['Hallie Golden'];['Washington state'
column2: 'US news'
column3: 'Indigenous peoples'];"In 2020
column4: an environmental non-profit returned over a dozen acres in Oregon to the Clatsop-Nehalem Confederated Tribes. Two months later
column5: a conservation group worked with the Esselen Tribe of Monterey county to return more than 1
column6: 000 acres in California to the tribal group. And then late last year
column7: in one of the largest transfers of its kind
column8: an environmental organization returned thousands of acres of wildlife rangeland in Washington state to the Colville Tribes. Although each agreement was distinct
column9: in recent years an important pattern has emerged of conservationists and Indigenous people working together by way of land transfers. The effect has been twofold: protecting ecologically vital spaces while helping to right historic injustices by returning properties to their original caretakers. The Colville Tribes agreement in October transferred about 9
column10: 243 acres of arid grasslands
column11: dotted with sagebrush
column12: that encompass several canyons in north-central Washington state that are valued by biologists as an important corridor linking the Cascade mountain range to the Rocky mountains for lynx
column13: wolverine
column14: wolves and grizzly bears. It was traditional territory of the Okanagan Tribe
column15: a First Nations and Native American people who spanned across the Canada-US border
column16: and it was part of the original Colville Tribes’ reservation that was stripped away by the federal government in 1892 after gold was discovered. In recent decades
column17: it has been used as a family ranch. But then when it emerged in a few years ago that the land would be put up for sale
column18: the environmental non-profit Conservation Northwest attempted to get it into the hands of a buyer who would preserve it. However
column19: according to the non-profit’s executive director
column20: Mitch Friedman
column21: these efforts were at first unsuccessful. Toward the end of last year the land’s ecological and historical elements seemed to align perfectly when tribal officials and the non-profit’s leaders worked to return it to the hands of the Colville Tribes. “It was
column22: I would say
column23: the best kind of news that we could receive
column24: to get land back
column25: ” said Andy Joseph Jr
column26: chair of the Colville Business Council
column27: who described stepping back on to the land in late October for a ceremony as a feeling of returning home. The community
column28: which consists of 12 bands
column29: is known for its substantial natural resources departments and had previously worked closely with Conservation Northwest
column30: most recently to relocate threatened Canada lynx on the reservation. In early October
column31: after Conservation Northwest raised about $4.6m in eight months to buy the property
column32: and the tribe approved a protective covenant that outlined protections on the land
column33: the group immediately transferred the land’s deed to the Colville Tribes. Preserving biodiversity Although Indigenous peoples make up only about 5% of the world’s population
column34: their territories encompass 80% of global biodiversity
column35: according to the 2020 report The Indigenous World. And nature on Indigenous peoples’ lands is “generally declining less rapidly” than other land
column36: according to a 2019 report by the Intergovernmental Science – Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services. Today
column37: it’s clear conservationists have been looking to traditional ecological knowledge in their work. At the same time
column38: environmental organizations and tribes have been coming together to protect the natural world
column39: and a crucial part of this teamwork has been land transfers. In September
column40: the Nature Conservancy transferred the 132-acre Safe Harbor Marsh Preserve along the west shore of Flathead Lake in Montana to the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes. The Indigenous community has a large natural resources department and developed a strong relationship with the environmental organization. They also have a long history with the preserve. Once a part of the tribe’s reservation
column41: the marsh had been lost
column42: along with thousands of other acres
column43: through a pair of federal allotment acts in the early 1900s. Chairwoman Shelly Fyant said the tribes had made it a point to buy these properties back
column44: but faced challenges with skyrocketing costs. She said they were extremely happy when the Nature Conservancy leaders approached them about the marsh. “It’s just so amazing and
column45: you know
column46: really heartwarming that we have allies that understand us. They understand what our goals are
column47: you know
column48: in the big picture
column49: ” she said. “It’s not about money; it’s not about making a profit or capitalism or development. It’s about conserving it for future generations
column50: so that our descendants can enjoy that.” The tribe passed a resolution specifying that the site will be dedicated to conservation
column51: wildlife and cultural uses. Fyant explained that they’re working to integrate it into their management plan and to preserve the marsh for the waterfowl and other migratory birds. But at the same time
column52: tribes are in no way a monolithic group. And there have been instances of Indigenous communities’ work running afoul of conservation efforts. The Navajo Nation Council
column53: for example
column54: recently spoke out in opposition of the Biden administration’s proposed ban on oil and gas drilling around Chaco Canyon. At the same time
column55: the Makah Tribe has spent years working to regain its whaling rights
column56: which has put them at odds with several conservation groups. Jill Sherman-Warne
column57: executive director of the Native American Environmental Protection Coalition and former elected official of the Hoopa Valley Tribe
column58: explained that given all the ignored treaties and other agreements cast aside
column59: tribes have been left to take care of themselves. And in some cases that may mean logging
column61: tourism or other practices that don’t necessarily align with conservation. But overall
column63: tribes are incredibly effective protectors of the natural world. “Tribal people have in their histories knowledge that before geologists or hydrologists can prove scientific fact
column64: ” she said. “Tribes have stories about the environment that existed before any of the science
column65: which now is proving their oral histories to be true.” Serra Hoagland
column66: a biologist and tribal liaison for the US Forest Service
column67: said that traditional ecological knowledge and western science can complement each other very well. Citing a 2012 Journal of Forestry study
column68: she said that while western science tends to be more concrete and look in short time periods
column69: traditional knowledge is often more abstract and looks in longer time periods. “You commonly hear throughout Indian Country
column70: tribes and Native people talking about the seventh generation
column72: a member of Pueblo of Laguna. “And that’s because we’re thinking that far ahead into the future about our decisions that we’re making today.” Conservation plan Officials within the Confederated Tribes of the Colville reservation have started putting together a conservation management plan guided by traditional knowledge and western science for the recently returned land. Cody Desautel
column73: natural resources division director for the Colville Tribes
column74: said the process will probably take about six months and involve examining the species on the property
column75: the condition of the land and the types of improvements that may need to be made. One of the species he said he anticipates will be a priority is the endangered sharp-tailed grouse
column76: which are known to have breeding grounds on the land. The Colville Tribes also plans to conduct a cultural plant inventory to identify those culturally significant to the tribe. They may also be seeing two additional pieces of land returned in the coming months. The Methow Conservancy recently bought more than 300 acres and has announced its plans to give it to the tribe. And after Conservation Northwest was able to raise about $300
column77: 000 over the amount needed for the previously returned land
column78: they plan to help the tribe with closing costs on another property within that same corridor. Chairman Joseph said given the importance of returning land and their shared caretaking goals
column79: he hopes to see others follow suit. He said that it is their traditional and cultural belief that “as long as we take care of the land
column83: they’ll always be here for us. “It seems like the conservationists feel the same way.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/03/original-caretakers-indigenous-groups-team-up-with-conservationists-to-protect-swaths-of-us

column5: 'Sport'];"Thomas Tuchel used to be about control. When he arrived at Chelsea a year ago
column6: that was what he brought: suddenly a team that had been desperately vulnerable on the break stopped conceding on the counter. They held the ball and a 3-4-2-1 formation gave them a naturally solid structure with two midfielders stationed in front of the defensive line. They won the Champions League because they demonstrated how it was possible to play pressing football without leaving yourself open in transition. That had always been Manchester City’s issue
column7: less in the Premier League (although Leicester have often troubled them
column8: as they did last week even in conceding six) than against top European sides. They were a remorseless attacking force
column9: as imposing as the Death Star

To an extent that is intrinsic to the philosophy: push high and there will be space behind the defensive line; the question was how to guard against balls played into that space without losing the aggression of the press.

column1: City have clearly worked on that. Even in possession they often have five men behind the ball. They are more measured in their approach than they were when Pep Guardiola first arrived in England. But it was Tuchel’s Chelsea who seemed to have found the balance
column2: beating City three times in the final seven weeks of the season
column3: including in the FA Cup semi-final and the Champions League final. But while City march on
column4: only 10 points dropped in the league this season
column5: Chelsea have lost that sense of control. Having conceded four goals in their first 12 league games
column6: they’ve leaked 12 in the past nine
column7: with only one clean sheet. Their form has been far from disastrous: they have lost only one of those games
column8: but equally they have won only three. And as so often
column9: once the rot sets in
column10: it spreads rapidly. Romelu Lukaku
column11: having suggested he was unhappy with the 3-4-2-1 to which Tuchel has returned

Not only is he a habitual goalscorer – only once in the past 12 seasons has he failed to get into double figures – but he is a player whose movement seemed ideal for Chelsea: why wouldn’t the same drift out to the right to create space for Kevin De Bruyne that has worked so well for Belgium work also with Chelsea’s inside-forwards? But as he has struggled to make an impact

column16: £47.5m for Timo Werner
column17: £34m for Hakim Ziyech … some have suffered injury or illness and some or all may yet come good

column3: directors and journalists eventually

column10: first to a hamstring injury and then to Covid
column11: has been hugely costly: Chelsea have conceded only four goals in his 10 league starts this season and three of those have come in the past two games when
column12: Tuchel has acknowledged

column14: and N’Golo Kanté’s ongoing struggles with a knee injury

column16: who has at times looked weary

column18: who has managed a total of 164 league minutes for Chelsea
column19: has not worked out
column20: and Ross Barkley
column21: 154 league minutes this season

column1: Injuries have also played havoc in the back five

column5: 'Isle of Wight'];Some of us binged on box sets

column8: a retired GP turned palaeontologist
column9: 2021 was a standout year featuring two big dinosaur discoveries and laying plans to make the Isle of Wight famous for its prehistoric inhabitants once more. “It was an absolutely thrilling time for me
column10: ” Lockwood said. Lockwood
column12: who retired as a family doctor in the Midlands seven years ago
column13: was behind the widely publicised discovery of a new species of iguanadontian dinosaur with a distinctively large nose and a second species
column14: nicknamed “the horned crocodile-faced Hell Heron”. At the start of the pandemic
column15: Lockwood re-registered with the General Medical Council and volunteered to work. However
column16: his daughter
column17: also a doctor
column18: pointed out that before vaccines were available
column19: hospitals would not want people in their 60s walking around wards. So for the past two years
column20: Lockwood has immersed himself in fossil hunting on the beach and sifting through boxes of bones from museum archives. In palaeontology
column21: like astronomy
column22: amateurs often work alongside academics and their scientific contributions are frequently recognised. On retirement
column23: Lockwood decided to put his lifelong interest in dinosaurs on a formal footing and persuaded his wife to move to the Isle of Wight
column24: where a steady stream of dinosaur fossils emerge from the cliffs as they are eroded. He contacted Prof David Martill
column25: of the University of Portsmouth
column26: about doing a PhD and was quickly accepted. “I felt I had to do something to keep me active
column27: ” he said. “I don’t think I could’ve just played golf or grown roses.” Lockwood is revisiting a golden era for dinosaur discovery with a focus on iguanodons
column28: the first specimen of which was unearthed by Gideon Mantell
column29: also a doctor turned palaeontologist
column30: in Sussex in 1825. Some have assumed that the long timeline of discovery means that the understanding of British dinosaurs is essentially “done and dusted”. On the contrary
column31: Lockwood said
column32: certain dogmas have remained unchallenged. And modern methods
column33: such as using software to cluster specimens into a most likely family tree
column34: have not always been applied to earlier finds. Most dinosaurs found on the Isle of Wight had been traditionally assigned to just one of two species: the plant-eating Iguanodon bernissartensis and Mantellisaurus atherfieldensis. After sifting through many hundreds of bones that had been sitting in boxes in the Natural History Museum and the Dinosaur Isle museum
column35: Lockwood identified a clear outlier with an enormous bulbous nose. The finding suggests there were far more iguanadontian dinosaurs in the Early Cretaceous of the UK than previously thought and raises the prospect of tracing the evolution of different traits through time. “You can almost liken this huge collection of iguanadontian bones to several jigsaw puzzles that are all mixed up
column36: ” said Lockwood. “I’m trying to put together something that is meaningful.” Officially
column37: Lockwood is doing his doctorate part-time
column38: but acknowledges that he has become “a bit obsessed”. “Sometimes I’ll work for 16 hours a day for a few weeks
column39: ” he said. “You struggle to find time to cut the lawn and decorate your house
column40: and friends and family have to put up with you talking about dinosaurs all the time.” Alongside his work on archive specimens
column41: Lockwood also makes daily surveys of the beach to spot any dinosaur bones emerging from the cliffs. Winter is peak collecting season. “Certainly with winter storms eroding things
column42: that’s when the big finds come in
column43: ” said Lockwood. He is also coordinating a bid to redevelop the Dinosaur Isle museum
column44: by a charitable group that Lockwood chairs together with a German company
column45: Dinosaurier-Park International
column46: after the local council launched a tender process. “I’m trying to take over the museum
column47: ” Lockwood said. “The Isle of Wight undersells its dinosaurs. Most people are unaware that we’re Europe’s hotspot for dinosaurs and early mammals. We need a much bigger museum.” Lockwood said he has “great sympathy” for former medical colleagues still working on the frontline during the pandemic and is particularly annoyed by the “lazy GP stereotype” sometimes aired in media coverage. “Nothing could be further from the truth
column48: ” he said. “You can see burnout happening all over the place.” Several doctors have got in touch to congratulate him on his recent successes. “Some of the nice tweets were from other doctors approaching retirement
column49: ” he said. “It’s really good to see that there’s a life after medicine.”;https://www.theguardian.com/science/2022/jan/03/isle-of-wight-dinosaur-hunter-need-bigger-museum-jeremy-lockwood

column5: 'World news'];"Fifty years ago
column6: the entire Creole population of the Chagos Islands were forcibly removed from their homes by British forces in order to make way for a US military base. Families were torn apart
column7: scattered between the Seychelles and Mauritius
column8: where they endured enormous economic hardships and discrimination. In Olivier Magis’ documentary
column9: the horrors of those nights are painfully alive. Over atmospheric shots of rippling ocean waves we hear shocking first-person accounts of people throwing themselves overboard and small babies dying during these arduous journeys. Sabrina
column10: a second-generation exile
column11: carries this startlingly recent legacy on her indefatigable shoulders as she fights for the rights of her people to return to their homeland. Perpetually displaced
column12: many of the Chagosian refugees currently living in England face insurmountable financial precariousness and get little state support. Their fervent protests outside the House of Lords also seem to fall on deaf ears: in 2016 the UK government decided against a resettlement of the islanders
column13: citing monetary costs.

column1: While Sabrina’s campaign is hampered by endless obstacles
column2: moments of solidarity shine through; a major section of the film is dedicated to the camaraderie of a Chagosian football team who participate in the 2016 World Cup for stateless and diaspora groups. As a Chagosian song is played before a match
column3: it not only rouses the spirit of the young athletes but also becomes a searing proclamation of statehood. There are some clumsy formal choices – Sabrina’s meetings with activists in the US are inexplicably scored to a jazzy improvisation – but this film is a damning reminder of a cruel imperialist intervention whose ramifications remain largely unfamiliar to the general public. • Another Paradise is available on 7 January on True Story.";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/03/another-paradise-review-chagos-islands

column5: 'Evolution'];In my first class on an archaeology course at Lund University in Sweden
column6: I stood out more than usual. It was not just that it was full of blond and blue-eyed students
column7: more than in any other class I had ever attended – it was that archaeology is not a field that many migrants study. My teacher and classmates were lovely
column8: yet I still had this feeling of “What am I
column9: a Somali refugee
column10: doing here?” Furthermore
column11: I had never even seen an archaeologist before
column12: or held an archaeological object. But I had read a sentence in a book (Africa: history of a continent
column13: by Basil Davidson) which said that to write African history we need to do archaeological research. As this first class was on European stone age archaeology
column14: stone implements were handed out. An axe was passed to me. To my astonishment the label read “Somaliland”. Wow: an axe from my own country. The moment was like a message. It was as if someone was saying to me: “Yes
column15: you belong in this classroom”. I bombarded our teacher with questions about the axe. He had no idea where it was from – he did not seem to care. Why would he? Stone age artefacts are mostly the same. No
column16: he did not think there was any further documentation: only that they were palaeolithic objects. I later discovered that these objects were extraordinary. It turns out the axes were in fact history-making implements
column17: taken out of my country in the exciting days when the idea of human evolution was taking shape. Fast-forward 20 years from that day in Lund and I’m creating a new global initiative
column18: a digital museum to bring together in one platform all Somali objects and materials. I want people across Africa to feel the same connection to the subject as I did. In archaeology
column19: context is everything: if your bones are found with those of extinct bears and mammoths
column20: then you’ve probably been dead for tens of thousands of years and are most likely not even a Homo sapiens. In 1856 the first Neanderthal was discovered in Neander Valley in Germany. The Neanderthal would understandably not have liked to be thought of as the only link between modern humans and the great apes – they were too sophisticated. So it must have been a relief when
column21: in the 1890s
column22: Homo erectus came into the picture. The Java man
column23: as this find came to be known
column24: was labelled the “missing link”. Soon this “upright-ape-man” was joined by more hominids discovered in Asia. These discoveries reinforced the theories of Charles Darwin
column25: first set out in 1859 in On the Origin of Species
column26: and his idea of natural selection gained more ground. This was further evidence for the idea that humans had evolved from one common ancestor. Archaeologists didn’t bother to look to Africa until 1896
column27: when Heywood Walter Seton-Karr
column28: a Scottish game hunter
column29: returned to London with hundreds of stone implements from British Somaliland. He proclaimed
column30: to global attention
column31: that he had found the garden of Eden: “Here it was
column32: in my opinion
column33: that the human race originated.” Major museums – one of which must have been the Lund natural history museum – lined up to acquire Somaliland artefacts
column34: including stone tools. More discoveries on the continent followed
column35: such as Kenya’s “Turkana boy” or Ethiopia’s “Lucy”. I have spent the past year surveying the same area where Seton-Karr stumbled on the stone axes. I asked village elders about him
column36: hoping for some lingering generational memory. And though the name did not ring a bell – why should it – they told me the Ingriiskii (the British) used to come looking for macdan (gems) here. Often
column37: foreign archaeological missions failed to tell the locals what they were really doing – indeed sometimes this still happens. The village chief vowed to me to protect his area
column38: which also includes newly located 5
column39: 000-year-old rock paintings. By uncovering the hidden history of African collections long forgotten in museums in the west
column40: the founders of our new archive have unearthed a wealth of art
column41: technology and human history. With the application of technology
column42: things of the past can come alive – through photogrammetry and 3D virtual tours – and feel more relevant to modern-day societies. We are collaborating with major western museums that hold African collections
column43: including a number of UK institutions (the British Museum and Powell-Cotton Museum among them). But with all our digital work being carried out by African local teams
column44: we are tapping into a new tech-savvy generation. The idea is to inspire Africans to be the owners of their heritage and its narratives. This is not just about the past. Our fast-growing demands for goods have put huge pressure on climate and resources and also made us forget our traditional ways of resource management and interacting with nature. One of the most extraordinary individuals we worked with was a blind potter. She had been trained by her mother who was in turn trained by her mother. Now she was with her own daughter who was training her daughters. This lineage of female potters will die out after surviving so many adversities just because so many people now opt for machine-produced pottery and imported plastic goods. Our museum aims to revitalise craft technologies such as pottery and iron-making. With objects often locally neglected
column45: or forgotten in the storage departments of major museums
column46: this heritage is at risk for the first time in history. If we do not bring together the people and stories that reflect what is most beautiful about human life – the ability to adapt to change and challenges – we may well lose sight of humanity itself. Sada Mire is an archaeologist and incoming associate professor of heritage studies at UCL Institute of Archaeology. She is author of the book Divine Fertility;https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/africa-humanity-heritage-archaeologist

column1: The Mower’s Song is one of four “Mower” poems by Andrew Marvell (1621-1678)
column2: complementing his most substantial work in the country house genre
column3: Upon Appleton House. All date from the period he spent at Nun Appleton House (1651-2) as tutor to Mary
column4: the daughter of Lord General Thomas Fairfax. The English civil war and the impending first Anglo-Dutch war enrich Marvell’s view of Arcadia. Lord Fairfax had laid out the gardens at Appleton “in the Figure of a Fort”. Upon Appleton House develops a brilliantly extended metaphor of the horticultural battleground
column5: producing one of the most unusual and moving anti-war meditations of any age. Images of wounding
column6: physical and psychological
column7: recur in the Mower quartet. Perhaps Damon the Mower provides the most relevant and helpful context here. Damon
column8: in love with Juliana (whose name is associated with July and thus the high summer heat of Damon’s desires) suffers not only the flames of love but accidentally wounds himself in the ankle with his own scythe. The theme of being “mown down” by love might suggest satire (for which Marvell certainly had no little talent) but its treatment is scarcely light-hearted
column9: any more than the Mower is simply a figure of rustic innocence. The Mower imposes his will on nature like the more sophisticated
column10: commercially motivated horticulturalist excoriated in The Mower Against Gardens. Intrinsic to banishment from Eden
column11: the war between nature and unnaturally greedy humanity further infects the vision of the garden as redemptive pastoral. Lost clarity of understanding is proclaimed by the Mower in the first verse of his song
column12: where the noun “survey” suggests a once informed

column15: addressing them directly in stanza three. He goes on to declare that he will vengefully enforce the meadows’ withheld “compassion” (they should have wilted in sympathy with the lover) and ensure that “flow’rs
column16: and grass

column21: “For Juliana comes

column23: does to my thoughts and me”
column24: brings the violence of the scythe into the syntax
column25: and turns the poem away from any potential comedy. Juliana’s verb

column9: 'Human rights']";"A milky-white and sky-blue stone hangs from a red string around Ethels Correa’s neck
column10: and every so often she rubs it between her fingers. “When I feel anger
column11: I grab this stone and I begin to relax
column12: because they taught me how to breathe
column13: to relax the body and to relax the mind
column14: ” she says. “I carry it with me all the time.” Correa
column16: from the south coast of Honduras
column17: is among a group on a visit to La Siguata
column18: a healing centre for women like her who are suffering from trauma as a consequence of having stood up for human rights in the country. “When I came here
column19: I felt old
column20: wrinkled
column21: ” says Correa
column22: a mother of five who has been involved in land struggles in her home town
column23: Zacate Grande
column24: for two decades. But now
column25: when she looks in the mirror
column26: she sees a different reflection. “I look beautiful.”

column1: Inaugurated earlier this year
column2: the 10-day retreat at La Siguata is part of a tiny but growing movement led by the Mesoamerican Initiative of Women Human Rights Defenders
column3: which funds this and another centre in Oaxaca
column4: Mexico
column5: addressing the mental health issues that come with working in one of the world’s most dangerous regions for activists and women. “We realised that there was lots of burnout and also strong impacts on women defenders as a result of structural violence
column6: as well as patriarchal violence that was very invisible and normalised
column7: ” says Ana María Hernández of Casa La Serena healing centre in Oaxaca
column8: Mexico
column9: which opened in 2016 and has since welcomed hundreds of women from across the region. “The very demanding dynamics of women defenders’ activism means that we don’t have time to recover our energies
column10: to connect with our bodies and needs. There is an imbalance between giving and receiving
column11: ” adds Hernández.

column1: Hernández and colleagues from the Consortium for Parliamentary Dialogue and Equity in Oaxaca developed a holistic approach to help women overcome trauma and recharge
column2: so they can continue their work with renewed vigour. During their 10-day visits to the centres
column3: women participate in activities from the artistic to the spiritual
column4: in groups and individually
column5: and are given a personalised self-care plan to take home. La Siguata – which means “the woman” in the Uto-Aztecan Nahuatl language – sits behind high walls in the pine-covered mountains above the capital Tegucigalpa. “Since entering that gate
column6: I felt connected
column7: I felt like a protected woman
column8: ” says Correa. Solidarity is a guiding principle of the centre
column9: encapsulated by a motto adopted from the Garifuna culture of the country’s north coast
column10: painted over its entrance. It translates as “You for me
column11: me for you.”

column1: The grounds of flowers and fruit trees provide a stark contrast to the concrete landscape of the city below. The women can relax in hammocks or gather around a firepit surrounded by marigolds. “This space teaches us to love nature
column2: to feel that energy of the earth and the air
column3: which I had not experienced
column4: ” says Sandra Laínez
column6: a member of the Network of Domestic Workers
column7: who were among the first group to visit La Siguata.

column1: The centre has facilities for massage
column2: bathing and acupuncture. “I arrived with a lot of body pain and I didn’t feel well
column3: ” says Correa
column4: who has suffered a lot of violence over her life
column5: including a blow to the head that she says she was lucky to survive. “If I’m sick
column6: then I’m no good to the organisation.” Inside the house are dormitories
column7: a spacious kitchen where cooking lessons are held
column8: and an altar with candles and flowers dedicated to environmentalist Berta Cáceres
column9: murdered after years of threats over her opposition to a dam project. It provides a poignant reminder of the hostility towards activists in Honduras
column10: a nation with the highest rate of femicide in Latin America. “In the midst of this struggle
column11: we have lost our sisters and our comrades
column12: ” says Rebeca Girón
column13: of the National Network of Women Human Rights Defenders
column14: who runs La Siguata.

column1: The centre is also open to survivors of sexual abuse and families of disappeared migrants. In the near future
column2: it is hoped that women from Nicaragua – where the government has brutally repressed dissent
column3: resulting in more than 300 deaths during the wave of protests in 2018 alone – will be able to visit. “We know that these 10 days are not going to be the 10 days that will transform their lives
column4: with sudden changes from one day to the next
column5: ” says Girón. “But we do consider that we open the way. “La Siguata represents the recovery of that internal flame of passion
column6: for wanting to live again and even to enjoy human rights work anew.” Sign up for a different view with our Global Dispatch newsletter – a roundup of our top stories from around the world

column8: 'World news'];"Cats have been effortlessly stealing scenes from their human co-stars for decades. Who could forget Audrey Hepburn’s adorable marmalade tabby in Breakfast at Tiffany’s? Or Jinx
column9: the toilet-flushing Himalayan in Meet the Parents? Behind every famous film cat
column10: there is a dedicated trainer patiently teaching them to obey a command
column11: making sure they’re happy on set
column12: and grooming them fastidiously to maintain their fluffy good looks. The film-makers behind The Electrical Life of Louis Wain
column13: a British period biopic about the Edwardian artist and illustrator who became famous for his surreal portraits of cats
column14: were adamant they didn’t want to use CGI for the shoot
column15: so animal trainer Charlotte Wilde was brought in with 40 feisty felines. “It was organised chaos
column16: ” she says. “They had their own green room and were treated like royalty.” Wilde
column17: who has also worked on Fighting With My Family and Bohemian Rhapsody
column18: runs a London agency that provides animals for film and TV. Felix
column19: her 10-year-old black and white moggie (“a very cheeky chap!”)
column20: was cast as Peter
column21: Wain’s furry best friend
column22: who inspires his first sketches. Cats
column23: of course
column24: are notoriously fickle and independent – but that doesn’t mean they can’t be trained like dogs to behave and do tricks on screen. Wilde says she uses positive reinforcement with plenty of snacks on hand to dish out as rewards. “We teach our cats to go to mark
column25: ” she says. “They’ll walk in and they’ll know where to stop. We train them so they run to the sound of a buzzer. We’ve got some that can roll over. A couple can retrieve. They’ll lie down
column26: rub against people’s legs
column27: walk alongside someone. We show them what they’ve got to do. Then we try to make that happen on the take.”

column1: A clicker is used as encouragement. “You might have a moment in between a couple of lines where we can get a click in
column2: just so the cat [knows]: ‘You’re doing really well. Wait. Food is coming.’ Obviously
column3: that’s really distracting for actors. They’re probably sick of the sound of a clicker by the end of the film!” Mark Harden
column4: an animal trainer based in Los Angeles
column5: was in charge of the five snowy white Chinchilla Persians who played Snowbell in Stuart Little
column6: and looked after 40 cats on the set of Catwoman including several rare Egyptian Maus. With cats
column7: he says
column8: it’s all about getting into their mindset. “They’re a predator but they can also be skittish. They’ve got a very strong flight reaction. The most important thing with a cat is desensitising them to strange environments. A movie set is a very strange environment.”

column1: Canadian animal trainer Melissa Millett has a novel way of desensitising the cats she works with: she stages mock film shoots at home. For the Pet Sematary reboot
column2: she recruited five Maine Coons from rescue shelters to play Church
column3: who is transformed into an aggressive zombie cat. This meant gradually acclimatising them to wearing makeup and being wet. The whole process took two months. “We started with a catnip party in the bathtub. A little bit of water on the cat while it’s eating. Then we worked up to a full bath. Separately
column4: we would start with a bit of egg white and then work our way up. All the products had to be edible.” Expectations for cat actors tend to be much lower than for dogs
column5: says Harden. “People are more in awe of you when you have a good working cat. I guess they expect the cat to be scared.” Even so
column6: animal trainers can teach cats to do the kind of tricks that would easily outshine Lassie. Millett has a talented Bengal named Sashimi
column7: who can ride a scooter. Wilde taught one of her moggies
column8: Leicester
column9: to pretend to play the harmonica
column10: while Harden trained Cairo
column11: an Egyptian Mau
column12: to pick up a mobile phone with his teeth and run off with it. But it’s not all cats being cute and cuddly on cue. Being bitten accidentally is an occupational hazard. Then there’s the cat hair that gets everywhere. “You certainly don’t wear your best clothes to work!” says Wilde. “You have to get up extra early because you’ve got to get the animals ready. You go to bed later because you’ve got to put them to bed. They come first no matter what. I’d say it’s a way of life rather than a job. It’s incredibly rewarding. They give you so much.” • The Electrical Life of Louis Wain is out in UK cinemas on 1 January.";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/03/whats-new-pussycat-how-feline-film-stars-are-trained-to-perform

column1: 5856;5856;Walk Me to the Corner by Anneli Furmark review – Brief Encounter for the digital age;2022-01-03T09:00:42Z;['Rachel Cooke'];['Comics and graphic novels'
column2: 'Books'
column3: 'Fiction'
column4: 'Culture'];"Elise
column5: a fiftysomething writer
column6: has work that she enjoys
column7: a husband of 23 years with whom she is “uncommonly happy”
column8: and two grownup sons. If her life is uneventful
column9: it’s also replete; she is content and (this is the more important thing) grateful for such contentment. But then
column10: as if a heavy stone had been hurled into a tranquil pool
column11: it happens. At a party
column12: she meets Dagmar
column13: and something inside her shifts. Back at home
column14: she considers her body in the bathroom mirror and thinks vaguely of what it might be like to sleep with this woman – or anyone! – at this point in her life. It is unthinkable and yet
column15: it’s about to happen. She and Dagmar start sending each other text messages. Quite soon after this
column16: they go to bed with each other
column17: and it is wonderful.

column1: Elise doesn’t lie to her husband. She tells him that she doesn’t want to leave him
column2: but that she cannot stop herself from seeing Dagmar
column3: and he makes his decision: they separate
column4: and he begins a new relationship. But freedom doesn’t make life any easier for Elise
column5: and not only because she misses Henrik so badly. Dagmar has a wife and two children
column6: and she will not leave them for Elise – though neither will she break off with her. Live in the moment
column7: she tells her lover; be happy with what we’ve got. But what have they got? Conversations conducted on cold park benches. Snatched weekends that are over almost before they’ve begun. An endless
column8: lonely present. Which would be worse
column9: Elise asks herself: a life without Dagmar
column10: or this half-life of longing and WhatsApp? Is a little bit of Dagmar
column11: however small
column12: really better than nothing at all? And if it is
column13: what does this say about the rest of their lives?

column1: I adored Anneli Furmark’s last book
column2: Red Winter
column3: about love among radical leftists in northern Sweden
column4: but I feel even more strongly about Walk Me to the Corner (translated by Hanna Strömberg). However painful to read
column5: it captures so brilliantly both the unexpectedness of sudden desire in middle age – as Elise tells her son
column6: she hadn’t realised that fiftysomething love would feel exactly the same as twentysomething love; that it would come with all the same ridiculous and paralysing uncertainties – and the utter misery that comes with falling for someone whose deeds simply do not match their words. Does Dagmar love Elise? She says she does. But will she give up anything for her at all? No
column7: she will not. Furmark’s richly coloured drawings are sketchy
column8: rough around the edges. But they’re wonderfully effective: I love the way she makes women’s bodies and faces look so seductively solid and generous; somehow
column9: she imbues even everyday objects – a quilt
column10: a coffee cup
column11: a freshly laundered vest – with an incredible tenderness
column12: as if these things
column13: too
column14: had feelings. Given the complexity of what she’s aiming to capture – all the agonising repetition of a lop-sided affair – her narration is amazingly concise
column15: in part because she’s so very deft at incorporating the tiny screens of mobile phones into her story. How swiftly yearning reduces a lover’s world to the length and breadth of their malevolent/ecstatic glow. With what astonishing speed a heart comes to depend on a brief text message. Walk Me to the Corner by Anneli Furmark (translated by Hanna Strömberg) is published by Drawn & Quarterly (£18.99). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/03/walk-me-to-the-corner-by-anneli-furmark-review-brief-encounter-for-the-digital-age

column8: 'Independence Day: Resurgence']";"Which films kept you entertained over the holidays? Was it Silent Night
column9: the sweary festive Britcom starring Keira Knightley? The courtroom drama Naked Singularity
column10: with John Boyega as a crusading lawyer? Or did you watch Leonardo DiCaprio as a dorky astronomer in Don’t Look Up
column11: a slapstick political satire? Whichever it was
column12: I hope you poured yourself a large one
column13: because none of those films are quite as light as they seem. All take place in the shadow of imminent Armageddon. That’s right: the end of the world is nigh
column14: and it’s no longer the preserve of megabudget disaster movies or bleak survivalist thrillers. These days the looming obliteration of our species can just as readily form the backdrop to some governmental mockery or a boozy country-house drama.

column1: Why the sudden change? After all
column2: existential catastrophe is hardly a new subject for Hollywood
column3: which has been churning out such tales for the best part of a century. Historically
column4: though
column5: they have largely come in the form of razzle-dazzle showstoppers
column6: be it during the original disaster-movie boom
column7: with titles like When Worlds Collide
column8: or more recent CGI-fuelled fare such as The Day After Tomorrow. The more muted end-times films have been generally been left to less popcorn-hungry countries like Russia (The Sacrifice)
column9: France (Time of the Wolf
column10: Delicatessen) and Canada (Last Night). But the mainstream movie industry has nonetheless made sure that even the most casual filmgoer will be well used to witnessing humanity’s spectacular destruction. We’ve seen it carried out by deranged scientists and comic-book villains
column11: by robot uprising and cosmic collision
column12: by viral outbreak and biblical flood
column13: by dragons
column14: birds and talking monkeys. And unsurprisingly
column15: a genre predicated on the ultimate worst-case scenario has tended to reflect the anxieties of the time. Invasion of the Body Snatchers offered an allegory for McCarthyism; Steven Spielberg’s War of the Worlds
column16: with its nightmarish urban devastation
column17: was the first truly post-9/11 blockbuster; Wall-E sounded the alarm about mass consumerism. The genre itself initially mushroomed during the cold war
column18: when “mutually assured destruction” became a household phrase. Now it’s exploding again. According to the Wikipedia page listing “apocalyptic films”
column19: there were more additions to the genre in the past decade than the previous two combined. In the last year alone the destruction of our planet has been either realised or threatened in sci-fi extravaganzas
column20: family tearjerkers and chirpy animated romps. This year will bring more of the same: slated for TV are two cheerless visions of post-viral dystopia
column21: The Last of Us and Station Eleven
column22: as well as the Ronseal-titled Extinction. At the cinema
column23: we’ll get the big-screen pageantry of Moonfall from disaster impresario Roland Emmerich
column24: and a Noah Baumbach adaptation of Don DeLillo’s eco-fiasco novel White Noise.

column1: But before all that
column2: treat yourself to the best film of the festive season: The Humans
column3: an understated chamber piece in which a dysfunctional family gather for Thanksgiving under a distinct atmosphere of – you guessed it! – creeping existential dread. The real drama
column4: though
column5: lies in the bickering of rival siblings
column6: senile grandparents and sozzled patriarchs. It’s more evidence that end-times anxiety can now be treated as mundane
column7: off-screen
column8: secondary to the domestic fallout: call it kitchen-sink nihilism.

column1: It’s a long way from the cigar-chomping triumphalism of Armageddon and Independence Day – both certified artefacts of Clinton-era America – but maybe this trend for quietly apocalypse-adjacent storytelling is to be expected in an era when the real-world headlines tell of survival bunkers
column2: fire tornadoes and doomsday glaciers. Dr Strangelove’s breakneck bomb-ride was the response to a world where nuclear decimation could arrive at any moment; maybe this new mode of restraint reflects a reality where the unthinkable seems to be unfolding bit by bit
column3: a matter of glum inevitability. Adam McKay’s climate-change satire Don’t Look Up takes its lead from Kubrick’s movie
column4: invoking the apocalypse as an act of ridicule towards a complacent political class. But six decades on
column5: the tone has shifted from anarchic glee to resigned exasperation. “Maybe the destruction of the entire planet isn’t supposed to be fun
column6: ” says Jennifer Lawrence’s scientist. “Maybe it’s supposed to be unsettling.” It’s a credo that unites this current crop of films
column7: which all provoke angst rather than excitement
column8: defeatism rather than hope. This is the way the world ends: not with a bang
column9: but a shrug. Or as Arnold Schwarzenegger grumbles in End of Days
column10: while the scenario of the title closes in: “We have some real serious problems here – and we’re not solving any of them!” And when it comes to the annihilation of humankind
column11: there’s a man who knows what he’s talking about.";https://www.theguardian.com/film/2022/jan/03/apocalypse-nowadays-the-new-wave-of-films-about-the-end-of-the-world

column1: 5860;5860;The big idea: should we eat like our ancestors? ;2022-01-03T08:00:42Z;['Farrah Jarral'];['Health

column4: 'Culture'
column5: 'Diets and dieting'
column6: 'Life and style'];"April isn’t the cruellest month – January is. There is no other time of year when we are as prone to navel-gazing
column7: often literally
column8: as this one. In this period of anxiety about the size of our waists and what we consume
column9: simple dietary rules are appealing. “Eat like our ancestors” is a particularly catchy slogan to live by
column10: at least on the surface. But who exactly are these ancestors we are supposed to emulate? Are they our great-great-grandparents
column11: cooking wholesome things from scratch? Or are they that nebulous group of hairy low-browed brutes we imagine “cavemen” to be? The popular “paleo” diet pins modern health woes on the birth of agriculture
column12: claiming that we should stick to eating meat
column13: nuts and berries. Strict paleo dieters are forbidden from eating beans
column14: as well as potatoes and grains. This kind of stone age reenactment has rather a loose grip on history
column15: however. For starters
column16: it’s based on the false premise that palaeolithic peoples all ate the same food
column17: regardless of their location. Somerset’s 9
column18: 000-year-old Cheddar Man
column19: who scientists tell us was rather disappointingly lactose-intolerant
column20: would not have eaten the same foods as his contemporaries on the Kenyan savannah. Geography
column21: climate and culture shaped the food choices of humans of the past as they do today. The amount of meat people ate
column22: and how much was obtained by hunting versus scavenging
column23: is also up for debate. Founded on what Giles Yeo refers to as the “‘Fred Flintstone and his brontosaurus ribs’ school of pre-history”
column24: the paleo fad has a streak of solipsism as well as hubris and fantasy. It is focused almost exclusively on what’s perceived to be good for our bodies
column25: without any concern for the rest of nature
column26: including other humans whose livelihoods are threatened by western overconsumption.

column1: Conversations about how to eat well and recreate the habits of the past often feature a selective suspicion of science and technology. What is supposedly “natural” – a category that includes polio
column2: death in childbirth and poisonous mushrooms – is conflated with what is good or right. Professor Heidi Larson has observed a clustering of identity markers on social media – “paleo
column3: gluten-free-diets
column4: home births” – with anti-vaccine sentiment. Beneath the intellectualisation
column5: there is a gnawing sense of alienation from our bodies
column6: and disenchantment with modern lifestyles. Yet attempts to recreate the past are not only misguided but impossible. The fruit and vegetables we eat today are the result of many generations of tampering with the genetics of once-wild plants. Growing cereal crops is necessary to feed populations that hunter-gatherer lifestyles could not sustain. Processing food in some way
column7: whether by cooking
column8: fermenting or drying it
column9: has allowed us to obtain more energy from it
column10: made it safer
column11: and helped us to preserve it for leaner times. Which is not to say that some of the changes we’ve made to our food and the way it’s produced are not harmful to our bodies
column12: other animals and the environment. While we are living longer than ever
column13: modern life can make us sick. Eating lots of ultra-processed foods – with excess salt and sugar
column14: emulsifiers
column15: inverted corn syrup
column16: flavourings and colourings – is associated with an increased risk of a range of diseases. Such foods are often designed to be hyperpalatable
column17: hitting a sweet spot of sugar
column18: salt and fat that makes them devilishly moreish. Michael Pollan’s suggestion that we should be wary of things our great-grandmothers wouldn’t recognise as food is a reasonable but blunt instrument to help avoid these. column7: 'US news'];"Wildlife officials in Yellowstone national park captured the “unusual” sight of a cheeky grizzly bear tagging along with a pack of hunting wolves
column8: then making off with their kill.

column1: The enthralling video
column2: posted to the National Parks Service Facebook page
column3: shows the October incident in which the wolves from the Junction Butte pack in northern Yellowstone were joined by a lumbering grizzly as they hunted a herd of elk. After the wolves take down an elk
column4: the bear moves in and steals the carcass: a phenomenon known as kleptoparasitism
column5: or parasitism by theft
column6: in which one species steals resources
column7: usually food
column8: from another. The Yellowstone incident was unusual
column9: the NPS said
column10: because wolves and bears usually compete for food and hunt separately. While bears stealing food wolves have captured is not uncommon
column11: in this case the bear decided its best interests were served by actively joining the hunt. “From the bear’s perspective
column12: it takes a lot of energy to follow a wolf pack around
column13: but the reward is high if it successfully takes over a carcass
column14: ” the NPS said. “A fresh elk carcass is a wonderful source of fat and protein for a grizzly bear preparing for hibernation. This bear seems to have figured out that following the wolves in the morning will increase its chances of encountering a high-calorie meal.” The wolves were forced to wait until the bear had finished its meal before taking advantage of their own kill. “Typically
column15: wolves will yield to incoming bears
column16: ” the NPS said. “Since hunting is dangerous and often unsuccessful
column17: it’s better for wolves to wait their turn at a carcass that has been usurped by a bear than it is for them to continue hunting.” Previous videos from Yellowstone show wolves and bears confronting each other. In one episode
column18: filmed in 2019
column19: a tour guide captured close-up images of a grizzly defending itself from a pack of wolves trying to reclaim an elk carcass. Yellowstone is home to about 123 gray wolves
column20: the NPS says
column21: with 90% of their winter diet consisting of elk. The park
column22: spanning parts of Idaho
column23: Montana and Wyoming
column24: also has about 150 grizzly bears
column25: listed as a threatened species in 1975. A federal judge restored protections for grizzlies in the greater Yellowstone ecosystem in September 2018
column26: after the US Fish and Wildlife Service
column27: claiming a “remarkable recovery”
column28: delisted the species a year earlier.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/03/kleptoparasitic-bear-steals-wolves-kill-yellowstone

column3: 'Books'
column4: 'Culture'];"Michelle de Kretser’s slyly intelligent sixth novel pairs two first-person narratives. One takes place in a dystopian near-future Melbourne
column5: where Lyle
column6: an immigrant father of two
column7: is employed by the state to write sinister-sounding “evaluations” nominating fellow migrants for arrest and repatriation; the other half of the book is set in 1981 and follows Lili
column8: a 22-year-old Australian working as a teaching assistant in France
column9: prior to postgraduate literary study in Oxford. It’s typical of De Kretser’s sophistication that she leaves the link between these narratives entirely up to you – even the order in which they are to be read is left to the individual reader
column10: given the book’s reversible
column11: Kindle-defying two-way design. I plunged straight into Lili’s intimately conversational reminiscence of running with a circle of young Europeans attached to her Montpellier lycée
column12: in particular Minna
column13: who takes a year out of art school in London to tag along with her boyfriend Nick. Lili struggles for cash
column14: has problems with her landlord and neighbour
column15: and faces everyday racism (her family emigrated to Australia from Asia
column16: like De Kretser
column17: who was born in Sri Lanka). She can’t help but fall for Minna and Nick’s rackety aura of entitled glamour
column18: not least when she learns that Nick is at work on a novel
column19: something it never occurred to her she could do
column20: even as an aspiring scholar under the spell of Simone de Beauvoir.

column1: As the three knock around together
column2: Lili’s story unfolds as a coming-of-age vignette portraying the lonely restlessness of unfocused sexual desire and shapeless creative ambition. Regular moments of comedy erupt
column3: especially when Lili joins Minna en route to Italy to visit John Berger’s mistress (apparently an acquaintance of Minna’s mother)
column4: where various mid-trip lunch options are rejected as bourgeois until Minna alights on a suitably authentic workers’ restaurant
column5: only to balk at what’s on the menu. Yet there’s steel
column6: too
column7: in De Kretser’s portrait of the chilly welcome Lili receives having arrived into the bosom of the western culture that has defined her intellectual interests. When Lili’s section ends in a moment of collective rapture at the election of François Mitterrand’s socialist party
column8: there’s an immediate shift in tone for the reader
column9: who then turns the book 180 degrees to begin the plottier
column10: more urgent thread set in Lyle’s Australia. Here there are hoverboards
column11: yes
column12: but three-figure-factor sun cream is the norm
column13: much of Sydney is underwater and Islamic worship is banned as a terrorist activity under a suite of laws targeting minorities.

column1: As a civil servant who is also a migrant
column2: Lyle recognises that he’s a hair’s breadth from falling foul of the authoritarian powers he helps enforce. When he speaks of a wind that “cuts as if it’s factory-fresh from Gillette”
column3: it’s a mark of De Kretser’s cleverness just how psychologically acute the line feels
column4: almost as if Lyle is trying too hard to signal his buy-in in order to pass without attracting suspicion. The plot turns on cranked-up domestic strife
column5: as Lyle’s go-getting wife sets out to exploit recent euthanasia legislation to kill off his mother and liquidate her assets to move to a new area better suited to the circles they aspire to. There’s an affinity here with the type of story found in George Saunders’s Tenth of December
column6: whose speakers unwittingly reveal the disturbing norms they have assimilated without question. Much of the energy comes from the way De Kretser lets us piece together the precise nature of her climate-ravaged hellscape
column7: as when Lyle speaks casually of prepping his cattle prod before walking to his car at night. De Kretser’s previous novel
column8: 2018’s The Life to Come
column9: also comprised discrete segments
column10: and as in that book
column11: there’s a certain riddling quality here. While the doomy tendency of Lyle’s segment all but snuffs out the heady sense of possibility captured in Lili’s thread
column12: the book’s overriding sense of anger and alarm also mingles with satirical glee. Even if she obviously has the apocalyptic drift of the present in sight
column13: De Kretser passes on to the reader the inescapable feeling that she’s also having fun
column14: in this engaging amalgam of lament and warning shot. Scary Monsters by Michelle de Kretser is published by Atlantic (£14.99). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/03/scary-monsters-by-michelle-de-kretser-review-anger-alarm-and-satirical-glee

column3: 'Culture'];"The first single that I ever bought Our House by Madness. I was four
column4: so the actual purchase was instigated by my father. He was such a big music fan and wanted to make sure that I knew this was the first song I was buying. I still adore it. In 2020’s lockdown
column5: we did Kitchen Discos: I sang on my Instagram with the kids. After 10 weeks
column6: I chose to close the whole thing with Our House. It celebrates the glory and chaos of family life.

column1: *** The song that is my karaoke go-to I used to sing Shoop by Salt-N-Pepa
column2: and it’s really fun to do the rap – but when you do a karaoke version
column3: the backing track is quite slow
column4: so you get people looking a bit concerned for you as you trip your way through it. Basically
column5: what you want is a people-pleaser. The one I go to is Faith by George Michael. It just always works.

column1: *** The song I’ve streamed the most In the days of having an Alexa
column2: the ruler of the roost is my little one
column3: Mickey. He’s two
column4: and he will get a passion for a song and just play it over and over. For a while it was Let’s Get Loud by Jennifer Lopez; now we’ve progressed to In Da Getto by Skrillex and J Balvin. He likes his heavy dance and his reggaeton as well. It could be a lot worse. *** The best song to play at a party If you want something a bit slinky
column5: Grace Jones – Pull Up to the Bumper. But if you’re trying to entice people to the dancefloor
column6: then I’d probably go disco. Thelma Houston’s Don’t Leave Me This Way is very seductive.

column1: *** The best song to have sex to For music that’s got that undercurrent of “the man singing wants you to get saucy”
column2: it’s got to be Darling Nikki by Prince – you’re not reading between the lines with that one. Kiss has got lots of flirtation
column3: too. Gett Off would be my top one. *** The song I want played at my funeral The one that I’ve said since I was really small is Mickey by Toni Basil – which
column4: I grant you
column5: is going to be quite weird. It came out when I was about two
column6: and it made a big impression on me. It’s got such urgency and passion and it’s a little bit off-kilter. It’s probably not one of the Top 100 hits for funerals
column7: but I think of it as “one of my songs”.

column1: *** The song I pretend to hate that I secretly like I’m not really afraid of saying what I like. I don’t believe in guilty pleasures. The things I say are my favourites are my favourites. There’s a song that came out by Rufus Wainwright song
column2: Peaceful Afternoon
column3: that’s just so beautiful. I like Everything Now by Arcade Fire
column4: Harmony Hall by Vampire Weekend.

column1: *** The song that is my actual favourite It depends what mood you’re in. But some songs are just pretty perfect. Something like Wichita Lineman [by Glen Campbell]
column2: it’s a very beautiful song – just glorious. It sounds wistful and captures the purity of wanting to find that connection with someone: you’re sending out your message to them. That’s all of us
column3: isn’t it? Hoping that someone’s on the line. Sophie Ellis-Bextor’s Kitchen Disco is available on BBC Sounds.";https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/03/i-want-mickey-by-toni-basil-played-at-my-funeral-sophie-ellis-bextors-honest-playlist

column7: 'Isas'];"Pay off costly debts first There is no point trying to save if you are burdened by costly debts. The average easy access savings account offers less than 0.2% interest
column8: while on some borrowing you could be paying in excess of 20%. Aim to pay off expensive credit card
column9: store card or overdraft debts before you think about putting money aside. Start a rainy-day fund Everyone should aim to have some cash in an easily accessible savings account to provide a financial safety net if the worst happens.

column1: “We all need robust savings to cope with the nasty surprises life tends to throw at us
column2: ” says Sarah Coles
column3: a personal finance analyst at the investment firm Hargreaves Lansdown. “We should be working towards three to six months’ worth of essential expenses in an easy access account.” Essential expenses should include items such as housing costs
column4: money for food and important bills. Do not be put off by how much this comes to – anything you can put away towards it will help if things do go wrong. Have a goal Beyond rainy-day savings
column5: you may want to put aside other cash – and having a purpose will motivate you. “Setting a goal and giving it a name can help keep you on track
column6: ” says Annabelle Williams
column7: a personal finance specialist at the investment firm Nutmeg. “By attaching meaning to your savings goals
column8: such as a new home
column9: a specific trip
column10: or big purchase
column11: you’re more likely to stick to your savings habit.” Make it a regular habit

column1: Regular savings accounts are a good option for those new to saving. You put aside money each month – usually via a standing order from your current account. These accounts offer some of the best interest rates out there
column2: although the maximum you can tuck away often isn’t that high. If you have a NatWest current account
column3: you can take advantage of its Digital Regular Saver account
column4: which pays a market-leading 3% interest and is
column5: it says
column6: designed to help customers with little or no savings develop a savings habit and build financial capability. However
column7: you can only pay in up to £50 each month. TSB’s Monthly Saver pays 2% and lets you save between £25 and £125 a month – again
column8: you need to have a current account with the bank to open one. Most regular savings accounts run for a year
column9: and the interest is paid at the end of the period. You will then need to shop around for a new account for your lump sum. Get some help For those on a low income
column10: the government’s Help to Save account is definitely worth considering. It lets certain people on working tax credit
column11: or receiving universal credit
column12: get a bonus of 50p for every £1 they save over four years. You can put in between £1 and £50 each month
column13: and the most you can earn in four years is £1
column14: 200 in bonus money. But paying into this account could affect some people’s eligibility for benefits and how much they get
column15: so read the details carefully before you commit.

column1: Then there’s the lifetime Isa
column2: which lets people save for a property or retirement. You can put away up to £4
column3: 000 each year until you are 50
column4: and the government will add a 25% bonus to your savings
column5: up to a maximum of £1
column6: 000 a year. To open one you must be aged 18 to 39. Round up your spending … Several banks are making saving easier by getting you to do it whenever you pay for something. Lloyds Bank has Save the Change. When you buy something with your debit card
column7: if your account is in credit it will round up the amount spent to the nearest pound
column8: and transfer the difference into a nominated Lloyds savings account. “If a purchase is £2.20
column9: the bank will transfer 80p
column10: which could see someone save £5.60 in a week if this is spent every day
column11: ” says Rachel Springall at the financial data provider Moneyfacts. The digital bank Chase does the same and deposits the small change into a separate account where it will earn interest at 5% for 12 months. … or round it down Another technique is to log into your current account
column12: look at the balance and mentally “round it down”
column13: Williams says. “If you have £221.60 until payday
column14: round it down to £210 and move £11.60 into savings. It all adds up over time.” Use an app Chip and Plum are just two of the apps that offer “auto-save” features. Every few days the tech does the maths and automatically transfers some of your money into another account
column15: which little by little adds up. Plum’s free option includes auto-saving
column16: while Chip is changing its pricing in mid-January so that standard membership will be free.

column1: A budgeting app could also help. Springall suggests Money Dashboard
column2: which automatically categorises spending into “buckets”
column3: such as household bills and groceries – this lets you see what you can afford to save once the essentials are covered. Another budgeting app to check out is Emma
column4: which analyses transactions across accounts and classifies them into spending categories. “Great budgeting starts with careful planning and reliable insights
column5: ” its website promises. Fix for a better return Some of the best interest rates are offered by fixed-rate savings accounts
column6: where you typically tie up your money for a year or more. Of course
column7: that won’t suit everyone. At the time of writing
column8: you could get about 1.3% on a one-year fixed-rate bond
column9: about 1.6% on a two-year bond
column10: and about 2.1% on a five-year bond. For the latest rates
column11: keep a close eye on Moneyfacts’ tables.

column1: Switch current account If your current account isn’t cutting the mustard
column2: you can get some free cash – enough
column3: perhaps
column4: to kick off a nest egg – by moving it to a new provider. Many banks pay £100-plus if you move to them. Nationwide will give you up to £125 if you are a member and switch to its FlexDirect current account. If you are not yet a member
column5: it is £100. Meanwhile
column6: HSBC is offering £150 if you move to its Advance or Premier accounts. Typically
column7: the money is paid into the current account you have switched to
column8: shortly after the move has been completed. You can then use this cash to start a new savings account or boost an existing one.";https://www.theguardian.com/money/2022/jan/03/new-years-resolutions-saving-interest-budgeting

column10: 'NFL'];"Herschel Walker has Donald Trump’s endorsement in the race for US Senate in Georgia but the former NFL star may be struggling to counter fears from some Republicans that he could damage the party’s chances of taking back a seat lost in 2020

column23: the Associated Press said “hundreds of pages of public records tied to Walker’s business ventures and his divorce

column1: The AP also reported that Walker “has at times been open about his long struggle with mental illness

column8: “in an online biography advertising Walker’s book
column9: at a campaign rally … and even during his introduction this year at a congressional hearing”. In a statement
column10: Walker said: “I was majoring in criminal justice at UGA when I left to play in the USFL my junior year. After playing with the New Jersey Generals” – a team Trump owned – “I returned to Athens to complete my degree
column11: but life and football got in the way.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/03/herschel-walker-video-build-back-better-georgia-republican-senate-run-trump
