column7: 'World news'];"Key Donald Trump loyalists Steve Bannon and Michael Flynn are at the forefront of a drive to expand Trumpist influence at the local level of US politics while forging ahead with efforts aimed at promoting baseless claims that Joe Biden’s 2020 election victory was fraudulent.

column1: The growing drive by Trump’s hardcore allies has spurred election watchdog groups to voice alarm about the threat to democracy posed by Flynn and Bannon – and other Trump acolytes – as they combine debunked claims about election fraud and calls for further 2020 election audits with planning conservative takeovers of official positions that run US elections. The moves come a year after the attack on the Capitol in Washington when a pro-Trump mob invaded the building in an attempt to stop the certification of Biden’s election victory. Flynn and Bannon
column2: using varying paths
column3: have focused new energy on increasing conservative influence by recruiting more allies for key posts at the local and precinct level with an eye on the 2022 and 2024 elections
column4: and building more political alliances on issues such as vaccine requirements and mask mandates. The strategies Flynn and Bannon are deploying overlap those of other conservative outfits
column5: such as the influential youth group Turning Point USA
column6: to expand the pro-Trump base at the precinct level
column7: and work to elect Trump-backed politicians to key posts such as secretary of state in Georgia
column8: Arizona and other battleground states. Flynn and Bannon have separately relied on a mix of non-profit groups
column9: including one backed by the multimillionaire Patrick Byrne
column10: conservative social media outlets favored by the far right like Telegram
column11: and events that convey evangelical Christian messages with political disinformation. Bannon
column12: for instance
column13: has used his War Room podcast to espouse plans for “taking over the Republican party through the precinct committee strategy” and invited would-be candidates to appear as guests. The podcast
column14: which has tens of millions of downloads
column15: has found a large and receptive conservative following. Flynn
column16: meanwhile
column17: touts the adage that “local action has national impact” and has been a star speaker in several key states at “ReAwaken America” events
column18: which are dubbed “health and freedom” conferences and combine evangelical themes with misinformation about the 2020 election and vaccine skepticism. The conservative crusades by Flynn and Bannon come after Trump pardoned them post-election for lying to the FBI and fraud respectively. Bannon and Flynn also were central actors with other Trump loyalists in scheming about ways to block Congress from certifying Biden’s election
column19: efforts that are under scrutiny as part of a House select committee investigation of the deadly Capitol attack by hundreds of Trump supporters. As they have carved out new roles in the conservative ecosystem
column20: Flynn and Bannon still support Trump’s conspiratorial claims that he lost in 2020 due to massive cheating
column21: a mantra that reinforces their drives to expand local and state electoral influence to give Republicans a better shot at recapturing Congress next year
column22: and the White House in 2024. “We’re seeing a dangerous trend of election deniers lining up to fill election administration positions across the country

column5: 'Rewilding'];"It’s an encouraging start to 2022. In an informal census – or perhaps a sort of watery award ceremony – the Wildlife Trusts’ marine review of 2021 has pointed to humpback whales off the north-east coast of Scotland and England
column6: increasing numbers of seal pups being born
column7: and seahorses in protected beds of eel grass off the Dorset coast. It seems the work of the trusts and other marine conservation bodies is having a good effect. Blue whales appearing in the Irish Sea may be physical beneficiaries of the general agreement of the International Whaling Commission in 1982
column8: effected three years later
column9: to halt the cull of the species. It is as if the whales themselves remember
column10: encouraged to return without fear of someone sticking a harpoon in them. But in many ways these optimistic signs are also the markers of what we have lost. In the 19th century the waterways of the Solent were so full of salmon that local apprentices
column11: according to one author writing in 1850
column12: “stipulated in their indentures that it should not be served up to them oftener than three times a-week”. The same author reported shoals of porpoises in Southampton Water
column13: “rolling and springing on the surface in their renewed gambols”. While in the 18th century
column14: Oliver Goldsmith reported on an English Channel filled with whales
column15: dolphins
column16: cod fish
column17: tuna and even great white sharks chasing columns of herrings. “The whole water seems alive
column18: ” Goldsmith wrote in one of the first popular science books
column19: Animated Nature
column21: “and is seen so black with them that the number seems inexhaustible.” Humans
column22: too
column23: were once more watery. In the north of England and Scotland
column24: fisherwomen were known as herring quines
column25: so covered were they in silvery scales they seemed to be becoming fish themselves. Charles Richard Weld of the Royal Society declared in 1859
column26: riffing on Darwin: “If a man may become a monkey
column27: or has been a whale
column28: why should not a Caithness damsel become a herring?” To these writers
column29: the idea that one day there might not be plenty more fish in the sea would have been unthinkable. The depredations of the natural world that began to accelerate in the 19th century would remove much of that marine biomass from around our shores
column30: with disastrous effects. The physical absence of the great whales such as blue
column31: fin
column32: humpback and sperm whales may have actually accelerated the climate crisis – because it deprived the oceanic food chain of their fertilising faeces
column33: and their rotting carcasses which
column34: on the sea bed
column35: helped sequester carbon from the ecosphere and sustain species
column36: from polar bears and seals to bone-eating osedax worms. The life cycles of smaller organisms depended entirely on carcasses. We look to science to point out what needs to be done
column37: but often art inspires as much as academic reports. In 2012
column38: Heather Ackroyd and Dan Harvey performed a kind of reincarnation on the skeleton of a minke whale stranded at Skegness by growing diamond-like chemical crystals on its bones. A year later
column39: the artists Ellen Gallagher and Edgar Cleijne used the bone-eating worm to conjure up a similarly alchemical transformation in their film
column40: Osedax: a dead whale slowly sways to the bottom to become
column41: in the words of Shakespeare’s Ariel in The Tempest
column42: “something rich and strange”. With its shapeshifting sense of gender (slipper snails form stacks upon each other
column43: changing sex from male at the bottom to female at the top) and of time (“shadow” parts of the ocean may be 1
column44: 000 years old)
column45: the sea defies all our assumptions. It is a decidedly queer place; just ask any dolphin. Nor does it recognise national boundaries
column46: of course.

column1: The sea is where our laws and jurisdictions run out. That inevitably raises contrary questions of responsibility and freedom. Indeed
column2: it is hard to divorce the threats to our native marine life from “alien species” without considering the human refugees arriving on those same shores. Or to note that the climate crisis is a driver for both. It is easy to ignore the sea
column3: or to think of it as a kind of highway with a fish shop attached. Some may consider it bizarre that commentators such as George Monbiot call for a rewilding of our seas as well as of the land. Others may worry there’s no chance of that while English and French politicians squabble over who has the “right” to take fish from the sea. But humpbacks off Whitby? Dancing sea slugs off Cumbria? White-beaked dolphins off Essex? These may be anomalies or signs of disruption
column4: but merely bearing witness to such wonders has the power to restore our faith. As I swim in the chilly winter sea
column5: the sleek black head of a grey seal pops up beside me
column6: and in the louring grey sky a skein of brent geese
column7: charcoal-coloured visitors from Siberia
column8: steer into view. It’s not quite Goldsmith’s vision of Eden
column9: but I’m still hoping for miracles in 2022. Happy new year to the sea
column10: all its species
column11: and to all of you. Philip Hoare is an author whose books include Leviathan
column12: Or the Whale";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/return-whales-seals-dolphins-british-coast-wonder

Bolsonaro and his sons have gone on the attack against him and this shows that they’ve grasped the danger of Moro stealing his place [in the second round].” Couto said Lula’s globetrotting was partly about re-engaging with foreign governments before what would be his third term as president.

column1: 5888;5888;La Niña weather pattern keeps temperatures in Australia down but 2021 still hotter than average;2022-01-03T04:50:50Z;['Graham Readfearn'];['Australia weather'
column2: 'Australia news'
column3: 'Climate crisis'
column4: 'La Niña'];"Australia’s 2021 was its coolest year since 2012
column5: but still half a degree hotter than average according to data from the Bureau of Meteorology. A dominant La Niña weather pattern kept temperatures lower than in recent years and total rainfall across the country was only slightly higher than average. Across the bureau’s temperature records going back to 1910
column6: 2021 was the 17th hottest
column7: with the national temperature 0.56C warmer than the average between 1961 and 1990. Australia has not had a year where the temperature was below the long-term average since 2000. The hottest year on record is 2019
column8: which was 1.51C above average.

column1: The data shows 2021 was the 28th wettest year nationwide since 1900 with a total of 507mm – only slightly above the annual average of 466mm. The wettest year on record remains 1974
column2: when the bureau’s records show 760mm fell. Neil Plummer
column3: a climatologist and consultant at Monash University’s climate change communication research hub
column4: said 2021 had been a “signature La Niña” year. “We get a lot of stronger south-easterly winds flowing in to tropical areas and we get more convection and more high clouds and more rainfall in northern and eastern Australia. “That’s what we’ve seen since the back end of 2020. This is a signature La Niña over Australia.” New South Wales and the ACT had the coolest year since 1996
column5: with the overall temperature only 0.15C above average. NSW recorded its wettest November since at least 1900
column6: and 2021 was its sixth wettest year on record.

column1: In Victoria
column2: the average temperature was the lowest since 2004
column3: but still 0.26C above average. Rainfall was 36mm above the state’s annual average of 663mm. Queensland’s statewide temperature was 1C above average
column4: making it the coolest year since 2012. Rainfall was also slightly above average. Western Australia
column5: Tasmania
column6: the Northern Territory and South Australia were all slightly warmer than average. The only state and territory to record below average rainfall was South Australia
column7: which dipped below its average by just 4mm. The bureau declared the La Niña in November.

column1: Plummer
column2: a former head of climate services at the bureau
column3: said 2021 was one of the warmest La Niña years on record and continued the long-term heating being driven by climate change. “There’s a very clear warming trend in Australia
column4: ” he said. “There is no doubt that the climate risks are continuing to build. “Even though this 0.56C [above average] in 2021 is less than we’ve seen for a decade
column5: that’s still giving us an almost straight line warming trend since 1950. “It is remarkable that we no longer see strong negative temperature anomalies. I wouldn’t say they’ve disappeared
column6: but it’s going to be increasingly hard to get them.” The bureau will release more information about the climate of 2021 later this week. Last month the bureau’s climate outlook for the next three months said there was an increased chance of “unusually high minimum temperatures” for January to March over much of the country. Rainfall was likely to be above average for eastern Australia
column7: with northern Queensland and coastal NSW in particular having a very wet January to March.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/03/la-nina-weather-pattern-keeps-temperatures-in-australia-down-but-2021-still-hotter-than-average

column4: 'Disability'
column5: 'Omicron variant'];"Something about the sticky floors of the dingy nightclub Gemma Moore was at on the New South Wales central coast gave her the sense she was about to get sick. “It was a good night
column6: but I just really didn’t feel comfortable being out
column7: ” Moore said. “There weren’t any QR codes and the staff weren’t wearing masks. And I remember thinking: someone in here has Covid.” A few days later
column8: the 28-year-old care worker’s hunch proved correct when she
column9: her boyfriend and her housemate all showed symptoms and tested positive to Covid.

column1: “It took me ages to believe it was Covid
column2: ” Moore said. “I couldn’t wrap my head around it. I had had a negative rapid antigen test and it all had felt so far away. “I also really didn’t want to have it
column3: because that meant the people I saw in the last two days
column4: my clients
column5: were exposed and I was really worried about them.” From the moment they received their PCR results
column6: the three went into isolation
column7: joining thousands of others across the country despite efforts by political leaders to open up the country ahead of Christmas. “We can’t leave the house
column8: ” Moore says. “It feels like this invisible barrier – we’ve all been saying it. We can go to the end of the driveway and watch people from a distance as they walk or drive past
column9: but we can’t go any further. “It’s weird to feel normal
column10: but also know that we’re infectious. It’s weird to think that just by me going out in the community I could share the love.” Moore
column11: however
column12: says they are among the lucky ones. With a stable housing situation
column13: an ocean view and their other housemates visiting their families for the holidays
column14: they have avoided a situation where they would have had to isolate from each other as well as the world. Their mornings are spent apart
column15: but they share meals and wait out the time in the afternoons. Anna Mazzone had a different experience when she travelled to Adelaide from Berlin via Melbourne
column16: and ended up spending almost three weeks in isolation over Christmas. It was the 35-year-old’s first trip home in two years to visit her parents and she had initially quarantined with her brother in a small unit in Adelaide. Over the course of the first week
column17: the siblings couldn’t avoid each other in the “one big space”. Then
column18: on the final day
column19: Mazzone tested positive.

column1: “Unfortunately
column2: I must have caught it travelling. When I landed in Melbourne
column3: I got a test that was negative and I was meant to do a final test
column4: and that was positive
column5: ” Mazzone said. While her brother
column6: who was vaccinated
column7: remained Covid-free
column8: the unexpected result caused chaos. The pair immediately tried to physically distance as best they could while they worked out what to do next. Though they were supposed to receive a call with instructions
column9: none ever came. Mazzone said they spent the day calling health authorities for details but had a “different answer for every person we spoke to”. Mazzone decided to take matters into her own hands by booking an Airbnb at a cost of $500 a day to isolate for 14 days
column10: which has left her in debt. “It feels like it’s the first wave in Adelaide
column11: like no one’s experienced Covid before. Even coming in through Melbourne
column12: it seems like no one knew what the right thing to do was.” Others like Alex
column13: who is chronically ill
column14: began isolating as a pre-emptive measure when they saw case numbers start to climb
column15: in a practice known as “shielding”. The 30-year-old
column16: who did not wish to be identified and who lives with myalgic encephalomyelitis
column17: otherwise known as chronic fatigue syndrome
column18: spends most of their day in bed and relies on the help of their carer. They have struggled to apply for the NDIS
column19: and have had to privately fundraise to pay for care. Alex
column20: who is vaccinated
column21: is not just worried about dying from Covid
column22: but after-effects like long Covid that will make their circumstances worse. Their isolation has taken on “another layer” as their carer and two friends who helped with groceries have been exposed
column23: and are isolating while waiting for test results. Until their results came
column24: Alex said they would be on their own and having to triage basic tasks.

column1: “Basically the level of care that I need is very high
column2: so whenever I have to exert myself
column3: like cleaning stuff
column4: sanitising all the stuff coming in
column5: it takes so much out of me
column6: ” Alex said. “I just prioritise where I put my energy each day. So it’s like: OK
column7: I’m meant to shower today
column8: do I shower
column9: do I make sure I’m having three meals?” Alex said for all the talk about “living with Covid” and allowing it to spread
column10: disabled people were being left to carry the cost – often without government support. “It’s not just disabled people shielding
column11: but the people who care for us
column12: that we rely on
column13: ” they said. “There’s a shortage of people who are caring for us. “A lot of people are going to wind up getting disabled from long Covid
column14: and the system already doesn’t support chronically ill
column15: disabled people enough.”";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/03/thousands-of-australians-are-isolating-with-covid-heres-how-some-of-them-are-coping

column5: 'Coronavirus'];"Obtaining rapid antigen tests over the next two weeks is likely to remain “bumpy” across Australia as supply chain issues cause shortages and price spikes. Distributing the tests is something “still being worked out with the government”

column1: Foley said he believed the distribution of the tests will be discussed at the national cabinet meeting on Wednesday. The prime minister

column5: split 50-50 with the states. The federal treasurer

column6: 'Health'];"Queensland’s chief health officer has said “all of us are going to be exposed” to Covid-19 in the coming weeks

column1: Asked what the government was doing to help vulnerable people in overcrowded homes in Indigenous communities
column2: the Queensland premier

column1: 5893;5893;Scott Morrison resists calls to provide free rapid Covid tests to Australians;2022-01-03T01:35:56Z;['Sarah Martin'];['Australia news'
column2: 'Australian politics'
column3: 'Coronavirus'
column4: 'New South Wales'];"Scott Morrison has resisted calls to make rapid antigen tests (RATs) free across the country as he insists the health system can manage the “very different virus” of the Omicron variant. Despite growing pressure to provide free tests more widely – including to vulnerable and low-income groups – the prime minister said subsidised tests would remain limited to people who were close contacts with symptoms. “We’re now in a stage of the pandemic where you can’t just make everything free
column5: ” Morrison told Channel 7’s Sunrise program on Monday. “When someone tells you they want to make something free
column6: someone’s always going to pay for it
column7: and it’s going to be you.” However
column8: he said the government was finalising arrangements to provide concessional access to the tests with costs split 50-50 with the states. He also said that the government’s policy on subsidised tests sent a clear message to the private market that “they can now go and stock their shelves with confidence that they won’t be undercut by the government.”

column1: The Pharmacy Guild and the Australian Medical Association have both criticised the federal government’s handling of the switch to rapid antigen testing as Australians struggle to access the take-home kits from the private market. Last Thursday

column10: and that isn’t affordable. This is a public policy failure the likes of which we haven’t seen in this country before.” He said that at the “very least”
column11: tests should be made freely available to people who could not afford them. The health minister
column12: Greg Hunt
column13: said the government was in the process of securing more RATs and 100m would come into Australia over the next two months. He criticised Labor for suggesting the tests should be freely available. “If there were an unconstrained flow of completely unpriced products – so if there was an infinite supply to an infinite number of people
column14: then
column15: of course
column16: that demand couldn’t be met
column17: ” Hunt said. “The common sense of providing an infinite supply of free goods somehow has been lost in this discussion.”

column1: He said it would be up to the states to decide if they wanted to forgo GST revenue on the sale of the rapid antigen tests
column2: as had occurred with women’s sanitary products. New South Wales recorded 20
column3: 794 new Covid cases on Monday
column4: with Victoria recording 8
column5: 577 and Queensland 4
column6: 249. Experts warned the health system faced being overwhelmed

column8: ” he later told Channel 9. “So the requirements for testing
column9: the requirements for isolation
column10: all of these things have changed because Omicron we now know is about 75% less virulent
column11: less severe than the Delta variant.” Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning

column1: “So we’re now dealing with a very different virus and so we’ve really got to change the way we think about it

column3: rising case numbers were part of the “new phase of the pandemic” and those in hospital were most likely to be unvaccinated or infected with the Delta strain.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/03/scott-morrison-resists-calls-to-provide-free-rapid-covid-tests-to-australians

column7: 'Transport'];"A motorist was caught driving while distracted nine times in the past four years

column1: 5899;5899;Anne review – Maxine Peake exudes raw horror in extraordinary Hillsborough drama;2022-01-02T22:15:29Z;['Jack Seale'];['Television'
column2: 'Television & radio'
column3: 'Culture'];"‘I lost my boy. Kevin Williams. I’m his mum. Anne.” Episode one of Anne
column4: ITV’s measured bio-drama about the Hillsborough campaigner Anne Williams
column5: ends with a small moment that carries the most profound significance. For an hour we’ve watched Williams (Maxine Peake)
column6: whose 15-year-old son Kevin was one of the 97 Liverpool fans killed by a terrace crush at the FA Cup semi-final in Sheffield on 15 April 1989
column7: being battered and swayed by the loss of her child and the agony of not knowing exactly how and why Kevin died. At times she has hidden
column8: sitting smoking late into the night or spending hopeless mornings in bed. But not now. Now
column9: at her first meeting of the Hillsborough Family Support Group
column10: she has stood up to say Kevin’s name and her own out loud. A life’s mission has begun. Future episodes will document how Williams spent nearly a quarter of a century before her death in 2013 challenging official narratives around the disaster
column11: specifically the claim that Kevin could not have been alive beyond 3.15pm on the day of the match
column12: and therefore could not have been saved. The story is one of solidarity in the face of injustice
column13: unending parental love and the confounding ways in which grief can be an inspiration as well as a burden. First
column14: though
column15: the series has to perform faithful groundwork. Opening instalments of dramas like this are difficult. They have to show the life before
column16: that we know is to be ripped apart
column17: without the dramatic ironies becoming heavy. They must show us how events turn an ordinary person into our extraordinary protagonist
column18: but not foreshadow their destiny too blatantly. Anne avoids these traps with assurance. The quick sketch of Kevin (Campbell Wallace) railroading Williams and her husband Steve into letting him go to the game
column19: is all the more affecting for how unremarkable it is: every parent of a teenager knows how it feels to weigh up demands to let them go here or there
column20: never sure if those things are safe. That point is made with minimal fuss
column21: an approach also taken to another potential cliche of the genre – the moment when the catastrophe has a mystical effect on those who cannot know about it yet. On the afternoon of 15 April
column22: Kevin’s sister is playing in the garden. At 3.05pm
column23: just as the match between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest is abandoned
column24: the sun goes in and the air turns cold. From there
column25: the episode is a tapestry of awful incidents tenderly observed
column26: a study of the bewildering eeriness of bereavement. Death means strangers coming to the house; trips to meet other strangers in unfamiliar buildings must be made. For Anne and Steve Williams
column27: that oddness is intensely magnified. The day after the game
column28: they enter the ad hoc system set up in Sheffield to name victims and find loved ones. They move
column29: stunned
column30: through musty halls full of trestle tables
column31: clipboard-wielding volunteers and anxious or already bereft parents
column32: before an appalling scene in a tiny room. Grotesque Polaroids of the unidentified dead are on a noticeboard
column33: numbered. Anne is desperate not to admit it
column34: so Steve (Stephen Walters) has to step forward and say it: Kevin is number fifty-one. Walters and Peake convey the raw horror of the moment with an almost unwatchable intensity. As for strangers at the house
column35: those people include a tabloid reporter posing as a delivery man before taunting the Williamses with The Sun’s despicable THE TRUTH edition and trying to steal a framed family photograph. The programme is careful to acknowledge the heinous behaviour of the press
column36: but the key scene is a visit in 1991 by an Inspector of the West Midlands Police
column37: played with patrician chicanery by Mark Dexter. Ignore the testimonies at the inquest that Kevin was seen alive after 3.15pm
column38: the Inspector says. Those witnesses have realised their mistake and changed their story. Don’t worry about it. The man is instructing Anne Williams
column39: after two years of intense pain and no clear answers
column40: to deny her instincts and accept what she is told. That this is something Anne is not wired to do is what makes Peake
column41: an apparently pale
column42: frail presence with fire beneath her skin
column43: ideal casting. She does the hard yards first
column44: showing us the times when Williams is confused and fallible and nearly beaten by sadness. But by the end of episode one she’s ready to unleash the righteous strength of a working-class woman who has been wronged. In both modes
column45: Peake embodies the role in life that Anne Williams would fulfil with the highest possible distinction: Kevin’s mum.";https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/02/anne-review-maxine-peake-exudes-raw-horror-in-extraordinary-hillsborough-drama

column12: 'Anneliese Dodds'];"More than half of black children in the UK are now growing up in poverty
column13: a new analysis of official data has revealed. Black children are also now more than twice as likely to be growing up poor as white children
column14: according to the Labour party research
column15: which was based on government figures for households that have a “relative low income” – defined as being below 60% of the median
column16: the standard definition for poverty. And over the last decade the total number of black children in poor households more than doubled – although that increase is partly explained by the overall size of the cohort increasing too. The proportion of black children living in poverty went up from 42% in 2010-11 to 53% in 2019-20
column17: the most recent year for which the data is available. The figures were released to the Guardian by the Labour party
column18: which described them as evidence of “Conservative incompetence and denialism about the existence of structural racism”.

column1: The Labour leader
column2: Keir Starmer
column3: has already committed the party to passing a new race equality act
column4: if elected
column5: to tackle structural racism. Further details of what this would entail are expected to be fleshed out in 2022. The party produced its figures by cross-referencing data from the Department for Work and Pensions’ reports on households below average income with population statistics. In 2019-20 4.3 million children (defined as people under 16
column6: or aged 16 to 19 and in full-time education) were living in households in poverty. They accounted for 31% of the UK’s 14 million children. But there was a wide variation among ethnic groups. The Labour research covered nine categories and it said Bangladeshi children are the poorest
column7: with 61% of them living in a poor household. The figures for the other groups were: Pakistani children (55%); black African or Caribbean or black British (53%); other ethnicity (51%); other Asian (50%); mixed ethnicity (32%); Indian (27%); white (26%); and Chinese (12%). There are 2.9 million white children living in poverty
column8: making them by far the largest ethnic cohort
column9: comprising 68% of all children living in poverty. Black children are the next biggest group: with more than 400
column10: 000 living in poverty
column11: they comprise 10% of the child poverty total. The Labour figures show that
column12: among some ethnic groups
column13: children are just as likely now to be living in poverty as they were a decade ago. In 2010-11
column14: 61% of Bangladeshi children were living in poor households – exactly the same figure as at the end of the decade. For Indian children
column15: the chances of living in a poor household have fallen from 34% a decade ago to 27%. For Chinese children
column16: the figure has fallen from 47% to 12%. But for white children
column17: the figure has risen from 24% to 26%; for Pakistani children
column18: it has gone up from 50% to 55%; and for black children it has increased from 42% to 53%. Overall
column19: 27% of all children were living in poor households in 2010-11; the latest figure is 31%. Anneliese Dodds
column20: the shadow secretary of state for women and equalities
column21: whose office produced the figures
column22: said the Conservatives should be ashamed of what they revealed. “There is little wonder that child poverty has skyrocketed over the last decade when Conservative ministers have done so little to tackle the structural inequalities driving it
column23: ” she said. “Conservative incompetence and denialism about the existence of structural racism are driving black children into poverty. Labour has a plan to lift them out of it
column24: with a new race equality act to tackle structural racial inequality at source.” Labour announced its commitment to a race equality act as it published a review last year by Doreen Lawrence
column25: the peer
column26: into the disproportionate impact of Covid on minority ethnic communities. The party has not said exactly what its act would contain
column27: but the Lawrence recommendations
column28: which the party has accepted
column29: would shape its contents. Although much of the Lawrence report focused on Covid-specific issues
column30: it also said the virus had “thrived on structural inequalities that have long scarred British society”. Its recommendations included forcing large employers to publish data on ethnicity pay gaps
column31: having clear targets to close the attainment gap for children and implementing a race equality strategy that has the support of minority ethnic communities. Halima Begum
column32: chief executive at the Runnymede Trust
column33: the race equality thinktank
column34: said the Labour figures
column35: although not surprising
column36: were nevertheless “cause for considerable concern”. She said: “These are not cyclical inequalities that are being flagged
column37: but systemic shortcomings that must be reversed quickly. “But the problems are nuanced. Black children face racism and poverty. But poverty is not defined exclusively by race. So
column38: for more than a decade
column39: the Runnymede Trust has argued that you can’t simply solve the issue of racial inequality without also addressing socio-economic disparities.” In response to Labour claims that the figures were an indictment of its record
column40: a government spokesperson highlighted separate figures showing that in 2019-20 there were 300
column41: 000 fewer children living in absolute low income
column42: after housing costs
column43: than there were in 2010. Absolute low income is defined as below the figure for 60% of median income for 2010
column44: adjusted for inflation. People can fall out of absolute low income if their incomes rise by more than inflation
column45: but can remain in relative low income – the more commonly used benchmark – if other people’s incomes rise by proportionally more. The spokesperson said: “The latest official figures show there were 300
column46: 000 fewer children of all backgrounds in poverty after housing costs than in 2010 and we continue to provide extensive support to reduce this number further. “This includes putting £1
column47: 000 more per year on average into the pockets of the lowest earners through changes to universal credit
column48: increasing the minimum wage next April to £9.50 per hour and helping with the cost of fuel bills.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/02/more-than-half-of-uks-black-children-live-in-poverty-analysis-shows

column3: 'US sports'];"Antonio Brown was apparently frustrated and angry. So he walked away. From the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. And possibly his NFL career. The mercurial wide receiver was kicked off the Buccaneers after a bizarre
column4: shirtless exit from the field before Tom Brady coolly led the Bucs on a 93-yard drive in the final minutes for a 28-24 victory over the New York Jets on Sunday. Coach Bruce Arians said after the game Brown was off the team. “He is no longer a Buc
column5: ” Arians said. “All right? That’s the end of the story. Let’s talk about the guys who went out there and won the game.” Brown’s mid-game meltdown came late in the third quarter with Tampa Bay trailing 24-10. He appeared animated while talking to Mike Evans
column6: who tried to calm his teammate. But Brown stripped off his pads
column7: jersey
column8: gloves and T-shirt – tossing the gloves and T-shirt into the stands – and then walked bare-chested down the sideline and into the end zone. He then waved to fans as jogged through the end zone and into the tunnel at MetLife Stadium.

column1: It appeared to be a show of frustration by Brown
column2: who had three catches for 26 yards. “I’m not talking about it
column3: ” Arians said. “He’s not part of the Bucs.” Brown was suspended last month for three games for violating the league’s Covid-19 protocols. He also has a history of personal conduct issues and bizarre behavior. “It’s a difficult situation
column4: ” Brady said. “Everybody should do what they can to help him in ways that he really needs it. We all love him. We care about him deeply. We want to see him be at his best. Unfortunately
column5: it won’t be with our team. ... I think everyone should be very compassionate and empathetic toward some very difficult things that are happening.” Brady connected with Cameron Brate for a touchdown on fourth-and-goal from the four shortly after Brown’s exit
column6: and the QB finished the Bucs’ rally with a 33-yard touchdown pass to Cyril Grayson with 15 seconds left. The Bucs stuffed Jets QB Zach Wilson on fourth-and-2 at the seven for no gain with New York trying to seal the victory. New York coach Robert Saleh said the play should’ve been a reverse to wide receiver Braxton Berrios
column7: but Wilson had the option to sneak it based on the look. “We did a very poor job of communicating that
column8: ” Saleh said
column9: adding that ”it just makes you sick” because a handoff to Berrios would’ve likely been a first down. Instead
column10: it gave Brady and the Bucs the ball back with 2:12 left. And that was more than enough time. Brady marched the Buccaneers (12-4) down the field on nine plays
column11: zipping a pass to Grayson – who was elevated from the practice squad – for the go-ahead score. It was Brady’s third TD pass of the game and 40th of the season
column12: joining him with Drew Brees as the only players to throw for 40 touchdowns in consecutive seasons. He finished 34 of 50 for 410 yards

column7: 'Peng Shuai'];"Sport is politics. There is no question about that at the beginning of the year when the Winter Olympics are taking place in Beijing and the World Cup in Qatar. You only have to open the newspaper these days. The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung
column8: the Guardian
column9: the Polish Gazeta Wyborcza and other quality media
column10: which gather many voices to report on the world
column11: deal on their sports pages with the diplomatic boycott of the Olympics by the USA
column12: Great Britain and other countries
column13: the “quiet diplomacy” of the International Olympic Committee and workers’ rights in Qatar. One news item received particular attention worldwide. Out of concern for the life of Peng Shuai
column14: the former world No 1 in doubles
column15: the WTA has suspended all tournaments in China. In total
column16: about 30% of the WTA’s revenue comes from China
column17: with the annual finals in Shenzhen paying out the equivalent of about €12m (£10m)
column18: more than any other event in women’s tennis. But the players are now saying: we’ll do without.

column1: Taking a strong stance is a tradition in women’s tennis
column2: whose history is marked by personalities. In the 1960s
column3: the WTA founder and multiple grand slam winner Billie Jean King campaigned for equal treatment and pay for the genders. Later
column4: the multiple Wimbledon winner Martina Navratilova campaigned for gay rights. The supposedly weaker sex actually dominates the fighting mode. Female athletes have turned their federation into an independent institution. The WTA’s consistent decisions send a signal: you can say no in sport. Negotiations require an interplay – approaching each other
column5: but also withdrawing from time to time. Countries in which human rights are not universal also invest in football. These countries are part of global sport and offer so much money that many find it difficult to refuse. The German television broadcaster ZDF recently ran a hidden-camera investigation. The reporter spoke to workers from Nepal
column6: Pakistan and Bangladesh who build stadiums and roads in Qatar. Eight of them lived in one room; they earn €300 a month each but have been waiting months for their salaries. The report also featured attractive match scenes from the 2021 Arab Cup and all eight new stadiums. In a country with 2.9 million inhabitants there are now eight of the most modern
column7: expensive and beautiful stadiums in the world
column8: less than an hour’s drive apart. The ZDF report was in anticipation of the dilemma facing the 2022 World Cup: people know about the situation in Qatar but they enjoy watching the spectacular pictures and the best teams. When the 1978 World Cup took place under the direction of the Argentinian military regime
column9: many players had no answer to questions about human rights. Today
column10: the world can no longer be viewed so naively. Everyone involved knows better than before about what is going on in faraway continents. Most footballers also have more time to deal with such issues
column11: due to advanced professionalisation. Public figures like them are also expected to inform themselves of matters outside their bubble. Now that the world has become a village
column12: everyone knows the conditions in Qatar.

column1: Some footballers are stepping in and calling for human rights to be respected. “I think more attention needs to be paid to this kind of thing in the future when awarding contracts
column2: ” the Germany international Leon Goretzka has said. Finland’s captain
column3: Tim Sparv
column4: wrote in an open letter: “We woke up too late
column5: I woke up too late.” Sparv called on players
column6: media and fans to talk about working conditions in Qatar. On a small scale
column7: this argument is already bearing fruit. When a black player was racially insulted by a spectator during the third division match between MSV Duisburg and VfL Osnabrück in Germany in December
column8: the teams forced a stop. All parties quickly agreed that they wanted to set an example: players
column9: both clubs
column10: referees
column11: the association and fans from both camps. The individual is not powerless; people can make a difference. Small is where you start
column12: big is where it can end. Greta Thunberg was 15 when she stood alone on a street in Stockholm to draw attention to climate change. Many joined in
column13: and Fridays for Future has since put the environment on the global agenda. This has changed politics. Football too: the 2024 European Championship in Germany can be judged a success only if it takes ecological aspects into account. Our preparations are under way.

column1: I consider myself lucky to have been born into a democracy. It was not long ago that the conditions in my home country were different. Three decades ago Germany was divided
column2: the eastern part a dictatorship. Other nations in Europe were also going through a change. The 1964 European Championship took place in a fascist state
column3: and Spain’s team won its home tournament in front of General Franco. He was still in power when the 1982 World Cup was awarded to Spain. By the time it took place
column4: Spain was a democracy. Major sporting events
column5: especially in football
column6: generate enormous attention. Nowadays
column7: European Championships and World Cups require everyone who takes part to deal with working conditions and human rights. At Euro 2024 in Germany
column8: too
column9: Europe will negotiate with each other how we want to live together. • Philipp Lahm’s column appears regularly in the Guardian. It is produced in partnership with Oliver Fritsch at Zeit Online
column10: the German online magazine
column11: and is being published in several European countries.";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2022/jan/02/sports-stars-can-no-longer-plead-ignorance-they-have-political-power-and-must-use-it

column1: This sort of performance

column7: 'National parks'];"Nothing beats the New Zealand bush. The writer Ashleigh Young once tweeted: “Sometimes NZ writers say ‘the forest’ instead of ‘the bush’ (and they definitely mean ‘the bush’) because they are nervous about saying ‘the bush’. Bring back the bush. If everyone does it
column8: we will be fine.” So here I am
column9: proclaiming
column10: “I love the bush!” Perhaps this is my opinion as an outdoor enthusiast and bisexual
column11: but “bush” is the more accurate descriptor for the native flora of Aotearoa. Our bush is dense and scratchy
column12: inured to the trample of boots. Our bush is thick and lush all year round
column13: as few native plant species are deciduous. Our bush is not some wan forest: it is wild and overgrown
column14: it does not encourage easy passage.

column1: As my family were neither middle class nor Pākehā (white European)
column2: I didn’t venture into the bush until I was an adult. It’s now been 10 years since my first foray into the bush but I’ll never forget that first experience. A friend
column3: who grew up with the bush
column4: convinced me to come on a two-day tramp. I had no idea what I was getting into. Surely a tramp was just a long walk. How difficult could a walk in the bush possibly be? I lacked outdoor gear but my friend sorted me with her spares
column5: save for tramping boots as our feet were not the same size. “Maybe I’ll get into tramping
column6: ” I decided
column7: buying the cheapest pair of boots I could find. The route was up Avalanche Peak
column8: the only poled summit in Arthur’s Pass
column9: a national park famous for its bush of silver
column10: red and mountain tawhai (beech) trees. I did not appreciate the bush on the way up. Instead
column11: I cursed the 1
column12: 100m ascent that left my lungs burning and back saturated with sweat. I envied my friend’s fitness that allowed her to walk ahead and find features of the bush to show me: the peat floor carpeted with prickly shield fern
column13: the sponge moss and lace lichen
column14: and the understorey of snow totara
column15: bearing edible cashew apple-shaped berries.

column1: I thought the uphill would be the hardest part but then I discovered what happens once you leave the bush. Past the bushline
column2: the tall trees were replaced by stout
column3: hardy shrubs. Some people refer to this as alpine scrub but I think you could equally call it alpine bush. This alpine bush featured plants I had never seen before
column4: like the Mount Cook lily
column5: with bristly white petals and leaves as tough as leather. This bush was patchy and uneven to walk on
column6: and somehow I was as slow on the flat as I was uphill. Soon
column7: the alpine bush too disappeared
column8: and the only vegetation was the moss and lichen that grew on the rock and shingle we crunched underfoot. My friend pointed out a fan of broken rock
column9: ranging from palm-sized to head-sized
column10: that dropped down into an open plain. We had to get down that scree slope to get to our accommodation for the night. There’s an art to running down scree slopes
column11: which my friend demonstrated
column12: where one “surfs” along the surface of the debris. She pulled away like a motor boat from a jetty
column13: generating a clattering wave of cascading rock
column14: leaving me to tread cautiously in her wake. I tried to replicate her movements but I fell repeatedly until I gave up. I sat on my bum and thought back to earlier in the day. I never fell in the bush. The bush was sheltered
column15: the bush was safe. I wished I was back in the bush. I ended up bum-shuffling my way down the slope
column16: tearing up the seat of my cotton shorts in the process.

column1: Thankfully that first trip didn’t put me off tramping and since then I’ve visited bush all around the country. There’s the bush of Kahurangi national park
column2: which looks blue from a distance
column3: and the goblin forests of Taranaki
column4: named for the gnarled trees and the mosses that hang off them. I can now enjoy the cool
column5: crisp air of the bush around me and look forward to where it may take me. Rose Lu is a writer
column6: software developer and cable car owner from Wellington. Her essay collection All Who Live on Islands is out now What’s your favourite wild place? If you would like to contribute to the series tell us about it in 200 words and send it to newzealand@theguardian.com";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/as-i-bum-shuffled-my-way-down-the-scree-at-avalanche-peak-i-wished-i-was-back-in-the-bush

column5: 'Sport'];"It had been tempting to fixate on Thomas Tuchel’s decision to drop Romelu Lukaku from the Chelsea squad after that interview. But it was a measure of what followed during 90 pulsating minutes that the club’s record signing – and all the drama around him – came to feel like a footnote. Tuchel said he did not select Lukaku because his situation had represented too much of a distraction on the eve of the game – what with him saying he was unhappy at the club and questioning the manager’s system. column10: 'Antibiotics'];"Though at times it can feel hard to believe – especially in recent weeks
column11: perhaps – this pandemic will not last for ever. With more than 5 million dead and huge economic and social costs
column12: its toll has been immense
column13: and unnecessarily so. Secrecy in China
column14: complacency in Europe
column15: reckless and callous rightwing populism in the US and Brazil
column16: and the inequity in vaccine distribution have all contributed. Yet if we learn its lessons
column17: we will be better prepared next time. For there will be a next time. Covid is not a once-in-a-century crisis – an idea encouraged by its arrival 101 years after the last major pandemic
column18: the “Spanish” flu
column19: which killed at least 50 million. The mega-flu outbreak that many experts had seen as the next great threat is no less likely to arrive because Covid got here first. A pandemic of similar scale is likely within the next six decades
column20: and could happen at any point in that timespan
column21: according to research published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) in August; others have put the risk of a comparable crisis within the next decade at around one in four. And as Prof Dame Sarah Gilbert
column22: the creator of the Oxford/AstraZeneca jab
column23: warned recently: “The next one could be worse. It could be more contagious
column24: or more lethal
column25: or both.” The price we pay then will depend on what we do now
column26: using Covid’s lessons. We have seen international scientific collaboration
column27: incredible dedication by researchers and healthcare staff
column28: and the ability and willingness of local and national communities to pull together. Richer nations will be less likely to take health security for granted. Covid-19 has also shown that the right decisions at the right time can make a profound difference. With a dozen direct flights from Wuhan each week
column29: Taiwan was heavily exposed to risk. But
column30: driven by the experience of the 2002-03 Sars epidemic
column31: it rapidly introduced health screening for arrivals
column32: border controls
column33: effective contact tracing and mask-wearing
column34: and gave its citizens clear and consistent messages. Fewer than 900 of its 22 million-strong population have died. Wishful thinking Yet the global response has too often looked like a triumph of science and a failure of politics. The wishful thinking seen in the first wave has been repeated again and again. And the way we live is increasing the risks of another major pandemic. The aforementioned research published in August in PNAS estimated that the probability of novel disease outbreaks will grow threefold in the next few decades. International trade and travel allow diseases to spread far more quickly. Some scientists argue that we have already entered another great pandemic: a wave of antimicrobial resistance that could see tens of millions die from currently treatable diseases
column35: coming gradually
column36: but ultimately proving far more punishing than the sudden Covid crisis. The overuse of antibiotics to treat humans and livestock is endangering us all. Both the frequency and severity of “spillover” events
column37: where diseases jump from animals to humans
column38: have increased as we encroach on and destroy animal habitats. Zoonotic diseases
column39: transmitted from animals
column40: represent around three-quarters of newly emerging diseases. And research suggests that
column41: as many species become extinct
column42: those that thrive are more likely to be ones known to host pathogens dangerous to humans. Though all this is frequently presented as a developing-world issue
column43: the global north is responsible too. Deforestation is often driven by the cultivation of crops for export. The focus on the perils of “bush meat” and “wet markets” has not been matched by attention to the risks posed by intensive
column44: industrialised farming. Humans will come into even closer contact with nature as global heating reduces available land
column45: and will be pushed into denser habitation and forced to move en masse. Existing diseases such as chikungunya may spread
column46: as warmer temperatures allow their insect carriers to move into new areas. Covid would have been far worse without the pandemic preparations that countries had been making for years
column47: however inadequate they proved. Many of the proposals now are essentially for more (or a better version) of the same
column48: focusing on data collection and analysis
column49: improvements to public health communication and exploratory work that could accelerate the development of vaccines and treatments. Above all
column50: experts warn that there needs to be a massive expansion of surveillance to detect novel pathogens. Prioritising public health An expert panel convened by the G20 has called for a doubling of international financing to tackle major weaknesses in surveillance and other pandemic preparedness requirements
column51: to $15bn a year. The price tag is tiny set beside the cost of Covid
column52: but many fear that even now our leaders are reluctant to spend enough. Specific preparations to fend off or tackle another pandemic could mean everything from better protective gear for abattoir workers to rethinking the ventilation requirements of buildings. But protecting ourselves also requires far more fundamental reassessments. Beyond addressing the climate crisis
column53: it means prioritising public health and acting on what the pandemic has demonstrated so graphically: that inequality – both within and between nations – kills; and it kills mostly
column54: but not solely
column55: the poor. Covid (and especially the Omicron variant) has shown that we cannot isolate ourselves from the physical or economic effects of disease elsewhere. By hogging vaccines and opposing patent waivers
column56: wealthier nations have imperilled their own citizens too. They should think again
column57: and make amends by helping to improve regional manufacturing capacity for tests
column58: vaccines and treatments. Since global solutions are needed
column59: it is positive that the World Health Assembly has agreed that work should begin on a pandemic accord covering prevention
column61: even if its parameters fall short of the tougher treaty that many hoped for. Finally
column62: we must address questions of trust
column63: and tackle the fissures in our societies – in many ways deepened by Covid. The challenge is truly daunting. But so is the alternative: “What we are going through is also a crisis of meanings
column64: ” Elif Shafak has written. “Do we want to go back to the way things were before the pandemic? Was that really normal?” The risk is to our bodily health as well as our wellbeing in the broader sense that Shafak describes. Covid has reminded us that disease is a social as well as a physical phenomenon
column65: produced and shaped by the ways we live. Will we do what is needed to protect ourselves?";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/the-guardian-view-on-the-next-pandemic-can-we-learn-covids-lessons

column15: 'World news'];"One of the architects of the Northern Ireland peace deal has said Boris Johnson and the former Brexit minister Lord Frost have risked “all the work” the previous generation of politicians put into the Belfast Good Friday agreement by putting their hard ideological beliefs ahead of people. column1: He also questioned why Frost had made the issue of the European court of justice a red line in negotiations on the Northern Ireland protocol when it was not responsible for either the practical difficulties in trade or the identity politics that has been heightened by the row over the Irish Sea border. column9: 'Disability'];The family of an autistic man confined to an apartment and fed through a hatch are planning a legal challenge against his conditions

column11: whose 24-year-old son has been detained under the Mental Health Act since September 2017 at Cheadle Royal hospital in Cheshire

Inspectors “observed a staff member pushing and forcing a person to sit in their wheelchair against their will” and others using derogatory language. There were not enough qualified staff

column14: 000 reported new daily infections. A number of experts have questioned if such reports cause unnecessary worry

Fauci said those concerns contributed to the decision by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) last week to reduce the recommended isolation period for those who have tested positive but are asymptomatic
column28: from 10 days to five. “You’re certainly gonna see stresses on the system

column6: 'Cancer'];"Good poo donors are so hard to find they’re sometimes called “unicorns”. These elusive
column7: healthy creatures service a market for faecal transplants that is growing rapidly as evidence of its benefits mounts. Emerging science shows that a human’s microbiome – their constellation of gut microbes – has a far greater effect on health than anyone previously imagined. This enormous ecosystem we host in our bodies includes bacteria
column8: fungi
column9: viruses and more. The collective genetic material in the microbiome performs myriad functions that affect our mood
column10: our immunity
column11: and our physical and mental health. Crappy western diets and antibiotics are depleting our microbiota. And in some cases
column12: a person’s microbiome is disordered enough that it needs a little boost from someone else’s.

column1: Restoring them to health has become a very serious scientific endeavour
column2: as the diversity of our gut bacteria is linked to everything from depression to how we respond to cancer treatment. The transfer of healthy stool into the gastrointestinal tract of an unhealthy recipient has been proven to treat people with intestinal conditions
column3: including the superbug Clostridium difficile colitis
column4: or C diff – which can cause diarrhoea
column5: sepsis and even death. But as scientific understanding of the microbiome improves
column6: the possibilities of faecal transplants are expanding. Now researchers are working on a “super stool” – a poo pellet you can eat that mimics a so-called unicorn’s special abilities. Replicating unicorns BiomeBank’s office is located in a hub in the suburbs of Adelaide. Chief medical officer Sam Costello and chief executive Thomas Mitchell wear lanyards emblazoned with depictions of bacteria – and Costello jokes that an organic-looking spill on his is probably a real-life experiment. The biotech company has been on a unicorn hunt. This place is home to a stool bank – and it’s a place where designer poo transplants are made.

column1: There’s a special donor room (a glorified toilet) where poo donations are received. There’s a lab with an anaerobic work station
column2: where donors’ bacteria strains are put into a “secret sauce” to grow and then isolate strains. Those strains are categorised and catalogued for future use. BiomeBank’s head of donor screening
column3: Dr Emily Tucker
column4: says there’s a long list of requirements for a stool donor. They have to be healthy
column5: obviously. They have to be screened for infections. A detailed history of their medical
column6: travel and antibiotic history is taken. Those who make it through all the assessments are enrolled for an eight-week program where they have to turn up on time
column7: fill out a questionnaire
column8: then (ahem) make a deposit inside a special room. So what happens if there aren’t enough unicorns? That question inspired BiomeBank’s latest endeavour – to replicate the contents of a unicorn’s guts. The poo factory People are building libraries of the very best that poo has to offer
column9: and BiomeBank is part of the effort to categorise premium stool strains. Costello
column10: a gastroenterologist
column11: says that humans historically had much more diverse microbiota. We lived more closely with other people and with animals
column12: and we ate more unprocessed food. There’s evidence
column13: he says
column14: that this depletion is evident across society – particularly western society.

column1: He describes a “microbial extinction event” in the modern world. As on Earth
column2: so it is in our intestinal system – we’re living with the consequences of a hollowed-out ecosystem. Mitchell explains that in BiomeBank’s first generation of microbial therapy they extracted the right bacteria
column3: freeze dried it and put it in a capsule. Patients can take it orally to treat specific infections. This generation has already been rolled out in hospitals
column4: and
column5: if approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration
column6: it will be the first microbial therapy in the world approved as a biologic (it currently has provisional approval). Then there’s the second generation – a replication. Think of the unicorns as Adam and Eve types
column7: but their genomic sequences can be reproduced. You can grow them. Isolate them. Identify them
column8: name them
column9: put them in a library
column10: and gradually build up knowledge about what each strand can do.

column1: And when you hit a vein of gold – a bacterial strain that sorts out a deficiency in someone’s microbiota – you scale it. Then you put it that bespoke bacterial recipe in a capsule that someone else swallows. “It’s a new way to treat disease
column2: ” Mitchell says. “It’s a little factory.” Why is the microbiome so important? From the moment we’re born
column3: and throughout our lives
column4: our microbiota are shaped by our environmental and dietary inputs. Babies born by caesarean section have a different mix to those delivered vaginally
column5: a major study has found. The C-section babies pick up more strains from the hospital
column6: which could explain higher rates of immune problems such as asthma and allergies in those babies. Prof Felice Jacka
column7: director of Deakin University’s Food and Mood Centre
column8: is a nutritional psychiatrist (and the author of There’s a Zoo in My Poo
column9: which features recipes for “better bog burgers”
column10: “farty toast” and “zoo poo stew”). The centre examines the “mindbogglingly complex” links between diet
column11: gut and brain health. “You have all these organisms that interact with each other in a way that’s impossible to map at this stage
column12: ” she says. “We’re still really at the beginning of working out what microbiota can do.”

column1: And Jacka’s a fan of the “super stool” plan
column2: not least because “giving people other people’s shit” has a bit of the icks about it. “It’s absolutely worth doing
column3: ” she says. “Finding those super donors is hard. Only about 3% of people qualify … Those super poopers are kind of rare
column4: so it you can distill that
column5: if BiomeBank can come up with a stool equivalent
column6: it’d be awesome.” Jacka
column7: as one of the world’s top microbiome experts
column8: says scientists are still working out exactly how the gut-brain axis works
column9: how the microbiome affects health
column10: and how it can be manipulated. There are dozens of studies under way in Australia
column11: but existing research has already shown that a bad diet – like the standard American diet – leads to increased inflammation in the body
column12: which means a higher risk of cancer.

column1: A team from the Imperial College London and the University of Pittsburgh compared African Americans to rural South Africans. The volunteers were tested
column2: then swapped diets and were tested again. After just two weeks on the fibre-rich rural diet
column3: the Americans had significantly less colon inflammation and a lower cancer risk. Unfortunately
column4: the rural group went the other way. Cancer and the gut The Food and Mood Centre is studying nutrition and its effect on depression
column5: on muscle and heart health
column6: on psychotic disorders
column7: on post-traumatic stress disorder
column8: eating disorders and a host of other health concerns. Jacka nominates cancer research as one of the most exciting fields in microbiome studies. Data show better responses to treatment
column9: particularly immunotherapy
column10: in people with more diverse gut microbes. But she warns much research is still nascent
column11: and that industries out to make a buck are capitalising on it too quickly
column12: selling products with vague promises of promoting “gut health”. “Be aware
column13: keep an open mind
column14: but not so open your brain falls out. Or your wallet
column15: more to the point
column16: ” she advises.

column1: The University of New South Wales’ Microbiome Research Centre is studying the effect of the microbiome on cancer
column2: women and children’s health
column3: infection
column4: immunity
column5: inflammation
column6: critical care
column7: and mental health and neuroscience. The centre’s director
column8: Prof Emad El-Omar
column9: says there while there is advanced research showing the benefit of a more diverse microbiome (and therefore faecal transplants) when dealing with C diff
column10: in other disorders researchers are still working through what works
column11: and how. He says the the number of genes in these microorganisms dwarfs that of the human genome. “It’s a very exciting field
column12: but there’s still a bit of work to be done to maximise the benefit for all humanity.” And he agrees with Jacka
column13: that the “wellness” industry is sometimes jumping the gun on “gut health”. How can you help your gut? At this stage
column14: poo transplants are only recommended
column15: or useful
column16: in very specific cases. But everyone can improve their microbiome – and you don’t need supplements. Jacka says for most people changing their diet is enough to change their bacteria. “To have what we understand to be a healthy microbiota
column17: where the microbes present are associated with healthy conditions and those that aren’t present that are associated with unhealthy conditions
column18: we already know what you should do
column19: ” she says.

column1: “Eat lots of plants
column2: different types of plants
column3: different-coloured plants and throw in some fermented foods.” Think kimchi
column4: kombucha and sauerkraut. And think fibre. Jacka says that with typical western diets your gut microbiota is so “weak
column5: wan
column6: pale and deficient” that it just can’t cope with fibre. Then when people try to incorporate more roughage
column7: they get gas or a stomach ache. Some people then mistakenly think they have irritable bowel syndrome or a gluten intolerance and back off the fibrous foods. You have to start gently
column8: she says. Increase the amount and type of fibre gradually. “The answer to a problem with beans
column9: ” she says
column10: “is actually more beans”. Costello says BiomeBank hopes to be “part of the global effort work to solve this big problem
column11: which is this loss of microbial diversity associated with disease … on a massive scale”. “We see it as a modern pandemic
column12: ” Costello says. And there is plenty of work still to be done. At BiomeBank
column13: researchers are beginning to understand the microbiome strains in frozen storage. Then there are the many strains yet to be understood – we don’t know yet what they might one day be capable of. Costello and Mitchell call that library of the known and unknown
column14: next door to the unicorns’ toilet
column15: the “cave of wonders”.";https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/03/super-poo-the-emerging-science-of-stool-transplants-and-designer-gut-bacteria

column5: 'Society'];"Pruning is usually a technique applied to roses in winter
column6: but more recently the gardening term has been cropping up whenever sociologists talk about our social lives. People have been pruning friends. Confined to our homes
column7: or separated by borders
column8: with too much time gifted to us in isolation
column9: and new ways to communicate online
column10: experts say we’ve unwittingly – or in some cases very deliberately – socially distanced ourselves out of a social life. Some say the silver lining is that we’ve been cured of Fomo
column11: others say it heralds a widening of the already growing loneliness gap. So has everyone Marie Kondoed their mates
column12: and what does this mean for the future of friendship?

column1: Bryan and his wife have two children
column2: aged six and four. They haven’t really made any new friends in the past two years
column3: and they dropped out of contact with a couple of close friends. “Just through no energy
column4: nothing to talk about
column5: no social setting
column6: or parent life commitments.” The couple thought they might make new friends when their eldest started primary school but rolling lockdowns stymied those opportunities. Meanwhile
column7: there is one friend Bryan doesn’t know how to approach. “It’s the one that hurts the most – but I think maybe I thought the friendship was stronger than it was
column8: ” he says. “Nothing bad happened … I just … had to stop trying to make social things happen.” Roger Patulny
column9: an associate professor of sociology at the University of Wollongong
column10: says a lot of people “got very serious and they focused on the people most important to them in their lives”. “So there was sort of a bunkering down … The difficulty now is adjusting to coming out of that
column11: and reengaging in those more distant connections.” It’s possible that Bryan was pruned
column12: or that he subconsciously made the cut himself. Now
column13: many people like Bryan genuinely don’t know where to start when it comes to rebuilding their social lives. We’re caught between re-embracing the office
column14: the gym
column15: the classroom and wanting to resist these places entirely. The incidental friendships of those spaces
column16: along with the opportunity to make new friends
column17: is still not a given
column18: and effort needs to be made to reach out and rebuild. ‘Particular groups were more vulnerable to losing friends’ Patulny and colleague Marlee Bower from the Matilda Centre for Research in Mental Health and Substance Use at the University of Sydney have surveyed more than 2
column19: 000 Australians over the past two years to capture a collective picture of people’s interactions
column20: lifestyles and plans during and after lockdown. Given Australia’s early
column21: if temporary
column22: exit from lockdown last year
column23: it offers a unique glimpse not just about Australians’ experience during lockdown but importantly
column24: and pertinently
column25: many months post-lockdown.

column1: Some key findings came out of the study
column2: says Patulny. “Social networks have become more insular and bonding-oriented
column3: plus particular groups of people were more vulnerable to losing friends
column4: including singles
column5: or those with social anxiety
column6: physical and mental disabilities – anyone lacking ‘prior social capital’. Then there were the people who were caught at major intersections of their life journey – think finishing school/starting uni/having kids; they could be more vulnerable to long-term disconnection and loneliness.” Like Bryan with his child starting school
column7: Reggie was unlucky enough to be hovering at a “life intersection” when the pandemic hit. She completed year 12 in 2020. The opportunity to make or cement friendships has been curtailed especially severely for young people. “The fear that we have missed out on so much … Makes me want to be in a million places at one time
column8: ” she says. But as with any aspect of this pandemic
column9: the most vulnerable members of the community have suffered the biggest fallout. “Those lacking physical health
column10: social capital and digital interactive skills are already more marginalised and at greater risk of loneliness in the post-Covid-19 world
column11: ” Patulny warns. It’s too early to tell whether that has the potential to “grow into entrenched cultures of loneliness
column12: or an expanded ‘loneliness gap’”
column13: but even the general signs pre-pandemic point to people having fewer friends. Thirty years ago
column14: 33% of US adults reported having 10 or more close friends
column15: not counting relatives. Now
column16: 13% say that. People already had less time to invest in friendships (one 2018 study says it takes 50 hours together to make a casual friend
column17: and 90 hours before you consider them a good friend) but the unique social dilemmas imposed by the pandemic could have serious long-term consequences for some people. Melbourne-based counsellor Monica spoke to many single people who were worried in the midst of lockdown about whether they’d be picked to be in a bubble or asked to join a picnic. Restrictions on the number of humans interacting meant grown adults were once again reduced to the schoolyard dilemma of picking their one best friend. “Often they weren’t asked
column18: and they were too afraid to take the initiative to ask anyone else themselves
column19: ” says Monica. “That perceived rejection
column20: real or otherwise
column21: has now really dented their confidence going back out into the world.”

column1: Pat struggled with social connection and loneliness pre-pandemic and is now trying to find avenues where they can make connections after lockdowns. They’re not having much luck so far. “It’s funny
column2: actually
column3: I didn’t feel lonely at all during lockdown – but as soon as things opened up this year and last
column4: it started up again.” ‘It’s cut to the core of people for me’ For many older people cut off from families and traditional get-togethers with friends
column5: the pandemic offered a crash course in online communication
column6: in a way that could continue to shape how they keep in touch with people. Research from the Australian Communications and Media Authority shows that the number of people aged 75 and over using social media and emails to connect doubled. Without the physical context of the cafe
column7: the office or the gym
column8: people found other ways to
column9: almost instantly
column10: rank and order our friends. There were the dozens of designated WhatsApp groups
column11: the few friends you pinged with random texts about recipes or dogs
column12: the handful of people you’d DM on Instagram
column13: family you’d fight with in the Facebook comments
column14: colleagues doomed to Zoom
column15: and the one friend you might actually pick up the phone to. So where do those friends rank now? It helps to start by asking ourselves exactly what friends are for. Countless studies tell us why we need them
column16: including linking them to the health of our hearts. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle might offer some clues. Friends were central to his overall conception of what constitutes a good life
column17: and what it means to be human. But even the philosopher ranked his pals into three different types of friendship: friendships of utility
column18: friendships of pleasure and “friendships of the good”. Co-workers and classmates fall under friendships of utility. A friend that sparks joy comes under friendships of pleasure – the friends of love affairs
column19: book clubs
column20: footy teams. But most important of all are those friendships of the good
column21: which are based upon mutual respect
column22: admiration and a strong desire to “aid and assist the other person because one recognises an essential goodness in them”. These top-shelf companions have most sustained us in the past two years
column23: and they’re also the ones we’re most keen to keep.

column1: Patulny and Bower’s study finds that “rather than experiencing a wholesale loss in connections and increased loneliness
column2: many instead consolidated networks
column3: and shifted from broad
column4: locally-focused bridging networks towards more selective
column5: online
column6: bonding networks”. For many
column7: a shared experience of a deeply traumatic time has either solidified existing friendships or forged new significant friends. Stephanie made local friends for the first time during the pandemic. Parents from her children’s school
column8: who hadn’t known each well
column9: started spilling their guts on WhatsApp once they went into lockdown. Then Stephanie’s young daughter contracted Covid. “They were the first to drop things
column10: share information with the school and protect our family. Local friends are a new thing for me … I think it’s easier to become deep friends more quickly
column11: to say I’m not doing OK and to be more open for others to say the same. It’s cut to the core of people for me.” Rose lived alone throughout the pandemic. “It was about vulnerability. I realised once I opened up about what I was going through
column12: that created room for my friends to open up too. Being real with each other through Covid brought us closer. During lockdowns
column13: I used socials a lot to connect. But now I love socialising in person
column14: more than before. I’m normally introverted
column15: but iso was too lonely
column16: so I’ve swung in the other direction towards extroversion. I’m throwing parties
column17: where once upon a time I dreaded those. And I’m going out of my way to make new friends.” But while it’s wonderful to focus on the friendships that enrich us
column18: Patulny and Bower warn that we can’t forget “the cost of potentially increased social and collective loneliness through losing more distant community connections”. As we all muddle through maintaining a social life while continuing to deal with rolling uncertainty
column19: for some the future of friendship will mean offering people the space to flake on a party
column20: to not text back
column21: to let friends check back in when they’re ready. For others
column22: it’ll mean jumping at any opportunity to meet new mates. Like Bryan and his wife
column23: Melbourne based Cynthia hadn’t really met anyone new over the last couple of years. But she recently struck up a conversation with a stranger at the local cafe
column24: and liked them immediately. At first she tried to play it cool
column25: but eventually she figured “fuck it – I invited them over for a BBQ. Nothing beats a new friend crush
column26: and it’s been a while.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/03/why-pruning-friends-has-been-so-common-during-the-pandemic
