column1: 5936;5936;When grit isn’t great: letting go rather than pushing through can help our wellbeing |  Gaynor Parkin;2022-01-02T16:30:23Z;['N/A'];['Mental health'
column2: 'Psychology'
column3: 'Health'
column4: 'Health & wellbeing'];"Is it possible to let that go? Is there someone else who can help you? Could you defer it for a week? To each of these queries and other similar ones
column5: Mary gave a firm shake of the head and an even firmer “no”. This was a pattern. Our sessions had a real “groundhog day” feel to them. Mary would arrive looking harassed and tired
column6: tell me how frantic her week had been and how many things there were still to do. We tried problem solving and planning
column7: prioritising and all manner of productivity hacks. Nothing shifted. Mary’s struggle was also too familiar. She reminded me of many other high-achieving people I have worked with who had sought help for exhaustion
column8: or health difficulties or burnout. One of their hallmarks is seemingly endless resources of grit. American psychologist Angela Duckworth is well known for her research on the phenomenon of grit: Grit entails working strenuously toward challenges
column9: maintaining effort and interest over years despite failure
column10: adversity and plateaus in progress. Her studies indicate that grit is more predictive of success and achievement in areas like education and business than intelligence or natural ability. Greater grit is associated with people sticking it out through difficult periods and staying longer in a job. Interestingly
column11: research also indicates that those with higher grit are happier and more satisfied with their lives. This finding certainly didn’t hold true for Mary. Is there a downside to too much grit? A 2015 study found that people with high levels of grit often persist with difficult tasks to their own detriment. Participants had to solve as many puzzles as they could – but some of the puzzles were unsolvable. Grittier individuals spent more time attempting to solve unsolvable puzzles and solved fewer overall than their less gritty counterparts. The researchers’ conclusion? There is value in knowing when to quit.

column1: Discussing this knowledge at an intellectual level is one thing. Translating it into a felt sense that some change is possible is much harder. One of the shifts in my work with Mary came after a good discussion about strengths and vulnerabilities. Often we use our strengths to protect ourselves from experiencing our vulnerabilities. Perhaps I over-work to keep feelings of vulnerability at bay
column2: or book myself up with social engagements to avoid noticing I’m feeling alone. It’s smart coping
column3: but it has a downside. Overusing strengths can mean we can rely on them too much
column4: or use them too often
column5: or miss noticing that they are not so helpful any more. Mary’s grit was definitely a strength and it was definitely over used. Gently
column6: to make sure we didn’t trigger too much emotional distress
column7: we brainstormed what the grit might be protecting her from. Mary’s protections again reminded me of other high achievers: protecting her from asking for help; protecting her from feeling vulnerable or not in control; protecting her from feeling that she had somehow failed if she didn’t nail every challenge. Another important insight was helping Mary to recognise that she is living and working in an environment that reinforces grit. Our western culture celebrates the qualities of persistence and striving. We love stories of people triumphing over adversity of all kinds.

column1: We are also quick to criticise anyone who appears to “give up”. The great basketball player Michael Jordan declared: “If you quit once it becomes a habit. Never quit.” Not persevering is seen as the “soft option” or taking the easy road out. For Mary
column2: moving away from too much grit then needed to be an individual journey but also a shared experience. Another young woman I worked with who was a successful athlete gave a presentation on grit to her team and coaches to spark better conversations about persevering and also recovery
column3: when to push and when to pause. When we speak freely about our struggles with family
column4: colleagues and friends
column5: we are better able to identify when someone else
column6: or ourselves
column7: might need a gentle nudge towards pausing instead of pushing. This means we don’t need to walk the path alone. We know from psychological research that we are more likely to succeed and lift our wellbeing with new behaviours if we seek to “add” rather than eliminate (ie set ourselves an “approach” goal rather than an “avoidance” goal). Supporting Mary to practise some active “letting go”
column8: asking for help
column9: learning to ease up on how much she could get done in a day
column10: and to find new hobbies that are more about experiences and being rather than achievements all helped to create some small shifts. And my athlete pulled back from competitions for a period of time to study and have more time with friends. When she returned
column11: her form and performance were better than ever. If you have too much grit
column12: I hope reading this gives you permission to gently check in with yourself (and maybe others). Is this useful for me? When is it not? What else could I do instead? And what other strategies might I learn that enhance my wellbeing rather than deplete it? Interested in how “gritty” you are? Take Angela Duckworth’s grit survey here. • Gaynor Parkin is a clinical psychologist and CEO of Umbrella Wellbeing";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/when-grit-isnt-great-letting-go-rather-than-pushing-through-can-help-our-wellbeing

column7: 'Life and style'];"In the second year of the pandemic I ran 2
column8: 000km. This was a big leap from the first year of the pandemic
column9: and the preceding 50 years
column10: during which I’d only ever dragged my dad bod around the same 5km route a few times a week. In running terms I was stagnating
column11: so my New Year’s resolution was to run further and faster. Go Forrest!

column1: To help
column2: I downloaded a running app to track each effort. The GPS recording of times
column3: routes and distances turned into a challenge (obsession) to go faster and beat personal records. I re-read Murakami’s What I Talk About When I Talk About Running and imagined myself following his disciplined daily running routine. Through January and February the runs stretched to 7km and then 8km. By March they included a 10km weekend effort. My legs ached and there were blisters
column4: but I lost weight and my legs strengthened. In April I was running up to 12km. I registered for a June half-marathon. When May came I was doing 15km runs and by the start of June I’d tackled a 20. This gave me confidence I could complete the race. Then the pandemic kicked-off again. With three days to go
column5: the marathon was cancelled as the Sydney lockdown began. So I ran my own half-marathon length on the day and finished in a respectable time. Murakami would be proud.

column1: While exploring my app’s advanced features
column2: I discovered the goal-setting function. Reviewing my the distance I’d already covered
column3: I set a goal of finishing 2
column4: 000km by the end of the year. It had a nice round-number sound to it. Lock it in. Working from home during lockdown
column5: my day was structured around a lunch run. With nothing going on
column6: it was always the highlight of my day. I ran the deserted Sydney CBD
column7: down an empty George Street to Circular Quay
column8: past the Opera House
column9: through the Botanic Garden.

column1: As restrictions eased I’d head over the Harbour Bridge or to Bondi
column2: the inner west or Centennial Park. Sometimes I’d run with a friend
column3: but usually it was solo. At first the family feigned interest in where I’d gone each day. I’d tell them what I’d seen
column4: how far I’d run. I’d share my pace and my exertion rate. And then they stopped asking.

column1: On a group run in October
column2: while chatting and distracted I rolled an ankle on a kerb. Pain shot up my leg. I hobbled home and removed my sock to find a swollen foot. By evening it turned purple-black. I retired to the sofa with an ice pack and an exaggerated war story for anyone who’d listen. There were doctor trips and an ultrasound and I was advised to take at least a month of rest. I tried to accept the end of my challenge. In the absence of running I felt stale and sluggish. I scoured running websites for recovery-time advice. Most concurred with the doctor but I kept looking until I found shorter recommendations. Call it stupidity or hope
column3: but three weeks after the injury I was doing short walks and a gentle shuffle. In the absence of searing pain I was back. Building up from short
column4: slow runs
column5: I increased to 5km and then 7km in the first week. With no significant complications I reviewed my challenge: I’d lost a lot of time.

column1: I was way behind the schedule. But I was also obsessed
column2: and it was mathematically possible that by running 11km a day for six weeks
column3: with one rest day a week
column4: I could reach my target on Christmas Eve. This would give me an end-of-year break
column5: and a chance to boast at the family Christmas table. It was back on. By December it was hot and wet. I learnt why running is not a summer sport. The morning runs got earlier to avoid the heat but the humidity was miserable and I was dripping and exhausted. With only one day off a week
column6: the relentless schedule became a chore. When the alarm went off I’d lie there dreading the kilometres I had to run before work. But I also had to do it. And I did. On Christmas Eve I completed my challenge. It was the first New Year’s resolution I’d kept longer than two weeks. To celebrate I did the final run with my sons
column7: who came along for the glory lap. Heading up the last hill
column8: I considered whether to keep going in 2022. But then we rounded the last corner and sprinted home
column9: while I ignored the twinges in my ankle. Two-thousand kilometres sounds like a long way – but it feels even further.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/commentisfree/2022/jan/03/in-2021-i-ran-2000km-it-was-the-first-resolution-id-kept-longer-than-two-weeks

column7: 'Northern Territory'];"April Fool’s Day 2015 was just another routine day for us. Late that afternoon I parked the car above Dripstone Cliffs and headed towards Casuarina Beach. Even though you can’t swim in the Northern Territory’s coastal seas because of crocodiles and stingers
column8: I loved the beaches and would run with my Tenterfield terrier
column9: Finn
column10: most evenings. Before letting Finn off his lead
column11: I checked the water for crocs. You can’t be too complacent; dogs have previously been a croc’s dinner here. This was my main concern that evening. Not the approaching storm or getting wet. Storms usually pass as quickly as they come. I remember the storm clouds rolling in
column12: some thunder and lightning from behind us. It didn’t stand out as potentially life-threatening. The remainder was like playing in a rugby game
column13: where you remember running on to the field then waking up concussed
column14: knowing nothing of the game’s final score. I worked as a general paediatrician at Royal Darwin hospital. I woke up there
column15: surrounded by fellow doctors and repeatedly asked them
column16: “Where am I? What happened? Did lightning strike me?” During my night in ICU
column17: I dreamed of being on the beach with Finn
column18: feeling exposed
column19: vulnerable and a bright flash. I don’t recall any other specifics. Thankfully
column20: Finn was safe. He was off his lead and further down the beach.

column1: Over the following weeks
column2: others relayed their recollections. Lots of people were on the beach that night. They saw the flash. Some even felt the ground shudder. They saw me fall and try to get up before collapsing. A medical doctor was running directly behind me. Her quick attendance saved my life. I was resuscitated on the beach before being taken to emergency by ambulance.

column1: Besides my physical signs of a burnt lip and mouth abrasions
column2: they’d picked up a heart arrhythmia and immediately performed CPR. A week later
column3: I broke out in a widespread rash – a delayed reaction to the strike. It looked terrible and was extremely uncomfortable. The doctors and I struggled to find an exact cause. It was either a post-lightning phenomenon
column4: where the lightning strike rattles the bacteria on your skin and you become more susceptible to irritation
column5: or a delayed reaction and an overwhelming stress response to the strike. While it took a few days to settle down
column6: I haven’t had any issues since. Although I only spent a night in ICU
column7: a series of cognitive tests were undertaken with a neuropsychologist
column8: monitoring my heart and brain to ensure there were no lingering effects. I resumed work six weeks later
column9: after the tests returned satisfactory results.

column2: I moved to John Hunter Children’s hospital in Newcastle. I grew up in South Africa
column3: and after uni
column4: I applied for jobs in Australia principally because I wanted to enjoy its renowned beaches and surf. Today
column5: Amalia
column6: my three-year-old daughter
column7: and beach activities occupy every spare minute of my time outside work. I know I’m extremely lucky to be alive. I’m still living the Aussie dream. I don’t have any fear or anxiety about storms
column8: because I don’t remember being struck. They also say lightning never strikes twice. I haven’t stopped running on beaches
column9: or in storms. It hasn’t changed my lifestyle
column10: but it has made me assess my life and what’s important. I don’t take anything for granted these days.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/03/a-day-at-the-beach-lots-of-people-saw-the-flash-they-saw-me-fall-and-try-to-get-up

column4: 'Australian lifestyle'];"Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition where your immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in and around your joints
column5: causing ongoing inflammation and pain. Some people have arthritis in the small joints of their hands and feet. In others
column6: the inflammation involves major joints
column7: such as the shoulders and the hips. Sometimes just getting out of bed and making it through the day with rheumatoid arthritis may feel like all you can manage. “But humans are designed to move
column8: ” says Dr Daniel Lewis
column9: a rheumatologist and chronic pain specialist.

column1: He says every system of the body – from the endocrine system to the nervous system
column2: the musculoskeletal system
column3: the sleep-wake cycle and mental health – is influenced by how physically active we are. “When you stop moving
column4: systems start to collapse
column5: ” he says. “Movement encourages the natural healing function of the body – if you rest
column6: you rust.” Errol Lim
column7: a physiotherapist and the managing director of BJC Health
column8: says that in the early stages of the disease
column9: exercise can help prevent worsening of the joints. In more advanced stages
column10: exercise can help reduce stiffness and pain. It can also improve mood and self-confidence. “There is no form of arthritis that won’t benefit from exercise
column11: and a form of exercise can be found for every individual
column12: irrespective of the pattern of their arthritis
column13: ” Lewis says. “Age is no barrier.” Activities like strength training and low-impact workouts can help relieve the pain. Here is a simple guide that can help you get moving
column14: but it is always best to seek advice from a physiotherapist before you begin an exercise program. The class: hydrotherapy Hydrotherapy can be beneficial in treating rheumatoid arthritis
column15: particularly when the pain makes exercising a challenge. It involves a series of exercises that generally focus on slow
column16: controlled movements done in a warm-water pool. The water temperature is usually 34ºC
column17: warmer than a typical swimming pool. The water supports your weight
column18: and the warmth allows your muscles to relax and eases the pain in your joints
column19: helping you exercise.

column1: The water also provides some resistance to moving your joints. By pushing your arms and legs against the water
column2: you can improve your muscle strength. The move: the deadlift Everyone could benefit from the deadlift exercise
column3: Lim suggests. “That’s a really functional position for all of us
column4: ” he says. “That’s how we lift children
column5: how we lift our luggage
column6: the box from the boot of our car
column7: the six bottles of wine that we carry back from the supermarket.” Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and your hands just outside your legs. Travel your hands along your thighs as you bend your knees and hips
column8: keeping the spine straight. Then slowly lift by straightening the legs
column9: as if you are picking up something from the floor. Lim recommends beginning with this simple movement and then progressing by increasing the number of repetitions or adding lightweights. “It’s a very slow progression.” The deadlift forces you to grip
column10: recruiting the wrist
column11: forearm and shoulder muscles. “A significant percentage of people with rheumatoid arthritis have issues with their upper back and neck
column12: ” Lim says. “This particular exercise can help with that.” The activity: dancing Dancing can be a fun activity to keep the body moving. Dancing can help improve blood circulation and lubricate your joints
column13: improving flexibility. It also releases serotonin and endorphins in your brain
column14: which lift your mood and help prevent the mental health issues often associated with a chronic disease.

column1: A morning playlist can help you move through gentle dance moves to relieve the morning stiffness most people with rheumatoid arthritis experience.
Dancing does not need to be vigorous. Small
column2: rhythmic movements that follow your favourite tune can still offer the joy of dance without putting too much pressure on the joints. Lim says he was surprised to find that dancing is very popular among his patients. “It’s the music
column3: and people love moving with it.” The hard pass: don’t overdo it Lewis says people with rheumatoid arthritis should avoid exercises that aggravate pain or make it last into the next day. “It’s about finding the movement that allows people to function and keep their body moving
column4: but not flare up.” “We spend a lot of time teaching our patients how to do appropriate pacing
column5: ” says Lim
column6: “and staging the amount of activity they do throughout the week. We teach them how to listen to their body so that they know they’re not over-pushing it.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/03/how-to-move-with-rheumatoid-arthritis

column1: 5940;5940;Easy wins: give speeches? No way. My not-to-do list gives me the power to say no ;2022-01-02T16:30:22Z;['Tory Shepherd'];['Life and style'
column2: 'Health & wellbeing'];"Sorry? Bugger that. It’s “no” that always seems to be the hardest word. Every time I look at my diary for the upcoming week
column3: there is at least one entry that triggers the thought: “Why did I say yes to that?” It’s a common problem among my many people-pleasing friends. It’s like a pokies hit. Someone asks a favour
column4: you say “yes”
column5: you get a smile in return. Ka-ching! Good feelings. Until the dreaded thing looms in the calendar and the good feelings disappear like coins into a slot machine. As with all personal problems that have an easy answer (say “no”)
column6: I overthought the issue
column7: catastrophised about the consequences of turning things down
column8: and ultimately researched the shit out of it.

column1: I read productivity books (well
column2: listened to the condensed versions on Blinkist
column3: because who has the time?). I looked at the habits of effective people
column4: thought fast and slow about life hacks
column5: tried to learn the subtle art of not giving a fuck. I cogitated on all the hints
column6: tips and tricks that people have written entire books about
column7: and came up with two things that have been helping me ever since. No 1: Write a not-to-do list. The not-to-do list is potentially endless
column8: but for the purposes of saying “no”
column9: should be kept to things you are asked to do by those who would suck your very soul from your body. Mine includes things like “give speeches”
column10: “drive long distances to catch up with people whose conversation is only bearable with copious amounts of wine”
column11: and “work for free”. It helps crystallise in my mind the things I am allowed to say no to. Sorry
column12: I don’t do speeches. I don’t do long drives (I usually leave off the bit about the conversations). I don’t work for free. It’s still not easy
column13: but having the list at least gives me pause before “sure
column14: I’d love to” trips off my traitorous tongue. No 2: Ask “would I want to do that tonight?” This is handy for all the other requests that have not yet made it on to the not-to-do list. It’s about being nicer to Future Tory.

column1: See
column2: I suffer from peoplepleasia to an extent
column3: but my larger problem is an entirely misplaced optimism about the capacity of Future Tory. Today Tory
column4: when asked to commit to something in the hazy future
column5: firmly believes that Future Tory will have her life in order by that point. Future Tory will have boundless energy and limitless time to spend on things other people want her to do. Future Tory
column6: when she sees what Today Tory has committed her to
column7: generally thinks Today Tory is a bitch. So now
column8: when someone asks if I’d like to pop along to their crochet circle in a month and give a talk about defamation law
column9: I think of Future Tory
column10: and I ask myself if I’d say “yes” if the crochet circle was tonight. The answer is
column11: almost invariably
column12: “no”.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/03/easy-wins-a-not-to-do-list-of-things-im-allowed-to-say-no-to

column1: 5941;5941;Australia’s Covid positive test rate: why is it rising and what does it really mean?;2022-01-02T16:30:22Z;['Michael McGowan'];['Coronavirus'
column2: 'Infectious diseases'
column3: 'Australia news'
column4: 'Omicron variant'
column5: 'Health'];"As Covid-19 case numbers have continued to rise following the arrival of the Omicron variant alongside the easing of restrictions in Australia
column6: the focus has begun to turn to the positivity testing rate. In New South Wales
column7: where the rise in cases has been steepest
column8: the infection rate as a proportion of the population is now one of the highest in the world. By New Year’s Eve the rate of infection was about 2.59 per 1
column9: 000 people
column10: higher than the United States. As cases have risen
column11: so too has the positivity rate
column12: which by Sunday had reached 20% in NSW. Other states have also experienced a steady increase in the ratio of positive cases. In Tasmania it reached 26% on Sunday
column13: Victoria’s was 14.8% and Queensland’s 10.5%.

column1: So what is the positivity rate? And what does it tell us about the spread of the virus as evidence of Omicron’s milder severity continues to mount and governments try to shift the focus away from case numbers? What is the positivity rate? The positivity rate of infection is the number of positive cases of Covid as a proportion of the number of PCR tests carried out. For example
column2: a positivity rate of 20% in NSW means one in five people whose tests were processed in the reporting period had the virus. The figure doesn’t tell us how many cases are circulating in the community
column3: but it can help to understand how many of the likely cases are being picked up. That
column4: according to Alexandra Martiniuk
column5: a professor of epidemiology at the University of Sydney
column6: was particularly true at the beginning of the pandemic. “In general
column7: the lower the positivity level
column8: the more likely we think we’re catching
column9: if not all
column10: then most of the cases in the community
column11: ” she said. “As it rises you think we’re likely missing cases
column12: and the more it goes up we’re likely to be missing more and more.” Why is it rising so quickly? Martiniuk says that throughout the Covid pandemic
column13: the reliability of the positivity rate has been affected by testing levels
column14: and the policies dictating who gets tested and who doesn’t. She uses the example of Malawi
column15: where she previously worked as a representative for the World Health Organization. Throughout the pandemic that country did very little population testing
column16: limiting it to people who presented at emergency departments. In Australia
column17: policy changes may be affecting the positivity rate. Recent changes to Covid-19 testing policies have seen governments ask people not to get tested unless they are symptomatic or fit a new and narrower definition of a close contact. As test numbers begin to fall
column18: as they did on Sunday
column19: it’s likely that the positivity rate will increase. “It’s like we had this bigger bag which contained all the people we have now
column20: but also a lot of other people. People who might have been a casual contact
column21: or who fit the old definition of a close contact
column22: or who might have had very mild symptoms
column23: ” she said. “So now our bag is smaller so that we just have those symptomatic people and the very close contacts. So we may be missing those other people.”

column1: The positivity rate can also be affected by other things
column2: such as the Christmas and new year holiday period. While the NSW positivity rate was 20% on Sunday
column3: the seven-day average was about 10%. Does it matter? Certainly for scientists trying to understand how the virus is spreading
column4: it is a figure worth watching. As Martiniuk puts it
column5: for people seeking to respond to the pandemic
column6: data “is like the flight path”. “Without it you’re flying blind.” And while changes to testing may affect the number of cases being caught
column7: she said it was also important to recognise the need to focus resources. “I’m not so silly as to think we’re not in the situation that we’re in
column8: ” she said. “I think epidemiologists recognise times are changing and they need to and it’s both good and bad at the same time. We are having a resource issue and there’s no way we could PCR test everyone with Omicron. “PCRs need to get turned around faster because a lot of the treatments are needed in the first five days
column9: so particularly vulnerable people need to know their status.” So as the focus of the pandemic shifts so that case numbers are no longer the focus of government
column10: is it still relevant? As the positivity rate in Australia has climbed
column11: some have pointed to the World Health Organization’s declaration that a positivity rate of 5% and under is evidence of spread that is under control. But that declaration was made towards the beginning of the pandemic in May 2020. At that point
column12: governments were still seeking to control the virus
column13: while Australia was trying to suppress it
column14: or in some states
column15: eradicate it. “Test positivity still has value
column16: as in the metric is still valuable
column17: but the benchmark of 5%
column18: I’m not sure
column19: ” Martiniuk said. “I think obviously if a country is at 5% that’s great
column20: it is a good indicator that their local pandemic is under control
column21: but whether it’s achievable for most countries to aim for that at this point is another question.” However that doesn’t mean people should believe the pandemic is over. “We still need to test and we still need to go back to that 2020 thinking of bending the curve so if someone is really sick they can get the care the need. I think that message has been lost a little bit. “We still need testing to stop those chains of transmission even though it does feel overwhelming.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/03/australias-covid-positive-test-rate-why-is-it-rising-and-what-does-it-really-mean

column8: 'Australia sport'];"Have Australia been good or have England been bad? Obviously

column1: 5945;5945;Croydon stabbing: second boy arrested over death of Zaian Aimable-Lina;2022-01-02T15:59:10Z;['Jessica Murray'];['UK news'];A second teenager has been arrested on suspicion of murdering 15-year-old Zaian Aimable-Lina
column2: who was stabbed to death in a park in south London on Thursday. A 15-year-old boy was arrested on suspicion of murder late on Saturday and is being held at a south London police station

column1: 5951;5951;For Labour and the Conservatives
column2: racism is really all about reputation management | Nesrine Malik;2022-01-02T14:55:56Z;['Nesrine Malik'];['Race'
column3: 'Conservatives'
column4: 'Labour'
column5: 'Politics'
column6: 'UK news'];"It’s rare that the quiet part is said out loud in British politics: the thing that arrives in a chilling soundbite a politician has let slip
column7: or in correspondence leaked many years after those who wrote it leave power. If you have ever
column8: for example
column9: scoffed at the idea that the rightwing press has a hold on British politics
column10: particularly over the Labour party
column11: then an incident that took place 20 years ago may still your rolling eyes. Last week we learned that after Stephen Lawrence’s murder Tony Blair’s Downing Street initially opposed an inquiry into police relations with minority ethnic communities. The arguments for the government’s objection formed a checklist of the hesitations
column12: prevarications and cynical cautions that still stalk efforts to confront institutional racism today. In his initial note recommending an inquiry
column13: Jack Straw
column14: then the home secretary
column15: wrote: “There is clear disquiet
column16: not least within the black community
column17: about the issues raised by this case. I believe that the best way to address these
column18: and draw something positive from this tragic case
column19: would be to launch a broader inquiry into police relationships with ethnic minority communities generally.” Then he hedged
column20: preempting what an uncomfortable proposition that was for Downing Street. “I am concerned
column21: ” he said
column22: “that this should not be perceived as undermining the police but as an opportunity to identify and promote good practice.” But even that was not enough to reassure jittery colleagues. In the margins
column23: an official whose identity was unknown addressed Blair’s policy adviser
column24: Liz Lloyd
column25: asking
column26: “Is this sensible?” “No
column27: ” replied Lloyd. Others weighed in
column28: saying “an inquiry would raise expectations” that would be hard to achieve
column29: and “even with good presentation” the inquiry would “look like an attack on the police”. You will notice that all these concerns were about the optics rather than the substance of the issue
column30: and the priority was protecting the police and not the Lawrence family or the ethnic minorities whose concerns they represented. Still
column31: perhaps there is nothing that surprising about a government trying to tread carefully when it comes to something as profoundly unsettling as an investigation into police bias towards ethnic minorities. Perhaps there is nothing surprising in government officials defaulting to cost-benefit analyses; you hardly expect the ranks of advisers to be staffed with racial justice warriors instead of steely reputation managers. And Sir William Macpherson’s inquiry did eventually go ahead
column32: such was the undeniable stench of it all and the pressure the Lawrence family wielded. But there is a kicker to the story
column33: and in it we see how the cynicism of self-preservation prevailed at the expense of doing something long-term and substantive about race relations. Shortly before Macpherson published his report
column34: Straw proposed a follow-up – an ambitious strategy that would prioritise race equality considerations in policymaking across government bodies. Yet taking on racial justice in such a direct manner was just too risky
column35: too destabilising to the government. “A regulation nightmare
column36: ” said Blair. Angus Lapsley
column37: an official in Blair’s private office
column38: decided not to back a proposal that racist police officers should be dismissed (government was “cool” towards this suggestion
column39: he said)
column40: not because the policy would be wrong
column41: but because of how rightwing papers would react to it. Here is where the decibel level rises. “This could easily become a ‘Telegraph cause celebre’ if taken too far
column42: ” said Lapsley. Blair agreed
column43: saying: “We do not want to go OTT on this.” The proposal was killed. There is a sort of sickening relief in seeing those sentiments – expressed behind closed doors – spelled out so matter of factly; in knowing for certain that concerns about racial injustice aren’t taken seriously not because they’re not believed but because they rock the boat. Indeed
column44: the smothering of a broad
column45: progressive race policy 20 years ago tells us much about where we are today
column46: with a government proudly hostile to interrogating the true state of race relations. On ethnic minority matters
column47: there is far more continuity between the Labour party and the Conservatives than there are material differences. Both parties share a notion that matters of race are merely a government liability and not something for which the government should take direct responsibility. Last year
column48: that notion was manifest in the shape of the widely discredited report by the Commission on Race and Ethnic Disparities chaired by Tony Sewell. The denial and dishonesty in that document about the extent of the country’s institutional racism was just one step away from Blair’s timidity in front of the rightwing gallery. He passively did not want to upset the Telegraph and its reactionary contingent; today’s Tories actively want to please it. But what Labour and Tory leaderships have both exhibited is deference to a status quo that preserves racial hierarchies and refuses by default to acknowledge any criticism that might challenge Britain’s moral sense of self.

column1: Such is the slippery slope of “moderation”. An unquestioned assumption has developed that the left can prosper in this country only if it sheds “radical” notions of social justice and redistribution that are unrealistic and extreme – that are
column2: in Blair’s words
column3: “OTT”. The best we can hope for is that the good guys go about pursuing change incrementally and surreptitiously. This is an abdication of responsibility
column4: but ultimately it’s worse than that. Lost opportunities to achieve racial equality don’t just throw ethnic minorities under the bus: they are also missed chances to shape the values of the country. Labour’s realpolitik on race may have saved a few fights and stabilised careers in the short term
column5: but in the medium term it also has tilted the ground in favour of the right. And it has sent all of us
column6: marginalised minorities and resentful majorities
column7: hurtling down that slope towards an ever more fractious future. Nesrine Malik is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/labour-conservatives-racism-stephen-lawrence-inquiry-rightwing-press

The thought of doing that to [my husband] Alan is unfathomable to process

column4: 'World news'];"At the cafe that doubles-up as a newsagent in Galliano di Mugello

column11: 300 or so inhabitants

column1: Galliano di Mugello became a symbol of Italy’s digital divide after a report from the ministry of innovation and AGCOM
column2: the communications watchdog
column3: placed it high among the 204 areas in Italy classified in the report as a “very white zone” because of its nonexistent mobile phone coverage and patchy internet service. Although people can access the internet at home via ADSL or through the more recent arrival of fibre broadband

column1: While the promotion of the scenery and charms of Galliano di Mugello

column3: was embraced

column11: whose office is based with the rest of the town hall in the better-connected Barberino

column13: especially in an emergency situation. In December 2019

column16: but the thing was that everyone was out on the streets and so couldn’t read the messages

column24: ” she said. “It’s essential now for security – how are we supposed to call the police or an ambulance if something happens?” The bad internet connection also proved to be an issue when students had to follow online lessons at home during coronavirus lockdowns
column25: with some being forced to take their handsets to the car park of a restaurant perched on a nearby hill
column26: from where a signal can sometimes be found.

column1: “We need the internet for everything nowadays

column8: ” said Suggelli. “She probably has no reception – you see the issues it causes?” Guasti

column12: which makes everything very costly
column13: ” he said. Mongatti said the thing that makes Galliano stand out from other towns or villages with no or precarious internet access is its sizeable population. Neither is it remote – Galliano lies close to the Apennine mountains and is just an hour away from Florence. The area is popular with hikers and even featured in a video for the Madonna song
column14: Turn Up the Radio. But Mongatti refuses to promote it as a holiday destination for those seeking to detox. “When I went to the beach for 15 days in the summer

column16: ” he said. “But the true liberty isn’t about not having a signal
column17: but about being able to choose when to switch off. And we need to give the citizens of Galliano that choice.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/02/the-italian-hamlet-that-gives-a-glimpse-of-life-before-the-web

column9: 'Politics'];"Once again we start a new year with the country in the grip of Covid-19. But as 2022 dawns
column10: the UK should have been better prepared for the disruption of a new variant. In March 2020
column11: the TUC and unions pressed the chancellor to adopt our detailed proposals for a furlough scheme – an emergency response to the first wave of the pandemic. It was a huge success – protecting millions of jobs
column12: keeping businesses open
column13: making the reopening smoother and quicker and making sure families all over the UK could pay their bills. Now
column14: as we face Omicron
column15: we’re having the same old argument about whether government should step in and protect working people’s livelihoods in a crisis. It’s been clear for months that the UK needs a permanent short-time working scheme
column16: learning from the success of furlough
column17: to protect jobs during periods of economic turbulence. Such schemes are common across Europe and help keep businesses afloat when there is a sudden temporary collapse in demand. But ministers have chosen not to listen. After cutting off furlough prematurely in the autumn
column18: the government watched as Omicron hammered our arts
column19: hospitality and aviation sectors in the run-up to Christmas. While the chancellor’s 11th-hour rescue package for pubs
column20: restaurants and theatres will help some
column21: serious damage has already been done to pay packets and to livelihoods. We need to end this stop-start approach to managing our economy.

column1: Businesses and working families shouldn’t be put through an emotional rollercoaster every time the pandemic flares up. They need financial certainty and stability so that when better times return our economy can bounce back fast. Having a permanent short-time working scheme in place
column2: conditional on upskilling and retraining
column3: will ensure that if new restrictions have to be imposed again there is support ready to go. But we can’t stop there. We need to build an economy that can help working families face the future with confidence. There are huge challenges on the horizon. Alongside Covid
column4: climate change is already causing global chaos and threatening jobs in energy-intensive industries such as steel and manufacturing. The longer we put off getting to net zero
column5: the more jobs will be put at risk. And let’s not forget the looming cost-of-living storm. The last 11 years have been the worst period for real wage growth since the Napoleonic wars. And this has come at a huge cost to people’s living standards. Over half of families in poverty today are working families. And many of our key workers – keeping hospitals and public services running – are still earning less in real terms than in 2010. It’s a national disgrace. Without action
column6: the pressure on UK household budgets will only get worse in 2022. This spring
column7: working families face a triple whammy of skyrocketing bills
column8: cuts to universal credit and a hike in national insurance contributions. We urgently need a long-term economic plan for getting wages rising. And the best way to start is by getting more workers covered by collective agreements
column9: sector-by-sector – so they can negotiate a fair pay rise with employers. Giving trade unions greater access to workplaces is the key to boosting pay and employment standards across the country. And it’s not just me saying this. The OECD and governments across the world
column10: from America to New Zealand
column11: have recognised the key role collective bargaining can play in reducing inequality and giving people security at work. Committing to industry-wide fair pay agreements would transform the lives of millions by setting minimum standards – on pay
column12: training
column13: health and safety – and prevent good employers from being undercut by the bad. And fair pay agreements would help ease staffing shortages in under-pressure sectors such as logistics
column14: food production and social care
column15: by making those industries better places to work in. Whether they can boost living standards and working conditions is the acid test of the government’s levelling up agenda.

column1: Alongside campaigning for a pay rise for working people
column2: we are still waiting for the employment bill Boris Johnson promised more than two years ago. Tackling insecure work
column3: outlawing fire and rehire and banning zero-hours contracts – all are long overdue. As too is fixing our broken sick pay system. It beggars belief that we are heading into another wave of the pandemic with millions unable to afford to self-isolate. This year is a crossroads. Beset by pandemics and climate chaos
column4: we can keep reeling from crisis to crisis
column5: unleashing rampant insecurity and inequality anew. Or we can harness the power of active government – in partnership with unions and employers – to create a fairer and more resilient economy. In this age of anxiety
column6: working people are crying out for security. That is my wish for 2022. • Frances O’Grady is general secretary of the Trades Union Congress";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/02/omicron-uk-government-should-join-us-to-create-a-fair-and-resilient-economy

column9: 'Science'];"This year promises to be an important one for space exploration
column10: with several major programmes reaching the launch pad over the next 12 months. The US is to return to the moon
column11: undertaking a set of missions intended to establish a lunar colony there in a few years. China is expected to complete its Tiangong space station while Europe and Russia will attempt to land spacecraft on Mars
column12: having failed at every previous attempt. India
column13: South Korea and Japan are also scheduled to put a number of missions into space. Rockets

column1: Particular interest is going to focus on Nasa’s mighty new space launch system (SLS). This is the most powerful rocket it has ever designed and has been built to carry astronauts to the moon and beyond as part of the agency’s Artemis deep space exploration programme. With these missions
column2: Nasa intends to reopen the solar system to investigation by humans – rather than robot probes – and regularly carry astronauts to the lunar surface. The programme’s first launch is scheduled for February when an SLS rocket – standing more than 300ft high – will carry an unmanned Orion capsule on a trajectory that will enter a highly elliptical orbit round the moon. At its closest
column3: the spaceship will sweep within 62 miles of the lunar surface before soaring 40
column4: 000 miles above it
column5: a distance that will take it further from Earth than any spacecraft built for humans has ever flown. Crucially
column6: Orion – designed to carry between four and six astronauts when fully operational – will be fitted with a European service module that will provide the capsule’s power and propulsion for manoeuvring in orbit. This will give its manufacturer – the European Space Agency – the opportunity to become a key partner in future Artemis missions. If February’s mission succeeds
column7: a crewed trip around the moon will take place in 2024 and this will be followed by a lunar landing in 2025 – a gap of 53 years since Apollo 17
column8: the last crewed moon mission
column9: touched down on the Taurus-Littrow valley in December 1972. This time the crew will include at least one woman and the mission will mark the beginning of a programme aimed at establishing a lunar colony where astronauts would work on months-long missions and develop technologies that could be used by future colonies on Mars. A prime target for the first lunar outpost is Shackleton crater
column10: near the moon’s south pole
column11: which is believed to hold reservoirs of ice. Water will not only provide precious sustenance for astronauts
column12: it can be exploited as a source of hydrogen and oxygen – by electrolysis – that can be combined as rocket fuel. The moon

column1: As part of its preparations to establish a lunar colony
column2: Nasa will also start a massive programme of robot missions through the agency’s $2.6bn commercial lunar payload services (CLPS) initiative. This will involve sending a flotilla of robot spacecraft to the moon
column3: with the first missions beginning this year. Built by private companies with Nasa backing
column4: these probes will attempt to map underground water deposits
column5: study the moon’s deep interior and release robot rovers to investigate the lunar surface. Fledgling space company Astrobotic will send its newly designed Peregrine lander to Lacus Mortis – “the lake of death” – a plain of basaltic rock in the north-eastern part of the moon. It will carry 11 different payloads of instruments and will be followed by another US company
column6: Intuitive Machines
column7: which is sending a spacecraft carrying six payloads to Oceanus Procellarum
column8: the Ocean of Storms. A further 12 CLPS missions are scheduled for the next three years
column9: though head of Nasa science
column10: Thomas Zurbuchen
column11: has warned that these privately funded efforts each face a high risk of failure. As many as half could go wrong
column12: he said recently. For good measure
column13: Russia and India are both planning to launch their own lunar landers next year
column14: while South Korea is scheduled to place a satellite in moon orbit to study its mineral composition. Mars

column2: which will land a robot rover on the Oxia Planum
column3: a 125-mile-wide clay-bearing plain in the planet’s northern hemisphere. The rover – named after Rosalind Franklin
column4: the British chemist and DNA pioneer – will be fitted with a drill capable of probing several feet below the Martian surface
column5: where it is hoped primitive lifeforms may survive or at least the remnants of extinct organisms. The 660lb rover was built by Airbus Defence and Space
column6: at the company’s UK facility in Stevenage. Launch is scheduled for 22 September and touchdown is expected on 10 June 2023. Hopes of success for the mission are guarded
column7: however
column8: as neither Russia nor Europe has had any luck in landing on Mars. Nineteen Russian and Soviet missions and two European bids to land on the red planet have all failed – including Europe’s Schiaparelli lander
column9: which was intended to be a trial run for the current ExoMars mission but which crashed on the planet in 2016. Asteroids

column1: Easily the most spectacular mission to the asteroids will be Nasa’s bid to test an anti-asteroid defence system for Earth. Launched last year
column2: the double asteroid redirection test (Dart) spacecraft will crash into the moonlet Dimorphos in September. Hurtling into its target at 15
column3: 000mph
column4: the 1

column6: a lump of rock the size of a football stadium
column7: around its parent asteroid
column8: Didymos. If successful
column9: Nasa and other space agencies will be encouraged to follow up the mission by developing craft that could deflect a larger asteroid heading towards Earth – and so avert an Armageddon-style impact
column10: say astronomers. Should an asteroid the size of Dimorphos crash on Earth
column11: it would trigger an explosion equivalent to 400-600 megatonnes of TNT. “A city like Manhattan would be completely obliterated
column12: ” Elena Adams

column14: told the journal Science. “This is to demonstrate a technique to save the world.” Nasa has plans for several other asteroid missions next year
column15: including the launch of the probe Psyche. Scheduled for lift-off in August
column16: the spacecraft will visit an asteroid called 16 Psyche that is thought to be the leftover core of a planet. This vast chunk of nickel and iron is the remains of a violent collision with another astronomical object that stripped off the planet’s outer layers and left its metallic innards exposed. Studying 16 Psyche will give scientists an unprecedented opportunity to examine a planetary core. It will also afford them a chance to explore a new type of world – one that is made of metal. Human spaceflight

column1: Boeing will attempt to get its Starliner crew capsule into orbit so that it can begin to ferry astronauts to and from the International Space Station (ISS). A 2019 flight failed to reach the station and another attempt last year was called off at the last minute when fuel valves failed to open. Boeing now plans to launch a crewless Starliner in early 2022
column2: followed by a test flight with astronauts later in the year. The capsule will then be used – along with SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spaceship – on a rota to ferry astronauts to the ISS. For its part

column4: Tianhe

China has said it hopes to keep its space station – which is considerably smaller than the ISS – inhabited continuously by three astronauts for at least a decade. A key task for crewmen will be to service the Xuntian space telescope
column6: which will be launched in 2024 and which will orbit in formation with the Tiangong station. Fitted with a mirror roughly the same size as the Hubble space telescope
column7: Xuntian’s tasks will include investigations of dark matter and dark energy as well as galaxy formation and evolution. Space tourism

column2: offering groups of tourists a few minutes of weightlessness before returning to Earth.";https://www.theguardian.com/science/2022/jan/02/to-the-moon-and-beyond-what-2022-holds-for-space-travel

column15: 'World news'];"The voice of Kirat Assi
column16: subject of the podcast Sweet Bobby
column17: is so familiar I momentarily forget we had never spoken
column18: let alone met. I am one of the million-plus listeners gripped by her story of being “catfished” – duped into a relationship by someone with a false identity. Assi
column19: who lives in London
column20: fell victim to a complex fraud that lasted eight years and involved up to 60 characters who only existed in the scammer’s warped imagination. At the centre was Bobby
column21: a handsome cardiologist with whom Assi formed a close friendship that turned into romance despite never meeting in real life. Bobby was a real person whose identity had been stolen by the scammer
column22: eventually exposed as Assi’s cousin Simran Bhogal. I ask how the scam
column23: which ended in 2018
column24: has affected her. She says that discovering the truth – that her partner
column25: and all of the other characters created by Bhogal
column26: did not exist – was devastating. “Imagine somebody really close to you had suddenly died
column27: and it’s not one person
column28: it’s all of them. I had lost everybody. Normally
column29: even if you lose a boyfriend
column30: your girlfriends come and look after you.” And then there is the fact that many from within Assi’s own community have chosen to not believe the story
column31: or to ask how she could have “let it happen”. But the breathtaking extent of the con was exposed as a result of Assi’s angry determination. She remains the very opposite of the stereotype of a naive victim – she is razor sharp
column32: witty and has an easy charm. “For me
column33: victim shaming is a big thing in this
column34: it’s what shuts people up
column35: ” she says. “Please focus on the perpetrator. Why did she do this?”

column1: The deception began in 2009 when Assi
column2: a 29-year-old radio presenter on a Punjabi station
column3: was contacted on Facebook by Bhogal’s ex-boyfriend
column4: JJ
column5: asking for help on how to win her back. They began to message each other
column6: then when Assi was told JJ had died from an allergic reaction
column7: Bhogal gave her the details for JJ’s brother
column8: Bobby
column9: so she could send condolences. He was someone Assi knew of from the west London Sikh community. As Assi was “getting to know” Bobby
column10: Bhogal ingratiated herself into her life
column11: and became her confidante as the relationship developed
column12: and
column13: later
column14: went horribly wrong. After five years of messages over Messenger
column15: Skype and WhatsApp
column16: Assi fell in love with Bobby
column17: and considered herself in a relationship
column18: “after much pressure and emotional guilt tripping”
column19: she tells me. But there were many obstacles from the outset. Bobby claimed he was in a witness protection programme having been shot in Kenya. He also apparently developed many life-threatening illnesses as a result
column20: which meant he was stuck in hospital in New York. He was manipulative
column21: and
column22: despite her doubts and being told he would only live a matter of months
column23: Assi became emotionally entrapped. “There was always an excuse why he couldn’t come to London
column24: ” says Assi. “When we tried to have a video call
column25: he told me his phone was broken and came up with extraordinary excuses for why he couldn’t get a new one. I said
column26: ‘I’m not turning my video on either’. That was me being angry. He would then say
column27: ‘Just turn it on for a minute
column28: just so I can see you
column29: ’ because he wanted to make sure I was sitting in my room.” Bobby began to exert more control over Assi
column30: monitoring her movements and dictating her choices. “Bobby would be like
column31: ‘Where are you? Why aren’t you at home? Why aren’t you in your room?’ I didn’t understand why I was sitting at home if he wasn’t here. It was not like me at all.” Assi tells me: “He used to test my reactions to things all the time
column32: it was part of him torturing me. One day he asked
column33: ‘If I joined Isis
column34: would you come with me?’ What was I supposed to say? If I said ‘no’
column35: he is going to pick a fight with me
column36: but he might have a heart attack (remember his life-threatening medical condition). But saying ‘yes’ didn’t feel right either.” When Bobby was supposed to be in London
column37: three years into their relationship
column38: Assi became suspicious of the real reason why he still refused to see her. She discovered real Bobby’s last known address was actually in Brighton
column39: and so confronted him there.

column1: After the horrendous events this confrontation unleashed
column2: Assi turned to Bhogal telling her what had happened
column3: and made the decision to report the deception to the police. “I told them
column4: ‘I’m scared
column5: I want something on record just in case something happens.’ [Bhogal] sat next to me and verified everything to the police.” The next day Bhogal confessed to the scam. “She said
column6: it was me
column7: I was Bobby
column8: I was all of them.” But when Assi reported Bhogal to police they told her: “You’re not the victim
column9: [the real Bobby] is.” Police have told Assi that what happened to her is not a crime
column10: which she refuses to accept. Having won a substantial settlement in her civil case against Bhogal for harassment
column11: misuse of private information and data protection breaches
column12: Assi is continuing to challenge the police decision to not pursue her for coercive control
column13: stalking and harassment. “It was a slow destruction of everything I had. Bobby targeted every part of my life – my career
column14: my dreams
column15: my hopes
column16: my relationship with family
column17: with friends
column18: my studies
column19: ” says Assi. “I could have met someone real
column20: had a baby during that time. But the other impact has been on my mental and physical health.” Assi is understandably upset that she is viewed as gullible by some who do not understand the lengths Bhogal went to in order to dupe her. “She could make up whatever she wanted as she was obviously stalking [the real Bobby] and his family and his wife’s family
column21: ” says Assi.

column1: There is no law against catfishing but Assi believes there should be. “Such a law would serve as a deterrent
column2: ” she says. “It’s shocking how common it is.” What does she think motivated Bhogal’s behaviour? “I think she enjoyed power; she enjoyed me being a challenge
column3: ” says Assi
column4: who is slowly rebuilding her life. She is back on her old slot at the radio station
column5: is working in freelance marketing
column6: and hoping to be in a position to move out of the family home and in to her own place soon. I ask Assi how she would feel if she bumped into Bhogal. After all
column7: they live only 20 minutes apart and share an extended family. “I don’t want to see or speak to her again for the sake of my health
column8: ” she says. “I just want her to be held accountable for her actions and to take responsibility. And if she needs help with her mental health
column9: she should get that
column10: too.” Sweet Bobby
column11: a six-part podcast
column12: is available now at Tortoise Media";https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/jan/02/kirat-assi-sweet-bobby-podcast-catfish-justice

column6: 'Sport'];"Thomas Tuchel will punish Romelu Lukaku for his explosive interview by dropping the striker for Chelsea’s home game against Liverpool on Sunday afternoon. column6: 'Health & wellbeing'];"In 1989
column7: when I was 16
column8: I moved into a pub with my parents and my younger brother
column9: Matty. It was highly exciting. I took to barwork as I liked the chat
column10: and also enjoyed the opportunities offered for eavesdropping. I was curious about the adult world and up until then had learned most of what I knew from books. Now I had all these real lives to study. I should write some of this down
column11: I thought
column12: and would scribble into my diary before bed. We couldn’t believe how busy it was that first Christmas
column13: culminating on New Year’s Eve
column14: when everyone piled out into the main street at midnight and exchanged drunken embraces and warm wishes for 1990. After the pub had emptied and the mammoth job of clearing up was done
column15: we gathered with our staff for a few drinks and the chat turned to resolutions. All the women wanted to lose weight. A couple of people wanted to stop smoking. I announced very firmly that I wanted to write a novel. I wish I could tell you what Matty said
column16: but I can’t remember. Perhaps he pledged to strive for good GCSE results. If he did
column17: he succeeded
column18: as he got the best grades in school. But by the time the results came
column19: that summer
column20: he had been knocked over by a car and was in a coma after emergency brain surgery. I was by his bedside in intensive care
column21: chattering away to him because everyone from the ambulance drivers onwards had suggested this might help keep him with us and then bring him around. I even tried to pray in the hospital chapel: “Please God
column22: please. Please don’t let him die. He’s too young. He’s too good. I love him too much. Please help him.” When I wasn’t with Matty
column23: I was at home. I could put on a brave face behind the bar
column24: but when I was alone I gave in to my desolation. I couldn’t believe the enormity of what had happened. I had no words. I knew that unless Matty woke up I could never write anything again. The very sight of my diary made me feel sick. I flicked through the pages
column25: hating my younger
column26: innocent self. I bundled them all up and threw them into the skip at the back of the pub
column27: poking them down beneath the flattened boxes and bin liners full of crisp packets and cigarette ends.

column1: Matty didn’t die
column2: but nor did he regain consciousness. He lived on for eight years in a persistent vegetative state until my parents and I went to the family court and were granted permission to withdraw nutrition and hydration so that he could die and we could
column3: finally
column4: eight years after we suffered the loss of him
column5: have a funeral. I was bereft. Over the next decade my words drifted back and I tried to make sense of what happened to Matty and how it felt to be the witness at his bedside. But it was always too hard. Surely if I was talented enough to be a writer
column6: then it would be easier and I’d have fewer doubts. Anyway
column7: what was the point? No one would ever want to read such a gloomy story. I tried to write novels instead
column8: but sooner or later Matty would arrive on the page wanting to be heard. I was stuck. Every so often I’d have another go and then give up. I felt like I was destined to fail at this
column9: as I did at everything else
column10: that the car that knocked Matty over had taken me out
column11: too
column12: that I was alive
column13: but only just
column14: and that I couldn’t ask for too much. I’d put my notebooks away in a drawer and try to care about other things. And then
column15: after the birth of my son
column16: I was filled with a renewed determination. I didn’t want to keep finding myself back at the drawer and realised that the only way I could free myself from this cycle of trying and failing
column17: was to get it all down. I made a new resolution. I just had to do it. It didn’t have to be any good
column18: or even in the right order. And I wouldn’t show it to anyone
column19: so I didn’t have to worry about what other people would think. I read a novel where a priest said that it is our secrets that make us sick. That’s it
column20: I thought. I need to cleanse myself
column21: confess everything on to the page. Only then will I feel better. It was hard. Often I felt like I was wrestling an octopus as I struggled to tame all the different tentacles of the story. I would feel tired and dispirited
column22: but this time I could carry on
column23: and word by word I excavated myself on to the pages
column24: which eventually became The Last Act of Love. It was a long haul. I was 17 when Matty was knocked over
column25: 25 when he died
column26: and 42 when I managed to finish my book about him. And I did and do feel better. There is an astonishing sense of achievement up for grabs if we can be brave enough to make a commitment and then have the stamina to hold steady through all the ups and downs. I am still in awe at the process of writing. The first steps are so simple. We find some paper or turn on a computer. Then we put down some words and fiddle about with them and something magical starts to happen. Writing is the nearest I get to touching the divine and I do feel a little evangelical about encouraging others
column27: so please allow me to suggest it to you as a New Year’s resolution. Much better for us in the long run than any goals around eating less or being less. Don’t resolve to shrink your body! Consider instead the benefits on offer if you are bold enough to mine the self
column28: to disinter your secrets
column29: to finally try to tell that story you’ve been carrying around
column30: perhaps for as long as I did. Or
column31: if that feels a bit much
column32: just write down your life; make a personal record of these interesting times we are living in. What you see on your way to work
column33: perhaps
column34: or what you dreamed
column35: or how you feel just before going to sleep. Three things to be grateful for
column36: four blue things you saw that day
column37: how you nourished yourself or notes from your exercise. Would it not be satisfying this time next year if you had written down a few lines about each day?

column1: Or grumble. I love to have a good old moan into my notebooks. There is a release to be had in having a private space to let off steam. In this world of hyper communication where anyone with a social media account can feel under pressure to issue press release style comment on every issue and event
column2: there is a glorious privacy to be found in taking up a pen and scribbling down our own thoughts with no aim other than making sense of things for ourselves. The best piece of advice I have for you is that you need to accept that you will have to put in some effort. Unhelpfully
column3: our culture over-focuses on talent. We think writers are special and imagine that those anointed ones simply sit at their magnificent desks in a book-lined room and allow beautiful prose to flow from their pens
column4: all in the right order. From my own practice
column5: and observing other writers
column6: we get along much better when we escape that idealised image and concentrate instead on effort. Most worthwhile activities do involve preparation and graft. We accept that if we want to run a marathon or climb a mountain
column7: we’ll need to work hard. My writing life has become less anguished since I have stopped being cross with myself that I don’t find it easy. Another cultural misunderstanding I’d like us to jettison is that writing should lead to publication and profit. We can do it purely for pleasure and our personal development
column8: in the way that we might go on a watercolour course
column9: or learn to play the ukulele
column10: or get into running or swimming. Not every pursuit in life needs to have a commercial purpose. Writing offers us stimulation
column11: meaning and purpose and a way to keep our eyes on the stars. Let that be enough in the early stages. Don’t put any pressure on those tender shoots. Though
column12: who knows what might happen? Writing is very much an acorn activity. The important thing is to start and then we may be amazed at what we end up cultivating. And my resolution this year? Well
column13: I do fancy dabbling in watercolour and ukulele and I also want to finish a book
column14: of course. Recently
column15: when I visited the pub
column16: one of my old friends there said: “You were always going on about writing. And now you’ve done loads.” I hope that more than three decades after I made my first resolution
column17: 2022 will see me finish my sixth book. I know there will be ups and downs
column18: but I’ve learned that it is so worth sticking with it. Write it all Down: How to Put Your Life on the Page by Cathy Rentzebrink is published by Bluebird on 6 January. Buy it for £13.04 at guardianbookshop.com";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/02/we-often-fail-to-keep-resolutions-but-writing-in-a-notebook-brings-great-rewards

column4: 'Culture'];"According to Brazil’s 2010 census
column5: 43% of citizens identify as mixed-race
column6: while 30% of those who consider themselves white have black ancestors. Brazil has always wrestled with issues surrounding colourism and racial classification. Even affirmative action policies – such as race-based quotas at universities – have proved contentious. Paulo Scott explores these tensions in his latest novel
column7: seamlessly translated by Daniel Hahn. Lourenço and Federico are from the same Porto Alegre family – their father is black
column8: their mother white. Lourenço is dark-skinned
column9: while Federico’s pale skin means he passes for white. Uncomfortable with the privilege this brings him
column10: Federico works with disadvantaged black youth and dedicates his life to fighting racism. But guilt taints his close relationships and fuels his quick temper. Eventually he moves away
column11: while his brother
column12: a basketball coach
column13: remains a popular figure in their neighbourhood. Phenotypes opens in 2016
column14: at the height of the quotas controversy. Some students have used their black ancestry to abuse the scheme
column15: while other eligible students are deemed “insufficiently brown”. Federico has been asked to sit on a government commission in Brasília charged with limiting race fraud. Meanwhile
column16: anti-government protests are spreading across the country and a family emergency calls him back to Porto Alegre.

column1: This is an artfully plotted tale about race
column2: privilege and guilt. Scott circles around the inflammatory event that occurred decades before – a racist comment that provoked a violent fight among teenagers – and demonstrates how quickly prejudice spreads
column3: often with lifelong repercussions. Years later
column4: this incident is linked to the detention of Federico’s niece for the illegal possession of a firearm. Scott’s characterisation is superb. Federico’s complexities are revealed through his interactions with others
column5: their different views of him
column6: his public image and inner angst. His conflicted protagonist is flawed but hugely sympathetic. The stream-of-consciousness narrative
column7: long sentences
column8: paragraphs that run over pages and lack of speech tags are challenging
column9: but careful reading proves richly rewarding. Phenotypes educates and entertains in equal measure. Phenotypes by Paulo Scott (translated by Daniel Hahn) is published by And Other Stories (£10). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/02/phenotypes-by-paulo-scott-review-artfully-plotted-tale-of-race-privilege-and-guilt

column9: 'Life and style'];"I had an uncle who
column10: intermittently and not necessarily simultaneously
column11: wore a kilt and played the violin. Each to me was exotic – twin roads to freedom from the dullness of a prosaic
column12: southern English childhood. For a short time I took up highland dancing
column13: with real swords and modest skill. I was seven when I begged to be allowed to join the new string class at school. Above all
column14: I wanted the “equipment”: an eighth-sized violin and silk scarf to wrap it in
column15: bow
column16: spare strings
column17: heavy wooden case with green felt lining (just as I’d wanted the kilt
column18: jacket
column19: sporran
column20: jabot and special laced shoes for dancing). The other children soon dropped out
column21: bored by playing long
column22: slow notes on open strings. It was deadly indeed and sounded awful. There’s no quick path to becoming even a modestly accomplished violinist. Left on my own
column23: things progressed. The nice teacher complimented me on my “good ear” as I sawed through Will Ye No Come Back Again. I won a place at the junior department of a London conservatoire
column24: going by myself
column25: aged 11 until I left school
column26: every Saturday morning: negotiating public transport
column27: having breakfast in cafes and spending the afternoon wandering up and down Charing Cross Road
column28: wondering at the mysterious rubber “health” objects (health meaning sex) hidden at the back of seedier secondhand bookshops. It was an education. It was
column29: too
column30: a wonder I escaped unscathed. A few creepy flashers aside
column31: I was left alone.

column1: The only abuse I got
column2: looking back
column3: was from the bullying violin teacher I was assigned. The experience of being confined in a tiny practice room with an emotionally and psychologically threatening adult is
column4: alas
column5: not rare for children learning musical instruments. The necessary intimacy of one-to-one lessons can be a joy or a peril
column6: the risks only very recently brought into the open
column7: and monitored. The same could not happen now. In my case
column8: the problem was not sexual. This teacher
column9: I’ll call her Mme Lorgnette – you must picture her
column10: squeezed into the unlikely attire of gold lamé smoking jacket and matching skirt
column11: and muddied brogues – arrived late every week
column12: puffing and blaspheming
column13: pulled by her charmless dog. While I struggled to play dull technical exercises
column14: madame blew smoke rings from her cigarillos and read her newspaper
column15: occasionally screaming “Shut up!” at the dog (or it may have been at me) as it yowled in open contest. Both dog and owner were acridly malodorous
column16: the windowless room a fug. Every minute was torment.

column1: At the end of each session
column2: I had to take the dog outside (“make sure it does its business”)
column3: making me late for my next lesson elsewhere in the large building. But I had a scholarship. I was lucky to be there. My parents were proud. How did one complain
column4: by oneself
column5: at that age? No one ever asked how I was getting on
column6: or inspected a lesson
column7: or wondered why my progress was so pitifully slow and lacklustre. Fortunately
column8: I had no intention of becoming a professional violinist
column9: for reasons of aptitude
column10: application and self-consciousness at performing. I can’t entirely blame that teacher
column11: but the experience closed off options. I learned less than I might have done. Yet those Saturdays were part of my identity and
column12: in a combative way
column13: the passport to wider horizons I so wanted. Though my playing had stalled
column14: I loved the other lessons: the theory and orchestra and music history. Without realising
column15: I was equipping myself for the job I would eventually have: writing about music. After I’d stopped lessons and the drudge of exams
column16: everything changed – too late
column17: yet just in time. I went on exciting music courses and spent every spare moment playing in student ensembles. No one shouted at me. There was
column18: even
column19: laughter. Music came alive
column20: it became life. I began to play in string quartets (that is
column21: usually
column22: two violins
column23: viola and cello) with friends and sometimes strangers. There’s an unrivalled pleasure in playing chamber music: a joint venture in which merely getting through can be harder
column24: and more rewarding
column25: than you’d ever think. New worlds opened. To forge the link between myself and the violin – by now in my first job as a journalist – I commissioned a new instrument
column26: not a common procedure
column27: for amateurs or professionals. I was introduced to a violin-maker
column28: Juliet Barker
column29: who was just establishing an important English violin-making school in Cambridge. I saved my meagre earnings each month to pay for it
column30: and watched as
column31: over two or more years
column32: seasoned white wood turned to varnished gold and became an instrument. No one else has ever played that violin. It’s far superior to any I could otherwise have afforded
column33: old Italian instruments being preeminent. It remains my prized possession.

column1: The brakes went on when children arrived. I was a violinist but one who was resting. The children grew up. I started playing again
column2: as far as a busy schedule would allow
column3: and reunited with the same friends. They’d gone on playing in the intervening years and opened the circle to let me back in. Then
column4: not long ago
column5: I smashed my left arm
column6: the one that creates the notes. Surgery and metal worked miracles but left it stiff. A Schubert string quartet can last 40 minutes. Straightening the arm afterwards takes a bit of teeth gritting. For a professional player
column7: that everyday accident would have ended their career. As so often in life – read Marcel Proust
column8: read Anthony Powell – the music of time has danced its onward dance. New lodgers
column9: models of the species
column10: moved in
column11: one a master luthier
column12: or maker of stringed instruments. The quiet plucking of lute or oud sometimes wafts up through the floorboards (a rare boast in Peckham
column13: south-east London). Could he put a little love back into my violin
column14: neglected in lockdown? He took it off to his workshop
column15: discovered its maker – now a revered pioneer and veteran in her 90s – and admired her craft. He renewed the glue and adjusted parts that had cracked or shifted
column16: restoring the instrument’s tone and vitality. I can’t call playing the violin a hobby. It’s part of me
column17: silent or not. Like everyone
column18: I’ll make various improbable resolutions for the new year. If I can get together with friends in one room to play quartets or trios or duos
column19: I’ll be OK. Just don’t expect me to go it alone. How to do it The rise of online lessons means that an army of tutors awaits the chance to discover your dormant virtuoso. Websites such as Music Teachers or Private Music Lessons are good places to look. Arts Council England-supported music hubs can also help you access lessons or groups in England. Many centres of musical excellence – such as Sage Gateshead and the Royal Academy of Music – offer lessons and community programmes for beginners and enthusiasts. The British Council has a list of national initiatives which might inspire you. If you’re a lapsed musician and want to find other people to play with
column20: look at Making Music or Contemporary Music for All. Both sites let you search for groups in your area from choral societies to samba bands. Someone local will be singing your tune.";https://www.theguardian.com/music/2022/jan/02/from-torment-to-pleasure-how-playing-the-violin-became-part-of-me

column2: not judgment
