column9: 'Politics'];"Amid rocketing Covid infection rates
column10: rising hospitalisation numbers and test shortages
column11: the opening weeks of 2022 are going to be defined by the UK’s vaccine gap. According to the latest official figures
column12: 91% of people aged over 18 in the UK have had at least one Covid jab
column13: 88% have received two and 64% have had their third. But the 9% who have yet to be vaccinated at all accounts for about five million people
column14: whose preponderance among those now being hospitalised is clearly a huge problem. Precise figures are a matter of debate: some senior NHS staff put the share of unvaccinated people on their wards at up to 90%
column15: although the most recent estimates show the share of people needing critical care who are unvaccinated running at just over 60%. What cannot be doubted is that if more people were vaccinated
column16: the latest phase of the Covid crisis would be much more manageable
column17: and the people in charge might not be faced with such a difficult set of options.

column1: If the NHS is soon overwhelmed
column2: tightening across-the-board restrictions might become inevitable
column3: but it would highlight the unfairness of disrupting the lives of the vaccinated majority to protect those who are still unjabbed. Coercing people into getting vaccinated using stringent Covid passports – let alone introducing compulsory inoculation – would infuriate the Tory backbenches
column4: make Boris Johnson’s future all but impossible
column5: and even to many of us outside Conservative circles mark a worrying extension to the state’s reach
column6: not least under a government as illiberal as this one. There are
column7: in fact
column8: no clear and easy choices
column9: beyond retaining a vague hope that the sudden urgency of the pandemic’s latest phase might convince more people to pitch up at a vaccination centre
column10: and keeping faith in the grassroots organisations currently doing their best to change minds. To some people
column11: though
column12: the issues are completely straightforward. Ten days before he was made a Knight Companion of the Most Noble Order of the Garter
column13: Tony Blair issued a characteristically sweeping verdict: “If you’re not vaccinated and you’re eligible … you’re not just irresponsible
column14: you’re an idiot”. He later expressed regret about his choice of words
column15: but by then it was rather too late: he had already triggered a wave of judgment on social media
column16: suggesting that most unvaccinated people were either reckless fools
column17: or the unhinged disciples of those online cults that put the past two years of human history down to a quest to tighten the grip of the secret world government. Inevitably
column18: the facts of the vaccine gap are immeasurably more complicated
column19: as no end of statistics prove. According to the latest numbers published by the UK Health Security Agency
column20: 30% of eligible people in Liverpool are yet to receive their first jab. In Birmingham
column21: the figure is 33%; in the London boroughs of Newham and Tower Hamlets
column22: about 38% and 34% respectively. Conspiracy theory and misinformation are sizeable and worrying features of the Covid era
column23: and our politicians still say surprisingly little about them. But particularly in cities
column24: beyond high levels of mobility and transience
column25: figures showing large numbers of unvaccinated people reflect much deeper questions of age
column26: class
column27: ethnicity
column28: faith and language – and what poverty
column29: insecurity and institutionalised prejudice do to people’s relationship with the state. In that sense
column30: the limits of the vaccination drive remind us of one of the most simple truths of power and politics: that if governments continually ignore fundamental issues of trust and basic empathy
column31: any big social rupture will instantly reveal the consequences.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: I spoke to Manisha Kumar
column3: an inner-city GP in Manchester and the medical director of the city’s health and care commissioning partnership
column4: which is steering a grassroots vaccination drive that involves an array of local organisations centred on the city council. The main figures she and her colleagues work with are based on people registered with a medical practice. Some come with caveats
column5: but they show the proportion of eligible Mancunian adults who have not received even a single vaccine dose currently standing at about 30%. In more affluent areas of the city
column6: less than 20% of eligible people have not been jabbed
column7: but in some poorer neighbourhoods
column8: the figures tend to hover at about 50%. In aggregate
column9: white people who identify as English
column10: Scottish
column11: Welsh or British register vaccine uptake levels of more than 80%
column12: whereas the current number for people from a Caribbean background is 52%; among those classified as Gypsy or Traveller
column13: the figure is 28%. Such numbers
column14: she said
column15: only tell you so much: what is important is to get to the complex combinations of factors that make people either hesitant about vaccination
column16: or downright hostile. “People come to this with their beliefs
column17: their experiences of Covid
column18: their perception of risk – there isn’t just one sort of person who hasn’t come forward
column19: ” she said. In some parts of the country
column20: she went on
column21: “you can just open your doors
column22: send out a text
column23: and people will come.” Her patch
column24: by contrast
column25: requires much more delicate and detailed work. “The majority of the city is hugely deprived
column26: and lives in very small communities defined by culture
column27: identity and geography. Knowledge of those communities is really important.”

column1: What is lacking from a lot of people’s understanding of the vaccine gap
column2: she told me
column3: is any real sense of the sheer weight millions of people have borne over the past two years
column4: and how precarious their lives often are. “The pace of change
column5: the amount of information coming out – for some people it’s just been overwhelming. They’ve gone: ‘I can’t do this – it’s too much. I’ve lost my job
column6: I’ve got issues with domestic abuse
column7: my children are out of school.’” She also talked about huge issues around access to the internet
column8: made worse by vaccines being introduced during lockdown. “People didn’t have phone credit or data roaming
column9: or wifi in their houses. So when you sent out a link saying ‘Book on the national booking service’
column10: they couldn’t do it.” By way of getting to the heart of it all
column11: a PowerPoint presentation she sent me made mention of “historic lack of trust in public institutions including health services within some groups and communities”. In some black communities
column12: she said
column13: people’s relationships with authority are so poor that that some have chosen to be vaccinated well away from where they live and work
column14: “because they’re almost embarrassed to be vaccinated
column15: thinking their community isn’t behind them.” She paused. “There’s no easy fix. We just keep on talking.” In a lot of what she said
column16: there were echoes of the kind of government actions that have only furthered people’s distance from the state
column17: from the creation of a cruel and punitive benefits system
column18: to the hostile environment doctrine that quickly led to the Windrush scandal. Cutting spending on English tuition was always going to keep people confined to the social margins; the innumerable other ways that austerity has hacked back even the most basic everyday help has made things even worse. If you are white
column19: middle class and confident enough to play the kind of games large institutions always demand
column20: the state might look benign and dependably helpful. But if it usually treats you with a mixture of hostility and indifference you will tend to keep your distance
column21: even when it says it has your best interests at heart. In the UK and elsewhere
column22: what all that means for any attempt to make all of us move in lockstep is simple enough. The vaccine gap shows us how far we are from being a society that understands itself collectively
column23: and how easily we still break into “us” and “them”. It demands not judgment
column24: but a level of understanding we have yet to get near. John Harris is a Guardian columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/understanding-not-judgement-unjabbed-uk-vaccination-gap

column1: 5969;5969;A wounded PM and ailing economy force England to ‘go Swedish’ on Covid | Larry Elliott;2022-01-02T11:23:00Z;['Larry Elliott'];['Business'
column2: 'Economics'

column4: 'Economic policy'

column8: 'NHS'];"Government policy towards Covid-19 has come full circle. For now
column9: at least
column10: England has returned to the Swedish way of dealing with the pandemic. Tough
column11: officially imposed lockdowns are out. Trusting the people to do the sensible thing is back in. Whether this approach will survive the expected surge in hospitalisations from Christmas and New Year revelries remains to be seen. Boris Johnson is the master of the screeching U-turn and with the number of infections hitting new records pressure on Downing Street to act is growing. We have been here before. Back in the early days of the pandemic the prime minister was minded to copy Sweden
column12: a country that imposed few restrictions and decided early on that it needed to learn to live with the virus.

column1: The prime minister’s flirtation with the “Swedish experiment” was brief
column2: and at the end of March 2020 a draconian lockdown was imposed. Ministers knew this would have a dire impact on the economy but felt the risk of the NHS being overwhelmed left them no choice. A paper published in the online journal Scientific Reports last year examined what would have happened had Britain followed the Swedish approach. Even assuming the public here would have been as willing to adhere to non-mandatory recommendations as the Swedes (a pretty big assumption) the UK death rate would have at least doubled. This time
column3: the decision is a lot less clearcut
column4: not least because vaccines are providing protection from the virus. The news from South Africa
column5: one of the countries where Omicron first surfaced
column6: has also been encouraging. While more transmissible
column7: the new variant has resulted in fewer hospitalisations and deaths. Case numbers
column8: after rising rapidly
column9: have started to decline. A degree of caution is needed when comparing the two countries
column10: because South Africa has a much younger population than Britain
column11: and it is summer rather than the middle of winter there. Even so
column12: it is clear the government has set a high bar for imposing further restrictions. The prime minister’s weakened political position is one reason the government has gone Swedish. The risk of causing serious damage to the economy when it is looking particularly vulnerable is another
column13: because this is going to be a tough year for the British public. Inflation is rising
column14: interest rates are going up
column15: and energy bills are expected to rocket in the spring just as Rishi Sunak’s increase in national insurance contributions comes into force. The cumulative effect is a whopping cut to living standards. According to the Resolution Foundation thinktank the average household is going to be £1
column16: 000 a year worse off. Those on the lowest incomes will be especially hard hit by soaring gas and electricity bills. In the circumstances
column17: it is easy to see why the government is reluctant to add to the economic pain by imposing tougher restrictions to slow the spread of the Omicron variant. Fresh curbs mean slower growth and a hit to the public finances. They would also test the resilience of the labour market. The Swedes came in for a lot of criticism for their go-it-alone approach. While death rates were much lower than the initial pessimistic forecasts
column18: they were still higher than in neighbouring Scandinavian countries
column19: where tough restrictions were imposed. Moreover
column20: the initial hit to the economy was as severe in liberal Sweden as it was in locked-down Denmark. That said
column21: as the second anniversary of Covid’s arrival looms
column22: governments are beginning to see merits in the Swedish approach. In part
column23: that’s because Sweden now has a lower death rate than countries that went down the full lockdown route
column24: including the UK
column25: France
column26: Spain and Italy. It is in the bottom half of the EU league table for deaths once the size of population is taken into account. Economic recovery has been pretty brisk. column1: All of which suggests the Scientific Reports paper will not be the last word on the Swedish experiment. There have been precious few upsides to the pandemic but one of them is that it has thrown up rich country-by-country data for academics from all disciplines – epidemiologists

column6: but not in England
column7: for New Year’s Eve. EU countries have varied in their approach
column8: while the US provides 50 states to study. What is clear is that no one country got everything right and all made mistakes
column9: unsurprisingly enough given they weren’t expecting a global pandemic. It is also obvious
column10: as time passes
column11: that governments – be they in London
column12: Edinburgh
column13: Rome or Paris – are only tightening restrictions with reluctance. In a way
column14: that’s a backhanded compliment to the Swedes for perhaps being on to something right from the start. • This article was amended on 4 January 2022. While Sweden kept schools open for under-16s throughout the pandemic

column6: 'Violence against women and girls'];"Women today are experiencing the “inherited trauma” of the persecution and execution of their forebears who were branded as witches
column7: according to the curator of a new exhibition on the period known as “the burning times”. Thousands of women were accused of witchcraft in the UK and Ireland between 1450 and 1750. Many were tortured until they identified relatives and neighbours as witches; those deemed guilty were hanged and
column8: in the case of Scotland

column1: “The burning times affected everyone within a community – men

column3: not just those branded as witches
column4: ” said Cali White

column11: ” said White. It became a way to rid a community of anyone viewed as a problem. “People who questioned the authority of the church or state could easily become a target. Women learned it was safer to stay quiet than to speak up or stand out.”

column1: Women were forced to betray each other under torture. “There was fear of betrayal

column7: isolated
column8: stuck
column9: divided

column11: ” said White. In 2020

column17: the campaign’s founder. According to White

column7: created by the Silver Spoons Collective

column9: painting
column10: film
column11: music and storytelling. “We offer a powerful opportunity for reflection and reconnection

column4: 'Technology'];A new tax rule will impact millions of small businesses in 2022. You can thank one small change buried in the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021. Let’s suppose you’re a small business owner or freelancer
column5: and you get paid from a digital payment service like PayPal
column6: Venmo
column7: Zelle
column8: Cash App or any third-party settlement provider that’s accepting credit cards on your behalf and putting money into your bank account. If those payments were for goods and services that you sold to customers
column9: it was previously up to you to make sure you were reporting that income on your tax return. But now
column10: beginning in 2022
column11: if you receive more than $600 in total during the course of the year – regardless of how many customers are paying – your payment service is required to report that amount to the IRS. Let’s be clear: you should be reporting those amounts as income anyway. But the reality is there are 30 million small businesses
column12: freelancers
column13: solo-preneurs and independent contractors in the US and – if my client base is any indication – many of them who receive a number of small payments from many customers throughout the year may
column14: well
column15: forget. Particularly if – as is often the case – there are many small transactions or their record keeping is sub-par. But no worries! The IRS will now be able to find out what you earned anyway. This means that whether you’re selling products or services on Amazon
column16: Etsy
column17: eBay or at craft shows or just face-to-face
column18: you can now expect to receive a 1099-K form – after 31 January 2023 – from the payment services that you’re using of the revenue they reported on your behalf to the IRS for the purchases of goods and services made in 2022. How do these services know that the purchases were made for goods and services and not just a payment from a friend or family member? Most of them are adding an extra form during the payment process for the payer to identify the nature of the payment. You can also expect more questions this year from your payment service provider. “You may notice that in the coming months we will ask you for your tax information
column19: like a social security number or tax ID
column20: if you haven’t provided it to us already
column21: in order to continue using your account to accept payments for the sale of goods and services transactions and to ensure there aren’t any issues when these changes take effect in 2022
column22: ” PayPal warns in a blogpost. This helps us meet our obligations to the IRS and ensures that you will be able to continue using your account and access PayPal and Venmo features and services.” There will be some overlap. For example
column23: if you’re an independent contractor working for a company and you receive more than $600 via a payment service then you’ll likely get both a 1099-MISC from that company and a 1099-K from the payment service. In this situation you’d use the amount on the 1099-MISC and
column24: assuming there are no other amounts from the payment service
column25: you’d disregard the 1099-K. Got it? So what will the government do with this information? Nothing bad
column26: I’m sure. They just want to know more about you and your business
column27: that’s all! According to the IRS the data collected will only be used for “taxpayer education and outreach products and services” as well as “new examination and collection approaches”. Translation: if you’re not reporting the right amount we’re gonna get ya! “For the 2022 tax year
column28: you should consider the amounts shown on your 1099-K when calculating gross receipts for your income tax return
column29: ” PayPal warns. “The IRS will be able to cross-reference both our report and yours.” Happy new year

column1: 5972;5972;Fashion designer Gabriela Hearst: ‘I could always have gone back to selling cattle’;2022-01-02T11:00:16Z;['Scarlett Conlon'];['Fashion'
column2: 'Life and style'];"Hang on
column3: wait there a minute
column4: I want to show you something
column5: ” says Gabriela Hearst
column6: hopping up from her chair in her airy Manhattan office and reaching for something on the shelves in the background of her Zoom frame. “These are my journals from when I was 16 or 17 – let me check the date
column8: yes I was 17 and look!” She flattens a page full of colourful teenage drawings and holds it up to the camera: “I designed a whole freaking shoe collection!” That these journals remain within reaching distance of the fashion designer’s desk in her Chelsea studio is testament to the fact that despite the success she has achieved
column9: Hearst never forgets where she came from. As creative director of her award-winning brand
column10: founded in 2015
column11: and a year into the same prestigious role at the fashion house Chloé
column12: it would be an understatement to say that Hearst is hot property in the fashion world right now. Not only can she count the likes of Angelina Jolie
column13: Gillian Anderson
column14: Greta Thunberg and Jill Biden as fans of her brand (she dressed the latter in the embroidered white coat for the evening of the 2020 inauguration)
column15: but she is making all the right kind of fashion headlines for her determination to demonstrate to an industry famed for its unsustainable practices that sustainable innovation can make good business sense
column16: too. It’s also a serious asset that her husband
column17: John Augustine Hearst – a senior member of the Hearst Corporation and an heir to one of the wealthiest families in America – is involved in the self-financed company. Since day one of her eponymous brand
column18: which is famed for its luxe-craft aesthetic
column19: she has raised the bar for how to run a luxury fashion house sustainably. She has set a goal to use 80% deadstock fabric within three years and no virgin materials by 2022. Her first fashion-week catwalk in 2016 – where she brought chairs from her house and donated the metal floorboards from the show when it was over – laid the foundations for the first-ever carbon-neutral fashion show in September 2019. Earlier that same year her brand declared itself plastic-free
column20: “front and back of house”
column21: using recycled cardboard hangers and bio-based TIPA packaging that is fully compostable. And she has re-romanticised the idea of waiting lists
column22: making her handbags more or less to order to avoid any waste.

column1: It’s a passion which comes from the bucolic childhood that Hearst likes to keep as close to heart as she does to hand. Born into a sixth generation of ranchers in remote Uruguay in November 1976
column2: she spent her childhood living pretty much off the grid
column3: herding cattle from a young age at her parents’ 17
column4: 000-acre ranch in Paysandú. “It is extremely remote
column5: ” she emphasises. “When I was a kid and it would rain
column6: you wouldn’t get out because the rivers would flood. We would have to plan a whole year of what we would eat because you couldn’t just pop to the supermarket or deli.” In the absence of a TV
column7: the radio provided entertainment
column8: while for the designer
column9: “My toy was my imagination
column10: ” she says. “A lot of the creativity I have today is from using my imagination [back then]. Imagination is all problem solving
column11: right? On a ranch you have to use it a lot; you can’t just bring in an expert if something doesn’t work. That time taught me that essentially quality comes from a utilitarian perspective… and even in a humble environment there is high quality
column12: because everything is made to last a lifetime.” This rationale – and the rhythms of following nature in her early developmental years – is what Hearst credits her appreciation of the earth and its resources to. She also has an innate understanding of how to use common sense: “Resetting your mind on what needs to be done in order to function? Ways to prioritise was ingrained in my upbringing!” she says. Such formative years would go on to create a force to be reckoned with later down the line.

column2: she won the prestigious womenswear International Woolmark Prize; in May 2018
column3: she won Pratt’s Fashion Visionary Award for her commitment to sustainability; in April 2019
column4: LVMH Luxury Ventures took a minority stake in the business; she was named the Fashion Council of America’s Womenswear Designer of the Year in 2020 (the fashion equivalent to the Oscars); and last month she was named a Leader of Change at the British Fashion Awards. “This recognition humbly gives us more drive for the road ahead
column5: ” she told her followers on Instagram (where
column6: by the way
column7: you can find her high-kicking her way into buying meetings
column8: demonstrating how to wear her designs
column9: and sharing inspirational images of her mother herding criollos horses). Hearst’s own road to success
column10: it transpires
column11: has been as dynamic as she is. Turning the page in her journal
column12: she proudly holds up a sketch that reads: ‘I am going to Australia!’ “When you live in Uruguay
column13: you are really far away from everything and [when I was 17] I wanted to go to Australia like nothing else in the world. I told everyone I was going there and they said I was crazy
column14: ” she explains. “Then one day a friend told me about a scholarship that would take me there. There was one place
column15: I applied with this whole presentation and I got it.”

column1: After returning to Uruguay
column2: Hearst convinced her mother to let her get a paid job to save money to go and see a friend in New York who she had met during her scholarship. “I arrived [in New York] in 1994 when I was 18 and within hours I said
column3: I am going to live here
column4: ” she says matter-of-factly. Six years later
column5: she made the move a permanent one
column6: enrolling at the Neighbourhood Playhouse School of the Theatre to study performing arts. After persuading her father to pay for her fees – “convincing my father who was a Gaucho to pay for acting school in New York was my best performance ever” – she worked around her studies to cover her living costs. While a career on stage proved not to be her calling
column7: she took an important lesson from her time there. “We studied Meisner technique
column8: which I got
column9: ” she says. “It’s the technique of being truthful – of dealing with the truth [it takes] to perform and performing from a place of truth. It was a remarkable experience and without it I wouldn’t be able to do interviews like this or be so present [today].” None of her friends or family are surprised that Hearst ended up as a fashion designer
column10: she says
column11: although she admits to falling into it by coincidence. Before Gabriela Hearst and long before Chloé
column12: came Candela
column13: the womenswear brand she started with two partners and $750 each. “At that point
column14: if it didn’t work out
column15: I would have needed to go back to selling cattle with my dad – so I gave it my all!” she laughs. “I don’t recommend it
column16: but at the time it was like 0% APR and so we maxed out credit cards [to get it started]. Luckily the business went from zero to a million dollars in no time so we were able to pay it off.”

column1: It was Candela that taught Hearst the nitty gritty of supply chains and logistics
column2: for which she is grateful
column3: but ultimately led to disillusion. “We were making [clothes] for the contemporary market at cheap prices and low quality and there was a total disconnect for me.” In 2011
column4: her father died and she inherited his ranch (that she still runs remotely to this day). Finding herself back in Paysandú “working with tradition
column5: organising animals
column6: [watching] the circle of life” she knew something had to change. “I thought about it and I said
column7: ‘If I am going to put something new out there
column8: it needs to be better made and with a lower environmental impact to anything else.” Four years later
column9: and after much research and planning
column10: her brand was born in partnership with her husband
column11: with whom she has three children
column12: Jack
column13: six
column14: and Olivia and Mia
column15: both 13. It was with his encouragement that Hearst pursued the top job at Chloé
column16: which came about in characteristic go-getting style. “I had one of these crazy Gabi moments when I told my future boss
column17: ‘Look
column18: my name is Gabi
column19: just like the founder Gaby [Aghion] so this is it’!” she laughs. “Then of course I did a 92-page presentation and justified my thought process
column20: but it was really meant to be because it’s a language I love.” To achieve a work-life balance while heading up two of the most successful fashion brands in the world is “very challenging”
column21: she says. “But I have a very supportive family. My husband’s responsibilities changed and adapted so there’s definitely sacrifice.”

column1: Living a “moderated” life that includes bed by 9.30pm to get at least eight hours’ sleep a night
column2: exercise and a healthy diet – “I mean
column3: I’ll derail in certain pressure times and eat too many freaking gummy bears and drink too many coffees
column4: sure” – she believes in keeping a clear head so she can “access information from the subconscious” and she picks what takes her away from home carefully. In November
column5: Hearst spent her birthday in Glasgow on a panel at Cop26 talking about achieving climate success through low-impact business models. “To spend your birthday away from your kids is painful and so if I’m going to do it
column6: I really wanted it to be worth it
column7: and it was.” Her work as trustee of Save the Children since 2018 has also turned her attention to Ghana
column8: Kenya and most recently Afghanistan. Not for the first time
column9: she leveraged the exclusivity of her waiting lists and limited-edition designs this December and donated 100% of net proceeds across all items in her flagship stores in London and New York as well as her website to the charity’s Afghanistan Crisis Children’s Relief Fund. “I don’t like it when brands bombard me with gifting lists and things like that
column10: ” she says. “The period of the holidays is about giving and consciousness of others
column11: so I’m not comfortable with just selling a product to make more money. Can’t we think of other people? Afghanistan is one of the places that is hell on earth right now and why do those children have to suffer? It may not be on the news now
column12: but that doesn’t mean the problem has been eradicated.” This year
column13: she quietly launched the Gabriela Hearst Youth Program in the States
column14: too
column15: to create a space for teenagers to be able to channel anxieties through teaching them about fabrics and the future of fashion design. One of her proudest accomplishments of the year
column16: it says a lot about Hearst’s motivation for doing everything she does. Two of her main takeaways from the Cop26 summit this year were: “Anyone who fights the youth will lose” and that when it comes to the environment
column17: we’re all supposed to leave our kids better off than when we started. “The mission is all worth it
column18: ” she says. “I can honestly say to my kids that I tried
column19: I freaking tried.”";https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2022/jan/02/fashion-designer-gabriela-hearst-i-could-have-gone-back-to-selling-cattle

column1: 5973;5973;Write it All Down by Cathy Rentzenbrink review – an arm around the shoulder for aspiring authors;2022-01-02T11:00:16Z;['Alex Preston'];['Autobiography and memoir'
column2: 'Books'
column3: 'Culture'];"In the weeks after my grandfather died in 2019
column4: I spent a melancholy few days sorting through the “Gramps” section of my filing cupboard
column5: mainly the many letters he’d sent to me over the years. It was a way
column6: I suppose
column7: of continuing the 40-year conversation we’d had about books
column8: of keeping his voice loud in my mind. One letter struck me with particular force
column9: though – a page and a half in response to a short story I’d sent him aged 10. It was typical of his letters about my writing: warm yet forthright in its criticism
column10: even at this early stage showing something that I came to recognise as a gift – the fact that he took me seriously as an author
column11: that this was feedback from one writer to another. It’s one of the central messages in Cathy Rentzenbrink’s wise and generous book about the writer’s life
column12: Write it All Down; this idea that one of the hardest things for a writer to do is to take themselves and their work seriously. There is
column13: as she acknowledges early on here
column14: an awful lot of snake oil sold in the creative writing industry: “Books that are too focused on structure make me want to cry
column15: ” she says. “Their authors seem to enjoy discussing the classical three-act structure
column16: protagonists and antagonists and all that
column17: but it is just too cold a way to go about things for me
column18: and I know it would never lead to anything good.” Write it All Down is not a book that gives you structure; rather it helps the aspirant writer fashion a vessel into which they might safely pour the contents of their heart.

column1: In a series of short
column2: chatty chapters
column3: Rentzenbrink doles out advice that conveys one central message: that in writing
column4: we become writers. This is not a book whose intended audience has had the privilege of a creative writing MA (or a sternly encouraging grandfather); it’s for anyone who picks up a pen
column5: or sits before the ominously blank computer screen
column6: and wonders if they have it in them to write. Rentzenbrink’s own background is salutary: her father was a miner who couldn’t read or write for most of his life. Her youth was marked with tragedy
column7: as recorded in her devastating memoir The Last Act of Love. She is now a furiously productive author – since that memoir in 2015 she has written four other books
column8: including a brilliantly caustic first novel
column9: Everyone Is Still Alive.

column1: Rentzenbrink teaches classes on life writing for Arvon
column2: and at Kestle Barton in Cornwall
column3: and reading Write it All Down feels like a decent second best to being in the classroom with her. She is disarmingly frank about both the limitations of creative writing as an academic discipline – “I don’t have all the answers and don’t believe that anyone does” – and on the challenges of entering an industry that is perhaps the most competitive and least well remunerated of any. Not to mention the physical and mental challenges of getting anything down on paper at all – “almost all writers exist in a continual vortex of despair and doubt”. What Write it All Down does more than anything
column4: though
column5: is to make the reader – the writer! – feel part of a community. Rentzenbrink peppers her work with thoughtful answers to the questions that get in the way of writing: “Should I work if I am ill? What about when depressed? How do I know if I’m doing it right? I keep getting stuck… I’m so confused!” At the end there are messages of solidarity and inspiration from a host of other writers
column6: from Lucy Mangan to Matt Haig to Maggie O’Farrell. They underline the collaborative
column7: confidence-building ethos of the book
column8: which provides an arm around the shoulder as we struggle with that most difficult of things: the “tricky
column9: slippery business” of writing. Write it All Down: How to Put Your Life on the Page by Cathy Rentzenbrink is published by Pan Macmillan (£14.99). To support the Guardian and the Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/02/write-it-all-down-by-cathy-rentzenbrink-review-an-arm-around-the-shoulder-for-aspiring-authors

column4: 'Health'];"A whistleblower in the Canadian province of New Brunswick has warned that a progressive neurological illness that has baffled experts for more than two years appears to be affecting a growing number of young people and causing swift cognitive decline among some of the afflicted. Speaking to the Guardian
column5: an employee with Vitalité Health Network
column6: one of the province’s two health authorities
column7: said that suspected cases are growing in number and that young adults with no prior health triggers are developing a catalog of troubling symptoms
column8: including rapid weight loss
column9: insomnia
column10: hallucinations
column11: difficulty thinking and limited mobility. The official number of cases under investigation
column13: remains unchanged since it was first announced in early spring 2021. But multiple sources say the cluster could now be as many as 150 people
column14: with a backlog of cases involving young people still requiring further assessment. “I’m truly concerned about these cases because they seem to evolve so fast
column15: ” said the source. “I’m worried for them and we owe them some kind of explanation.” At the same time
column16: at least nine cases have been recorded in which two people in close contact – but without genetic links – have developed symptoms
column17: suggesting that environmental factors may be involved. One suspected case involved a man who was developing symptoms of dementia and ataxia. His wife
column18: who was his caregiver
column19: suddenly began losing sleep and experiencing muscle wasting
column20: dementia and hallucinations. Now her condition is worse than his. A woman in her 30s was described as non-verbal
column21: is feeding with a tube and drools excessively. Her caregiver
column22: a nursing student in her 20s
column23: also recently started showing symptoms of neurological decline. In another case
column24: a young mother quickly lost nearly 60 pounds
column25: developed insomnia and began hallucinating. Brain imaging showed advanced signs of atrophy. The Vitalité employee
column26: who asked not to be named because they were unauthorized to speak publicly and feared repercussions for speaking out
column27: said they decided to come forward because of growing concerns over the speed with which young people have deteriorated. “This is not a New Brunswick disease
column28: ” said the employee. “We’re probably the area that is raising the flag because we’re mostly rural and in an area where people might have more exposure to environmental factors.”

column1: But in January
column2: the province of New Brunswick is widely expected to announce that the cluster of cases
column3: first made public last year after a memo was leaked to the media
column4: is the result of misdiagnoses
column5: which have mistakenly grouped unrelated illnesses together. The Special Neurodegenerative Disorder Clinic
column6: also called the Mind Clinic
column7: in the city of Moncton is the clearing house for cases referred from within the region as well as neighbouring provinces. Prospective cases have typically stumped doctors and resisted a battery of standardized neurological tests used to rule out certain conditions. Using a case description guideline developed by a team of neurologists and epidemiologists
column8: the clinic decides if the patients warrant further investigation or if they may have a known illness or disease. Determining who becomes part of the cluster is subjective
column9: largely because the brain is notoriously difficult to study. Certainty is often only obtained after the patient dies and the cerebral tissue can be fully tested. Despite the striking details surrounding the newer cases
column10: the province has worked to tamp down fears. In October
column11: officials suggested that the eight fatal cases were the result of misdiagnosis
column12: arguing that instead of suffering from a shared neurological illness
column13: the victims had died of known and unrelated pathologies. But experts familiar with the cluster are alarmed
column14: largely because of the age of the patients. Neurological illnesses are rare in young people. “The fact that we have a younger spectrum of patients here argues very strongly against what appears to be the preferred position of the government of New Brunswick – that the cases in this cluster are being mistakenly lumped together
column15: ” said a scientist at the Canada’s public health agency
column16: who specializes in neurodegenerative illnesses but was unauthorized to speak. In October the province also said an epidemiological report suggested there was no significant evidence of any known food

column11: 'Coronavirus'];"Of the handful of historic working farms in the UK
column12: Acton Scott Farm is perhaps the best known. The Shropshire farm was the setting for the BBC series Victorian Farm
column13: and generations of schoolchildren have visited the rolling Shropshire hills to see the shire horses plough the fields and the dairymaid milk the cows. Yet the future of the farm is in serious doubt. Shropshire council
column14: which runs the farm
column15: shut it down in June after an outbreak of E coli and there are no plans to reopen it. In the coming weeks
column16: the council will launch a consultation inviting the public to come up with ideas about how to fund Acton Scott Farm
column17: which it says loses £168
column18: 000 a year. But campaigners are desperate to ensure the survival of England’s first historic working farm
column19: where workers in period costume demonstrate traditional skills and use horse-drawn ploughs to work the land and manage the rare breed livestock.

column1: Already there are concerns among the villagers in Church Stretton that the decision has in effect been taken. Shropshire council’s cabinet had been due to consider an “options appraisal” in November
column2: but the decision was delayed by the byelection caused by Owen Paterson’s resignation as the MP for North Shropshire. This month’s consultation was announced only after a local campaign had begun. Some of the farm animals have already been sold. The flock of six pygmy goats is gone. Of the five Gloucester Old Spot pigs
column3: only two are left. The Shropshire sheep
column4: the Dairy Shorthorn cattle and the pair of magnificent shire horses remain
column5: as do the ducks
column6: geese and chickens
column7: although they are in lockdown to avoid becoming infected with bird flu. Shropshire council said that animals are sold regularly as part of the farm’s stock management programme and the majority of the rare breed animals have remained. The campaign to save the farm was started by Alice Walker
column8: a barmaid in Church Stretton who has been a regular visitor since she was a child. “It’s a really special place
column9: ” she said. “You can see them tacking up the horses and ploughing the ground
column10: then drilling it with old drills. We have visitors from all over – Australia
column11: America – there’s a big Canadian following.”

column1: The farm was founded in 1975 by Tom Acton
column2: whose family has owned the farm estate for more than 900 years. His ancestor
column3: Richard Acton
column4: built the family’s Elizabethan manor house in 1580. Acton
column5: who died last year aged 95
column6: had been keen to retain traditional farm methods and had built a collection of Victorian seed drills and ploughs. It was picked by the BBC for Victorian Farm
column7: a series charting a year when the historian Ruth Goodman and archaeologists Alex Langlands and Peter Ginn lived on the farm reliving the experience of Victorian farmers. The farm also offers training and qualifications in traditional rural crafts and trades
column8: from stone masonry to wheelwrighting
column9: and Walker did an NVQ there when she was young. “We started to hear whispers
column10: ” Walker said. “We had the Covid closures
column11: and then the E coli outbreak. I thought it was slipping off the radar and it might have closed without anybody realising it was even an option. So I started a group. “I thought it would be me and my mum shouting in a room
column12: but we had 1
column13: 000 Facebook members in less than a month.” The group has had all sorts of support – from a woman whose mother donated her old English game chickens to the farm when it opened to people whose grandfather was educated in the schoolhouse.

column2: and the chief executive
column3: Christopher Price
column4: wrote to the council last month
column5: urging it to “ensure that the farm remains safeguarded for the future”. The E coli outbreak in June involved two visits and a council health and safety report recommended “essential works” costing £130
column6: 000 were required. Shropshire council said that visitor numbers peaked at around 45
column7: 000 a year in 2009
column8: when Victorian Farm first aired. However
column9: since then
column10: numbers have fallen to an average of 20
column11: 000 a year since 2014
column12: the council said. A spokesperson said: “Shropshire council
column13: like many other local authorities
column14: is facing an extremely challenging financial future and it is in this climate that an options appraisal has been undertaken to determine whether an alternative commercially viable model is achievable.” Cecilia Motley
column15: Shropshire council’s cabinet member for communities
column16: culture
column17: leisure and tourism
column18: and transport

column1: 5982;5982;Can you capture the complex reality of the pandemic with numbers? Well
column2: we tried… | David Spiegelhalter and Anthony Masters;2022-01-02T10:00:14Z;['David Spiegelhalter'
column3: 'Anthony Masters'];['Coronavirus'
column4: 'Infectious diseases'
column5: 'World news'
column6: 'Science'];"Individual experiences and suffering are
column7: of course
column8: at the heart of the pandemic. But one way to understand what has happened is through putting those experiences together – and statistics are those personal stories writ large. And this pandemic has brought unprecedented demand to explain all the numbers that have been flying around. This has not been without its problems and we’ve had to learn some hard lessons
column9: such as the journalistic skill of brevity. Since January 2021
column10: we’ve been writing a weekly column in this paper about Covid numbers
column11: covering everything from infections to deaths
column12: vaccines to mental health
column13: masks to lockdowns. It can be frustrating not being able to show all the graphs
column14: but the same holds for radio and TV interviews and More or Less on Radio 4 has shown how much can be done to explain statistics without visual aids. Mathematical formulae and technical jargon need to be avoided
column15: but we have also had to be sparing with numbers
column16: which is harder when they are so precious to us. We had to agree our purpose
column17: as a particular challenge is to fend off the voracious media appetite for blame
column18: speculation and controversy
column19: naturally fed by the broad spectrum of opinion among experts. One camp has supported viral suppression and even elimination
column20: while others have expressed scepticism about the measures taken; it’s become a cliche that their extreme followers can be identified by the phrase “I’ve done my own research”. In the theatre of political combat
column21: numbers are often weapons to beat opponents
column22: but they should really be used to raise the quality of the debate. So we see ourselves as part of a group who have attempted to keep away from policy disputes and some of our most trusted sources are skilled individuals doing analyses in their spare time
column23: who then share their insights on Twitter – to inform rather than persuade. Unfortunately
column24: this pandemic has been rife with false claims and misinformation
column25: particularly about vaccines. One approach for dealing with this
column26: supported by empirical evidence
column27: is the idea of “inoculation” – pre-empting misinformation and telling people about the incorrect interpretation before they catch it in the wild.

column1: We tried this strategy back in June 2021 when Public Health England first published data showing that
column2: among older people who had recently died with Covid-19
column3: most had been vaccinated. We wrote an article pointing out that this did not mean the vaccine was ineffective – just that it was imperfect – and that the great majority of people had been vaccinated: in essence
column4: a small proportion of a large number can be bigger than a larger proportion of a small number. Another useful analogy is with seatbelts: most people who die in car accidents are wearing seatbelts
column5: but this does not mean that seatbelts are not effective – it’s just that nearly everyone wears one and they are not perfect. The response to our “pre-bunking” was not encouraging. The Twitter link to our article included only its title
column6: Why most people who now die with Covid in England have had a vaccination
column7: and not the subhead
column8: Don’t think of this as a bad sign
column9: it’s exactly what’s expected from an effective but imperfect jab. As such
column10: it was mistakenly interpreted as an anti-vaccination article (or worse) and circulated online. This
column11: in turn
column12: led to critical comments suggesting that we had encouraged vaccine scepticism and even an extraordinary tweet saying we (and the paper’s editors) were “genocidal” and should be “hunted down and destroyed”. We made light of this
column13: saying this seemed a bit harsh
column14: but we had had worse referees’ reports. That account was subsequently removed from Twitter. Among the repeatable insults
column15: DS has been called an “idiot”
column16: a “shameless liar” and “Nazi collaborator”. Of course
column17: this is mild compared to what others have received (although “fossil” did hurt).

column1: It got more complicated in September 2021 when ITV’s political editor
column2: Robert Peston
column3: tweeted (and later deleted) “Infections higher among double vaxxed for those 40 to 79 than for non-vaxxed”. Surprisingly
column4: he was not referring to the absolute case numbers
column5: which could be explained using the reasoning above. Instead
column6: this referred to the case rates per 100
column7: 000 people reported by Public Health England. That seems strange
column8: but can be explained by PHE’s use of National Immunisation Management System (NIMS) for population figures
column9: which uses GP lists and so tends to overcount due to many and defunct registrations. Using Office for National Statistics (ONS) population estimates
column10: themselves uncertain
column11: leads to the expected lower case-rates in vaccinated than unvaccinated groups. This UK data
column12: apparently showing higher case rates in the vaccinated than the unvaccinated
column13: was later used by Brazil’s President Bolsonaro to support his bizarre claim that vaccines cause Aids. Complaints by the watchdog Office for Statistics Regulation have had little impact and PHE’s successor
column14: the UK Health Security Agency
column15: stubbornly refuses to change its publication (even though unvaccinated rates are in a lighter font)
column16: so that these misleading numbers continue to feed vaccine misinformation. These stories might give a poor impression of how the media has handled Covid-19 numbers. But
column17: on balance
column18: our impression is that a valiant attempt has been made by most outlets to explain their complexities. All
column19: of course
column20: impossible without the extraordinary behind-the-scenes work of those who produce the Covid dashboard
column21: the ONS Infection Survey
column22: and the other sources that it is too easy to take for granted. We started working together through the Royal Statistical Society
column23: since statisticians care deeply about the use of numerical evidence in public debate. Data does not speak for itself – it needs people to speak honestly and carefully on its behalf. A misunderstood statistic could have terrible consequences – in health
column24: wealth and justice. By contrast
column25: better statistics should lead to better debate and
column26: we hope
column27: better decisions. • David Spiegelhalter is chair of the Winton Centre for Risk and Evidence Communication at Cambridge. Anthony Masters is statistical ambassador for the Royal Statistical Society. Their book
column28: Covid by Numbers: Making Sense of the Pandemic With Data
column29: is published by Penguin";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/2021-year-when-interpreting-covid-statistics-crucial-to-reach-truth

The Ukrainian conductor Oksana Lyniv said she was surprised to learn she was making history after receiving the offer from the Teatro Comunale opera house in Bologna. The 43-year-old begins the three-year posting as musical director this month. “I didn’t realise
column7: when I received the letter from the Teatro Comunale

column9: ” she said. “I am very honoured and happy to be part of this historical turning point.” It is not the first time Lyniv

column12: she became the first female conductor to open Germany’s Bayreuth opera festival in its 145-year-history. She conducted Richard Wagner’s Flying Dutchman to a rapturous audience that included the former German chancellor Angela Merkel.

column1: Born in Brody

column3: to musician parents

She said it was difficult for female musicians to get on at the time as the majority of conductors and teachers were male. “There was no live example of a woman who we could learn or get advice from

column4: I mean

In the hopes of getting a sense of my son’s development over the past year

column1: 5987;5987;The BBC’s Ros Atkins: ‘I do a bit of body-boarding… posting videos is like catching a wave’;2022-01-02T09:30:14Z;['Michael Hogan'];['Television'
column2: 'Culture'
column3: 'Television & radio'
column4: 'BBC'
column5: 'Radio'
column6: 'X'];"Ros Atkins
column8: grew up in Cornwall and the Caribbean before reading history at Cambridge. His BBC career began on Radio 5 Live shortly after 9/11. He now presents Outside Source on the BBC News Channel and recently went viral for his “explainer” videos
column9: broadcast on BBC Breakfast and posted online. He lives in south London with his wife and two daughters. How are you finding newfound fame? Well
column10: I’ve neither been mobbed nor chased down the street
column11: but it’s always pleasant if people pay attention to what you do. You’ve been called “the Facts Man” and “2021’s explainer-in-chief”. Happy with those descriptions? I’ve been called a lot worse
column12: so I’ll take either of those more flattering monikers. How did you hit upon the explainer format? I’ve long been passionate about explanation as a form of news journalism. I launched Outside Source in 2014
column13: so it’s a culmination of seven years of honing how we use language and images to explain stories as clearly as possible. I’ve definitely ended up using a different tone to a classic news bulletin. Three years ago
column14: I noticed that the format was very successful on TV but not getting traction digitally. It wasn’t working for audiences who consume news online. I started to study different types of storytelling – how friends do it in the pub
column15: how comedians
column16: podcasters and documentary-makers do it. That took me to a different place in terms of how I offer up information.

column1: It’s been called “assertive impartiality”. Is that what you were aiming for? In some ways
column2: what we’re doing is new. In others
column3: it’s as old as the BBC itself. The BBC’s journalism has always been rooted in facts
column4: fairness
column5: objectivity and providing context. These videos reimagine how we do that. Partly because of how politics has evolved
column6: our approach to impartiality was struggling to cope. There was an appetite from audiences to be more robust in our assessments of what’s true. Let’s properly dissect what people are saying. If it’s not true
column7: let’s say so – in no uncertain terms. You don’t bring opinion or emotion into it. It’s simply about using language that’s sparse and direct to help viewers understand. “Assertive impartiality” isn’t my phrase
column8: but it’s not a bad description. The videos get shared by people from both ends of the political spectrum. Is that a sign that they strike the right balance? The number of views has been a lovely surprise
column9: but I’d put that on a par with the fact that they’ve been well received across the spectrum. It’s thrilling that influential people
column10: from a whole range of political backgrounds
column11: think the videos are helpful.

column1: Your video about Downing Street Christmas parties was watched 6m times on Twitter. What’s it like going viral? I’m normally sitting on the train home when the videos go live. For a news clip to get a million views on Twitter is very unusual. Six times that is extraordinary. Your messages suddenly light up. It also goes through stages. You might get an initial flurry of activity
column2: then it’ll pause. You assume it’s run its course
column3: but then someone like Prof Brian Cox or Gary Lineker might share it and it’ll gather momentum again. I do a bit of body-boarding and posting videos is a bit like catching a wave. Do you have trouble keeping a straight face during belief-beggaring reports? No
column4: it’s the news and what we’re covering is serious. There may be elements within a story that people find humorous
column5: but for me
column6: the facts take centre-stage. I could’ve sworn I saw the hint of a smile when you said: “Drinks
column7: nibbles
column8: games”… Never! You have a very consistent look. How many blue shirts and jackets do you own? An awful lot. A stylist called Jane Field said navy blue suited me
column9: so we went shopping in Oxford Street and bought loads. It means the videos all look the same – same shot
column10: similar clothes – so people recognise them when they pop up in their feed.

column1: You’ve broadcast from home a lot over the past two years. How’s that been? Quite convenient
column2: actually. I set up my study as a home studio. I used three spare mattresses for soundproofing. I got a pallet from a skip down the street and put my chair on it
column3: so it was at camera level. My younger daughter
column4: who’s 10
column5: operated my autocue and became very proficient. We made signs saying “No entry
column6: live on-air”. The doorbell rang occasionally
column7: but there’s not much you can do about that. Do your daughters find it strange that you’re on social media more than them? There’s certainly a pretty direct correlation between the popularity of these videos and my family’s frustration about how much time I’m on Twitter. They often say: “Dad
column8: put your phone down.” I always say: “But it’s a big story” and they say: “It’s always a big story.” You were once a drum’n’bass DJ. Do you still hit the decks on occasion? No
column9: but I might come back to it when the kids are older. My last gig was in the mid 00s at a festival in Regent’s Park. Our first daughter was born a few days later. You’re the founder of The 50:50 Project
column10: to increase representation of women in media content. What inspired that? I started it in 2016
column11: primarily aimed at my own programme. We all felt that gender balance in our journalism was important
column12: but weren’t managing to achieve it. On a trip to California
column13: I visited lots of academics
column14: corporate people and newsroom leaders
column15: which rearranged my brain. We started systematically generating data on everything we produce. This self-monitoring system worked
column16: other BBC teams joined in and it snowballed. Now it’s in more than 100 organisations in 25 countries. We’re all incredibly proud of it. Most importantly
column17: it’s delivered significant shifts in the diversity of what we make. What makes you happy when you’re not working? I love squash but got a nasty knee injury
column18: so I’m waiting to have surgery before I can play again. I’ve got quite into running instead. I started cooking in lockdown. I used to be terrible but my wife
column19: Sara
column20: got me a book called Persiana by Sabrina Ghayour
column21: which changed my entire view of the kitchen. Otherwise
column22: I just love pottering about with football on the radio. I follow Dulwich Hamlet and Plymouth Argyle. How do you see politics panning out in 2022 and how will your explainers fit in? I’ve given up all predictions since 2016. The pandemic is obviously ongoing. So is the Brexit process. It’s hard to imagine these huge stories won’t continue to dominate the news. There’s so much information coming at all of us and people want a hand with that. Someone said that watching my videos is like having 10 podcasts and five long reads crammed into your head within a few minutes. They’re a shortcut. There was a groundswell of opinion last year that you should do an explainer for Line of Duty too… I saw that. There are limits to what the team can do. Perhaps the Line of Duty finale is beyond us.";https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/02/ros-atkins-bbc-explainer-videos-viral-interview

column1: 5988;5988;It’s not the police’s job to shut down political debate. They should stick to solving crime | Sonia Sodha;2022-01-02T09:30:13Z;['Sonia Sodha'];['Women'
column2: 'Transgender'
column3: 'Society'
column4: 'Men'
column5: 'Law'];"A man gets a call from a police officer. He is told that
column6: while he has done nothing criminal
column7: his social media posts have offended someone
column8: so the police have recorded them as a non-crime hate incident that may show up on criminal record checks. The officer warns that if he continues to “escalate” matters
column9: the police may take criminal action against him
column10: a message later reinforced by his superiors. It may sound like something out of a police state. But this happened in Britain in 2019
column11: in a case that led the high court judge who later ruled the actions of Humberside police force unlawful to warn them
column12: “in this country we have never had a Cheka
column13: a Gestapo or a Stasi”. Despite there being no evidence that Harry Miller
column14: the man in question
column15: might ever stray into unlawful speech
column16: the police took action that reasonably led him to believe that he was being warned not to exercise his right to freedom of expression on pain of potential criminal prosecution; they also opined to the press that Miller’s tweets were “transphobic”. And just before Christmas
column17: in a landmark judgment that has attracted surprisingly little commentary from human rights lawyers given its profound implications
column18: the court of appeal went further in ruling that the College of Policing’s guidance that the police should record all non-crime hate incidents
column19: as perceived by those taking offence at them
column20: is an unlawful incursion on citizens’ freedom of expression. How did we get to the position where an individual had to risk financial ruin to legally defend his right to free expression in the face of unlawful police actions? The well-intentioned roots of police recording non-crime hate incidents stem from the 1999 Macpherson report into Stephen Lawrence’s murder in 1993
column21: which found institutional racism in the Metropolitan police. Macpherson recommended that the police adopt the definition of a racist incident as any “perceived to be racist by the victim or any other person” and that non-crime incidents should be reported
column22: recorded and investigated with equal commitment to crimes. The aim was to help the police overcome their institutional racism and to build confidence within ethnic minority communities. This has today evolved into a system of recording non-crime hate incidents that cover five of the nine protected characteristics in the Equality Act
column23: including transgender identity (but not
column24: bizarrely
column25: sex). In a world where the police do not have the resources to investigate non-crime incidents
column26: partly because of the volume of reports generated by social media
column27: the College of Policing tells police officers to record as hate incidents all those perceived by the person reporting them as motivated by hostility
column28: including unfriendliness or dislike. This has become open to manipulation
column29: with sinister consequences for freedom of expression. Anyone can complain to the police if they don’t like something someone says. It will get recorded as a hate incident
column30: in a way that could significantly damage careers and reputations but with none of the due process of a criminal charge. And it is impossible to overstate the chilling impact of getting a call from a police officer warning you off exercising your democratic rights.

column1: Miller is chair of the Reclaim party
column2: led by Laurence Fox; hardly a political ally of this newspaper. The judge noted his tweets were “for the most part
column3: either opaque
column4: profane or unsophisticated”. But that does not justify impeding his right to contribute to a live and contentious political debate on the relative importance of biological sex and self-declared gender identity in determining how society constitutes things such as single-sex spaces and sports. It is a far from settled matter with legitimate competing perspectives. Yet people (often women) of the “gender critical” view – that biological sex cannot be wholly replaced by gender identity in law and society – have been vulnerable to incursions on their free expression
column5: because opponents have sought to misrepresent their position as so hateful that it is beyond the limits of legitimate discussion. (The absurdity of this mischaracterisation is shown up in the confirmation by the courts last year that the scientific understanding that biological sex is immutable is a protected belief under equalities law.) There are several other cases where the police have acted inappropriately against people lawfully expressing this position. Some forces even have a track record of misstating the law to the public: last February
column6: Merseyside police wrongly claimed “being offensive is an offence”
column7: while the West Yorkshire police in 2018 threatened to prosecute anyone posting “insulting” messages on its Facebook page. The police need to be politically impartial – they must not police people differently because of their political opinions. Yet there are numerous examples of police forces actively taking political sides in the sex and gender debate. Paul Giannasi
column8: the national policing adviser for hate crime
column9: has praised Lancashire police for expressing disappointment at lawful expressions of gender critical belief
column10: congratulating them for their “initiative and empathy” in doing so. Several police forces pay the LGBT charity Stonewall for advice and training
column11: despite Stonewall’s promotion of a contested political stance on gender identity. The police officer who unlawfully warned off Miller told him
column12: Miller said
column13: that a foetus could have a female brain but grow male body parts
column14: later confirming he learned this unscientific belief on a training course. Greater Manchester police social media accounts have used and defended the derogatory and misogynistic term “terf”
column15: associated with rape and death threats against women expressing gender-critical beliefs. Several dreadful murder cases from the last year have served as a reminder that many police forces remain tarnished by institutional misogyny
column16: racism and homophobia. But there are no shortcuts to the cultural change essential for the non-discriminatory policing all citizens have the right to expect. Telling the police to record all non-criminal hate incidents or to believe all victims despite their role as investigators are inappropriately blunt approaches that undermine fair and impartial policing. The court of appeal judgment’s implications for free expression go way beyond policing: it observes “how quickly some involved in the transgender debate are prepared to accuse others with whom they disagree of showing hatred
column17: or as being transphobic when they are not”. We see this everywhere: from Harry Potter actors condemning JK Rowling for her “hateful” views
column18: to broadcasters saying interviewees should be “cancelled” for saying biological sex is immutable
column19: to academics such as Kathleen Stock abused for wrongthink. There is no democracy without freedom of expression. That the police have unlawfully acted to shut down legitimate political debate in 21st-century Britain should remind us that
column20: even in mature democracies
column21: the most basic human rights should never be taken for granted. • This article was amended on 4 January 2022. An earlier version said: “it is impossible to understate the chilling impact of a call from a police officer warning you off exercising your democratic rights”. The intended word was overstate. • Sonia Sodha is an Observer columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/policing-sex-and-gender-debate-worrying-freedom-of-expression

column6: 'US sports'];"DeMar DeRozan hit a three-pointer at the buzzer for the second straight game to give the Chicago Bulls a 120-119 win over the Washington Wizards on Saturday night. Kyle Kuzma’s three-pointer with 3.3 seconds to play gave Washington a 119-117 lead

column1: DeRozan finished with 28 points and Zach LaVine had 35 points to help the Bulls to their seventh straight win

column2: 'Spa breaks'
column3: 'Coronavirus'
column4: 'Health'
column5: 'Health & wellbeing'
column6: 'Health and fitness holidays'
column7: 'Healthcare industry'];"Underneath the shadow of the snow-topped Austrian Alps
column8: in front of a forest of thick green trees and behind a pure azure lake
column9: sits a sprawling chalet that has seen everyone from Kate Moss to Michael Gove pass through its wide glass doors. The VivaMayr health resort in Altaussee
column10: Austria
column11: has long been the picturesque home of celebrity detoxes – strict bans on caffeine and alcohol
column12: combined with stricter rules about the number of times you need to chew your food (40
column13: naturally) have helped numerous celebrity clientele lose weight. The detoxing might sound harsh
column14: but tranquillity oozes through the resort’s Instagram page
column15: where enchanting mists tickle thick evergreen trees and women pose with mugs in sleek
column16: pine interiors. It’s not the image that comes to mind when you think “long-Covid clinic”
column17: but it is one. For £2
column18: 700 a week (excluding accommodation)
column19: sufferers can attend VivaMayr’s post-Covid medical programme
column20: which promises a “better quality of life”. There is currently no cure for long Covid – the condition in which individuals continue to suffer Covid-19 symptoms for months after first being infected – but there are plenty of treatments. There is an entire network of specialist NHS long-Covid clinics across the United Kingdom – here
column21: patients can undergo rehabilitative programmes to help them improve their stamina
column22: breathing and cognitive functions (for many
column23: long Covid is characterised by fatigue
column24: breathlessness
column25: and concentration problems). Yet in September
column26: the Office for National Statistics estimated that 1.1 million people in the UK currently suffer with long Covid
column27: while between July and August
column28: only 5
column29: 737 people were referred to specialist NHS clinics. With the Omicron variant threatening more lives
column30: there’s a gap in the market for long-Covid care
column31: and plenty of private practitioners are happy to fill it – for a price. Gwyneth Paltrow was one of the first. In February 2021
column32: the actor and businesswoman wrote a blogpost on her lifestyle website
column33: Goop
column34: detailing her post-Covid regime
column35: which included fasting and “doing an infrared sauna as often as I can”. Paltrow’s post helpfully listed the numerous products she’d used to get a handle on her “long-tail fatigue and brain fog”: £112 Goopbrand vitamin C serum
column36: a nearly-£400 sauna blanket
column37: and a single £105 drinking glass (purchasable from the Goop site) via which long-Covid sufferers can sip non-alcoholic gin (also helpfully linked). The National Medical Director of NHS England
column38: Stephen Powis
column39: warned against Paltrow’s advice
column40: saying
column41: “Some of the solutions she’s recommending are really not the solutions we’d recommend in the NHS. We need to take long Covid seriously and apply serious science.” But Paltrow is far from the only person who can be accused of commercialising and commodifying long-Covid treatments. Over the course of the past year
column42: numerous long-Covid wellness retreats have sprung up across the globe
column43: offering treatments for breath-taking prices. In ascending order of eye watering
column44: there’s: the Park Igls Fit After Covid “therapeutic module” in Austria for £3
column45: 000 a week; the RAKxa long Covid programme in Thailand at £2
column46: 893 for three nights; and the Arrigo Long Covid Healing Programme in Somerset
column48: 500 a day (minimum seven-day stay). Then there’s VivaMayr
column49: where patients can exercise in the Alpine air
column50: jump into the icy lake and have frequent massages to help them relieve their symptoms.

column1: All four of the above programmes involve qualified medical professionals
column2: diagnostic tests and tailored diets alongside wellness practices
column3: such as yoga
column4: mud baths
column5: “aquagymnastics” and acupuncture. Although there are some unorthodox treatments on offer – Park Igls promises patients “three liver compresses with beeswax”
column6: while RAKxa patients undergo Ya-Pao therapy
column7: in which a paste is applied to their chest and set on fire – these complement traditional medicine. Brendan Delaney is a professor of medicine at Imperial College London who
column8: alongside 30 other doctors
column9: spent six months putting together a set of recommendations for recognising and managing long Covid; it was published in the British Journal of General Practice in November. Delaney personally isn’t too concerned about the types of treatments on offer to patients at long-Covid retreats. “They’re getting the medical input and then they’re getting the rehab type input via some form of wellness activity
column10: ” Delaney says. “If they happen to be able to afford to have that in a trip to the Austrian Alps
column11: well that’s a wonderful place to have your rehab.” The problem
column12: of course
column13: is that the vast majority of long-Covid sufferers can’t afford it. “The idea that long Covid patients are the Knightsbridge worried-well that can ship off and do these kind of wellness things is completely erroneous. The biggest groups [of sufferers] are healthcare workers and teachers
column14: followed by care home staff
column15: because they’ve had the biggest exposure to Covid early on
column16: and possibly quite large viral loads
column17: ” says Delaney
column18: who himself has had long Covid for almost two years. Although most sufferers can’t afford bespoke multi-thousand pound retreats
column19: Delaney says that many do seek private help
column20: be it “packages of online wellness treatment for a few hundred pounds” or hyperbaric oxygen therapy
column21: a treatment where patients breathe pure oxygen at high pressures to help oxygenate their tissues and promote healing. “If you’re in a situation where you are unable to work
column22: you feel awful
column23: and you can’t carry out your family and your social obligations

column13: 'Motoring'];It’s a new year and many of us are looking for a fresh start after a very difficult 2021. We’ve asked a group of experts for their advice on how to tackle some of the most common personal finance dilemmas. I want to spend less money this year
column14: what should I do? Damien Fahy
column15: founder of personal finance site Money to the Masses The key to spending less is having a budget – if you can quantify it
column16: you can control it. Luckily
column17: there are lots of resources to help work out a monthly budget
column18: including budgeting and banking apps. I’d recommend Money Dashboard and Emma. Try using the “three-day rule” to curb frivolous spending – if you want something
column19: wait three days before buying it to see if you genuinely want or need it
column20: rather than it being a momentary impulse. You can also introduce zero-spend days into your week
column21: aiming to have 24 hours without additional spending
column22: over and above essentials
