column24: founder of the Debt Camel advice blog Overdrafts are a hard type of debt to clear
column25: as your balance keeps changing through the month. But they are also very expensive
column26: so are a priority to tackle. You can be very disciplined
column27: and aim to cut your overdraft usage each month. Many people find it is more practical to change to a new current account with no overdraft and move all of their banking over. That way you can pay off the old overdraft by setting up a standing order from your new account. If you have been continuously in your overdraft for a long while
column28: never getting back into the black
column29: you should also look at making a claim for unaffordable lending. This would be based on whether the bank “completed reasonable and proportionate checks” that you could repay in a sustainable way. Details at the Financial Ombudsman Service website. I need a decent pension. How do I begin? Steve Webb
column30: partner at LCP and former pensions minister If you earn more than £10
column32: your employer should put you in a workplace pension and make a contribution
column33: so simply not opting out is a great start. Next
column34: review your pension contribution each time you get a pay increase
column35: as it’s less painful to commit a bit more before you’ve got used to the extra income. Also
column36: find out if your employer will do more
column37: if you do more. Many bigger firms will match the money you put in (up to a limit). Make the most of this “free money”. Finally
column38: it’s never too late to start. You get good tax breaks for saving in a pension
column39: plus money from your employer
column40: so even building up a small pot is worthwhile. How can I drive an electric car without breaking the bank? Melanie Shufflebotham
column41: co-founder of Zap-Map
column42: which gives information on charging and electric vehicles One of the best routes to getting a good value electric vehicle (EV) is via a salary sacrifice scheme. Another flexible option is to subscribe to a short-term
column43: all-inclusive service such as Onto
column44: which includes insurance
column45: charging and tax
column46: among other expenses. There are also more secondhand EVs available to buy – try out one of the specialist companies
column47: such as Weareev or Drive Green. Once you have secured your electric vehicle
column48: your next step is to get a charge point installed at your home and sign up to an EV energy tariff with discounts for off-peak charging when available
column49: given current energy tariff issues. With this
column50: costs can be as low as 2-3p/mile – even less if you can link it to solar panels. Alternatively
column51: you can check out community charging via Co-Charger
column52: or take a look at the close to 30
column53: 000 public charge points on Zap-Map
column54: about 5
column55: 000 of which are still free to use. Energy bills are killing me
column56: how do I save money? Laura McGadie
column57: group head of energy
column58: Energy Saving Trust There are a series of simple and straightforward things you can do that will save you money without compromising your health or lifestyle. Firstly
column59: turn off devices that are on standby and turn off lights when you leave the room. Be sure to draught-proof around windows
column61: floorboards and skirting boards and insulate hot water cylinders with an 80mm British Standard jacket. In the kitchen
column62: fit an aerator to the tap – it reduces the amount of water flowing – and only boil water you need in the kettle. Reduce the number of washing machine loads you run by one a week
column63: and ensure they are always full. Wash clothes at 30 degrees. Avoid using a tumble dryer – dry clothes outside where possible
column64: or inside with ventilation. Limit shower times to four minutes and swap a weekly bath for a shower. Take all of these steps and you could save up to £248 a year. How can I prepare for my child starting university this year? Laura Brown
column66: Save the Student It’s worth familiarising yourself with the student finance system and
column68: saving up some money to help them get by. Research has found that
column70: students receive £120.56 a month from parents. But one in eight feels their parents don’t give enough financial support. As maintenance loans are generally calculated on household income
column71: you might find the government actually expects you to contribute
column72: offering a smaller loan as a result. We have a parental contributions calculator that helps you work out how much this could be. Saving to financially support your child
column73: as well as sharing your best money-management tips
column74: could make a huge difference. I want to eat more sustainably – what should I do? Sian Conway-Wood
column76: Consume Less The first thing is to not do something – and that is waste food. Households account for 70% of food waste in the UK
column77: and the majority of food thrown away would have been edible. The cost of that adds up to £284 a person each year. Plan ahead
column78: buy what you need and take steps to avoid waste. All of these steps are the first moves towards sustainable eating and can save you money as a result. Potatoes
column79: bread and fresh fruit and vegetables are some of the most wasted foods. We’re often encouraged to buy in bulk
column80: but they can be purchased in smaller quantities. Pay attention to how much you actually use and reduce the amount you buy. I am scared of being scammed. What steps should I take to protect myself? Jason Costain
column81: head of fraud prevention at NatWest When buying goods
column82: only use sellers or shops that accept card payments. Be suspicious when answering calls
column83: texts and emails. There will always be the latest ingenious scam

column90: such as through a salary comparison website like Glassdoor. If you’re already being paid the average salary
column92: it could prove harder to justify an increase
column93: so you may want to go for a promotion

column5: 'Culture'];"In one of Mary Gaitskill’s best short stories
column6: The Agonized Face
column7: a female journalist watches a “feminist author” read at a literary festival. The author begins by complaining about her biographical note in the festival brochure
column8: which
column9: she feels
column10: has played up her past experiences with prostitution and psychiatric wards to make her seem like “a kooky person off somewhere doing unimaginable stuff”. But just after she has persuaded the audience of the unfairness of such a portrayal
column11: the author reads a funny story aloud from her book
column12: which leaves the journalist unimpressed. The story – about an encounter between a man and an older woman – is flimsy and provocative
column13: where the complaint had been tender and serious. “She sprouted three heads
column14: ” the journalist writes
column15: “and asked that we accept them all!” The feminist had evaded something important
column16: according to the journalist
column17: by changing gears so abruptly: “the story she read made what had seemed like dignity look silly and obscene.” Gaitskill’s characters are often unjustly perceived as kooky people doing unimaginable stuff
column18: but her stories are neither silly nor obscene. In Secretary – later made into a treacly film starring Maggie Gyllenhaal and James Spader – you can never quite tell how Debby feels about being abused and spanked by her male boss. Unlike in the movie
column19: there is no blossoming relationship between boss and secretary
column20: but might Debby be looking for dignity in the routine humiliation? In Oppositions
column21: a new collection of Gaitskill’s essays
column22: she asserts that the tragedy of the story is not so much that Debby is a victim
column23: but that a “hunger for contact underlies her perversity and to some extent drives it”. It is a wordless yearning that contemporary feminist discourse now and again skips over in its quest to invert the male gaze and normalise female desire. And yet
column24: as the journalist in The Agonized Face suggests
column25: “sometimes you wish it could be that easy”.

column1: Gaitskill skips over nothing on the page. Her sentences are leavened by a novelist’s spirited discontent with mere facts
column2: a distrust of transparent surfaces. Recounting an incident when she was sexually assaulted at 16
column3: she wonders why she had described it for a while as “rape”. She’d lied “not for revenge but in service of… the metaphorical truth – although what that truth was is not at all clear to me”. In a piece on Lolita
column4: where she is withering about the “haters” who conflate art and life
column5: Gaitskill is moved by Nabokov’s bizarre claim that he was inspired by a newspaper article about a chimpanzee in a zoo that drew with charcoal the bars of its cage. “For those of us for whom metaphors are a natural way of seeing
column6: ” Gaitskill writes
column7: “it makes instant
column8: terrible sense.” The remaining essays – on music
column9: films
column10: the Bible
column11: American sex scandals – together make up a shadow autobiography. We learn
column12: from a piece on the Book of Revelation
column13: that Gaitskill ran away from home in her teens
column14: and that at 21 she was briefly a born-again Christian. A trip to Russia becomes an occasion to recall the time she worked at a strip joint in Canada.

column1: Listening to Talking Heads
column2: she realises how their music was always playing somewhere in the background
column3: and in her head
column4: when she was starting to write in her 20s. A song by B-Movie conjures up memories of a thwarted romance from the 80s. About music
column5: Gaitskill declares at one point that “she is not a fan by nature”
column6: but her longueurs on bands and songs have a certain underhand charm. Fans of her fiction will relish the impossibly cool image of a younger Gaitskill typing out her early stories with the headphones on every morning. With Gaitskill
column7: you scarcely get or sometimes even expect popular opinions
column8: regardless of whether she is riffing on Chekhov or the Clintons. She is seldom persuaded by groupthink
column9: be it the “psychological uniformity of experience” that she decries in both “rape-crisis” American feminists and their critics in the mid-90s
column10: or years later
column11: the “hive-mind” that she feels is at work in the bestselling novel Gone Girl: “There is nothing here but ‘that guy’ or ‘that girl’
column12: and that means nothing
column13: period.” She defends John Updike’s right to be narcissistic
column14: Norman Mailer’s impulse to be a “kook”. I can’t imagine another writer today
column15: in this age of lucrative film rights and airtight confidentiality agreements
column16: even mildly disapproving of a movie based on one of their stories. Gaitskill is gloriously trenchant
column17: but never gimmicky
column18: in these unsparing essays. Oppositions: Selected Essays by Mary Gaitskill is published by Profile (£16.99). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/02/oppositions-by-mary-gaitskill-review-wide-ranging-unsparing-essays

column8: 'Hubble space telescope'];"After years of delay
column9: and massive cost over-runs
column10: the James Webb space telescope (the JWST) was launched on Christmas Day. It will need to perform complex automated operations now it’s in space. The first and most challenging is happening this week: unfurling a heat shield the size of a tennis court. After this
column11: its 6.5-metre mirror must be assembled from 18 pieces packed within the launching rocket’s nose-cone. There’s much that can go wrong and astronomers will remain anxious for the several months that will elapse before all necessary manoevres and tests are completed. After the Hubble Space Telescope was launched more than 30 years ago
column12: its mirror turned out to be poorly aligned. But astronauts undertook a “rescue” mission to make adjustments and later made further visits to upgrade the instruments. The stakes are higher for the JWST: it’s vastly more elaborate
column13: but there is no prospect of a repair mission. The Hubble telescope was in a low (and accessible) orbit: in contrast
column14: the JWST’s orbit will be several times further away than the moon – far beyond the reach of astronauts. Some might argue that we therefore need to instigate more ambitious plans for human spaceflight: to enable human assembly of large structures in deep space
column15: to return to the moon
column16: and eventually to reach Mars. But I don’t share this view. Indeed as robotics and miniaturisation improve
column17: the practical and scientific case for human spaceflight weakens. Its prime motive now is simply as an adventure – an ultra-expensive sport that should be left to billionaires and private sponsorship. Space technology has burgeoned – for communication
column18: environmental monitoring
column19: satnav and so forth. We depend on it every day. Unmanned probes to other planets have beamed back pictures of varied and distinctive worlds. And telescopes in space have revolutionised our knowledge of the cosmos. During this century
column20: the whole solar system will be explored by flotillas of miniaturised probes
column21: far more advanced than
column22: for instance
column23: Nasa’s wonderful Cassini probe
column24: which spent 13 years exploring Saturn and its moons. This was launched 20 years ago and based on 1990s technology. Think how much better we could do today. Robotic fabricators will assemble vast lightweight structures in space (huge
column25: gossamer-thin mirrors or solar energy collectors
column26: for instance)
column27: maybe using raw materials mined from the moon or asteroids. And they could repair spacecraft in orbit far beyond the moon. Robotic and AI techniques are evolving fast. For instance
column28: the Curiosity vehicle sent to Mars a decade ago trundled slowly across a Martian crater; if it encountered a rock
column29: it needed instructions from Earth about how to divert its path. In contrast
column30: Perseverance
column31: which landed on Mars last February
column32: has sufficient intelligence to find its way around obstacles. In another decade
column33: such a probe will have AI sufficient to identify and explore interesting sites and geological formations. Nasa’s programme for human spaceflight
column34: ever since Apollo
column35: has been impeded by public and political pressure into being exceedingly risk-averse. The space shuttle failed twice in 135 launches. Thrill-seekers would willingly accept this 2% level of risk. But the shuttle had
column36: unwisely
column37: been promoted as “safe”. So each failure caused a national trauma and was followed by a hiatus while costly efforts were made (with very limited effect) to reduce the risk. Because of this safety culture
column38: Nasa will confront political obstacles in achieving any grand goal within a feasible budget.

column1: But private enterprise ventures – SpaceX
column2: Blue Origin and the rest – bringing a Silicon Valley culture into a domain long dominated by Nasa and a few aerospace conglomerates
column3: can cut costs and tolerate higher risks than a western government could impose on publicly funded civilian astronauts. So it’s these ventures
column4: with private funds and sponsorship
column5: which should front manned missions. The phrase “space tourism” should be avoided. It lulls people into believing such ventures are routine and low risk. And if that’s the perception
column6: the inevitable accidents will be as traumatic as those of the space shuttle. These exploits must be sold as dangerous sports or intrepid exploration. Don’t ever expect mass emigration from Earth. And here I disagree strongly with Elon Musk and with my late colleague Stephen Hawking. It’s a dangerous delusion to think that space offers an escape from its problems. We’ve got to solve them here. Coping with climate change is a doddle compared to terraforming Mars. Nowhere in our solar system offers an environment even as clement as the Antarctic or the top of Everest. There’s no “Planet B” for ordinary
column7: risk-averse people. Nonetheless
column8: this century courageous thrill-seekers may establish bases independent from the Earth. Musk himself says he wants to die on Mars – but not on impact. Although we may not want to join these space adventurers we should cheer them on. This is why. They’ll be ill-adapted to Martian conditions
column9: so they’ll have a compelling incentive to redesign themselves. They’ll harness the super-powerful genetic and cyborg technologies that will be developed. These techniques will
column10: one hopes
column11: be restrained on Earth
column12: on prudential and ethical grounds
column13: but settlers on Mars will be beyond the clutches of the regulators. We should wish them good luck in modifying their progeny to adapt to alien environments. This might be the first step towards divergence into a new species. So it’s these spacefaring adventurers
column14: not those of us comfortably adapted to life on Earth
column15: who will spearhead the post-human era
column16: evolving within a few centuries into a new species. (This evolution
column17: proceeding on the timescale of technological advance
column18: is potentially thousands of times faster than Darwinian selection.) Moreover
column19: if they make the transition from flesh and blood to fully inorganic intelligences
column20: they won’t need an atmosphere. And they may prefer zero-g
column21: especially for constructing massive artifacts. So it’s in deep space – not on Earth
column22: nor even on Mars – that non-biological “brains” may develop powers that humans can’t even imagine. The sun will survive 6bn more years before its fuel runs out. And the expanding universe will continue far longer
column23: perhaps for ever. So even if intelligent life had originated only on the Earth
column24: it need not remain a trivial feature of the cosmos: it could jump-start a diaspora whereby ever more complex intelligence spreads through the whole galaxy
column25: via self-reproducing machines
column26: transmitting DNA
column27: instructions for 3D printers or suchlike. Interstellar voyages would hold no terrors for near-immortals. There’s plenty of time ahead. Martin Rees is astronomer royal";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/james-webb-space-telescope-thrilling-future-for-mankind

column11: 'Politics'];"There was a distinctive moment
column12: at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic
column13: that neatly encapsulated the mistakes and confusion of Britain’s early efforts to tackle the disease
column14: says Mark Woolhouse. At a No 10 briefing in March 2020
column15: cabinet minister Michael Gove warned the virus did not discriminate. “Everyone is at risk
column16: ” he announced. And nothing could be further from the truth
column17: argues Professor Woolhouse
column18: an expert on infectious diseases at Edinburgh University. “I am afraid Gove’s statement was simply not true
column19: ” he says. “In fact
column20: this is a very discriminatory virus. Some people are much more at risk from it than others. People over 75 are an astonishing 10
column21: 000 times more at risk than those who are under 15.” And it was this failure to understand the wide variations in individual responses to Covid-19 that led to Britain’s flawed responses to the disease’s appearance
column22: he argues – errors that included the imposition of a long-lasting
column23: national lockdown. This is a strategy that Woolhouse – one of the country’s leading epidemiologists – describes as morally wrong and highly damaging in his forthcoming book
column24: The Year the World Went Mad: A Scientific Memoir. “We did serious harm to our children and young adults who were robbed of their education
column25: jobs and normal existence
column26: as well as suffering damage to their future prospects
column27: while they were left to inherit a record-breaking mountain of public debt
column28: ” he argues. “All this to protect the NHS from a disease that is a far
column29: far greater threat to the elderly
column30: frail and infirm than to the young and healthy. “We were mesmerised by the once-in-a-century scale of the emergency and succeeded only in making a crisis even worse. In short
column31: we panicked. This was an epidemic crying out for a precision public health approach and it got the opposite.”

column1: Rather than imposing blanket lockdowns across the nation
column2: the government should have adopted measures designed to make contacts safe
column3: Woolhouse maintains. “You can see from the UK data that people were reducing their contacts with each other as cases rose and before lockdown was imposed. That
column4: coupled with Covid-safe measures
column5: such as masks and testing

column4: 'World news'];"When Americans go to the polls in the 2022 midterms

column8: 'Prince Andrew'];"For years
column9: she was described as a “socialite”
column10: a word that conceals more than it explains. Socialites are almost always women from a wealthy if not an aristocratic background and their defining characteristic is being photographed with famous people. Ghislaine Maxwell fitted the bill
column11: appearing in photos with everyone from Donald Trump to Elon Musk to Prince Andrew. But being a socialite is not a job and it was unclear how she financed her opulent lifestyle
column12: especially after the death of her father
column13: Robert. Over recent weeks
column14: during her trial on sex trafficking charges in a New York courtroom
column15: the answer became clear. Maxwell’s wealth came from her erstwhile boyfriend
column16: the financier Jeffrey Epstein
column17: who gave her at least $30.7m (£23m) over a period of eight years. By all accounts
column18: Maxwell went from being in love with him to discovering that her usefulness lay elsewhere
column19: in providing a steady stream of young girls to satisfy his depraved sexual appetite. The girls trusted her
column20: thinking of her as an older sister
column21: and only realised later that they had been betrayed. The “socialite” was actually a procurer
column22: a word with deservedly unpleasant connotations. It does not sit easily with Maxwell’s glamorous lifestyle – the planes
column23: helicopters and visits to Epstein’s private island. Many well-known people will surely be regretting that they ever moved in the same circles as Maxwell and Epstein
column24: let alone appear in the aircraft logs revealed in court. Indeed
column25: Maxwell’s conviction last week on five charges seems to have created a kind of cognitive dissonance in some circles
column26: as though such things simply should not happen to a woman with a degree from Balliol . Well-connected individuals who rarely display an interest in American penal policy have complained bitterly about Maxwell’s prison conditions
column27: as though she is in a different class from other inmates. (Assumptions about class are
column28: of course
column29: all over this case.) Her siblings have rallied round
column30: insisting that they cannot accept the jury’s guilty verdicts
column31: although that seems to be more an expression of denial than in any real expectation that she will win an appeal. We know from rape trials that the public imagination struggles to accommodate individuals who challenge stereotypes about sex offenders
column32: whether it is the good-looking date who turns out to be a rapist or the “socialite” who facilitates a paedophile. It is easier to believe terrible things about Rosemary West
column33: a dumpy
column34: working-class woman who helped lure girls into her husband’s car and joined in his abuse of them
column35: than an heiress who once rested her boot on the thigh of an entranced Boris Johnson. Fred and Rose West committed horrific crimes together
column36: torturing their victims as well as killing them
column37: but Fred West was already a murderer when he chose 15-year-old Rosemary Letts
column38: who had a horrendous history of childhood sexual abuse
column39: as his accomplice.

column1: Predators have a sixth sense when it comes to choosing co-conspirators. Maxwell was a grown woman when she met Epstein
column2: and fully responsible for the choices she would go on to make
column3: but it is striking that their relationship seems to have begun around the time of her father’s fatal fall from the yacht he named after her
column4: the Lady Ghislaine. It is no excuse to say that the discovery that her father was a fraudster
column5: so soon after his death
column6: would have shaken Maxwell to her foundations. But it may be that Epstein recognised her weaknesses

column8: the Duke of York. Maxwell’s connections boosted his sense of impunity
column9: which is perhaps the single most important factor in allowing predators to get away with their crimes. He would later describe Maxwell in humiliating terms as an ex-girlfriend who had fallen on hard times
column10: framing himself as the benefactor who had allowed her to live in the style to which she had become accustomed. The mystery surrounding the source of Epstein’s wealth has led to comparisons with Jay Gatsby
column11: the enigmatic main character in Scott Fitzgerald’s novel

It is a depressing fact that women who identify with powerful men often share their misogyny and reflect it back in a desperate quest for approval. Profiles of Epstein remarked on the disturbing fact that his homes were full of teenage girls. “They’re nothing
column13: these girls
column14: ” Maxwell once told a confidante. “They are trash.” It must have occurred to Maxwell by now that the two men she put absolute faith in
column15: her father and her ex-lover
column16: both left her to face the music after their apparent suicides. And for what? The columnist Barbara Amiel

column23: or lack of it

column3: 'Gardens'];"There are a few cultural conundrums out there in gardening which I wonder if I will ever get to the bottom of. As someone who has recently gotten into dabbling in a little home-breeding with rare begonia species
column4: here is one that perpetually fascinates me
column5: even if merely mentioning is likely to get me cancelled: why are so many new plant cultivars so hideous? If you have flicked through any major gardening catalogue recently
column6: you will know what I mean
column7: especially when it comes to bedding plants. Cultivars with ever-more fluorescent hues
column8: often with jarring colour breaks
column9: where highlighter-pink juts up against Day-Glo acid green. Breeders will often layer up these mutations
column10: too
column11: with ruffled petals
column12: dramatically variegated leaves and flowers so huge the poor plants can barely hold them up. Short of spraying them in glitter and dunking them in gold paint
column13: there is very little else you could do to a plant to make it more dazzling.

column1: Now
column2: I am fully aware of how much of a terrible horticultural snob this makes me
column3: and also of the incredible level of breeding ingenuity and dedication that is needed to achieve this level of tackiness. However
column4: my question – personal taste aside – is whether these cultivars are any good for horticulture. I absolutely recognise the importance of having a huge range of plant options to help support the widest diversity of gardening styles
column5: but how many people do these Barbara-Cartland-meets-Drag-Race varieties really appeal to? Are they created this way because the aesthetic barometer that breeders work to – as with many cultural aspects in horticulture – is a few decades out of date? After all
column6: plant breeding is a notoriously slow process. These varieties would make perfect sense in an era when crocheted loo-roll covers or chintzy potpourri were commonplace in interior design. But they are totally out of step with really every current trend in fashion
column7: graphic design
column8: architecture and interiors. Is it because these are simply the most common genetic quirks that come up when plant breeders are searching for novel traits? Variegation
column9: colour breaks and ruffled petals are indeed some of the most common mutations that occur
column10: for example
column11: when plant breeders try to induce them using things such as gamma radiation. So is it more about the function of the characteristics that are available to play with
column12: rather than the aesthetic goal they are actively working towards? Or is it just the thirst for novelty? If all you are searching for is something that stands out as visually different in a sea of thousands of identical plants on a breeding bench
column13: maybe that starts to take precedence over something that actually looks good. Who knows? It’s so depressing to see such a diverse range of plants
column14: from begonias and fuchsias to petunias
column15: that look so impossibly elegant
column16: exotic and
column17: above all
column18: different from each other in the wild
column19: all being turned into the same frilly
column20: marshmallowy
column21: pompoms that are virtually interchangeable. They aren’t just in horrible taste
column22: they all look the flipping same. Am I alone in wondering this? Or have a I just become one of the terribly opinionated gardening snobs I have always tried my best to avoid? Follow James on Twitter @Botanygeek";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/02/why-are-we-breeding-such-ugly-flowers

column5: 'Life and style'];"I have an Auld Lang Syne earworm

column33: ressembling a benign

column1: A university friend

Who was “Liam’s Dad” or “Matthew handyman”? Is Elke still working in Brussels airport? How is my son’s speech therapist from 2008 doing

column7: 'Bradley Cooper'];"There’s something propulsively intoxicating about the films of Paul Thomas Anderson. column7: 'Farming'];The harsh midday sun beats down on the withering pawpaw plants in Maureen Adhiambo’s patch of land. The villagers in Kamenya have not seen rain for months

column12: ” says Adhiambo

column30: 000 Kenyan shillings

column2: 'History books'
column3: 'Race'
column4: 'Class issues'];"‘For me
column5: history is the record not only of how things change
column6: but how people make things change
column7: how they act individually and collectively to create a better world.” So wrote American historian Tyler Stovall about his approach to his craft. The echoes of historians such as EP Thompson and Eric Foner
column8: Barbara Fields and Robin DG Kelley are unmistakable in his work. Primarily a historian of France
column9: Stovall’s work bears on many important present-day themes – the relationship between race and class
column10: the tension between universalism and particularism
column11: the contradictions of liberalism. Yet few people outside academia know of him and his death last month was almost unmarked in the mainstream media
column12: a testament
column13: perhaps
column14: to the parochialism of our culture. Engaging with his work is a useful means of illuminating many contemporary debates. Stovall’s early research in the 1980s looked at the making of working-class communities
column15: especially in the “red belt” around Paris. Increasingly
column16: though
column17: his attention became drawn to some of the blind spots of French historiography
column18: notably issues of race and imperialism. His studies of French colonialism and of colonial labour in France helped to challenge the idea of a colour-blind nation
column19: not mired by the racism that beset the Anglo-Saxon world
column20: and to unpick the ways in which the traditions of French universalism could be wielded to deny rights and dignity to those deemed not to belong. Stovell’s final book
column21: White Freedom
column22: published last year
column23: was in some ways the culmination of his life’s endeavour. Yet it is also as frustrating as it is enlightening
column24: revealing both the significance of his work and also the confusions that infest contemporary thinking about race. Modern ideas of freedom and liberty
column25: Stovall observes
column26: emerged alongside theories of race. While liberty and racism are usually seen as opposing claims
column27: they are
column28: in fact
column29: he insists
column30: inextricably linked
column31: because ideals of freedom and liberty assumed the exclusion of non-whites. As such
column32: they bear “the unmistakable stamp of whiteness and white racial ideology”. Unquestionably
column33: many thinkers who helped to shape modern ideas of freedom and liberty held racist views and supported exclusionary practices. John Locke
column34: often regarded as the founding philosopher of liberalism
column35: defended slavery and owned shares in a slave-trading company. Immanuel Kant
column36: the towering Enlightenment figure
column37: believed that “humanity is at its greatest perfection in the race of whites”. The French revolutionaries who proclaimed the Declaration of the Rights of Man denied those same rights to slaves until forced to do so by an insurrection in the colony of Saint Domingue. Abraham Lincoln launched the civil war that ended slavery in America but insisted also that he was not “in favor of bringing about in any way the social and political equality of the white and black races”.

column1: For all this
column2: Stovall’s own work shows that the struggle over the meaning of freedom was more complex than can be captured by a notion such as “white freedom”. The demand that certain groups be excluded from the benefits of freedom was provoked primarily not by racial concerns
column3: but by political needs
column4: especially by fears of social disorder. Throughout the 19th century
column5: Stovall points out
column6: France was torn between “the radical vision of democracy championed by… the sans-culottes of the French Revolution” and the liberal desire to “not endanger private property”. This struggle sparked the revolutions of 1830 and 1848 and the 1871 Paris Commune. The crushing of these revolutionary challenges led to the institutionalisation of more restricted notions of freedom. The tension Stovall describes here goes back to the 17th century and forward to the 20th. In the famous Putney debates during the English civil war
column7: Oliver Cromwell’s son-in-law Henry Ireton spoke for the officer class in insisting that “Liberty cannot be provided for in a general sense if property be preserved”. A century later
column8: this question was at the heart of the struggle between the radicals and the moderates of the Enlightenment. In the 19th century
column9: the liberal imperialist Thomas Macaulay argued
column10: in response to Chartist demands for democracy
column11: that “universal suffrage… is incompatible with property” and hence “with civilisation”. The notion of race provided a means of casting inequalities as natural and inevitable. This became the justification for enslavement
column12: for the brutal treatment of colonial subjects and for the denial of rights to non-white peoples in Europe and America. It was also the justification for suppressing working-class rights. In the 19th century
column13: as Stovall acknowledges
column14: the working class was viewed as a distinct and inferior race. The French Christian socialist Philippe Buchez wondered how “within a population such as ours
column15: races may form
column16: so miserable
column17: inferior and bastardised that they may be classed as below the most inferior savage races
column18: for their inferiority is sometimes beyond cure?” He was talking not of Africans or Asians but of the working class and the rural poor of France. Racial divisions became also a means of dismantling challenges to the ruling order by persuading white workers that their interests lay in their “whiteness”
column19: not in their status as workers. In the American south
column20: for instance
column21: “Jim Crow” laws
column22: which imposed apartheid-style segregation
column23: were mainly enforced at the turn of the 20th century in response to the “Fusion” movements
column24: which brought together black workers and poor white farmers
column25: to challenge the established order and
column26: in North Carolina
column27: win power. The Democrats
column28: the ousted ruling party
column29: launched a violent “white supremacy campaign” to rupture the coalition
column30: win white working-class support for treating blacks as outcasts and regain political control. This complex relationship between liberties
column31: race
column32: class and whiteness is ill-served by a concept such as “white freedom”. Nor is this just an issue about history. “Whiteness” has become an idea fetishised today both by racists and by many anti-racists
column33: the one claiming that all white people have a common set of interests
column34: the other reframing racism as “white privilege”. In doing so
column35: both
column36: in different ways
column37: obscure the political and structural reasons for racism
column38: on the one hand
column39: and the social problems facing the working class
column40: on the other
column41: making it more difficult to challenge either. Tyler Stovall’s work is important in illuminating previously ignored areas of class
column42: race and colonialism and should be better known and cherished. It should also be challenged and questioned
column43: especially the arguments about “white freedom”. Intellectual legacies
column44: like freedoms
column45: are always contested. • Kenan Malik is an Observer columnist";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/race-class-freedom-liberty-and-work-of-historian-tyler-stovall

column9: 'France'];"Fresh proof that the Nazis set up fake auctions and phoney paperwork to disguise their looting of art and valuable possessions has been uncovered by an amateur sleuth researching her own family mystery. French writer Pauline Baer de Perignon’s investigation has revealed the fate of a missing collection of art that included work by Monet
column10: Renoir and Degas and also exposed the reluctance of Europe’s leading museums to accept evidence of the deceit. Baer was prompted to look into the past when she bumped into an English cousin who told her he believed the family had been “robbed”. “The whole thing has changed my life
column11: ” said Baer this weekend. “I have had to look back at a long-forgotten family story as well as at the hidden secrets of the Gestapo. And then I had to confront the truth about paintings held by galleries such as the Louvre and the state museum in Dresden. I was so naive when I started.” Baer’s three years of research have led not just to a better understanding of the way in which significant works of art were systematically stolen after Germany invaded France
column12: but will culminate later this month in the high-profile sale of a recovered painting at Sotheby’s in New York.

column1: Portrait of a Lady as Pomona
column2: by the revered 18th-century French artist Nicolas de Largillière
column3: once belonged to her great-grandfather
column4: the Parisian collector Jules Strauss
column5: and was only returned to his descendants last year. It is now expected to sell for $1m-$1.5m (£750
column6: 000-£1.1m). “I could have asked my father to tell me about Jules Strauss
column7: but I never did
column8: ” Baer has explained. “My father died when I was 20
column9: before I was bold enough to ask him about the war
column10: about his parents and grandparents
column11: about his emotions and his memories.” Baer’s curiosity was aroused when she bumped into her cousin Andrew Strauss at a concert in Paris eight years ago. The two had not met since she was a teenager
column12: but he told her that he worked at Sotheby’s and believed the apparent sale of the Strauss collection in the early 1940s was “shady”. He mentioned the involvement of dummy companies
column13: Nazi officers and museum inventories to his bemused cousin. “Andrew’s words sent my mind tumbling down a rabbit hole
column14: ” said Baer. Armed with a scribbled note listing the names of famous artists
column15: Baer began to piece together the lost past. She was now as interested in finding out what happened to her distant family members as in the fate of the missing art. A book about her efforts
column16: The Vanished Collection
column17: has already made waves in France
column18: where it was published last year and where critics have compared it to a compelling suspense novel. A reviewer for Elle said it was as “devourable as a thriller”
column19: while others have compared the family’s story to those of other famous Jewish families whose art was looted in the war
column20: such as the Camondos
column21: the Rothschilds and the Ephrussis. At the start of Baer’s inquiries
column22: all she had was one photograph of Strauss
column23: her illustrious great-grandfather
column24: and another of the many portraits hanging on the walls of his former home on Avenue Foch in Paris. She knew the apartment had gone
column25: but that there was one elderly living relative with first-hand knowledge of what had happened. She delved into the archives of great museums and asked difficult questions of the French ministry of culture. She was surprised to discover how the thefts had been covered up
column26: but her English translator
column27: Natasha Lehrer
column28: believes the most powerful part of the book concerns howmodern art institutions have dragged their feet and
column29: at worst
column30: avoided doubts about the ownership of important paintings.

column1: “What Pauline stumbled upon was an apparent unwillingness among those leading various large state museums to admit that they were holding looted works of art until very recently
column2: ” said Lehrer. “This despite the fact that families and collectors often had all the provenance information available to identify them as the rightful owners. There has been a notable reluctance to return artworks.” The English version of Baer’s book is to be published next month by Head of Zeus. Baer tracked down the portrait by Largillière to Dresden’s state art collections and found archival evidence to prove that Strauss had been forced to sell it. The masterpiece had apparently been acquired in 1941 for the Reichsbank in Berlin and then transferred to the ministry of finance
column3: before going to Dresden in 1959. Baer found the words “Collection Jules Strauss” next to the Largillière’s listing in the German Lost Art Foundation
column4: but was then told that the Dresden museum’s director was not minded to return it. She was questioned about whether Strauss was originally happy to sell
column5: despite evidence of laws that prevented Jews from profiting by such deals. “The more I continued with my investigation
column6: the more I realised how unlikely it was that Jules had been able to avoid his collection becoming seized by the Nazis
column7: ” said Baer. “Even before the invasion of France
column8: the Germans had compiled a list of large French collections.”

column1: Dresden’s state art collections has since said: “The investigation of this complex case was as extensive and thorough as is necessary to ensure that a work of art is returned to its rightful owner.” The portrait’s sale in New York this month will now allow all 20 of Strauss’s heirs a share in its value. column3: 'Immigration and asylum'
column4: 'Windrush scandal'];"This picture of a young couple arriving at Gatwick airport from the Caribbean on 30 June 1962 was taken on the evening before the Commonwealth Immigrants Act came into force. The act had been passed by Harold Macmillan’s Conservative government to halt the flow of citizens from current and former British colonies. It was designed in particular to bring to an abrupt end the “open door” welcome for people from the West Indies – characterised by the arrival of the Empire Windrush in 1948 – to help rebuild the so-called “mother country” after the war. Macmillan had been under pressure from his militant backbenchers
column5: some in the newly formed far-right Monday Club
column6: to introduce the bill. Labour leader Hugh Gaitskell called it “cruel and brutal anti-colour legislation”. The couple in the picture
column7: striding confidently across the tarmac from their BOAC plane in their Sunday clothes
column8: therefore represent perhaps the last moment that Commonwealth citizens from the Caribbean arrived in Britain with unclouded hope. In the subsequent decade
column9: two further immigration bills tightened the legislation against the free movement of families
column10: and the subject became an emotive and divisive political issue right up to the present moment
column11: with the draconian nationality and borders bill passing through parliament.

column1: This photograph is included in an exhibition
column2: Changing the Story
column3: that uses pictures from the TopFoto archive to challenge received ideas of the “whiteness” of Britain after the first world war. The exhibition
column4: brought to life by poet and performer Rommi Smith
column5: includes images from between 1917 and 1962 that question the monocultural stereotypes of nation that conservative forces promoted. “I open the album and am spellbound
column6: ” Smith writes of encountering this archive. “I am immediately struck that what unites these stories of people and places across time and space is the racial diversity of the protagonists in them. These photos flip the script on Britishness: my history lessons did not look like this.” Changing the Story: Photographs of British Life in Black and White
column7: 1917-1962 is at the North Wall Arts Centre
column8: Oxford
column9: 10-29 January";https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2022/jan/02/the-big-picture-last-call-for-commonwealth-arrivals-1962

column12: 'Politics books'];"In their terrific new book
column13: the veteran reporters Mark Bowden and Matthew Teague argue that the mob that invaded the Capitol in Washington almost exactly a year ago “had no more chance of overthrowing the US government than hippies in 1967 had trying to levitate the Pentagon”.

column1: The “real insurrection” was the one “led by Trump and his coterie of sycophants” in Georgia
column2: Wisconsin
column3: Nevada
column4: Michigan
column5: Pennsylvania and Arizona. It “was only slightly better organized than the mob but considerably more calculated and dangerous”. That real insurrection is the subject of this timely and important volume. The authors have used a stethoscope to examine the minutia of the American election process. The result is a thrilling and suspenseful celebration of the survival of democracy. The attempted coup was led by Donald Trump. Its intended denouement
column6: in which the vice-president
column7: Mike Pence
column8: would ignore the votes of the six states above plus Washington DC in order to swing the election to Trump
column9: was outlined in an insane memo written by the lawyer John Eastman
column10: described here as “surely the most seditious document to emerge from the White House in American history”. That final act
column11: of course
column12: never happened. Not even Pence
column13: the most sycophantic vice-president of modern times
column14: could bring himself to violate the constitution so blatantly to keep his boss in the White House. But the genuine heroes
column15: brought to life here
column16: were the “hundreds of obscure Americans from every walk of life
column17: state and local officials
column18: judges and election workers. Many of them were Republicans
column19: some were Trump supporters. They refused to accept his slander of themselves
column20: their communities and their workers
column21: and they refused to betray their sworn duty to their office and their country. They were the real patriots.”

column1: Bowden and Teague – the latter a Guardian contributor – take us through six battles that lasted from the night of the election
column2: 3 November 2020
column3: until Joe Biden’s election was finally certified by Congress early on 7 January last year. Their book performs a vital service
column4: demonstrating just how well our tattered democracy managed to function despite vicious partisanship and all the new challenges created by the pandemic. For the first time
column5: I understood how brilliantly new machines used to count the votes performed
column6: the intricacies of opening outer and inner envelopes
column7: capturing the images of both then preserving the vital paper ballots inside
column8: making it possible to confirm electronic results with a hand count in case of any failure in technology. In Arizona
column9: the elections department conducted “the mandatory hand count of election day ballots from 2% of the vote centers and 1% of the early ballots as required by Arizona law and it yielded a 100% match to the results produced by the tabulation equipment”. Scott Jarrett was co-director of elections in the populous Maricopa county
column10: and he is one of the crucial bureaucrats celebrated here: “A pale slender young man … dressed in a plain gray suit
column11: the very picture of an earnest functionary
column12: a man happily engaged in the actual machinery of government and quietly proud of his own unheralded importance and competence.” In a public hearing crowded with crazed conspiracy theorists
column13: Jarrett carefully explained how only one of the two “encrypted memory cards (both with tamper-proof evidence seals)” was transported from various polling centers to the main counting location
column14: “so that the results on one card could be double-checked against the other as well as the precinct ballot report they had generated. Backing up that memory were
column15: of course
column16: the actual ballots that had been run through the machines. The memory cards and the ballots were sealed and delivered by “two members of different parties”
column17: escorted by county sheriffs. Clint Hickman
column18: chairman of the Maricopa county board of supervisors
column19: noted that if the eyes of some in the audience were glazing over
column20: he just wanted “people that are watching this” to understand “we don’t glaze over”. The authors point out that Hickman was touching on a fundamental feature of The Steal
column21: the factitious narrative concocted by Trump and his cronies: conspiracy theorists depend on ignorance. “They begin with distrust: only a sucker believes the official story. They then replace the often tedious
column22: mundane details of an intricate process … with a simpler narrative”: theft.

column1: They invent colorful stories about a “deal struck with a late Venezuelan dictator to deliver tainted election machines
column2: or a plot to preprint fake ballots in the dead of night”. This creates what cognitive scientists call “a community of knowledge”. The big problem that didn’t exist even 30 years ago is the speed with which such idiotic stories are spread through the internet and by the Twitter feed of a malevolent president like Trump
column3: exploding the reach of such stories and their power to undermine democratic norms.

column1: The book reminds us that democracy itself depends on a modicum of trust. That is why Trump’s ability to persuade so many Americans of the truth of so many lies has had such a disastrous effect on our body politic. Bowden and Teague have performed a singular service by revealing the details that disprove Republicans’ unceasing inventions about voter fraud. The problem is that so many Republicans will continue to ignore the lessons of this book. American democracy could still be destroyed by the torrent of voter suppression laws already passed by Republican-controlled state legislatures
column2: spurred by lies invented by Trump and amplified by insidious “journalists” like Maria Bartiromo and Tucker Carlson
column3: whose perfidy is brilliantly dissected in these pages. If democracy does prevail
column4: it will survive because of the ability of authors like Teague and Bowden to make the truth even more compelling than Fox News fictions. The Steal is published in the US by Atlantic Monthly Press";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/02/the-steal-review-stethoscope-democracy-trump-biden-2020-michigan-arizona-nevada-georgia-pennsylvania-bowden-teague

column5: 'Culture'];"In more innocent or credulous days
column6: the faithful sat in the dark to gaze at strange beings with detachable heads who were actually phantasms of light. Among the stars in this custom-made galaxy
column7: the most alluring and yet the most distant was Greta Garbo
column8: whose persona alternated between carnal heat and ascetic frost. After wickedly enticing her male victims in The Temptress
column9: she redeemed herself as the dying courtesan in Camille; in Queen Christina
column10: she was exalted by sacrifice and in a last mesmerising closeup all emotion blankly drained from her face as she renounced the throne and sailed into exile. Gradually this astral creature edged down to Earth. Publicists issued an excited proclamation when Garbo talked for the first time on screen in Anna Christie
column11: even though she began by gruffly demanding a whisky in a waterfront bar. In Ninotchka
column12: she made headlines all over again by contorting her alabaster features in a sudden fit of laughter.

column1: Then
column3: she abruptly abandoned her career. Middle-aged fault lines in her perfect countenance have usually been blamed
column4: but Robert Gottlieb’s book points to a change in the temper of the times. The young Fellini
column5: puzzled by Garbo’s lunar pallor
column6: mistook her for a ghost. In wartime
column7: movie goddesses had to be less ethereal: they were now called bombshells because pilots painted their bodies on to the fuselage of the planes they flew into battle. Wispy and tremulous
column8: Garbo lacked the ballistic sexual impact of Rita Hayworth in Gilda and unlike the pistol-packing Joan Crawford she was no spitfire. “I had made enough faces
column9: ” Garbo remarked when explaining why she quit. She knew herself to be a product
column10: not a person
column11: and disowned the mystique manufactured by the studio. The surname that MGM assigned to her was supposed to be Swedish for sprite
column12: although alliteration prompted impish schoolboys to nickname her Greasy Garbage.

column1: “You are in love with Garbo
column2: ” she told her besotted co-star John Gilbert
column3: implying that he would not have been so infatuated by Greta Gustafsson from Stockholm
column4: a shy mouse who late in life jokingly offered to work behind the counter in a Scandinavian deli near her New York apartment. Affecting anonymity in retirement
column5: she insisted on being addressed as Miss Brown. Despite a succession of lovers
column6: Garbo’s only long-term relationship
column7: as Gottlieb says
column8: was with the lens. She surrendered gladly to the Hollywood cameramen who trapped her soul on emulsion; later
column9: she had to fend off paparazzi who stalked her in the street and tried to penetrate her disguises. When Chaplin became the most recognisable man in the world
column10: he chummily acknowledged the applause of the multitudes. But Garbo fled from crowds in genuine terror and felt no sense of charitable obligation to her fans; it’s alleged that she even refused to sign an autograph book pitifully proffered by a soldier who was in uniform and on crutches.

column1: Some called her divine
column2: while for others she was a demon. A photograph by Clarence Sinclair Bull superimposes her imperishable head on the recumbent body of the Sphinx
column3: which crumbles in the Egyptian desert. In Mata Hari
column4: she performs an orientalised belly dance
column5: dressed as a profane priestess and wearing a pagoda-shaped hat. Her earliest American films cast her as a vamp
column6: a successor to the bewitching Theda Bara
column7: whose invented name was an anagram of Arab death; the widow of Garbo’s saturnine protector George Schlee called her “that vampire” and after Schlee died
column8: summoned a Russian Orthodox priest to exorcise their fridge because
column9: when the purported blood drinker visited
column10: she sometimes reached into it to grab a can of beer. Favouring men’s shoes and clothes
column11: Garbo cultivated a teasing androgyny and one of the later projects with which she toyed was an adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s The Picture of Dorian Gray in which she would play the ageless
column12: cruelly insensitive dandy; for the nubile actor who commits suicide when seduced and then spurned by Dorian
column13: she wanted Marilyn Monroe. Envious and venomous
column14: Marlene Dietrich boosted the emasculating myth by claiming that Garbo “raped men
column15: she unzipped her fly and pounced on them”. Garbo retaliated with hazy hauteur. “Who is this Marlene Dietrich?” she once asked a reporter. Gottlieb is a renowned New York editor who at the age of 90 has earned the right to be self-indulgent and he chats wittily about his idol while leaving others to do the hard work of analysing Garbo’s appeal. In a small anthology of critical comments
column16: Kenneth Tynan’s empurpled rhapsody about her physique – a neck that could be tilted at right angles to her spine
column17: concave pectorals
column18: a wayward
column19: loping walk – is supplemented by a mystical reverie in which David Thomson regrets that “the church of cinema” where Garbo’s worshippers gathered has now been deconsecrated.

column1: The Swedish actor Fritiof Billquist contributes a sharp insight that makes sense of her craving for solitary boredom and domestic banality
column2: a condition she attained in her long
column3: vacuous phone monologues about paying bills and shopping for groceries. “Hers
column4: ” Billquist says
column5: “was the artistic nature’s jealousy of real life.” Best of all
column6: Gottlieb dispenses with words in a gallery of photographs in which Garbo cups her head like the calyx of a flower
column7: lowers her eyelids to semaphore desire or perhaps drowsiness and smokes a cigarette as if lighting a candle to place on her own altar. The mutable human face is saved from decay and flesh and blood are somehow sculpted into the likeness of Pallas Athene. • Garbo by Robert Gottlieb is published by Farrar
column8: Straus and Giroux (£32). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/02/garbo-by-robert-gottlieb-review-distant-darling-of-the-silver-screen

column2: 'Coronavirus'

column4: 'Medical research'
column5: 'Science'
column6: 'World news'
column7: 'UK news'
column8: 'Microbiology'];"A growing body of evidence indicates that the Omicron Covid variant is more likely to infect the throat than the lungs
column9: which scientists believe may explain why it appears to be more infectious but less deadly than other versions of the virus. Six studies – four published since Christmas Eve – have found that Omicron does not damage people’s lungs as much as the Delta and other previous variants of Covid. The studies have yet to be peer-reviewed by other scientists. “The result of all the mutations that make Omicron different from previous variants is that it may have altered its ability to infect different sorts of cells
column10: ” said Deenan Pillay
column11: professor of virology at University College London. “In essence
column12: it looks to be more able to infect the upper respiratory tract – cells in the throat. So it would multiply in cells there more readily than in cells deep in the lung. This is really preliminary but the studies point in the same direction.” If the virus replicates more in the throat
column13: that makes it more transmissible
column14: which would help to explain the rapid spread of Omicron. A virus that is good at infecting lung tissue
column15: on the other hand
column16: will be potentially more dangerous but less transmissible. Researchers from the University of Liverpool’s Molecular Virology Research Group published a pre-print on Boxing Day that shows Omicron leading to “less severe disease” in mice
column17: according to Prof James Stewart. The paper showed that mice infected with Omicron lose less weight
column18: have lower viral loads and experience less- severe pneumonia. “It’s one piece of the jigsaw
column19: ” he said. “The animal model does suggest that the disease is less severe than Delta and the original Wuhan virus. It seems to get cleared faster and the animals recovered more rapidly
column20: and that ties in with clinical data coming through. “The early indications are that it’s good news
column21: but that’s not a signal to drop our guard
column22: because if you’re clinically vulnerable
column23: the consequences are still not great – there are deaths from Omicron. Not everyone can rip their masks off and party.” The Neyts Lab at Leuven University in Belgium found similar results in Syrian hamsters
column24: with a lower viral load in the lungs compared with other variants. Prof Johan Neyts said this may be because the virus was better at infecting humans than hamsters
column25: or that it was more likely to infect the upper respiratory tract
column26: or that it provoked less-severe disease.

column1: A further pre-print
column2: submitted to Nature last week by researchers in the US
column3: also found that mice with Omicron lost less weight and had a lower viral load. And researchers at the University of Glasgow’s Centre for Virus Research have found evidence that Omicron has changed the way it enters the body. Omicron was substantially likely to evade the immunity of people who had had two doses of the vaccine
column4: but a booster dose gave a “partial restoration of immunity”. The slew of Christmas research builds on a study from the University of Hong Kong last month showing less Omicron infection in the lungs
column5: and on research led by Prof Ravi Gupta at the University of Cambridge
column6: whose team investigated blood samples from vaccinated patients. They found Omicron able to evade vaccines
column7: but less able to enter lung cells. The latest scientific research comes amid a debate about how best to carry out home-testing. Last week
column8: some scientists suggested that lateral flow tests (LFTs) might be more accurate if people took swabs from the throat as well as the nose. Prof Jennifer Rohn at University College London said that her experience of using LFTs was that she had tested negative using nose swabs but positive when taking a sample from her throat. That seemed to be supported by a study from South Africa showing that saliva samples subjected to PCR tests were better than nasal swabs at detecting Omicron. However
column9: Prof Lawrence Young
column10: virologist at the University of Warwick
column11: said the study was not significant enough for conclusions to be drawn. “This is a small study on acutely symptomatic
column12: non-hospitalised patients. On the one hand it confirms previous studies indicating that salivary testing could be useful as a more easily performed sampling approach. I don’t think this study is significant enough to conclude anything about the behaviour of Omicron.” The UK Health Security Agency said there was no indication that rapid tests differed in their ability to detect the Omicron or Delta variants
column13: although the tests were continuously monitored by researchers. “All lateral flow devices used by NHS Test and Trace have gone through rigorous validation and are proven to be highly effective at detecting Covid-19 in people
column14: ” a spokesperson said. “We are currently seeing high numbers of positive lateral flow device tests reported. This means we are detecting tens of thousands of cases that might otherwise have gone undetected.” • This article was amended on 3 January 2022 because an earlier version said: “If the virus produces more cells in the throat
column15: that makes it more transmissible ...”. The reference should have been: “If the virus replicates more in the throat...” This has been corrected.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/02/new-studies-reinforce-belief-that-omicron-is-less-likely-to-damage-lungs

column5: 'World news'];"When Hungarian opposition leader Péter Márki-Zay was in Brussels at the end of last year
column6: he visited the street where an MEP from prime minister Viktor Orbán’s ruling party
column7: Fidesz
column8: had fled down a drainpipe to evade a police raid on a “gay orgy” that broke lockdown rules. The MEP
column9: who later resigned
column10: had been an architect of a clause in Hungary’s constitution defining marriage as a heterosexual institution. The drainpipe visit was easy political capital for Márki-Zay
column11: seeking to draw attention to the hypocrisy of the governing party
column12: while stressing his commitment to LGBT rights and conservative credentials. It’s the kind of move that has discombobulated Fidesz
column13: who weren’t expecting to face this kind of challenge in Hungary’s parliamentary elections in spring 2022. Márki-Zay
column14: a conservative churchgoing father of seven
column15: is the candidate for prime minister of six opposition parties
column16: spanning social democrats to the former far right
column17: who united to take on Orbán. “After 16 years it’s the first time the opposition has a real chance to win
column18: ” Róbert László
column19: an election specialist at the Political Capital institute in Budapest
column20: said. Hungarians go to the polls in April or May in a contest that could bring down Orbán
column21: whose 11-year experiment with “illiberal democracy” has resulted in Hungary becoming the first EU member state to be classed as only “partly free” by the NGO Freedom House.

column1: “Nobody expected the left and centre parties who dominated the opposition could be led by an outsider coming from the right
column2: ” László said. “One of his super-powers is that he can’t be blamed as the puppet of the past leftist parties
column3: or the ex-prime minister Ferenc Gyurcsány
column4: ” a wealthy former leader who remains deeply divisive. Fidesz was preparing for a left-liberal candidate
column5: such as the mayor of Budapest
column6: Gergely Karácsony
column7: or the leader of the Democratic Coalition
column8: Klára Dobrev
column9: who is married to Gyurcsány. “Now we can see that the Fidesz propaganda machine is confused
column10: ” László said. “[Márki-Zay] is not a liberal intelligentsia
column11: he seems to be much more like a Fidesz member.” Márki-Zay was never a party member
column12: but he did vote Fidesz. He hasn’t since 2010. “I just became more and more upset with their populism
column13: their betrayal of western values … corruption mostly
column14: ” he told the Observer. “Orbán has changed
column15: not me.” Speaking to journalists
column16: Márki-Zay sought to distinguish his faith from Orbán’s professions in defence of Hungary’s Christian culture. “I was a Christian way before Orbán. Orbán was still in the Communist youth movement when I attended church every Sunday in communist times.”

column1: It’s a typically blunt statement from Márki-Zay
column2: who is equally plain-speaking in English and Hungarian. He polished his English during nearly five years in North America
column3: where he worked for a car-parts company. Márki-Zay
column4: who has two degrees and a PhD in economic history
column5: spent five weeks in Canada working as a door-to-door salesman. His firm later promoted him to a job in the US
column6: where political curiosity took him to 2008 campaign events for presidential contenders Barack Obama

column8: Márki-Zay made his political debut in his hometown of Hódmezővásárhely

column10: he was dismissed from his job at an electrical components company. Soon after
column11: five surveillance cameras appeared on his street. Government-friendly media launched vicious attacks on his wife. More recently he has been called an American spy
column12: a CIA agent and a tool of Gyurcsány.

column1: This kind of smear campaign is typical

column4: he is not the kind of guy who wants to be a politician just for the sake of politics… You can see it in his eyes that he has determination to change the system for the good.” Kész offered his support
column5: despite their political differences. “He’s a conservative
column6: I’m a liberal [libertarian]. He’s very religious

column10: 'World news'];"Britain’s electricity generation went through an unfortunate phase last year. According to the UK-based website Carbon Brief
column11: it got dirtier for the first time in years as renewable sources failed to provide sufficient power to help the nation’s economy recover from lockdown restrictions. More coal and gas had to be burned to generate electricity. This jump occurred – in part – because 2021 was notable for its low winds. Wind farm output dropped by almost 15% from 2020
column12: despite the fact that more turbines had been installed across the nation. At the same time
column13: nuclear power generation fell by almost 10% because of problems with ageing reactors. It is a sobering reminder that the road to limit climate change is going to be a long one
column14: though
column15: in this case
column16: the news is particularly unfortunate
column17: given that Britain is still in charge of the negotiations that followed the Cop26 summit in Glasgow last year. Indeed
column18: the nation will remain in this position of leadership until Egypt takes charge at the end of 2022
column19: when its Cop27 summit opens in Sharm el-Sheikh. Until then
column20: the world will be looking to Britain to set a lead and to play a major role in ensuring that the promises made in Glasgow are fulfilled.

column1: What other nations will have witnessed so far will not have made a good impression
column2: however. The fact that the UK last year failed to clean up its power generation
column3: one of the easiest ways to start on the business of cutting carbon emission
column4: is bad enough. Sadly
column5: there have been many other setbacks in the UK’s attempts to fight climate change. Another example was provided by the public accounts committee
column6: which last month savaged the government over the failure of its green homes grant scheme in England. The programme underperformed so badly it risks damaging future efforts to deliver net zero
column7: the committee warned. Hailed by Boris Johnson as a key plank in his green industrial revolution
column8: the scheme was intended to help the public make their homes more energy efficient and less reliant on fossil fuel heating. This was to be done by providing grants for installing heat pumps and other equipment. A total of 600
column9: 000 homes were targeted but in the end just 47
column10: 500 were upgraded
column11: while only a small fraction of the expected jobs were created in the process. As Dame Meg Hillier
column12: chair of the committee
column13: put it: “This scheme was a slam dunk fail.” Power generation and carbon-friendly housing are clearly issues that need to be tackled urgently. But they are not the only problems that lie ahead. As another government body
column14: the Climate Change Committee
column15: made clear last month
column16: the UK desperately needs a strategy to reduce carbon emissions from agriculture and to review how tax policy can help deliver net zero. This last issue is particularly important because the Treasury is now under pressure to reduce VAT on gas in response to the energy crisis – at a time when it should be making it more expensive in order to discourage its use. However
column17: the committee’s key message was even more direct: the UK must now focus on implementation rather than targets. In other words
column18: we need action
column19: not words
column20: when it comes to tackling climate change in 2022 and that action should come not just from Alok Sharma
column21: currently president of Cop26
column22: but from all senior ministers
column23: including Boris Johnson. Certainly
column24: if they do not act firmly over the coming year
column25: and provide international leadership
column26: then the goal to limit global warming to 1.5C will be dead.";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/observer-view-britains-climate-crisis-targets

column6: 'Filipino food and drink'];"Sarap Filipino Bistro
column7: 10 Heddon Street
column8: London W1B 4BX (020 3488 9769; saraplondon.com). Starters £8.50-£13; mains £18-£25; desserts £5.50-£7.50; wines from £27 Eating a whole piglet is like staging an orgy; you need more than two people to get the job done. The problem is that
column9: when I review a restaurant there are only ever two of us
column10: and that makes both propositions very tricky. Admittedly the latter is rarely on the menu during restaurant visits; neither of us is likely to be orgy fit. But at Sarap Bistro the former most certainly was an option
column11: and I was at least four people short of a piglet party. Sarap belongs to the chef Ferdinand “Budgie” Montoya
column12: and is part of his ongoing exploration of the food of the Philippines
column13: where he was born. Key to that is the famed lechon: roast piglet
column14: with golden
column15: shattering skin and the tenderest
column16: sweetest of meat. (If you are a meat eater with a taste for lamb
column17: but still want to be absolutely livid about the consumption of young pigs
column18: muster your arguments now.) Here
column19: the lechon comes stuffed with lemongrass and truffled adobo rice. Sounds great doesn’t it. There’s only one problem: you have to order a whole damn piglet two days in advance
column20: and muster a party of six to eight people to do the eating. It costs £295.

column1: About 10 minutes after we arrive there is a cheer from the far end of the dimly lit dining room. A small crowd is gathered
column2: cameraphones aloft. I wander down to find them recording the portioning up of their piglet
column3: plumes of steam rising from the chopping board as Montoya works the cleaver over the meat. The legs go one way
column4: the snout another. I take a few pictures
column5: but end up feeling like an interloper at the celebration of a stranger’s birthday. I am not friends with these people. I cannot share their piglet. Well
column6: in truth
column7: I probably could have done if I’d asked nicely. I could have told them I was Grace Dent and they’d instantly have told me to fill my boots. I can rock a leopard-print wrap dress
column8: me. The point is that
column9: the most diverting item on the menu here at Sarap (which means delicious) is the one I can’t order. Still
column10: there are a bunch of other things available and by the end of the night
column11: following the beguiling instructions of our waiter
column12: I will have tried all but one of them. Montoya has been on a long and twisting journey to get here
column13: both figuratively and literally. He only started cooking professionally when he arrived in the UK in 2012 from Australia. He worked at Restaurant Story
column14: Foley’s and the Dean Street Townhouse
column15: while all the time nurturing a desire to interrogate his family’s favourite dishes. It began with a supper club which led in turn to various pop ups
column16: and then a casual place in Brixton Market.

column1: Now he has taken over this spot on Heddon Street
column2: which has become a bit of an incubator for new restaurant ventures; previously
column3: it was home to the rugged nose-to-tail Italian Manteca
column4: which has moved on to Shoreditch. Montoya describes what he is doing here as delivering authentic flavours “proudly inauthentically”
column5: a thoroughly engaging term I first came across in chef Ravinder Bhogal’s Jikoni cookbook. It’s a short menu. Our enthusiastic waiter tells us we should order three starters between the two of us. There are only three starters. The food here strikes me as a softer
column6: often warmer version of the sharp
column7: sweet and salty flavours I am used to from elsewhere in southeast Asia. Pearly pieces of seabass are cured in a soft sour coconut vinegar. There is a gel made from calamansi
column8: or Philippine lemon
column9: and for crunch there are pieces of cucumber. It’s all bright and refreshing. In the mellifluously named Ensaladang Talong it is the addition of crumbled salted duck egg which shifts a rough smoked aubergine purée and slices of tomato away from the Mediterranean. But the most compelling dish
column10: because it nods towards the lechon
column11: is a boned out
column12: rice-stuffed pig’s trotter
column13: with skin that is hinged in a remarkable place between crisp and chewy. It feels a little like a consolation prize for not being able to give the piglet a seeing to. It’s a good consolation prize.

column1: There are four main courses. We are told we should order three. The most diverting are the hunks of roasted celeriac in a ripe
column2: creamy peanut sauce
column3: with the lightest waft of truffle. Poussin has been marinated in lemongrass
column4: citrus and vinegar before being grilled over charcoal to produce the kind of savoury blackened skin which gives point to these small
column5: often flavourless birds. Finally
column6: there are rosy slices of beef
column7: in a thick citrus and soy sauce. It’s very good beef indeed
column8: though the £25 charged for four less-than-vast slices is ambitious. (Amusingly
column9: they plated six slices of the beef for the dish prepared for the photographer who visited a few days later.) Still
column10: we have a bowl of rice with which to absorb the gorgeous liquor. These are I think
column11: all meant to be showstoppers. Intriguingly
column12: the most thrilling dish is actually a simple side of kale braised for hours in coconut milk
column13: ginger
column14: garlic and chilli. It is both comforting and a wake up; an intense
column15: rich vegan stew which I wanted to lean over and focus on. At £6 it also feels like the best moment of value on the menu
