column5: 'Politics'];"The contrast between the upbeat tone of the prime minister’s new year message and the political cloud hanging over him as he goes into 2022 could not be starker. Boris Johnson said Britain is in an “incomparably better” state in the fight against Covid than it was at the start of 2021; thanks to the scientific research that produced a vaccine in less than a year
column6: that is certainly true. But Johnson begins the new year as an irrevocably weakened political figure
column7: his poll ratings significantly down from a year ago
column8: his authority within his own parliamentary party eroded. Just two years after winning a decisive parliamentary majority of 80
column9: this will be the year that requires him to fight for his survival. While 2022 will hopefully bring a diminishing of the disruption and harm caused by Covid
column10: it will also see the launch of the independent inquiry into the government’s handling of the pandemic. Johnson’s dreadful errors of judgment over the last 21 months will be raked over: his decisions to hang back in introducing social restrictions not once
column11: not twice
column12: but three times cost too many people their lives
column13: and still more the hardship of living under harsher social restrictions for longer as a result of his delays.

column1: The inquiry may also uncover further revelations about Johnson’s hypocrisy in his approach to enforcing the social restrictions he imposed on the country within his own residence. The Cabinet Office investigation into the Downing Street parties will report and
column2: if it generates evidence that the law was broken
column3: may even lead to a police investigation. Johnson will also continue to face scrutiny over his lack of probity around declaring political donations. The country is facing an acute cost of living crisis that the government has made immeasurably worse through its policies. A decade of tax credit cuts enacted by successive Tory chancellors – which effectively paid for tax cuts for more affluent families – has eroded the incomes of low-paid parents
column4: for some households by thousands of pounds a year. Yet this did not stop Johnson enacting a further tax credit cut of £1
column5: 000 a year in October
column6: the biggest overnight benefit cuts for low-income families with children in history. The increase in generosity of the universal credit taper rate the government introduced in November still leaves three-quarters of families on universal credit worse off
column7: and despite the pandemic
column8: unemployment benefits are now at their lowest real rates since 1990. These cuts will hit families living in the constituencies the Conservatives won from Labour in the so-called red wall much harder than those in their heartlands and will make it even harder for families to cope with fast-rising housing
column9: energy and food costs. It is likely that the cost of living crisis – and the lack of government support to help the lower-paid weather the storm – will further damage Johnson in the coming months. The Brexit that Johnson so coveted as a cynical route to the premiership will also continue to throw up difficulties. The key Brexit conundrum remains unsolved: there is no Brexit that involves a complete break with all of the EU’s regulations and institutions that is compatible with both no border in the Irish Sea and no border on the island of Ireland. Given that the UK willingly sacrifices sovereignty in exchange for trade in other trade agreements
column10: it seems extraordinary that this should become the sticking point of principle over which Conservative politicians are willing to undermine the Good Friday agreement. But thanks to the ideologues of the Eurosceptic right
column11: that is where we are. Johnson’s approach thus far has been to pretend this irresolvable dilemma does not exist
column12: misleading the public that the Northern Ireland protocol would involve no customs checks on goods coming from Northern Ireland into the rest of the UK. And the insidious economic impact of Brexit will continue; voters do not need to associate its economic malaise with Brexit itself to hold the government responsible for the state of the economy as we move towards the next election. Voter discontent with the government has translated into a consistentpoll lead for Labour in recent weeks. This creates a window of opportunity for Keir Starmer to position Labour as a government in waiting
column13: one the country can get behind. There have been some important achievements in the first 20 months of Starmer’s leadership. He has begun the journey towards rooting out antisemitism from his party
column14: suspending Jeremy Corbyn from the party after he minimised the findings of the statutory regulator
column15: the Equality and Human Rights Commission
column16: on antisemitism in Labour. He has introduced rule changes that should help ensure future leaders are more appealing to Labour voters. And after a botched reshuffle last May
column17: he has recently promoted promising talent to Labour’s frontbench. What he has not yet succeeded in doing
column18: however
column19: is communicating to voters how Britain would be different under a Starmer premiership. To be fair
column20: this is difficult for any opposition leader to achieve in the first year or two of a new parliament and even harder when there is an ongoing national crisis that has quite rightly dominated the political discourse. But 2022 will be a make-or-break year for Starmer as to whether he can succeed in mustering enthusiasm among voters alongside their growing disenchantment with Johnson. It is far too early to write him off altogether
column21: but we begin 2022 with a glimmer of hope that there may be an end in sight to the corruption
column22: hypocrisy and incompetence of Boris Johnson and the damage his premiership continues to wreak on Britain. That is sufficient to make the new year wishes for good health
column23: wellbeing and prosperity glow with a political optimism that was absent 12 months ago.";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/02/observer-view-on-uk-politics-in-2022

column5: 'World news'];"New York City’s new mayor
column6: Eric Adams
column7: was sworn into office soon after midnight yesterday. It was a fitting time of day for a cop-turned-politico who has indicated that he plans to return some personal panache to a metropolis knocked by a pandemic

column14: who campaigned on raising taxes and spoke divisively of a “tale of two cities”. On Friday

column18: eating pizza with a fork

column31: as a populist Brooklynite

column33: in many ways
column34: more accustomed to the rhythm of the city and its relationship with its commercial reason for being. Business leaders
column35: hoping to stem an exodus of firms and high-earners

column43: centre of New York’s shift to progressive politics. Clashes are brewing over a plan to reinstate solitary confinement at the city’s brutal Rikers Island pre-trial detention complex. “I’m going to ignore them
column44: ” Adams said last week. “If they like it or not. I’m the mayor.”

column1: But there are subtleties to Adams’s approach. He loves the nocturnal nightlife scene

column3: or a play
column4: before dropping by Zero Bond
column5: one of the city’s new private clubs. “When you’re out at night
column6: it helps decrease crime. It attracts tourists to the city
column7: ” he said recently
column8: adding that every time a New Yorker goes to a restaurant “we’re making sure that a dishwasher
column9: a cook
column10: a bartender and a waiter is employed.” It’s a strategy that Serge Becker
column11: nightlife force behind art nightclub AREA
column12: La Esquina restaurants and others
column13: says helped the city reinvent itself in the late 70s and 80s. “Populated streets are safer than abandoned ones. It helped build communities
column14: and Mayor Adams is sending encouraging signals that he has a nuanced view of nightlife – that it has a positive role to play in revitalising the city.” But there’s a question mark over where Adams sleeps. Some say New Jersey

column16: ” he told NY1 in November. “The 24-7 city that never sleeps. We have heard the alarm clock. We are up now.”";https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2022/jan/02/eric-adams-sworn-in-as-mayor-of-new-york-city

column3: 'Life and style'];"The question My teenage daughter has been depressed for 18 months. During the past two years
column4: I have been in the process of separating from her dad and their relationship has deteriorated to the extent that when we move apart she says she no longer wants to see him. She is not attending school and is struggling to engage with learning despite it being an important exam year. I have taken a step back and
column5: together with the school
column6: we have allowed her to only go in when she can
column7: maybe for an hour or two. Her father sees this as giving in and allowing her to be “lazy” and says giving her this freedom means she will just take advantage. According to him
column8: she needs more structure and discipline
column9: and she needs to get used to the fact that pressure is a part of life. It feels as if he can’t acknowledge that she is depressed
column10: despite her GP confirming this to be the case. I can see she has started to respond well to having the pressure taken off. My daughter and I have always had a good relationship and she confides in me a lot. Her dad and I have very opposing parenting styles
column11: which is partly what led to us splitting up. He lacks the ability to empathise and listen to her. Unless both her parents believe in her
column12: she tells me
column13: she won’t be able get through her depression
column14: so there’s no point in trying. We are due to move apart soon. In the meantime
column15: how can I help her to believe in herself? Philippa’s answer I think what I’m going to say might be very difficult for you to hear. But I hope for the sake of your child you hear me out. You seem to be so driven and burning to be right that you cannot see that there might be another way of looking at this situation. Now
column16: I might have got this wrong
column17: I have only your email to go on and I am reading between the lines
column18: but it feels as though you may be playing a game of “me-right
column19: you-wrong” with her dad. It almost feels to me as though your child might be a pawn in this fight. I know you are desperate to do your best for your child
column20: but I’m fearful that – unintentionally – you may not be.

column1: You have got the school and the GP on side. I’m fearful that this is like lining up chess pieces to win a game. If you could try to understand your ex’s fears and concerns for your daughter he might be more willing to listen to yours. Your teenager sounds conflicted. On the one hand she very dramatically doesn’t want to see him again
column2: but on the other
column3: she wants him to believe in her
column4: she needs his good opinion. When your ex moves out of the family home
column5: your daughter will lose her dad in her everyday life and from your letter I don’t see anyone focusing on that. I imagine
column6: to her
column7: it might feel as bad as losing a leg. It might feel like she is being convinced one of her legs
column8: that’s held her up all her life
column9: is no good. A greater part of your world when you are a child is your family
column10: your mum and dad. And in lockdown that world will have got even smaller. Imagine what it does to you when that world splits apart in an unamicable way. It’s not as though she’s an adult and can just choose another house share. A child may unconsciously see themselves as part mum and part dad and if one part or both parts say the other one is bad
column11: well it’s not surprising if it makes a child feel uneasy in themselves. Some kids are more resilient than others
column12: but some are sensitive and when their parents argue or appear to hate each other they experience this as trauma. To a child
column13: the only solution their psyche may come up with when parents are warring is to throw in their lot with just one parent. It’s quite complicated to see each one as a mixture of good and bad and so it’s easier to make one good and the other bad. These processes are largely unconscious and when we cannot process our difficult feelings into words it can be a cause of depression. You and your ex-partner have taken up polarised positions. You both need to exercise some give and take to come to a compromise. Your daughter has thrown in her lot with you. And if you describe him to her as somehow lacking
column14: you are in danger of alienating her from her father. Don’t be in league with her against her dad. Her home being in flux and about to fall apart could be a reason she is too distressed and depressed to go to school
column15: as there is a crisis at home. It is not unknown that when parents war a child may become ill. I’m sorry if this is hard to take in and
column16: as I said
column17: I may be reading the situation wrong
column18: but to make sure your split doesn’t exacerbate your daughter’s depression I urge you to make an appointment for the three of you at the Family Separation Clinic (familyseparationclinic.com). This clinic offers a specialist service to families experiencing separation
column19: in particular where a child is rejecting a relationship with one of their parents. Also
column20: I recommend listening to my BBC Radio 4 documentary about parental alienation called When Parents Split
column21: available online. If you have a question

column1: Heather Hallett The name Baroness Hallett may mean little to most people outside the upper echelons of the legal establishment
column2: but from early 2022 she will be in the news as much as anyone in public life. Lady Hallett
column4: a former senior appeal court judge
column5: who also served as coroner in the inquest into the July 2005 terror attacks on London’s transport network
column6: has been appointed to chair the official inquiry into the Covid-19 pandemic
column7: which begins in the spring. The fact that hearings will be held in public means she will be firmly in the media spotlight. The draft terms of the inquiry are expected to be published early in the new year

But they insist that they will be pressing her to uncover the full extent of mistakes by government and the reasons why it and the NHS were so underprepared for the pandemic. Science Robin McKie

column2: of Oxford University

column4: the world’s largest study aimed at finding potential treatments for Covid. Over 46

In recent years EU efforts have been led by the impressive European commissioner Margrethe Vestager yet her landmark data privacy laws are haphazardly enforced and competition cases have become bogged down in legalese. The EU’s answer is more rules – the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act – to regulate illegal content and improve competition respectively. Schaldemose has been tasked with shaping the former into something which will become law – which has involved wrangling 2

column6: 'Education'];"It’s break time at Valayanchirangara primary school and the pupils run freely beneath the mango trees and palms. Girls race against the boys
column7: hitching up their knee-length shorts
column8: cargo green for girls and teal blue for boys
column9: as they go. It’s been three years since this small government primary school introduced gender-neutral uniforms for its pupils
column10: and in doing so set in motion a quiet revolution that is now sweeping across the south Indian state of Kerala. “I feel very thrilled and comfortable with the uniform. It’s quite distinct from that of my friends studying in nearby schools. I can play well with this dress
column11: ” said 10-year-old Sivananda Mahesh. Inspired by the Valayanchirangara model
column12: more than a dozen schools in Kerala have shifted to gender-neutral uniforms and the state’s ruling Communist party of India has pledged to support the movement being implemented across the state. Several women’s rights groups have also come out in support of the unisex uniform initiative
column13: saying it will help bridge the gender gap. Kerala has India’s highest literacy rate
column14: but there is still a higher literacy rate for men than women and gendered and patriarchal expectations continue to be placed on women in society. However
column15: this initiative to tackle gender inequality at a young age is now facing stiff opposition from a section of Muslim organisations in Kerala
column16: which accuse the schools of forcing western dress on their children and denying girls the right to wear what they deem to be appropriate feminine clothes. In December
column17: a protest rally was organised by the Muslim Coordination Committee in Balussery
column18: a town in north Kerala
column19: when the local secondary school introduced a unisex uniform of trousers and shirts for boys and girls. Prominent Muslim organisations in the state warned the state government against enforcing gender-neutral uniforms in other educational institutions in Kerala
column20: a state that is 26% Muslim
column21: saying it would be un-Islamic for girls to wear trousers. The decision at Valayanchirangara primary came after Benoy Peter
column22: the former head of the parent-teacher association
column23: noticed the difficulties that girls often faced wearing skirts in the playground and while playing sports. The school enlisted the help of a local fashion designer Vidya Mukunda to create a gender-neutral uniform that had “style and elegance”.

column1: The school
column2: which has 756 pupils who are mostly Christian and Muslims
column3: said only one parent objected to the uniform
column4: and after the benefits of the initiative were explained
column5: in particular how it would make it easier for girls to move about comfortably
column6: the resistance was dropped. “When the idea came up
column7: we were worried about the reaction of parents who prefer their girls’ wearing skirts. But we were able to implement it easily and without any protests
column8: ” said KA Usha
column9: the school’s former headteacher. Usha said the uniform had not only bolstered the performance of pupils

column11: ” she said.

column1: The school has also pushed its gender-equality initiatives beyond uniforms. After concerns that the school materials were filled with content “often in conflict with gender parity”
column2: they created their own gender-neutral textbooks
column3: which are designed to sensitise children to gender equality from a young age. “We made our books with teachers writing the content and a former student doing the drawings. The books carry images of women driving vehicles and men cooking in the kitchen. The books convey the message that no job or task is gender-specific
column4: ” said Usha. The school has also designed a new logo with the image of a girl and a boy to spread the message of gender equality. KP Suma
column5: a teacher at the school
column6: said: “Now the boys and girls have equal happiness and freedom. The uniform has boosted their confidence. Gender sensitivity is at the heart of the school
column7: and we are ensuring easy mingling of boys and girls without bothering about gender.” After the successes of Valayanchirangara primary
column8: the state education minister

column2: 'Death and dying'
column3: 'South Africa'
column4: 'Africa'];"The body of Archbishop Desmond Tutu will undergo aquamation
column5: an increasingly popular and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional cremation methods
column6: using water instead of fire. With aquamation
column7: or “alkaline hydrolysis”
column8: the body of the deceased is immersed for three to four hours in a mixture of water and a strong alkali
column9: such as potassium hydroxide
column10: in a pressurised metal cylinder and heated to around 150C.

column1: The process liquifies everything except for the bones
column2: which are then dried in an oven and reduced to white dust
column3: placed in an urn and handed to relatives. Like human composting
column4: a technique of composting bodies with layers of organic material like leaves or wood chips
column5: aquamation is still authorised only in certain countries. In South Africa
column6: where Tutu died last Sunday
column7: no legislation at all governs the practice. First developed in the early 1990s as a way to discard the bodies of animals used in experiments
column8: the method was then used to dispose of cattle during the mad cow disease epidemic
column9: said US-based researcher Philip R Olson. In the 2000s
column10: US medical schools used aquamation to dispose of donated human cadavers
column11: before the practice made its way into the funeral industry
column12: Olson wrote in a 2014 paper. Tutu
column13: who died on Boxing Day aged 90
column14: was known for his modest lifestyle. He left instructions that his funeral ceremony should be simple and without frills. The anti-apartheid hero
column15: whose funeral was held on Saturday
column16: specifically asked for a cheap coffin and an eco-friendly cremation.

column1: With burial space in urban areas worldwide becoming increasingly scarce and expensive
column2: aquamation has obvious attractions. Its advocates say water is a gentler way to go than flames. They also claim a liquid cremation consumes less energy than a conventional one
column3: and emits less greenhouse gases. According to UK-based firm Resomation
column4: aquamation uses five times less energy than fire
column5: and reduces a funeral’s emissions of greenhouse gases by about 35%. Aquamation is also used to dispose of animal carcasses in slaughterhouses
column6: where it is considered to be more efficient and hygienic.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/02/what-is-aquamation-the-process-behind-desmond-tutus-green-cremation

column9: 'Investments'];"Too much of a good thing can make anyone queasy – as many will be aware after a week of turkey leftovers. The same applies to the economy and markets
column10: if analysts’ predictions for the year ahead are anything to go by. Sitting around doing nothing (or passive investment) is an admirable strategy in most years. In 2021 it was masterly. London’s stock benchmark
column11: the FTSE 100
column12: ended December 14.3% higher than last January
column13: and in the US buying shares has been even more rewarding: the S&P 500 went up more than a quarter in value. But even though money was apparently so easy to make last year
column14: investors and economists are putting on a show of wariness for 2022. “Investors have enjoyed bumper returns over the past 18 months
column15: but these returns are
column16: in large part
column17: borrowed from the future
column18: ” says Joseph Little
column19: chief global strategist at HSBC Asset Management. He thinks a “pay-back period” is in order. Guy Foster
column20: his counterpart at wealth management firm Brewin Dolphin
column21: says 2021’s gains increased at “breakneck pace”
column22: and the best we can hope for is a gentle deceleration rather than a painful crunch. And Emiel van den Heiligenberg at Legal & General Investment Management even mentions the dreaded b-word – “bubble” – even if only to point out that we’re not quite there yet
column23: despite some of the market madness of 2021. Forecasting stock index movements is always a bit of a mug’s game – as the pandemic has underlined – so some limited kudos must go to those who still place their bets publicly. The brave souls who have put their reputations on the line to make forecasts for the year ahead range from Morgan Stanley (S&P 500 down 9%) to Wells Fargo (S&P 500 up 11%) – a sign of the uncertainty among investors.

column1: Credit Suisse is one of the few banks to have nailed its colours to the FTSE 100 mast
column2: predicting London blue chips will gain a fairly measly 7%. Stockbroker A J Bell is even more pessimistic
column3: going for only 4%. Analysts at HSBC and Deutsche Bank predict that economies in the US and Europe will grow at between 3.75% and 5% during 2022. Yet Japan’s Nomura cautions that US growth could slow considerably in the second half of the year. Among those lining up to spoil the party are China’s president
column4: Xi Jinping
column5: who has already turned down the music on his country’s tech tycoons. Sino-experts suggest Beijing is taking away the punch bowl with tighter credit and regulations. Then there is inflation
column6: the dog that may finally be barking after 12 years of conspicuous silence. This time things really could be different: UK consumer prices have risen by 5.1% in the past year and US prices by a scorching 6.8%.

column1: Andrew Bailey at the Bank of England has already done his best Mervyn King impression
column2: raising interest rates just as a slowdown looked imminent (though it may be only a slight
column3: Omicron-related one). Nevertheless
column4: the rate rise is a signal that central banks are really feeling the constant digs about inflation – even if some of the price increases are caused by pandemic disruption rather than widespread wage increases. Stopping the flow of money to the economy while not damaging the recovery could turn into a nail-biting balancing act. “It is devilishly difficult to achieve a soft landing
column5: ” says Deutsche’s David Folkerts-Landau. “But it can be and has been done.” Buckle up.";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/02/after-sparkling-year-investors-advised-to-tone-down-2022-hopes

column17: 'Energy industry'];The number of UK households living in fuel poverty could climb to the highest level on record by this spring unless the government moves to soften the blow of a looming record high energy bill hike
column18: according to a fuel poverty charity. Around 4 million homes in the UK were already classed as fuel poor before a surge in global energy market prices triggered one of the steepest ever energy bill hikes in October
column19: but campaigners are braced for a record increase in the numbers unable to pay their energy bills following another hike this spring. The charity National Energy Action warned that the double blow to household bills could cause at least 2 million more homes to slip into fuel poverty compared with the start of 2021
column20: taking the total to 6 million households. This would be the highest level of fuel poverty across the UK since records began in 1996. The looming energy price hike has not yet been finalised by the regulator but Adam Scorer
column21: chief executive of National Energy Action
column22: told the Observer that the number of households in fuel poverty would “skyrocket” in April. This is expected to deepen the UK’s national energy crisis and compound the “year of the squeeze”

column24: which threatens to trigger a “cost of living catastrophe” for hard-pressed families. Households are already paying record prices to put petrol in their cars
column25: and can expect the cost of consumer goods to rocket as fuel prices and supply-chain disruptions take their toll on major companies. “Those on lowest incomes and in less-efficient homes will not just face financial hardship but intolerable living conditions
column26: ill health and
column27: for too many
column28: a shortened life
column29: ” Scorer said. “This is not just conjecture. It will happen and we’ve had enough time to see it coming and act.” Energy market prices climbed steadily over 2021 before leaping to record highs in October and fresh record highs in December. The market rally has fuelled one of the steepest energy price hikes in the history of the UK’s liberalised energy market. Ed Miliband
column30: shadow secretary of state for climate change and net zero

column35: Ofgem

column39: from £1

column43: and the party would also “ramp up ambition with our plan to retrofit 19 million homes” to make them more energy efficient and help bring down household bills. “It is a moral and social scandal that fuel poverty exists in modern Britain. But with national leadership

column9: 'World news'];"Two of Prince Andrew’s efforts to prevent or stall the progression of Virginia Roberts Giuffre’s sex assault lawsuit against him were blocked on Saturday when a US federal judge ordered the prince’s lawyers to turn over key legal documents

column11: in a written order

Kaplan also rejected arguments by the prince’s lawyer
column13: Andrew Brettler
column14: on jurisdiction grounds after they argued last week that the lawsuit should be dismissed because Giuffre
column15: a US citizen
column16: no longer lives in the US. Brettler has called the lawsuit “baseless”. The prince’s lawyers claimed evidence was so strong that Giuffre does not reside in the US that it was pointless to exchange evidence until that question is resolved because it could result in the lawsuit’s dismissal. They argued that Giuffre has lived in Australia for all but two of the past 19 years
column17: has an Australian driver’s licence and lives in a $1.9m (£1.4m) home in Perth
column18: Western Australia

column20: an Australian national

column25: in a written order on Friday
column26: noted the prince’s lawyers have requested that “extensive” materials be turned over by Giuffre by 14 January

column29: in which she accuses Prince Andrew of sexual assault.

column1: In a separate development
column2: Andrew’s lawyers are also reported to have not provided documentary evidence that he has the “inability to sweat”
column3: despite the claim supporting his denial against allegations he had sex with Giuffre. The duke is also said not to have so far named any witnesses to support his alibi that he was in Pizza Express in Woking on the night in 2001 he was accused of having sex with Giuffre. The developments intensify Andrew’s predicament as he faces intense pressure over his friendship with Ghislaine Maxwell. Last Thursday Maxwell
column5: was found guilty of recruiting and trafficking young girls to be sexually abused by Epstein. The verdict
column6: which has no direct bearing on the Giuffre civil action
column7: could increase public pressure for further prosecutions and push men in Epstein and Maxwell’s orbit to settle actions against them. “As to whether Prince Andrew is in greater jeopardy in terms of the civil suit now being stronger there could be some pressure on the court because the public wants to know why the users of these young girls were not held accountable
column8: ” former sex crimes prosecutor Wendy Murphy told the Observer. “The public wants a pound of flesh from the rapists – not just the pimps – but the civil suit is all about money and when the right numbers are paid the case will go away
column9: assuming it survives the jurisdictional challenges
column10: ” Murphy added. But the duke was barely mentioned during the Maxwell proceedings and his lawyers are likely to seize on testimony from the key witness “Carolyn”
column11: who said it was Giuffre who introduced her to Epstein and Maxwell. Separately
column12: it is reported that Giuffre could be permitted to deliver a victim impact statement at Maxwell’s sentencing. Sigrid McCawley
column13: a lawyer for Giuffre
column14: told the Telegraph on Saturday that she anticipates the court will hear from “many
column15: many other women who were not able to be heard at the trial”. At the same time
column16: government prosecutors have made no indication since Maxwell’s conviction that they intend to prosecute further
column17: either other members of Epstein’s staff or alleged customers of the Epstein-Maxwell sex trafficking conspiracy. Instead
column18: they have given signs that they are closing the book. Last week

column20: named in Epstein’s 2007 non-prosecution agreement
column21: have said they have been informed that no criminal charges will be brought against their client. On Saturday

column23: lawyer for Giuffre
column24: said Maxwell should have “cut a deal”

column26: her ex-boyfriend. Boies told the Times: “She could have cut a very good deal early on but she passed up that opportunity. I think that’s proven to be a fatal mistake.” Giuffre’s legal team have made requests for new information in readiness for a possible longer hearing

The duke told Newsnight that her account could not be true “because I have a peculiar medical condition which is that I don’t sweat or I didn’t sweat at the time”. He also said that on the day in question he had taken his daughter Beatrice to a children’s party at Pizza Express in the late afternoon and was at home with his children for the rest of the night. As pressure mounts on the duke

column7: generally to fit female
column8: European beauty standards
column9: with thinner faces
column10: smaller noses and plump lips. Mia

column1: “I’m a bigger girl

column9: it doesn’t even look like me. “I was in bed crying some nights about how ugly and disgusting I felt. I’m almost 30! I shouldn’t feel that way … Imagine a 10-year-old using these filters. That’s scary to me.” There isn’t yet a full body of research on the psychological effects of these filters but Dr Jasmine Fardouly
column10: a body image expert from the University of New South Wales
column11: says a study she conducted last year suggests the more unattainable the beauty standard that young people are exposed to online

column14: really

column18: both in traditional and social media

column21: it doesn’t seem to make a difference.” There’s a strong relationship between negative body image and the use of photo editing but Fardouly says it’s less clear which direction this correlation flows; whether people’s self-esteem is lower due to the constant augmentation of their images or if those with low body images are more likely to use these features in the first place.

column1: “Body dissatisfaction is an important predictor for eating disorders

column4: and then I’ve stopped myself and gone

column7: ” she says. “The ease [with] which people can use filters [is a problem]. Especially if they’re changing the structure of the face and promoting these unattainable beauty ideals

column11: Spark AR

Snapchat … is private by default to create an environment where people feel free to authentically be themselves.” The spokesperson says Snapchat has “invested in an in-house sociologist who is tasked with thinking about the impact our product and features have on our community”. “When someone sends a snap with a lens to someone else on Snapchat

column4: 'Oceans'];"There’s a reason surfers like to keep their best breaks a secret. For decades
column5: wave riders have blazed a trail into little-known coastal towns – and in their wake come the planners and developers. When Clint Bryan bought his house 40 minutes north of Perth city
column6: one consideration was paramount: it had to be near his favourite surf break. And sure enough
column7: his Kallaroo home is just five minutes’ walk from the Indian Ocean. The suburb name is a Noongar word meaning “road to the water”. But by the end of this summer
column8: the waves that Bryan built his life around will disappear as the beach is redeveloped for the $252m Ocean Reef Marina. The marina is within the Marmion marine park and will transform 1.5km of coastline into shops
column9: restaurants
column10: boat moorings
column11: a protected beach and new homes. The local state MP
column12: Emily Hamilton
column13: says it will create “thousands of jobs” and inject $3bn into the Western Australia economy. But it will also kill three surf breaks – Mossies
column14: Big Rock and Pylons. The community group Save Ocean Reef says it will mount a legal challenge to the project because it is damaging the marine park
column15: and a petition to construct an artificial reef has grown to nearly 2
column16: 500 signatures. Ocean Reef has been a surf destination since at least the 1950s
column17: when it was little more than sand dunes and beach shacks
column18: with just a caravan park nearby. “It’s like we are losing our playing field and the grassroots waves we learned to surf on
column19: ” says Bryan
column20: a 43-year-old aviation rescue firefighter. “It’s the end of an era and our group [Ocean Reef Artificial Reef] just wants the opportunity to keep the surf community alive in our area.”

column1: The fragile magic of the break Sean Doherty
column2: the chair of the advocacy group Surf Rider Foundation
column3: says dozens of surf breaks around the country are at risk from development or sand dune work. “The pressure on the coastline is growing
column4: ” Doherty says. “For every surf break that is in some kind of danger
column5: it is the result of some development nearby and it takes different forms.” In some places the developments are similar to those proposed for Ocean Reef. On 1 May almost 700 surfers paddled out to protest against the development of eco-cabins
column6: a conference centre and a restaurant on crown land near a surf spot called the Farm in Killalea
column7: south of Wollongong. Opponents say the state-funded development will impinge on a national surfing reserve that was declared in 2009
column8: although the proponents of the development insist it will affect less than 2% of the reserve.

column1: But Doherty says the most endangered breaks now are Narrabeen and South Narrabeen on Sydney’s northern beaches
column2: where construction has begun on a 7m-high 1.3km concrete seawall to save 49 properties
column3: a club and a car park built right on the beach. While the seawall will protect homes from erosion and storm surge
column4: it will also affect the flow of sand.

column1: For waves to form
column2: the movement of sand
column3: which helps shape the seabed
column4: is crucial. Waves break when there is a reef or an accumulation of sand under the water
column5: making it shallow enough for the incoming swell to rise up and form waves. In a natural system
column6: sand blows in and out to sea or is brought in by ocean currents. But Doherty says sea walls
column7: houses and vegetation are increasingly anchoring sand to the shore
column8: taking away the lifeblood of waves. “The magic qualities that make a good surf break are quite ephemeral and quite easily disturbed and changed
column9: often as a result of development
column10: ” Doherty says. The foundation says other breaks are also threatened by proposals for seawalls
column11: including at Wamberal on the NSW Central Coast and Byron Bay
column12: nine hours north
column13: where locals have been fighting the suggestion for years. Last year
column14: authorities were forced to install emergency sandbagging and close Main and Clarkes beaches at Byron
column15: where erosion caused by natural processes
column16: development on frontal dune systems and changing weather patterns have wreaked havoc. Further threats to surf breaks in NSW
column17: Queensland
column18: Victoria and Western Australia come from climate change
column19: overcrowding and water pollution

column1: A wealth of benefits In 2010
column2: New Zealand became one of only two countries in the world to legally protect surf breaks (Peru is the other). In Australia
column3: neither state nor federal environment legislation protects waves. Ana Manero
column4: an environmental economist at the Australian National University who researches surfing economics
column5: says the legal gap is a “massive blind spot”
column6: but legislation is not the only way to defend surf breaks. “We don’t have environmental laws to protect surfing resources in Australia
column7: but we have an economic argument
column8: ” Manero says. “Surfing brings a wealth of benefits
column9: it makes places more desirable to live in
column10: it is good for the local community
column11: so the question is: when waves are impacted
column12: how is that loss of value going to be accounted for?”

column1: There are an estimated 2.5 million recreational surfers in Australia and surf tourism expenditure was estimated to be about $91bn a year globally before the pandemic. “It’s crucial we understand the real value of surfing before we lose the many benefits it brings
column2: not only for Australia’s surfing community but also for the hundreds of coastal towns where surfing underpins the local economy and lifestyle
column3: ” Manero says. For decades
column4: environmental economics has been applied to quantify the value of recreation activities
column5: such as scuba diving and fishing. Manero hopes surfing research will help inform better decisions when developments affect waves. “The problem for policymakers is that surfing’s ‘intangible’ benefits – such as mental health or social connections – are much harder to measure than jobs and retail sales – but I can tell you that they translate into millions of dollars
column6: ” she says. Manero says protecting waves does not mean leaving beaches untouched – there are many examples where the building of groynes
column7: piers or sand dredging have improved the quality of waves. At Snapper Rocks on the Gold Coast
column8: a “superbank” was unexpectedly formed after work to remove sand from the entrance to the Tweed River. “During the planning process
column9: if we could put a little bit of brain power into understanding how waves form and the benefits they bring
column10: then we would have a better chance of improving the wellbeing of coastal communities
column11: ” Manero says. “It is difficult
column12: but it can be done.”";https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/jan/02/wave-goodbye-the-battle-to-protect-australias-surf-breaks

column11: getting lost in the seagrass. Even on low visibility days like this

column1: The Cabbage Tree Bay aquatic reserve is McClellan’s top snorkelling spot in Sydney. He says conservation efforts made it so. “It has been a no fishing zone since 2002.” Since then

column4: would-be snorkellers should look for spots with calm waters

column2: I know language is alchemy and there’s no exact prescription for good writing. But I also know grammar is central. Meaning can turn on a single word or punctuation mark and a little fine-tuning can prevent ambiguity and inconsistency. Just read this sentence and tell me grammar doesn’t matter: After being whipped fiercely
column3: the cook boiled the egg. Almost everyone has a grammatical pet peeve
column4: and commas attract a lot of attention. When they’re needed
column5: they’re essential – compare “I’m sorry I love you” and “I’m sorry
column6: I love you”. But haphazard or unwarranted commas can be distracting and even misleading. Jonathan Franzen wrote a whole essay on the “irritating
column7: lazy mannerism” of comma-then
column8: as in: “He dims the lamp and opens the window
column9: then pulls the body inside.” I sympathise but I’m personally more irritated by comma-but and comma-too.

column1: The Guardian style guide is clear on the Oxford comma (comma-and in a list); it’s definitely not needed in “he ate ham
column2: eggs and chips”
column3: although an essential distinction between these two sentences: I dedicate this book to my parents
column4: Martin Amis
column5: and JK Rowling. I dedicate this book to my parents
column6: Martin Amis and JK Rowling. But I give punctuation champion Lynne Truss the last word: “Don’t use commas like a stupid person. I mean it.” On non-comma matters
column7: F Scott Fitzgerald thought the exclamation mark was “like laughing at your own joke” and should be done away with
column8: and Milan Kundera claimed he once left a publisher for trying to change his semicolons to full-stops. (I’m a big fan of the semicolon; it encourages the reader to linger a little longer on the thought before it.) And Proust cringed at cliches: “It’s quite true that the sun is on fire at sunset
column9: but it’s been said too often.” Some of my personal bugbears come up more regularly than others. “Compared to” is different from “compared with”. Use the first if you want to liken one thing to another
column10: the second to contrast. And that reminds me: in my book “different from” is correct
column11: “different to” and “different than” are not. “Who” and “whom” are both needed but not interchangeable. The same goes for less/fewer
column12: like/such as and imply/infer. And there’s a simple rule for “that” v “which”: if the sentence needs the (restrictive) clause the word is connecting it to
column13: use “that”
column14: otherwise use “which”. (Some of the grammarati point to an irregular restrictive “which” that can replace “that” but I’m yet to be convinced.) If all of this sounds like so much nerdy nitpicking
column15: I concede some arcane rules are just begging to be bent
column16: although I would still argue you have to have a good reason. The Guardian says it’s fine to split infinitives because “stubbornly to resist so can sound pompous and awkward”. Ditto on ending a sentence with a preposition. And while strictly plural
column17: “data” can take a singular verb
column18: as in “data shows”
column19: because how often do you come across “datum” anyway? Common sense should come into it
column20: and so too aesthetics. Think of how the prose flows. If a sentence is long and inelegant
column21: change it. Sometimes I use an en dash or even parentheses to break up a string of commas. And don’t dangle a verb at the end of the sentence
column22: far from its subject. “How high will emissions from the project proposed for the northern region and the existing plants in the south and west be?” is just ungainly.

column1: Words should sound right too. If you’re torn over whether the possessive of James takes a second S after the apostrophe – James’s – say it out loud. To quote Joan Didion
column2: grammar is “a piano played by ear”. Some words have lost their meaning from overuse. I once edited out three appearances of “iconic” on a single day; “unforgettable”
column3: “infamous” and “emblematic” stepped in admirably. Others become unusable if they’re loaded with an agenda. Politicisation is dangerous. As Orwell said: “If thought corrupts language
column4: language can also corrupt thought.” Language matters. It matters how laws and treaties are written
column5: and whether coal is “phased out” or “phased down”. It matters that news is truthful and that literature inspires. Language reflects – and can even define – who we are. So a little respect
column6: please
column7: for its rules. • Susan McDonald is a news producer for Guardian Australia and a freelance writer";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/01/different-from-is-correct-and-iconic-is-meaningless-what-i-know-after-two-decades-as-a-subeditor

column11: in his new role as the cabinet’s major-domo and minister in charge of “levelling up”
column12: is about to expend large amounts of intellectual and political capital attempting to close the gap between the south-east and everywhere else. Levelling up
column13: as we are told repeatedly by No 10
column14: will be the defining achievement of the Johnson administration and 2022 is the year that efforts to transform the much-neglected regions begin to gather pace. With this in mind
column15: Gove is about to publish a white paper that outlines how the government plans to tackle this gargantuan task. So far the prospects for a major commitment across Whitehall are looking slim. The chancellor
column16: for one
column17: wants to make sure that whatever Gove wants comes with no new cash attached. Recycling is popular in government
column18: especially when it concerns money. Gove’s response appears to be a renewed focus on the bureaucracy supporting the regions. He has floated a scheme to fill the geographical gaps between the metro mayors who run most of England’s big city regions with a new concept of US-style regional governors. There is no suggestion of mimicking the neo-colonial mini-White Houses that host governors in most US state capitals – just a network of elected chiefs able to reduce regional inequalities and drive growth around the country. Gove’s mistake here is his apparent determination to join the list of reformers who focus more on structures than desired outcomes. One advantage he can claim as he prepares to confront the many entrenched and powerful interests in the shires (which dominate the Conservative party apparatus and will object to governors) is the lack of agreement among political opponents on an alternative to whatever structure he puts forward.

column1: Labour and the thinktanks that feed ideas to shadow ministers agree on one thing – that extra funds and power should be devolved away from Whitehall. But they have not found an alternative system of local democracy to coalesce around since John Prescott’s proposal for regional assemblies was crushed in a referendum held in north-east England almost 20 years ago. And there is good reason. As Prescott found out
column2: extra layers of government appear to the public as civil-service employment schemes. Even sharp-shooting governors can quickly look like jobsworths to those who see themselves as taxpayers first and citizens second. Labour is rightly more concerned with issues that Gove wants to sidestep
column3: such as how to foster more productive regional economic engines based on a collaboration of public and private capital. The access to private capital in England’s north-east
column4: north-west and south-west

column8: 'Coastlines'];"From a distance
column9: the beach at Winterton-on-sea in Norfolk looks like the opening scene of Saving Private Ryan
column10: with hundreds of grey bodies lying motionless across the sand. On closer inspection
column11: it becomes clear they are not fallen soldiers but a huge colony of seals taken to the land for pupping season. It’s an amazing annual sight that draws tourists and nature-lovers from across the country
column12: but another process is taking place that is pushing people back – the growing threat of coastal erosion. Just along from where the armies of grey seals lay with their white pups
column13: there used to stand the Dunes Cafe
column14: a much-loved beach facility with a large and loyal clientele. A year ago it was demolished to prevent its imminent collapse as a result of land lost to sea and storms. The ground where it stood is
column15: like the cafe itself
column16: no longer there. It’s a story of disappearance taking place all along the eastern coast of England
column17: but particularly in East Anglia
column18: that bulbous protrusion jutting into the North Sea. That climate change and rising sea levels take their toll on the landscape is an old story
column19: but one with an urgent new twist. “The sea level’s been rising since the last ice age
column21: 000 years ago or so
column22: ” says Jim Hall
column23: professor of climate and environmental risk at Oxford University’s Environmental Change Institute. “And it’s going faster. We’re probably not seeing its effect very much yet on the coast
column24: though we will in the future.”

column1: A 2020 report by the Committee on Climate Change
column2: on which Hall sits as an expert on coastal erosion and flooding
column3: found 1.2m homes at significant risk of flooding and a further 100
column4: 000 subject to coastal erosion by 2080 – which
column5: although it sounds safely distant
column6: will be within the lifetime of most of those born so far this century. Two years ago
column7: the US-based climate change research group Climate Central went further. It produced a map showing areas of the UK at risk of being underwater by 2050. They included sections of north Norfolk
column8: all of the Lincolnshire coast and much of Cambridgeshire
column9: along with parts of East Yorkshire
column10: Merseyside and the Bristol area. According to the group
column11: this would happen even if “moderate” attempts were made to combat climate change. Such predictions are based on highly complex
column12: and disputed
column13: modelling
column14: yet there are significant warning signs that such an outcome is growing rapidly more plausible. Last month
column15: scientists monitoring the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica
column16: an ice shelf the size of Great Britain
column17: warned it is in danger of collapse. “It’s being melted from below by warm ocean waters
column18: causing it to lose its grip on the underwater mountain
column19: ” said Peter Davis from British Antarctic Survey and the International Thwaites Glacier Collaboration. He said research suggested that the ice shelf will begin to break apart within two decades. Should there be a complete collapse
column20: it would lead to a highly consequential rise in sea levels of 60cm. That may be a worst-case scenario
column21: but it will almost certainly have a notable impact on the British coastline.

column1: In a sense Norfolk is a real-time lesson in how weather and sea can drastically alter a landscape. After the Dunes Cafe was dismantled
column2: a chef called Alex Clare set up a mobile silver Airstream cafe to cater to locals and visitors at the car park next to where the cafe once stood. He’s had to move the Airstream four times in eight months
column3: as sections of the dunes on which the car park sits have collapsed into the sea under pressure from storms and high tides. “In the last two weeks
column4: ” Clare told me
column5: “a strip about as long as this caravan has disappeared. You hear about erosion
column6: but you don’t know what it means
column7: what it involves
column8: until you witness it. And it’s a shock to see the physical transformation.” The car park owner has tried to slow the erosion by laying down large concrete blocks on the beach
column9: but it’s the definition of a losing battle. Winterton’s coast possesses a bleak beauty
column10: enhanced by the fact that the village sits back from the sea
column11: behind a broad wall of dunes. By contrast
column12: at Hemsby
column13: a mile or so south
column14: the town
column15: with its amusement arcades and fairgrounds
column16: stretches all the way to the shoreline. Four years ago
column17: there was a line of seven chalets close to the edge of the sandy cliffs that drop down to the beach. They all had to be knocked down as the land beneath them began to fall into the sea. The local council is looking at sea defences
column18: but the only workable answer involves large-scale investment and a major process of sandscaping. That is what took place at Bacton
column19: 15 miles north along the coast from Winterton.

column1: A four-mile-long dune was built to protect Bacton Terminal
column2: which supplies around a third of the UK’s gas and had been moving steadily closer to the cliff edge
column3: literally and metaphorically. Designed by the Dutch engineering company Royal HaskoningDHV
column4: it involved the placement of 1.8 million cubic metres of sand along the beaches near the terminal. The design relies on the sand being shifted into place by wind
column5: waves and tides. The Dutch are world leaders in land reclamation and protection
column6: having over the years reclaimed more than a sixth of Holland’s landmass from the sea. “In the long run
column7: ” says Professor Hall
column8: “any coast protection is temporary. We’ve been doing engineering to protect the coast for a very long time. Almost half of the UK coast has some kind of protection – sea walls
column9: revetments
column10: promenades
column11: that kind of thing. The Victorians were inveterate promenade builders.” Such protections don’t stop the sea rising. They merely fix
column12: for a while
column13: the point of the shore profile. At Happisburgh
column14: near Bacton
column15: wooden revetments did that job
column16: until they collapsed 20 years ago
column17: leading to a sudden and damaging exposure to the sea. “Once you lose [the protection]
column18: there’s a lot of pent-up erosion capacity
column19: ” says Hall. Although there is growing media coverage of coastal erosion
column20: it’s as Alex Clare said: knowledge of the thing isn’t the same as experiencing it. “There’s a bit more recognition that the sea level is rising fast
column21: ” says Hall. “But I don’t think coastal communities have really understood what the future holds.” He believes there should be an “honest conversation” between government
column22: local government and the affected communities.

column1: While the money required to protect cities like London and Hull will have to be found
column2: that’s not likely with isolated villages. When I visited Norfolk last month
column3: the locals seemed fatalistic or in denial
column4: pointing out that the situation was worse somewhere else
column5: either up or down the coast. As I drove back
column6: it began to rain
column7: and that night the weather deteriorated. The next day there was a large landslide at Mundesley
column8: near Bacton
column9: with a huge chunk of the cliff face collapsing on to the beach. Above it
column10: houses stood on the precipice
column11: their future looking about as secure as Norwich’s position in the Premier League. As Pete Revell
column12: station manager at Bacton HM Coastguard
column13: said
column14: Mundesley was viewed as stable by comparison with nearby Happisburgh
column15: and the landslide came as “a bit of a surprise”. It certainly shocked local resident Antony Lloyd
column16: who said he was “very nervous and agitated about any further incidents.” He was finding it hard to sleep and thought he would have to move. Of course
column17: the occasional landfall or loss of beachside chalets is hardly cause for national panic. But like canaries in a coal mine
column18: the inhabitants of the villages strung along Norfolk’s shifting coastline are a warning of a worrying future. There are processes under way whose outcomes are unavoidable
column19: and those that can potentially be arrested. But it will require unblinking foresight and long-term action
column20: neither of which are our national strong suits. If you take the path north from Winterton’s beach car park you come to the roped-off seal sanctuary. Beyond
column21: seals and their pups lie still and vulnerable in the dunes
column22: hundreds of yards from the shore
column23: as if waiting for the sea to rescue them. And come it will
column24: not now or next year
column25: but much sooner than we care to think.";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/01/sands-slip-england-crumbling-coasts-erosion-rising-sea-levels

column7: 'Ghislaine Maxwell'];"There was much wailing and gnashing of teeth a few weeks ago when the Daily Telegraph announced that the renovation of the fire-ravaged Notre Dame cathedral would turn it into a “politically correct Disneyland”. As so often when that august publication buckles on its cuirass and bascinet in the War on Woke
column8: it helps to look closely at its sources and evidence. In this case
column9: it relied on the opinions of a conservative architect called Maurice Culot and sight of rather general proposals to install “modern art murals” in some of the side chapels and to project quotes from the Bible in languages that include Mandarin. A more measured and informed article in the Washington Post
column10: by the art historian Elizabeth Lev
column11: later pointed out that these chapels were formerly “an ill-kept hodgepodge generally passed over by tourists” and there should be nothing very terrible about a cathedral communicating the scriptures in the world’s leading languages. France’s National Heritage and Architecture Commission has since backed the proposals
column12: with a couple of reservations. The work might yet be clumsy and inane or beautiful and thoughtful – it’s just that convincing evidence of its monstrosity hasn’t been produced by its detractors. The devil
column13: so to speak
column14: will be in the detail. Form over function

column1: Cedric Price was an architect and thinker whose insights
column2: more than 18 years after his death
column3: continue to resonate. One of these was to challenge the assumption of architects and their clients that erecting a building is the best solution to a given problem. A big shiny structure called The Centre for Ending Poverty (to use a hypothetical example) might not actually do what it claims. Price’s wisdom is pertinent to the saga of the Nightingale hospitals
column4: the facilities created with much fanfare and expense early in the pandemic
column5: which treated fewer than 400 patients. Now Sajid Javid is doubling down on this less than triumphant idea by ordering eight “Nightingale surge hubs” – units in hospital car parks to deal with a possible wave of Omicron admissions. One obvious but unanswered question is where the staff might come from to run these hubs. Even more obviously
column6: would it not have been better to implement policies that reduce this potential surge
column7: so that the Nightingales would not be needed at all? BBC morals off course

column1: I imagine the BBC’s moral compass to be a handsome and substantial instrument
column2: brass-trimmed and Latin-inscribed
column3: kept in a Reithian marble vault deep in Broadcasting House. It seems
column4: though
column5: that someone has tunnelled into its vicinity and placed a powerful electromagnet there
column6: one programmed to switch on and off to an unpredictable synth funk beat. How else to explain its decision to interview Alan Dershowitz as an apparently objective commentator on the crimes of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell
column7: in particular on the credibility of the couple’s victim Virginia Giuffre? Dershowitz
column8: as the BBC failed to mention
column9: was one of Epstein’s lawyers and associates and is himself embroiled in lawsuits with Giuffre over her accusations that he was another of her abusers. In 2020
column10: he wrote an article in the Spectator
column11: “The Ghislaine Maxwell I know”
column12: which attacked the “one-sided narrative” of “lying witnesses” such as Giuffre. The case against Maxwell
column13: he sagely concluded
column14: “is far from over”. The BBC acknowledged its error
column15: but why make it in the first place? In case my electromagnet theory is not strictly accurate
column16: here’s another: the corporation is now so thoroughly browbeaten and disoriented by accusations of liberal bias that it truly doesn’t know north from south and east from west. • Rowan Moore is the Observer’s architecture correspondent";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/01/notre-dame-disneyfied-unlikely-devil-in-detail

column4: 'Sport'];"Arsenal were left nursing a sense of injustice after VAR decisions contributed to their dramatic 2-1 defeat against Manchester City
column5: with their assistant manager
column6: Albert Stuivenberg
column7: suggesting they had been denied a “clear penalty” when Martin Ødegaard was challenged by Ederson in the first half. Stuivenberg was overseeing Arsenal in the absence of Mikel Arteta
column8: who looked on from home after testing positive for Covid-19. He and his players felt the referee
column9: Stuart Attwell
column10: should have been asked to review Ederson’s tackle on the monitor
column11: just as he did when awarding City the second-half spot kick from which Riyad Mahrez equalised.

column1: “I think it is a clear penalty
column2: but at least a moment for the referee to check
column3: like what happened with their penalty
column4: ” Stuivenberg said. “It is inconsistent.” Aaron Ramsdale
column5: the Arsenal goalkeeper
column6: was similarly confused after seeing City’s penalty appeal at close quarters. Attwell originally awarded nothing when Bernardo Silva went down under Granit Xhaka’s challenge but when invited to review the decision by the VAR official
column7: Jarred Gillett
column8: he changed his mind. “I don’t know why the referee is told to see one and not the other
column9: ” Ramsdale said. “It is there for a reason
column10: go and use it. It is the inconsistency. The whole point is to help the game out. In real time it didn’t look like one
column11: [but] slow it down on a screen and it is given.” Despite their frustration at not being awarded a penalty
column12: Arsenal surged ahead later in the first half through Bukayo Saka and were by far the better side before Mahrez levelled. The equaliser was followed quickly by a second yellow card for Gabriel Magalhães
column13: whose first was for what Stuivenberg termed a “normal comment … no dirty language was used”
column14: and Arsenal paid the price through Rodri’s late winner. “I’m sad that we don’t end up with three points
column15: that’s the most frustrating part
column16: ” Stuivenberg said. Ramsdale agreed: “I don’t think for large parts of the game teams have done that to Manchester City.”

column1: An 11th straight win for City gives them an 11-point advantage at the top
column2: although Chelsea and Liverpool have opportunities to reduce it with games in hand. There have been two bigger gaps on New Year’s Day in the Premier League era. Pep Guardiola accepted City had been fortunate. “Arsenal were better
column3: ” he said
column4: before pointing out that City had two days to recover from their win at Brentford. “It was so tough for us to come back. We had no energy. We were incredibly tired and they were better
column5: but football has happened and sometimes it comes in our side.”";https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/jan/01/arsenal-bemoan-var-inconsistency-after-clear-penalty-denied-in-city-defeat

column12: 'Conservation'];"Twitching is synonymous with birdwatching
column13: which can often involve long journeys in search of rare species. But now a new breed of climate-conscious birder is trying to persuade fellow enthusiasts to keep it local instead. A group of young birders has created a challenge for spotters to find birds in their own patch close to home rather than routinely travelling long distances to spot particular birds
column14: a practice known as “twitching”. The Green Patch Challenge
column15: created by Joe Parham
column16: a 22-year-old birder from the Midlands
column17: invites under-25s to attempt to travel only on foot or by bike to see birds. “We all need to make changes to our lives to address the climate crisis
column18: and the goal of the challenge is to capture this while encouraging young birders to explore and enjoy nature close to them
column19: ” Parham said. “It’s not about stopping everything. It’s about making positive changes
column20: doing much less travelling and when you do it
column21: try to do it low-carbon.” Birdwatching has been growing in popularity in the UK and there was a lockdown boom last year when numbers taking part in the RSPB’s annual garden survey
column22: where people report which birds they can see in their gardens
column23: jumped by 85%. About three million people do some birdwatching every year. The Green Patch Challenge has been followed up by Birdwatch magazine
column24: which set its readers a #LocalBigYear challenge for 2022
column25: inviting birders to find species in patches within 10km of their home. The challenges harness the passion that most birders – whether twitchers or patchers – have for drawing up lists of birds they’ve seen. Many have overlapping lists of birds seen in their back garden
column26: in their county
column27: in the UK or the rest of the world. The lists can be quite competitive – on New Year’s Day
column28: many birders began their year list by trying to see as many birds as possible on their patch. At peak migration times
column29: some twitchers travel almost every week to see rare birds
column30: a practice that is increasingly under fire from some parts of the birding community. In November
column31: about 100 birders travelled to Papa Westray
column32: one of the smallest of the Orkney islands
column33: to see a varied thrush – a bird usually seen only in north America and last spotted in the UK in 1982. Some chartered planes and boats to reach the island for the sighting. Javier Caletrío
column34: a researcher based in north-west England
column35: set up the Low Carbon Birding blog in 2018 to try to persuade birdwatchers to travel less. He said it was important for birders to set an example. “If people see us acting as if there is a crisis requiring immediate action
column36: it is more likely that others will also demand urgent
column37: radical action from politicians.” Birding was often dominated by stories about “the excitement of travelling to distant places and seeing rare and exotic birds” he said. “These young people are telling other young people that they can be good birders and have fun without travelling to distant places by means of burning fossil fuels. And obviously low-carbon birding is not about the end of travel. It is about doing it differently – planning your holidays differently and making the most of public transport.” Matthew Broadbent
column39: who helps run the Green Patch Challenge
column40: said: “I know the feeling when you see a stunning
column41: rare bird
column42: and it’s fantastic. It’s a buzz
column43: and makes you want more. But we need to learn to travel shorter distances to see birds
column44: we need to do what we can to protect our planet.” Keir Chauhan
column46: began birding seriously in 2020 and said that joining the Green Patch Challenge in north London had changed his life during the lockdowns. “It provided an outlet
column47: ” he said. “If I’d had a bad day
column48: I’d go looking for a new bird around Ally Pally.” A pair of peregrine falcons haunts the BBC signal tower on Alexandra Palace. “It’s amazing to watch them hunt in the mornings
column49: chasing the crows
column50: ” he said.

column1: “There’s a reservoir near there and most of the time there’s no birds whatsoever. But one time I saw a kestrel land and it turned out they were nesting there. Even in a place as birdless as that – it’s not a foreign country
column2: it’s not a nature reserve – you can see interesting birds.” Stephen Moss
column3: a lifelong birder and author
column4: whose book
column5: Skylarks with Rosie
column6: charts the lockdown birdwatching he did in the patch near his Somerset home
column7: said that making local observations had an important ecological purpose as it enabled research into the prevalence of bird species. “Low-carbon birding is clearly a good idea
column8: ” Moss said
column9: “but some people are arguing that we should not be doing any long-distance trips – Chris Packham said he’s never going to do it again. “But there are places like Costa Rica
column10: the Gambia
column11: Trinidad and Tobago
column12: or Kenya where vast amounts of its economy comes from wildlife tourism. We need to find the right balance between the local and global.”";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/01/travel-distances-britain-twitchers-birds-birdwatchers-species-foot-cycle

column10: 'Infectious diseases'];"The UK’s vaccine rollout has largely been a success: more than 90% of the population aged 12 and over has now had at least one dose
column11: with just over half having had a second dose and the booster. However
column12: there are thousands of people who still haven’t had a jab
column13: despite estimates suggesting that 90% of the most severely ill Covid patients in hospital at the moment are unvaccinated. A number of strategies are being employed to convince those who have so far avoided it get vaccinated
column14: with outreach groups and GPs working to encourage take-up. The Observer spoke to three people who have
column15: in recent weeks
column16: changed their minds. Here
column17: they explain their initial hesitancy and the reasons for their change of heart. Jess Haghkerdar
column18: 32 PhD student
column19: Fife Ecology student Jess said she “wasn’t against the vaccine” and had received her first and second doses. But she had decided not to get the booster. In August 2021
column20: shortly after having her second jab
column21: she had a miscarriage at eight weeks pregnant. “I was worried the vaccine had contributed to my miscarriage and became wary of getting a booster once I found out I was pregnant again” she said. She considered waiting until she had given birth to have her booster
column22: but the became concerned about Omicron and about the number of unvaccinated pregnant women ending up in intensive care. “I realised that my hesitance was based on grief and worry
column23: ” she said. “Just looking at the data proved that Covid is a much greater risk than any of my worst fears about the vaccine affecting my pregnancy.” She changed her mind and had the booster. “I don’t want to get Covid while I am pregnant and be in a situation that could potentially be harmful to me and the baby. “I’m a scientist and I know that if there was something seriously wrong with the vaccines
column24: fellow scientists would stop at nothing to discover it and improve our understanding of them. “I understand the visceral response and fear of vaccination
column25: but we need to be realistic about how serious Covid can be and recognise how hard scientists and doctors have worked to keep us safe. No matter how I look at it now
column26: getting vaccinated is worth it.” Kevin Buckland
column27: 46 PhD student and university lecturer
column28: Sutton Coldfield Kevin has had a phobia of needles from an early age. “I just hate them. I forged my mum’s signature when I was 14 to avoid getting the TB vaccination
column29: saying she didn’t want me to have it. They wrote to her six months later
column30: I was found out
column31: and they dragged me into Birmingham kicking and screaming to have it.”

column1: His plan was to remain unvaccinated
column2: taking precautions to avoid infecting himself and his elderly parents
column3: who live nearby. The emergence of the Omicron variant made Kevin reassess his approach
column4: as he was concerned by its rate of transmission. “I was reading that just a whiff of an infected person’s breath would be enough to contract it. I’ve dodged it for this length of time and thought
column5: how much longer can I go on? “I booked an appointment about a month ago and chickened out. I then rearranged that one and finally went along. I just concentrated on the fact that it was a good thing. I hardly slept the night before. “On the day
column6: I didn’t even realise she had done it. It helped that I walked into the place not wearing glasses so I couldn’t see anything anyway. There was one person taking my details
column7: the other had a hypodermic needle. “I was talking to the one with a laptop about my phobia and
column8: without me noticing
column9: it was done. I didn’t feel a thing. I have my second booked for February and plan to get a booster.” Adam
column11: from Cheshire Adam (not his real name) lost faith in the government in 2020
column12: largely because of Dominic Cummings and the Barnard Castle affair. “I just thought if they can lie about something of this magnitude
column13: what else can they lie about?” He then became sceptical because of the speed of the vaccination programme rollout. “I felt like it was quite rushed to begin with. There wasn’t much research published or data coming out
column14: which led me to believe that it was being pushed out for other reasons – not just to save lives
column15: but to save the economy
column16: which to some extent I understand
column17: but I feel like saving lives is much more important. Damage to the economy can be repaired
column18: but you can’t bring back someone who has passed away.” Over time Adam
column19: who works for his family’s wealth management business
column20: came to believe in the benefits of vaccination by following hospitalisation figures in trusted news sources.

column1: “I was hesitant about getting my first vaccine
column2: which I didn’t have until about three months ago. I had my second dose three weeks ago. “The hospitalisation numbers for people who were vaccinated compared with people who were unvaccinated were scary. At the same time
column3: I felt like there was a bit more control on the misinformation that was being put out there. “The information that was published was worrying
column4: so I thought it was best in the long run to get the vaccine
column5: rather than not
column6: despite what my feelings were at the time.”";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/01/needle-phobia-refused-covid-jabs-refuseniks-vaccination
