column8: 'Consciousness'];"The thing about history is that it sometimes repeats itself. As far as the tech industry is concerned
column9: we saw that in the year just ended and it looks as though we’re about to see it again in the year that’s just begun. First things first
column10: though: 2021 was the year in which it finally became clear that the free ride that Google and co have enjoyed for two decades was coming to an end – that tech was going to become a regulated industry. Exactly how that was going to pan out was unclear
column11: but the direction of travel was unmistakable. In the US
column12: for example
column13: the incoming Biden administration began appointing to government smart people who understood the societal dangers of unrestrained corporate power. People such as Lina Khan
column14: who now chairs the Federal Trade Commission
column15: the country’s main regulatory body; or Tim Wu
column16: now on the White House’s National Economic Council with responsibility for antitrust and competition; or Jonathan Kanter
column17: a leading antitrust advocate
column18: now assistant attorney general. And so on. Given that all the leading tech companies are US-based
column19: these were the most significant moves
column20: but there were indications in other parts of the world too (including the UK’s Competition and Markets Authority) that democracies were emerging from the long slumber during which tech companies had prospered obscenely. The tech companies saw this coming
column21: of course
column22: and it was eerie to see how their responses echoed the playbooks of the tobacco and energy companies of an earlier period
column23: as chronicled
column24: for example
column25: by Naomi Oreskes and Erik Conway in their 2010 book
column26: Merchants of Doubt: How a Handful of Scientists Obscured the Truth on Issues from Tobacco Smoke to Global Warming. The other day
column27: Andrew Bosworth
column28: the incoming chief technology officer of Meta (nee Facebook) was asked whether he thought “vaccine hesitancy would be the same with or without social media”. His reply
column29: verbatim
column30: reads: “I think Facebook ran probably the biggest Covid vaccine campaign in the world. What more can you do if some people who can get that real information from a real source choose not to get it? That’s their choice. They’re allowed to do that. You have an issue with those people. You don’t have an issue with Facebook. You can’t put that on me.”

column1: Sounds familiar? It’s what oil companies came up with when they invented the idea of the “carbon footprint” – ie your footprint on the biosphere
column2: not theirs. It’s the displacement of responsibility strategy: since it’s a free country
column3: nobody’s forcing you to do the thing that’s bad for you. Childhood obesity is the responsibility of the child or of his or her parents. Alcoholism happens because you don’t “drink responsibly”. Radicalisation of the mass shooter is not YouTube’s responsibility. It’s always your fault
column4: not that of the manufacturer of the addictive product. Next. Looking forward to 2022
column5: what we can anticipate is a repeat performance of that perennial staple of capitalism: irrational exuberance – the phenomenon by which
column6: in the words of the economist Robert Shiller

column5: 'Energy'];"Juliet Davenport may have made a lucky escape from the energy supply market. The founder and former chief executive of green power supplier Good Energy ended her 20-year tenure last February
column6: months before an unprecedented surge in global energy prices left the industry reeling. But then
column7: it’s not unusual for Davenport to be ahead of the curve. Set up in the late 1990s
column8: Good Energy was one of the first “challenger” suppliers to compete with the behemoths of British Gas and others
column9: which had been created by privatisation. It was also a pioneering investor in renewable power
column10: and an early champion of small-scale community energy ventures. “I think you can become a bit of an institution if you’re not careful

column13: the UK’s first supplier of 100% renewable power

column19: Oxford University
column20: MSc Economics
column21: Birkbeck. Last holiday Cornwall
column22: to Delabole
column23: site of the UK’s first windfarm. Best advice she’s been given “Try to work with people you like on things that interest you.” Biggest career mistake “Hiring people just on their credentials.” Word she overuses “Cool.” How she relaxes “Riding and reading – I’m still working on doing them simultaneously.” * * * and has weathered a long-term public squabble with fellow energy maverick Dale Vince
column24: including an attempted boardroom coup by his company
column25: Ecotricity
column26: earlier this year. Having stepped back from the day-to-day running of Good Energy
column27: Davenport sits on the boards of a string of companies that are helping tackle the climate crisis. Perhaps her most notable role is as chair of rooftop solar innovator Atrato Onsite Energy
column28: whose flotation in November made it the first company with an all-female board to list on the London Stock Exchange. Davenport says she was no longer content with “turning up and doing the same thing” when she realised that
column29: after decades of hard-learned lessons in the industry
column30: she could spread her wings and help new energy firms navigate the market. Good Energy was in need of some new skills too – notably in digital innovation. Proving that sometimes being ahead of the curve means recognising when others are further ahead
column31: Davenport said she wanted to bring in “someone who was better at digital than I could ever be”. She remains a director of the London-listed company
column32: which she says is in a good position to weather an energy crisis in which dozens of small suppliers have gone bust. The company has always hedged its exposure to global commodity prices by buying plenty of energy in advance
column33: she says
column34: and has negotiated supply deals directly with local renewable energy projects
column35: which also helps to establish a fixed price. At the root of the industry’s crisis
column36: she adds
column37: are small energy companies which have failed to maintain the support of investors by differentiating themselves in a busy market
column38: along with a string of problems with how that market is regulated. So is the growing criticism of the industry watchdog
column39: Ofgem
column40: justified? Absolutely
column41: comes the matter-of-fact response.

column1: “We’ve been having conversations with the regulator around various areas related to competition in the market for probably the past six or seven years

column3: and the amount of switching between suppliers. That has always been a problem.” The clarion call for households to help address sluggish competition in the energy market by shopping around for the cheapest deal unleashed a flood of poorly financed suppliers and unsustainably low energy deals. This race to the bottom has left more than 4 million households in need of a new energy supplier after record prices caused 26 companies to collapse. “The UK needs energy companies which are prepared to invest in the future
column4: ” Davenport says. “If you’re constantly competing on price alone
column5: you can’t invest.” As chair of Atrato
column6: Davenport has her mind on investment: it’s just weeks since the rooftop solar venture raised £150m in an oversubscribed market listing. The company plans to use rooftop solar installations to unlock the largely untapped potential of commercial properties. Its strength lies in bringing together staff who have “a significant understanding of the commercial property market” with experts in renewable energy development. In time
column7: Atrato expects to create standardised contracts that can make the still-niche decision to fit a leased office block with solar capability a “plug and play” option. “The original Good Energy headquarters was owned by a pension fund
column8: ” she says. “I remember trying at least once a year to put solar on the roof and completely failing
column9: because the [owners] were so far removed and just didn’t want any complications. “Now a lot of corporates have a commitment to using renewables
column10: and installing projects on their own site is part of fulfilling that. Helping them navigate the way forward if they don’t own their building is a huge part of that. The energy market has to be about making things easy for consumers.” The Atrato ethos echoes in some ways that of Good Energy
column11: which for decades made it easy for households to play a role in the growth of renewables by choosing a tariff from a company that invests directly in renewable energy projects. “The question is how fast we can do it
column12: ” she says. “And how standardised we can make this process. If we keep everything as simple and repetitive as possible
column13: we can move faster.” Energy companies that can “enable” consumers to decarbonise their energy use because it’s the easier option are the ones to watch
column14: Davenport believes. “For many years I saw big companies and government try to do big projects because that’s what they can control. But so much can be done on a decentralised level if you can get inside the head of a consumer
column15: ” she says. In her next chapter Davenport plans to do just that
column16: all over again.";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/01/juliet-davenport-good-energy-founder-spreads-wings-and-expertise

column18: recounting one of his few memories of life in the High Nest. “She couldn’t call me back and I was already in the house and she knew it was lost. They hit my mother. I can still remember.” Janny
column19: her family and the other Jewish occupants were sent to the Dutch transit camp of Westerbork. (Robbie and Liselotte were spared as Janny’s husband was not Jewish). At Westerbork

column23: Janny
column24: Lien and the Frank sisters were sent by train
column25: then forced on a death march to Bergen-Belsen. At this overcrowded
column26: disease-ridden camp – “a runaway fair of insane
column27: sick and dying people” wrote van Iperen – Janny worked as a nurse

column1: Janny and Lien survived the war. Robert remembers the day his mother came to the family’s rented house on the Amstel in Amsterdam. “I cried out to the whole street
column2: look ‘My mother is back

column6: with a large J stamped on it
column7: is also on display. Joseph Brilleslijper
column8: his wife Fietje and their son Jaap
column9: died at Auschwitz. Janny devoted her life to the recognition of war victims. She died in 2003. The collection also includes a poetry album belonging to Lien Brilleslijper
column10: a booklet where family and friends would write life lessons in verse. “When you read it now with the knowledge that many of them didn’t survive the war

column4: 'Television & radio'];"It sounds troublingly shallow
column5: but when I saw the tweet that said “Holy shit
column6: ANTM [America’s Next Top Model] is on Amazon Prime” my heart soared. I am not one who can pretend the pandemic isn’t still raging but
column7: in that fleeting moment
column8: I felt a spiritual lightness I hadn’t experienced since 2019. I dropped everything to binge the episodes
column9: then fell deep into a rabbit hole of detective work: where are the contestants now? Are they on Instagram? I found a whole subsection of TikTok dedicated to calling out where the show was problematic
column10: and YouTuber Oliver Twixt has a highly viewed series of interviews with ANTM contestants levelling accusations of maltreatment at the show’s producers. Whatever the reason
column11: ANTM is back in the cultural sphere. For the uninitiated
column12: ANTM premiered in 2003 and continued for 24 series or “cycles”
column13: until its last gasp in 2018. Each season
column14: young wannabe models competed for a modelling contract. They were mentored by supermodel Tyra Banks and her fellow judges
column15: including runway coach Miss J Alexander who participated in 18 cycles. Way back in 2003
column16: we weren’t where we are now in terms of trans or non-binary representation. Cycle 1 contestant Robin Manning christened Alexander “Miss J” to differentiate them from creative director “Mr” Jay Manuel. As we’re now in 2021
column17: I ask Miss J to clarify the pronoun situation. “Miss J answers to all and any pronouns ... Just respect me – call me what you want – but don’t forget to sign that cheque.” There’s something pleasingly quaint about the fact Miss J flip-flopped his pronouns and gender expression – often wearing self-made dresses on the judging panel – without having to label himself as trans
column18: non-binary or a drag queen. Nowadays he would be asked to define himself; here I am
column19: literally doing just that. Miss J appeared in hundreds of episodes
column20: so it’s not surprising that his decade on the show is something of a blur to him. “I look back on that time as me
column21: doing me
column22: being me
column23: ” he says. “Feeling fierce and fabulous. Being creative. I created my wardrobe.” But not all the memories are good ones. “I think about the girls
column24: what they went through and how they were treated. I look at the backlash and I do wonder if we knew what we were putting them through.” Indeed. Some moments have aged terribly. Yes
column25: I’m thinking of the two occasions when white models donned blackface for photoshoots. The show is also guilty of cultural insensitivity - visits to overseas destinations were treated as an excuse to caricature indigenous peoples – and pressuring contestants to lose weight. Miss J is philosophical: “I can’t speak on the photoshoots because I wasn’t on [them].” I suggest it’s slightly unfair to judge TV from 15 years ago by today’s more enlightened standards. Miss J agrees. “Did we mean harm? No. I didn’t understand it
column26: why [the blackface] photoshoot happened. Was the idea to make them feel what it’s liked to be mixed? I would have asked them what the takeaway was. But it wouldn’t fly right now.” Some of the former contestants have been less than complimentary about the show
column27: since it re-entered the spotlight. “Some of the girls got upset because they didn’t make it
column28: ” says Miss J. “They were competing with other girls and only one girl can win. So now they feel they didn’t get the support they needed. But these girls watched the show. They knew the formula.” And there definitely was a formula. Audiences came to recognise that if a contestant spoke about her home life
column29: it was almost certainly because she was returning to it by the conclusion of that episode. You could also set your watch by the moment when a pretty prom queen-type entered the salon for “makeover week”. Nothing beats the feeling when the stylist takes that Rapunzel-length ponytail in hand and cruelly snips it off while the poor model wails. TV gold. “It was as good for me as it was for you!” Miss J laughs. I’m always surprised that the contestants were surprised. Surely they’d seen the show before? “They knew what they were getting into. They knew we were gonna chop that shit off! Why talk shit about it online?” A few contestants went on to greatness: Winnie Harlow and Leila Goldkuhl notably escaped the “curse” of Top Model
column30: and worked with Calvin Klein and Chanel among others. But most (including a smattering of male models) returned to small-town obscurity. For some
column31: their post-show destiny involved prison (Renee Alway) or addiction (Jael Strauss); one former contestant was murdered (Mirjana Puhar). Even with the criticisms of exploitation directed at talent shows
column32: Miss J thinks there’s still life in the old format. “The fashion world has changed
column33: ” he says. “Plus-size models on the catwalk; dark-skinned models are totally taking over. Black Lives Matter has meant everyone wants a Black girl in their campaign. There’s a lot of trans models – and no-one knows. Some are out
column34: some aren’t.” In fairness to ANTM
column35: they were ahead of the curve there. Trans model and actor Isis King competed on the show in 2008
column36: one of the first prominent trans women of colour to break through into the mainstream. But post #MeToo
column37: and with a far greater awareness of the exploitation of young models
column38: is it OK to portray the world of fashion as even dimly aspirational? Would it be safe even? “It can be
column39: because right now everything is microscopically watched
column40: ” says Miss J. “We need to change our tone and language. It needs to be a safe space for all of us.” Despite everything
column41: I really
column42: really hope they bring it back. I want more. I’m sorry
column43: I can’t help it; I do. I wonder if
column44: when we dig out the comfort blankets of our past
column45: it’s a subconscious desire to flee back. I watched ANTM in my early 20s when I was truly free for the first time in my life. It was pre-mortgages
column46: pre-pandemic
column47: before my transition and all the transphobia that came with it. Truly
column48: a simpler time. I think that’s what I’m trying to find within America’s Next Top Model
column49: the carefree Juno I was back then.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/the-person-who-got-me-through-2021-miss-j-and-americas-next-top-model-transported-me-to-carefree-times

column1: 3. Book How to Do Nothing by Jenny Odell I’m currently reading this – I put off reading it because it looks like a self-help book – but it’s really fascinating. column1: I’ve been travelling a lot for work

column9: as I have
column10: living in the city. 5. Film Eve’s Bayou (Kasi Lemmons

column4: who is maybe cheating on his wife
column5: his daughter sets out to kill him and punish him

column2: creative director] is doing with sculpture and architecture through fashion is some of the most interesting theatre of our time. It’s like a marriage of Romantic and gothic style – it’s a bit ecclesiastical

column9: 'Life and style'];"Doctors and health officials have warned that the rising number of Covid-19 infections poses a significant threat to the UK’s ability to run trains

column12: they say. As a result
column13: isolation times for those testing positive for Sars-CoV-2 have been cut from 10 to seven days to reduce the pressure on industry. But is this reduction justified? Or is there room for even further quarantine cuts to be made
column14: as has been done in the US? These are critical questions
column15: the answers to which could determine how quickly the nation emerges from the wave of Covid-19 cases it is now experiencing. What are the rules for self-isolating after a positive Covid-19 result? In England
column16: Wales and Northern Ireland
column17: if you’ve tested positive or have symptoms
column18: you can now stop self-isolating after seven days
column19: instead of 10
column20: if you get two negative lateral flow test results on days six and seven. In Scotland
column21: the 10-day limit is still in force. What evidence is there that this reduced period of self-isolation is sufficient to halt people infecting others? “We know that people who get Covid-19 are most infectious early on around symptom onset
column22: and that the risk of transmission declines pretty quickly after that
column23: ” says epidemiologist Billy Quilty
column24: of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. “By the time someone finds out that they are infected by developing symptoms or testing positive
column25: it’s already been two or three days since they were exposed
column26: and they may have already been infectious for a day or two. So after five days of isolation
column27: they’re really on day seven or eight of their infection. As a result
column28: we estimate that there is a low risk associated with isolation periods of five days or more.” Does Omicron behave differently from previous variants in terms of its period of infectiousness? Scientists say Omicron may infect people more quickly
column29: but possibly for a shorter period than previous variants. “However
column30: we need to find out if that is the case as soon as possible
column31: ” said Quilty. “We also need to make sure that people are not isolating for an unnecessarily long time
column32: especially if this becomes a very acute staffing crisis.” The need for further research is also backed by epidemiologist Prof Dame Anne Johnson
column33: of University College London. “There is a large variability in how infectious people are and how much virus they shed. So we need more studies to understand when it’s reasonable for people to be released from quarantine – though we need to face the fact that we cannot eliminate all risk.”

column1: Johnson added that she wanted to see more data on the distribution of viral loads in different people according to their symptoms and at different times of their infection. “We need to better understand how infectious individuals are likely to be at different times and to know when infectivity drops off
column2: ” she said. What is the probable long-term outlook for the latest variant? Most scientists are now more optimistic about the likely impact of Omicron
column3: though they worry about the short-term effect it might have on hospitalisations. “In a population that was previously unexposed to a virus
column4: it takes time – through natural infections and vaccines – to get to the situation where you have gradually built up immunity in the population to the extent that people will be getting infected without much impact
column5: ” said Johnson. “That is the general direction we are travelling in – as long as we don’t get a new variant that is so different it causes a lot of disease.” • This article was amended on 2 January 2022. The self-isolation period in Wales is seven days

column9: 'New year'];"I have asthma
column10: and there’s a fairly major respiratory disease going around
column11: as you may have heard
column12: and also I am a smoker. A quick inventory of my coat pockets: inhaler
column13: face mask
column14: Marlboro Gold. I never fell into smoking as a teenager when everyone else seemed to think it was cool
column15: but took it up in my 30s
column16: as others might develop an interest in birdwatching
column17: or CrossFit. Four or five a day
column18: for the best part of a decade
column19: and more at the weekends. This piece is anonymous because my mother cannot know. I don’t have the words to express how unbelievably stupid I feel about all this. There’s quite a lot going on here
column20: and not all of it is solely of interest to me and my therapist. You might imagine that a continuing and lung-buggering international emergency which a study says is specifically more dangerous for smokers would mean there were fewer idiots like me. But in fact
column21: stress and boredom are more than a match for serious health concerns: research published in August last year suggested that the number of young adults smoking in England went up by about a quarter during the first lockdown. There was a spike in the number of people across all ages giving up smoking in England during that same first lockdown period – but no sign of the plummeting rates you might rationally expect. Then again
column22: nothing about this habit has ever been rational.

column1: For my own part
column2: I don’t know exactly what kind of smoker I am
column3: but I know I’m not casual
column4: or social: I’m highly committed to something very unpopular. The persistence of the packet in my pocket is not for the want of trying. It’s more for a want of wanting. My figurative heart just isn’t in it
column5: although my literal heart would probably have quite strong opinions in the opposite direction. (Unlucky
column6: literal heart
column7: only sentient organs get a vote!) I don’t suppose I speak for the other 1.1bn people still grimly puffing away
column8: but it feels as if my problem is that I still
column9: somewhere in my lizard brain
column10: think this habit that makes me smell awful and look desperate is … cool
column11: a deftly executed little ritual that makes me a more compelling figure to people at a party. Did you feel cool when you were a teenager
column12: my therapist asks
column13: and it’s obvious to us both that the question is a rhetorical one.

column1: That makes a grim sort of sense
column2: but it’s probably also a crutch
column3: and a way to ignore the obvious fact that I’m addicted. After all
column4: I’ve barely been to any parties for quite a long time and
column5: apart from the neighbour’s terminally unimpressed cat
column6: there’s no audience when I’m huddled in the back garden on a rainy Tuesday morning getting ash on myself. I started
column7: for reasons I don’t fully understand
column8: as some sort of warped
column9: bloody-minded reinvention shortly after a breakup. I should have known from my permanent inability to leave half a pack of sweets in a cupboard for the next day that it wouldn’t work; before long I had slipped from a pack a month to one every few days. I wish I had properly understood then how insidious an addiction nicotine would turn out to be
column10: how misleading and unhelpful the term “craving” would prove
column11: at least for me: it suggests a siren in your brain when you go without
column12: when the truth is something more like the little fillip you get when it occurs to you that you’d like a cup of tea and a biscuit. I don’t often leave it long enough to be faced with a more powerful compulsion than that
column13: but because it doesn’t seem especially intense
column14: I almost always give in to it. I think I have a constitutional weakness for treats. I still don’t think I really
column15: deeply
column16: want to stop
column17: or understand how urgently I have to. But I know I don’t want this bleak internal monologue motoring in my head any more: an endless
column18: boring chunter that slides into my mind any time I’m not thinking about anything much. It may be that the pandemic’s additional opportunities for mental drift has helped me reach at least this caveated breakthrough
column19: because in 2021 I started Juul-ing. Whereas previous attempts failed spectacularly – the time I lit up while chewing Nicorette is a particular low point – this time
column20: I’ve gone more than a week between cigarettes
column21: at the cost of an umbilical attachment to a mysterious little obelisk whose long-term impacts remain unknown. I buy menthol vape pods in bulk and feel nervous if the battery light blinks red. I always come back to smoking in the end
column22: but the gaps are getting a bit longer
column23: and a bit easier to tolerate. None of this is consoling. Helpful though the vaping is
column24: and good though I feel about smoking less
column25: I seem to be stuck on it as a harm-reduction method
column26: not a step towards kicking the habit. I tell myself that once all this – I am waving my hands at the universe – has eased off a little
column27: I’ll really get on with it.

column1: The prospect of slowly killing myself is fixed as an abstraction. I feel I’d stop if I were having a kid
column2: but that might just be another rationalisation for putting it off. So here I am
column3: the sort of person who vapes behind their hand in Zoom meetings
column4: and blows a conspicuous little cloud out of the corner of his mouth as if anyone’s not going to notice it because it comes out sideways. I miss being the person I was before I smoked
column5: when I had no idea how much of a luxury it was never to have thought about it
column6: and I know that even if I succeed in giving up nicotine completely
column7: that victory will be shadowed by an obscure sense of loss. I also can’t believe how much less funny this piece is than I meant it to be. But maybe
column8: two years into a global pandemic
column9: that counts for personal growth: the ability to face the absurdity of the harm you are doing to yourself as something more consequential than a morbid joke.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/cant-quit-wont-quit-confessions-of-a-die-hard-smoker

column8: 'Homes'];"Last year I stood in the shallows of my house

column14: I say

column21: in that way things do today. I’m reluctant to encourage others to join me as an auction hobbyist because
column22: of course

column7: 'New year'];"Every January
column8: the same old battle cry: this will be the year that I get thin. Last January
column9: I did a week-long juice cleanse
column10: and the year before that
column11: I fasted for three days. It wasn’t quite nil by mouth
column12: but almost. At the time
column13: I told myself the science interested me (the fervour with which fasting evangelists assure you that a few days without food can reset your microbiome or stave off cellular ageing is compelling enough to make you ignore the health warnings). Really
column14: though
column15: what I wanted was rapid weight loss
column16: minimum one dress size. I made it to 81 hours. Practically levitating with hunger
column17: I ignored the advice to reintroduce food slowly (soups and juices before solids) by bingeing on a cheese sandwich
column18: which I promptly threw up. Happy new year to me. This January
column19: though
column20: I have brokered peace with myself – and I am determined to live inside my body as it exists now. No diets
column21: no fasting
column22: cheese sandwiches whenever I want. It won’t be easy at a time when body fascism is taken as common sense. An estimated 26 million British people will vow to lose weight for the new year. As psychoanalyst Dr Susie Orbach tells me
column23: “It makes it very
column24: very difficult to feel OK about your body when the assault on you is so intense.” But I’m going to give it a go. My body is
column25: by most people’s standards
column26: average – a fact that I apply like a balm whenever my thoughts become too barbed. Revelling in one’s “averageness” might not sound like much in a world of declarative self-love
column27: but after a lifetime of body shame
column28: this is a hard-won detente.

column1: I realised a toxic attitude to my body had accrued over time. Much like rocks washing downstream will catch on the bough of a fallen branch
column2: the thought that my body was not acceptable built up incrementally
column3: pebble by pebble
column4: until one day all other thoughts were stopped up by it. One of the earliest diets I remember embarking on was at age 12
column5: when I decided I’d eat only tinned peaches. I can’t quite recall where my concept of fatness and thinness came from at that time – I just remember feeling that I took up a lot of space
column6: in a particularly grotesque way
column7: with soft
column8: dimpled thighs and a vast
column9: unacceptable
column10: rounded stomach. Even now
column11: I rarely look at photos of myself from that time. But when I do come across one I see a perfectly normal-looking child. As a teenager
column12: when I gained weight because of various factors (including the discovery of junk food)
column13: embarrassment bloomed into horror. This was the early 00s
column14: the era of objectification as empowerment
column15: when most of the girls at my school dreamed of being glamour models. Culture was dominated by lads’ mags and weight-loss transformation TV shows
column16: both deeply concerned with policing the female body. In fashion
column17: the trend for “heroin chic” – lithe
column18: narrow-hipped – would soon be supplanted by size zero
column19: as seen on Paris Hilton
column20: Lindsay Lohan and Nicole Richie
column21: who were all dressed by super-stylist Rachel Zoe; they were catnip for women’s magazines. It was a look so ubiquitous that even as a 13-year-old living in a mining village in Yorkshire
column22: I had to engage. Like most women of my generation
column23: I internalised that particular body type as the ideal and became determined that I’d bring my own body to heel by any means necessary. In my 20s
column24: this included such a vast array of diets – South Beach
column25: Atkins
column27: a paid-for subscription to a food-tracking app – that I’d struggle to name them all. And all along
column28: hyper-aware of my size regardless of what that size actually was
column29: I lived with that same sense of shame
column30: a feeling I experienced physically
column31: as a tension in my chest. (It can’t have helped that I walked around with my stomach sucked in
column32: which meant that I rarely drew full breaths.) No one single thing has happened to take away this feeling. I’m yet to have an epiphany about my body like the ones we read about from mothers (“it grew a life!”) or those who survive grave illnesses. But after the fasting incident two years ago
column33: I started to question why I was still so obsessed with thinness. I followed “body positive” accounts on social media (the brilliant Jessamyn Stanley and Megan Jayne Crabbe among them) – but found their brand of self-love too difficult to put into practice on myself. I admired their stance but the fact was
column34: I did not love my body
column35: and found that my critical inner voice could not be corrected by force. Then I came across the idea of body neutrality
column36: where your body is not something you either love or hate; you just accept it. It’s a theory that speaks to much of what Orbach has been writing about since the 1970s. “You have to ask yourself
column37: who would I be if I wasn’t focused on my body the whole time? What is this preoccupation getting in the way of and what could I achieve without it?” she says.

column1: And so
column2: I have begun gently to question the effort I’d put into my obsession over the years. It wasn’t so much the health foods
column3: calorie-counting apps or hours in the gym I began to resent; it was the brain space that body shame was taking up. From the moment of waking to the moment I closed my eyes at night
column4: the idea that my body was wrong had reverberated through my mind like the vibrations from a struck gong. Self-loathing coated every decision I made
column5: from the obvious – what I ate and wore; how I exercised – to the oblique. I’d felt
column6: for instance
column7: that I should not apply for certain jobs (and these were run-of-the-mill office jobs rather than fashion magazines) as my body would not allow me to fit in. In her 2010 book Bodies
column8: Orbach points out that “eating problems and body distress now constitute an ordinary part of everyday life”. Women in particular – but increasingly men
column9: too – accept displeasure (or worse) as their baseline emotion when it comes to their bodies. In 2019
column10: the Mental Health Foundation found that almost a fifth (19%) of UK adults felt disgusted by their bodies
column11: while more than one-third were anxious or depressed because of their body image.

column1: The everyday nature of body dissatisfaction leads some people to dismiss the gravity of it
column2: but
column3: as Orbach writes
column4: it now “constitute[s] a hidden public health emergency
column5: showing up obliquely in the statistics on self-harm
column6: obesity and anorexia – the most visible and obvious signs of a far-wider-ranging body unease.” Never having been diagnosed with an eating disorder
column7: I can’t claim to understand the pain of feeling so deeply alienated from your body
column8: but I understand “unease”. The basic tenets of body neutrality include being grateful for what your body can do: its strength in carrying you from A to B; its skill in keeping you alive. You aim to avoid conversations about food
column9: weight and how your body does (or should) look. You wear clothes that feel good and allow you to move freely and joyfully. And you opt to engage in activities you find fun
column10: rather than ones that promise to “transform” your body. It’s harder than it sounds. Personally
column11: I try not to think about it – a small act of resistance in a world that constantly tells us our bodies need to be refined
column12: reworked
column13: tweaked or transformed. Obviously
column14: 30 years of discomfort cannot be undone in a few months. This chimera of emotions that rears up whenever I think about the way I look
column15: or the size of my clothes
column16: cannot be killed by logic alone. But I am going to keep trying; to accept that I
column17: a very average woman
column18: am absolutely fine as I am.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/ditching-the-diet-how-i-learned-to-accept-the-body-i-have

Guys goggle and ogle all the time. That was [American broadcaster] Howard Stern’s character. He is very sexual as a person on his show

column1: The second time [in 2013]

It’s exciting – we need those kinds of rock stars out there. I don’t even know how many surgeries I’ve had in my life. But every time I’ve gone through crap

Large areas of Indonesia and Malaysia have been deforested for palm oil plantations
column6: including carbon-dense peatlands that have been drained and burned

column9: RSPO certification accredits producers and consumers of sustainable palm oil. The UK government is consulting on plans to ban large companies from using products grown on illegally deforested land.

Ideally on non-wire hangers (it’s better for them). 70 Skinny-dip with friends. 71 Switch your phone off on holiday (or at least delete your work email app). 72 Always use freshly ground pepper. 73 Thank a teacher who changed your life. 74 Respect your youngers. 75 Keep your keys in the same place. 76 Ditch the plastic cartons and find a milkman – The Modern Milkman has a comprehensive list. 77 Rent rather than buy a suit/dress for that forthcoming wedding (even if it’s your own). 78 Always book an extra day off after a holiday. 79 Ignore the algorithm – listen to music outside your usual taste. 80 Mute or leave a WhatsApp group chat. 81 Learn a TikTok dance (but don’t post it on TikTok). 82 Cook something you’ve never attempted before. 83 Join a local litter-picking group. 84 Handwash that thing you’ve never cleaned. 85 Don’t get a pet/do get a pet. 86 Nap. 87 Learn how to breathe deeply: in through the nose
column3: out through the mouth
column4: making the exhale longer than the inhale. 88 Buy a bike and use it. Learn how to fix it
column5: too. 89 Politely decline invitations if you don’t want to go. 90 If you do go
column6: have an exit strategy (can we recommend a French exit
column7: where you slip out unseen). 91 If in doubt
column8: add cheese. 92 Don’t look at your phone at dinner. 93 Do that one thing you’ve been putting off. 94 Give compliments widely and freely. 95 Set up an affordable standing order to a charity. RNLI and Greenpeace spring to mind …

column1: 96 Keep a book in your bag to avoid the temptation to doomscroll. 97 Listen to the albums you loved as a teenager. 98 Make a friend from a different generation. 99 Staying over at a friend’s place? Strip the bed in the morning. 100 For instant cheer
column2: wear yellow. • This article was inspired by a similar exercise in Weekend magazine in January 2000. See the original list at theguardian.com/100-tips-from-2000 • This article was amended on 2 January 2022 to remove advice in point 23 that is not applicable in all circumstances.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/marginal-gains-100-ways-to-improve-your-life-without-really-trying

column1: 6116;6116;The endless pleasure of potted ivies | Alys Fowler;2022-01-01T11:00:03Z;['Alys Fowler'];['Gardening advice'
column2: 'Gardens'
column3: 'Life and style'];"I have a little outdoor table by the french windows that houses an ever-changing display of pot plants. In summer it has pomegranates
column4: citrus and
column5: towards the back
column6: some ivies. In winter
column7: when the lemons are indoors
column8: I move the ivies to the foreground. Their curtain of leaves distracts from the real reason the table is there: to hide all the pots and seed trays underneath it. I don’t own a shed because I can’t bear to part with the space in the garden
column9: so I am forever finding ways to squirrel away the unsightly parts of gardening. I am not generous to these ivies – they survive in 30cm pots. In spring and autumn I top them up with a little fresh compost
column10: but that’s about it. And yet they thrive. Come winter
column11: I dot pots of early-flowering bulbs between them – reticulata irises
column12: miniature daffodils and snowdrops – so small hints of spring bring a little cheer.

column1: Ivies can spread and climb great distances
column2: but there are many varieties suited to life in cramped
column3: hard conditions
column4: whether that’s a north-facing window box
column5: a sliver of soil along a side return
column6: a shady basement courtyard or an unheated porch. Just don’t try to keep them indoors: ivies are often touted as good houseplants
column7: but you’d need a very cold and damp house to keep them happy. That said
column8: I have visited some very cold bathrooms where they might thrive.

column1: On the whole
column2: variegated forms are bred to be vigorous
column3: so there are only a few that will do well in pots. The cream-and-yellow Hedera helix “Little Luzii” is compact and doesn’t spread or climb much. Its mid-green leaves are speckled and splashed with cream. Likewise
column4: H. helix “Midas Touch”
column5: with its heart-shaped leaves and white-and-gold variegation around the edge that turn a lovely pink with a little frost
column6: is good at brightening a dull corner.

column1: There are numerous pretty deep-green types – my tabletop variety is H. helix “Koniger’s Auslese”
column2: which has narrow
column3: star-shaped leaves that look good against a painted wall. The same goes for “Ivalace” or “Parsley Crested”
column4: which have crinkled
column5: glossy leaves and do well even in deep shade. The miniature-leaved “Duckfoot”
column6: with its wedge-shape light-green leaves will fill out a pot quickly
column7: which makes it particularly good for hanging baskets. Fibrex Nursery and the Plantsman’s Preference both have an extensive collection. Ivies are not particularly fussy about soils
column8: but do better in slightly alkaline soils
column9: and thrive in composts with good water-holding capacity. This can be achieved by adding composted bark to peat-free compost. Finally
column10: do allow the plants to dry out between watering. A dry plant can make a miraculous recovery
column11: but an overwatered one rots away quickly.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/the-endless-pleasure-of-potted-ivies

column1: 6117;6117;‘There are no bad kids. Just kids making bad choices’: the campaigner battling youth knife crime | Guardian angel;2022-01-01T11:00:02Z;['Sirin Kale'];['Life and style'
column2: 'Knife crime'
column3: 'Society'
column4: 'Young people'];"If you made a film of Mark Bracewell’s life
column5: audiences would probably look on sceptically and think: “That’s a bit extreme.” Bracewell grew up on an estate in Moss Side
column6: Manchester
column7: in the 1980s. When he was 13
column8: he watched members of a gang hack a man to death in a pub with a machete. The following year
column9: his friend Benjamin was murdered in a takeaway. The killers were never found. Bracewell thinks it was probably a case of mistaken identity. He was with Benjamin on the day he died. He found out about his murder on the news. “We were kids
column10: ” says Bracewell
column11: who is now 44 and lives in Stoke-on-Trent. “But we were living in a war zone.” He began breaking into cars and selling drugs for the older kids on the estate. “We were manipulated
column12: ” he says. “Today you’d call it county lines. Police wouldn’t stop kids.” He joined a gang when he was 13 and became addicted to cocaine four years later. “As I grew older
column13: ” he says
column14: “my heart got tighter and smaller. When you’ve seen someone hacked to death with a machete
column15: you grow numb. It was easier to brush everything under the carpet than deal with it. I took drugs as my way out of reality.” Aged 26
column16: he robbed a taxi driver at knifepoint – he was high on cocaine at the time and needed money for drugs – and spent three years and nine months in prison. “It’s embarrassing
column17: ” says Bracewell
column18: “but it’s part of my journey.” In 2010
column19: he got out of prison
column20: and started to rebuild his life. He worked as a bar manager but still occasionally used drugs
column21: despite his best efforts to quit. Then
column22: on New Year’s Eve 2016
column23: he got involved in a nightclub fight. “I saw the knife coming towards me
column24: ” Bracewell says. “And that was the last thing I ever saw out of that eye. Instantly I knew I was blind in my left eye.” The stabbing was a turning point. As Bracewell was taken to hospital
column25: he cried out to God. “I said
column26: ” he remembers
column27: “‘I don’t want to die.’ And I heard God say
column28: ‘You won’t die. I need you to see.’”

column1: After his release from prison
column2: Bracewell moved to Stoke
column3: where he was supported by a Christian charity called Walk Ministries
column4: which works with ex-offenders. “I was at a crossroads in my life
column5: ” he says
column6: “and I knew I didn’t want to continue doing what I was doing.” The experience reawakened Bracewell’s dormant faith. “I was a Christian growing up
column7: ” he says
column8: “but I never followed it.” Now he is committed. At Bracewell’s request
column9: Walk Ministries got him a placement doing youth volunteer work
column10: and he became an anti-knife crime campaigner. He sees a certain symmetry in his new line of work. “The crime I went to prison for involved a knife
column11: ” he says
column12: “and I was stabbed with a knife. God is using me as a tool.”

column1: He goes into secondary schools to speak about his life
column2: and the mistakes he made. “You get a few kids
column3: ” says Bracewell
column4: “who think they know it all
column5: and talk all the way through.” Bracewell has an unorthodox way of grabbing their attention: “I walk up to them
column6: ” he chuckles
column7: “and pop my glass eye out
column8: so they get a shock.” That usually quietens them down. The message of these speeches is a serious one. He talks about the statistics of knife crime
column9: and walks them through the consequences of his own mistakes. “I tell them that every decision has a consequence
column10: ” Bracewell says. “What do you want that consequence to be?” In the past week
column11: he tells me
column12: he’s spoken to over 4
column13: 000 children in just four days
column14: and is absolutely knackered. “It definitely connected with the kids
column15: ” says Marc Inchley
column16: who recently invited Bracewell into his further education college. “They sat up and listened to him. Not all the speakers we get in have that impact. He’s doing this for the right reasons.” Bracewell also cofounded an organisation called Blinded Faith
column17: which works with local authorities to mentor at-risk children. He does one-to-one sessions with children who are vulnerable to knife crime. “I can’t get anywhere without building trust
column18: ” he says. “If I say to the kids
column19: ‘I’ll be there’ and something happens to them
column20: I have to come through. If they don’t trust me
column21: they won’t give anything back.” When the kids run away from home
column22: or get arrested
column23: Bracewell is often the person they call. He’s driven to Leeds and Wales in the early hours of the morning to collect them. “There are no bad kids
column24: ” he says. “Just kids who are making bad choices.”

column1: With all his talks at schools
column2: or driving to meet with his mentees
column3: Bracewell spends a lot of time away from his wife and baby. “That’s the hardest thing
column4: ” he says. So for his treat
column5: he asked for a night out in London with his wife Kelisha and son Zion. He loves architecture and she loves food. The Ting Shangri-La restaurant in the Shard skyscraper near London Bridge offered to host the family – but it’s on the 35th floor
column6: and Bracewell is afraid of heights. “It’s all about conquering those fears
column7: ” he laughs. They spent quality time together for the first time in weeks. “I can only do what I do with my wife by my side
column8: ” says Bracewell. “So it was for both of us.” He particularly enjoyed seeing his baby in the Shard
column9: looking down on the world below from on high – “that was amazing”. Want to nominate someone for Guardian angel? Email us – with their permission – and suggest a treat at guardian.angel@theguardian.com";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/guardian-angel-former-gangster-battling-youth-knife

column1: 6118;6118;‘Everyone came at once’: America’s national parks reckon with record-smashing year;2022-01-01T11:00:01Z;['Annette McGivney'];['National parks'
column2: 'Travel and transport'
column3: 'US news'];"After more than a year of Covid cabin fever
column4: the landscapes of the west called out to cooped up Americans
column5: who arrived in greater numbers than ever before. As a result
column6: 2021 saw bucket-list parks – including Yellowstone
column7: Grand Teton
column8: Zion
column9: Arches
column10: Canyonlands and Glacier – smash their previous visitation records. But the mass exodus into the outdoors has come at a cost. The 1960s-era wastewater system in Yellowstone was pushed to the brink. Arches temporarily closed 120 times because all the parking lots were full. The Grand Canyon struggled to cope with a record number of rescues
column11: and an influx of remote workers have driven rents sky high in gateway towns such as Jackson Hole
column12: Wyoming. Interviews with park supervisors
column13: staff and guests paint a picture of a system under increasing strain and struggling to adapt to this new reality. National parks have become the go-to destination for vacationers craving dazzling sights at a social distance
column14: but the surge has collided with a host of existing problems on public lands
column15: including years of underinvestment. That has left staff overwhelmed and guests frustrated.

column1: “The whole country had been pent up and everybody decided to come to the American west at the same time
column2: ” says Jason Williams
column3: chair of the Jackson Hole chamber of commerce and owner of a wildlife tour company. “Last summer people were rolling into town without reservations or a plan but they had very high expectations.” Now that the chaotic tourism season is over
column4: park superintendents are taking a deep breath and examining how Covid has changed America’s relationship to the outdoors. The record turnout has been a phenomenon largely affecting parks in the western US
column5: and marks a shift from 2020
column6: where people were more likely to visit parks closer to home. That changed when the relaxing of Covid restrictions made wild
column7: celebrated landscapes more accessible
column8: and park authorities say that will continue. For Chip Jenkins
column9: the superintendent of Grand Teton
column10: which saw a record 3.8 million visitors in 2021
column11: that means balancing the benefits of more people heading outdoors with the logistical challenges of accommodating them. “I am thinking about what this means for 2022 but also for 2042
column12: ” says Jenkins. “How are we going to preserve a high-quality visitor experience?” It’s not Disneyland: park staff strained by larger crowds Inspired by well-funded state tourism campaigns and an endless feed of beautiful photos on Instagram
column13: Americans headed to crown jewel parks expecting a picture-postcard experience. But the upbeat marketing pitches glossed over the fact that Covid coincided with a period of chronic underfunding.

column1: According to the not-for-profit National Parks Conservation Association
column2: National Park Service staff has shrunk by 14% over the last decade
column3: primarily due to federal funding cuts. Total visitation to all national park properties has increased by 20% during the same period. Making the situation even more difficult were staff housing restrictions and supply chain problems created by Covid. While visitors would find the Tetons or Delicate Arch as spectacular as ever
column4: they would also discover there were not enough park employees to shoulder the increased demand for basic services like cleaning bathrooms or answering questions at visitor centers. Tourists in gateway towns also encountered closed restaurants due to lack of staffing
column5: empty store shelves caused by supply chain problems
column6: hotels that were booked out for months
column7: traffic jams and frazzled local residents.

column1: In Yellowstone – where visitation hit 4.4 million in 2021
column2: a million more than in 2020 – the sudden influx created a kind of operational whiplash. “Historically
column3: we had 20 years between each additional million visitors and there was plenty of time to adjust
column4: ” says Cam Sholly
column5: Yellowstone’s superintendent. “But getting that increase in just a 12-month period made it hard to react fast enough.” Sholly says the primary impact of last year’s visitor increase was the extra stress placed on park infrastructure and staff rather than on the wild landscape. “All of a sudden we are having to clean the bathrooms five times a day instead of three
column6: ” he says. “And we are needing to empty 2
column7: 000 trash cans more often.” Supply chain problems caused food to run low at even the most highbrow Yellowstone restaurants and hotels. And staffing shortages often left dining rooms without enough servers. Chris Schultz and his wife visited the park’s Old Faithful Inn in late September. Given the hotel’s historic reputation and $500-a-night price tag
column8: they had high expectations but came away disappointed. “The only thing you could get for breakfast was a cold bagel that was being served out of a cooler
column9: ” says Schultz
column10: who lives in Tennessee. Yellowstone visitor activity traditionally tapers off in the fall when snow arrives
column11: but last year the park set a September visitation record of more than 9
column12: 000 people. Park managers say attractions like Old Faithful and Mammoth Hot Springs are now just as packed in the fall as they are during summer.

column1: “Yellowstone reached the point several years ago where there are more visitors inside the park than there are services to accommodate them
column2: ” says Mike Keller
column3: general manager for Yellowstone National Park Lodges. But Keller
column4: who has worked at Yellowstone for 30 years
column5: does not think adding more hotel rooms or camp grounds is going to solve the problem. He is more interested in educating new park visitors about how Yellowstone’s rustic atmosphere is very different from places like Disneyland – and he wants it to stay that way. “I saw more visitors come to Yellowstone who were unprepared for what the park experience is like
column6: ” he says. “We have never had TVs or swimming pools in our hotels. But there were so many times when guests would complain about it to our employees
column7: saying they didn’t know what to do with their family at night. There was a real fatigue for staff caused by visitors wanting services that we don’t offer.” Danger for visitors who are ‘underestimating the challenges’ Park staff say a lack of preparedness
column8: particularly among newcomers who may underestimate the extremes of these wild places
column9: has driven up search and rescue costs and monopolized ranger time. In Grand Canyon national park
column10: the strain of backcountry rescues has become especially acute. Though visitation decreased in 2021 due to a drop in international tourism
column11: park rescues increased by 30% compared with the annual average. The park carried out at least 400 backcountry evacuations in 2021
column12: the most in 20 years. The park informs people about the challenges of hiking in the canyon
column13: where temperatures routinely climb into the triple digits and trails are relentlessly steep
column14: but Grand Canyon superintendent Ed Keable says many of last year’s first-time visitors to the park did not heed those warnings. “They were underestimating the challenge and overestimating their physical abilities
column15: ” says Keable. “They were just so eager to get out and hike but they were not as fit as they had been before the pandemic.”

column1: While the rescue data from Grand Canyon and other parks show that the new visitors are often lacking in preparation or a sense of caution
column2: they also share other characteristics
column3: according to a recent study conducted by social scientists at the University of Montana
column4: Penn State and the Leave No Trace Center for Outdoor Ethics. The study surveyed nearly 5
column5: 000 adults across the United States during May and June 2021 to find out who was recreating outdoors during Covid. The results revealed a fairly homogeneous group: people who are predominantly white
column6: middle aged and have slightly higher than average disposable incomes. “It turns out the new outdoor recreationists are not very different demographically from the existing recreationists
column7: ” says Peter Newman
column8: a co-author of the study and a professor with Penn State’s department of recreation
column9: park and tourism management. The survey found that 76% of the outdoor recreation newcomers were white; 73% of people who had been going outdoors before Covid were white. Meanwhile
column10: people who had been recreating outdoors but dropped that activity during Covid were predominantly people of color and lower income. These demographics mirror a longstanding lack of diversity among national park visitors. According to a 2015 National Park Service report
column11: only 20% of domestic national park visitors were people of color despite the fact they make up 40% of the US population. “The new visitors going to parks during the pandemic were people who had fewer constraints economically and more flexibility related to work
column12: ” adds Rice. Squeezing out locals Remote working has played a large role in bringing more people into gateway communities that surround national parks. Outdoor recreationists and wealthy families fleeing cities during the pandemic for scenic rural communities have sent rents spiking in destinations such as Jackson Hole
column13: Wyoming
column14: which is just outside Grand Teton and is near Yellowstone.

column1: Residents in Jackson Hole say that many of the houses in the 10
column2: 000 population town that had been rentals for service industry workers and ski bums have been bought to be torn down for new construction. The average price of a house in Jackson Hole is $2.5m
column3: more than double what it was a decade ago
column4: and rent for housing set aside for service industry workers over the summer started at $3
column5: 000 a month for a 400 sq ft apartment. The result is an inflated housing market that’s priced out longtime residents. “Tourism drives interest in Jackson Hole
column6: and that interest drives real estate investment
column7: which then raises the cost of living and changes the labor market entirely
column8: ” says Chris Dickey
column9: who has lived in Jackson Hole for 17 years and owns a digital marketing agency. “People visit the area a few times and then decide they want to move here. There are plenty of people out there willing to pay $3m to $5m for a home in Jackson Hole
column10: but the problem is that’s not a price locals can afford.”

column1: Dickey has observed that many new residents in Jackson Hole come from urban centers like San Francisco and New York City. They are tech executives
column2: finance industry professionals and successful entrepreneurs. Dickey acknowledges that park visitors are an essential part of the thriving Jackson Hole economy but all the attention can also pose an existential threat. “The real problem is not the crowds or traffic but the loss of our community because no one can afford to live here any more
column3: ” he says. “That is the true cost of tourism.” Park leaders are hopeful that a watershed of new federal funding set aside for parks will at least begin to tackle some of these challenges. Joe Biden’s infrastructure bill includes $1.7bn for roads
column4: bridges and other improvements inside national parks
column5: while a bill currently under consideration in Congress contains a proposed $2.93m for National Park Service operations that would facilitate hiring more than 1
column6: 000 additional Park Service rangers and other employees
column7: as well as funding for diversity and inclusion programs. “The politicians in DC now know the public really loves these places and wants more investment in them
column8: ” says Kristen Brengel
column9: senior vice-president of government affairs for the National Parks Conservation Association. As for managing crowding
column10: parks that experienced the most congestion during Covid are looking at ways to require online reservations before arriving. Arches national park is implementing a timed entry system
column11: while Zion will soon require permits for its popular day hike to Angels Landing. Online entry reservations that were implemented during 2020 at Rocky Mountain and Yosemite national parks as Covid precautions will probably stay in place.

column1: But national park advocates and managers worry that these systems could further alienate the people who are not visiting America’s crown jewels. “What park managers are doing to control impacts from increased visitation could make the parks less accessible to people of color or lower income
column2: ” says William Rice
column3: a professor of outdoor recreation and wildland management at the University of Montana and a co-author of the study on Covid-era park visitation. Rice points out that problems with internet speeds
column4: digital literacy and knowledge about new requirements can pose additional barriers for certain groups. For example
column5: the primary National Park Service reservation site
column6: Recreation.gov
column7: is only in English. “Our research serves as a note of caution to land managers and the tourism community at large
column8: ” he says. “Covid had negative impacts on efforts to create a more inclusive outdoors. We need to figure out how to distribute our nation’s recreation resources more equitably.”

column1: This article was amended on 4 January 2022 to correct that the number of backcountry evacuations conducted in the Grand Canyon in 2021 was the most in 20 years
column2: not in the park’s history.";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/01/national-parks-us-tourism-crowds-busy

column6: 'Wildlife'];The weekend before Christmas we were in a holiday cabin in the forest. We saw lots of birds. My brother and I fed them so we could get a good look. When we were getting ready to go home
column7: my dad shouted: “Come upstairs
column8: now!” We ran up to the bedroom. We looked out of the window
column9: and in the fog stood a little bird! My brother found the bird book and flicked through it. “It’s a bullfinch!” he cried
column10: and he was right. It was amazing! There were a lot of facts I learned. It’s only 15cm long – that’s half a ruler! These birds’ chests can be orange or pink. Sometimes they look like a robin or a chaffinch. The males have bright colours but the females have dull brown feathers. They feed voraciously on seeds
column11: buds and insects. Their tune is a soft whistle noise. They are endangered so they need help. They breed in May to July and lay up to four or five eggs. They make their nest on the ground. It was amazing that on a cold winter day one was hopping about in front of my eyes. Seeing the bullfinch made my holiday. Orla

column2: 'Money'
column3: 'Life and style'
column4: 'UK news'
column5: 'New year'

column13: 'Ethical money'];"Money plays a key role in many people’s new year’s resolutions to change their lifestyle
column14: so we asked five people to tell us about their financial goals for 2022 and how they plan to achieve them. The rising cost of living and the uncertainty over the pandemic are just two of the challenges that people are having to deal with
column15: so what are some of the things that individuals are planning to do differently this year? ‘I’m hoping to support my activism through Patreon’ Natalie Evans’s financial goal relates to 2020
column16: when her life changed after she filmed a racist incident on a train. The video went viral and Natalie
column18: and her sister Naomi ended up setting up the Instagram account Everyday Racism to help educate people about the issue
column19: teach them how to become anti-racist and offer resources they have created. After accruing 190
column20: 000 followers
column21: it has become such a huge platform that last month Natalie quit her job at a youth charity
column22: while Naomi went down to three days a week in her role as a teacher to focus on the account. To help her survive financially
column23: Natalie’s focus for 2022 is to attract people to their newly set-up Patreon account
column24: where people can donate to support their work on Instagram. Patreon is an online platform used by musicians
column25: artists and others where people can fund someone’s creative work via monthly membership.

column1: “People kept telling us to set one up. I wasn’t sure but it takes time to write up resources and do the things we want to do
column2: and we need support
column3: ” Natalie says. “It’s a great way of having a safety net.” The Patreon platform will enable the sisters to create more exclusive content. “It would be great if there was enough of an income from it for me
column4: and then potentially for Naomi for the two days she’s working for Everyday Racism
column5: ” she says. Their Patreon membership has various tiers of access with different prices. Those signing up for the £3 a month tier receive a monthly newsletter plus resources
column6: while a £10 subscription gives supporters access to a monthly Zoom Q&A focused on different topics. There are guest speakers and the chance to ask questions about anti-racism work and discuss current affairs with the sisters. As a result of quitting her job
column7: Natalie says that another goal is to rein in her spending this year. “I’ve gone from a full-time wage to being freelance
column8: so I need to cut down as much as I can in terms of personal spending. I’ll be cutting down on things like buying new clothes
column9: meeting people for coffee
column10: eating out and other subscription services.” ‘I’m going to give away 10% of my income’ Martin Hall
column12: has made a big commitment for 2022 – and beyond. The data engineer from Manchester has signed up to give away 10% of his income to charities for the rest of his working life. Hall has joined Giving What We Can
column13: an organisation that encourages members to give 10% or more of their income to charities that have been found to have the most impact. It offers information to help members choose causes and organisations to donate to
column14: and provides a list of charities it says are effective. A calculator on the site shows you how much impact your 10% donation could have. Everyone who has made the pledge – including Hall – is listed on the site
column15: to encourage other people to add their name.

column1: “I’ve understood the arguments to do this for a while but now I feel like I’m at the point where I can commit
column2: ” says Hall
column3: who will organise the payments directly from his bank account. “It feels like the right thing to do. I am fairly comfortable and my needs are met
column4: so 10% doesn’t make much difference – a nicer car or more takeaways doesn’t make much difference to me
column5: whereas the money could have a huge impact on someone else’s life. I’ll stick to the pledge through continued belief in the value of what I’m doing
column6: budgeting
column7: and having a wider community around me that have taken the same pledge.” Hall has picked six organisations – which he can change later – including the Global Health and Development Fund and GiveDirectly
column8: a non-profit organisation that allows donors to send money directly to people in poverty with no strings attached. “It’s a nice balance of global health and development but also long-term solutions to reduce global catastrophes such as reducing the risk of human extinction
column9: ” he says. What did friends and family think of his pledge? “My parents said it was a good idea. But for me
column10: it’s primarily a thing you do for yourself and decide on your own.” Giving What We Can is part of the Centre for Effective Altruism
column11: a charity. ‘I’m going to manage my finances better and scale back spending’ After recently switching from being a sole trader to setting up a limited company and hiring her first employee
column12: Leila Hrycyszyn
column14: says that this year she plans to be more rigorous with her finances and set aside money for her tax bill.

column1: “I’m usually frantically saving for my tax bill at the end of the year

column12: and if not

column14: and Amazon Prime. I need to stop thinking I need six different things today. I’m going to cut back as much as I can. I’ll be looking at subscriptions and whether I need them. I don’t think I’ll stop using Amazon – I find it incredibly useful but what I have done is removed the app from my homepage.” Looking ahead
column15: she is feeling positive. “Marketing budgets have kicked off again and I’m the busiest I’ve ever been
column16: ” she says. “Even if there’s another lockdown
column17: I don’t feel like budgets would go again like they did last time. I’m hoping the business will continue to thrive.” ‘I’m looking to focus more on using cash’ Tristan Verran
column19: a performer and educator living in Plymouth
column20: wants to spend 2022 exploring alternative ways of transacting. For him
column21: this means going against the cashless trajectory and paying more with notes and coins. “I like cash
column22: ” he says. “There’s no privacy issues. It’s not really traceable
column23: there’s more anonymity with it
column24: and it’s not micromanaged by some unseen AI somewhere.” “Although spending cash might be tough as more places are turning card-only
column25: especially after the pandemic. I’m an academic and I deal with books but this is a social project I’d like to do. I know little in the way of finance but all I know is that it’s become clear that the global finance system is incapable of meeting the material needs of the majority and is instead committed to systemically transferring wealth upwards.”

column1: Verran is keen to explore negotiation and exchanging services
column2: and see who is willing to participate. “I’m definitely going to step up and be more vigilant
column3: and look at where things come from
column4: and shop local more
column5: ” he says
column6: adding: “I’ve started bartering. I taught someone’s kids in exchange for their parent sorting out the plumbing.” He says he would also like to look into creating a local version of the Bristol pound
column7: the city currency that is in the process of transforming into a new scheme called Bristol Pay. “That model has been interesting. I’ve already started putting feelers out about creating something similar in Plymouth
column8: ” he says. “I want to invest in communities
column9: not extracting wealth and giving it to some unseen billionaire to build spaceships. I’d like to push for that kind of model in Cornwall and possibly Devon. I just think what is happening right now isn’t working – we need different ways of doing stuff and exchanging services. We need more community engagement.” Verran hopes to knock £10
column10: 000 from his £27
column11: 000 student loan debt in the first six months of the year. “This is optimistic to manageable as I am seriously curtailing my weekly expenses on food and travel

column22: 000 a month from his student loans. ‘I’m setting up a green and ethical pension’ A committed environmentalist

column1: Bushnell’s goal is to invest in a pension for the first time. “It’s incredibly difficult to live off a state pension

column6: 'Science'];"The sun has risen from its slumber
column7: its light reflecting on the still water. I go outside
column8: attacked by the icy winds blowing hard. I retreat into my home to fetch my coat. December days are the coldest of all. I pass the hours skimming stones and making fires – watching the flames dance always helps me relax. I watch as my brothers play with the rocks
column9: seeing how far they can throw. I join them
column10: throwing stones until my arm becomes sore. Lunch now. My stomach growls as my mum hands me my food. I sit outside
column11: watching the waves of the Channel
column12: eating my ham sandwich and drinking a juice box. After
column13: I go for a walk
column14: climbing over big rocks and exploring caves. I look at the cliffs
column15: searching for treasure. But what’s this? I see small shells embedded into the rocks.

column1: I pick at the shells
column2: prying seven from the cliff. Ammonites
column3: I tell myself
column4: recognising the twisted shape. Fossils as old as the dinosaurs. I turn towards the sea. I think of the shells floating in the water
column5: not rocks
column6: but alive. I put an image in my head of them drifting in the ever-blue
column7: tiny tentacles limp and lifeless
column8: like in the books. I put them in my pocket and set off for home. The sun sets as I reach my house
column9: the stars shimmering above my head like little lights in the dark sky. James
column10: 12 • Read today’s other Young Country Diary piece
column11: ‘Now I know loads about bullfinches’ • Footnoted added 27 January 2022. The West Dorset fossil hunting code of practice states that there should be no digging in situ in cliffs

column6: the practice is to alternate between the sauna and a body of water

column5: so I could do the things I like – like yoga – during the school day. I feel like I grew up a lot during that time. Having school start at 8.05am again this year was rough. I get up at 5.30
column6: but I’m really busy
column7: so it limited what I could get done before class. Lots of my friends sleep until the very last minute and roll out of bed and come to school without even brushing their hair. Even an extra half hour would have made the adjustment easier. Going back to school and having to ask to use the restroom also felt odd. My friends were feeling it
column8: too. I work in an after-school program. During quarantine
column9: a lot of kids got jobs during the day
column10: and did school work late at night. One friend of mine works at Starbucks. His school lets him take a free period first period of the day
column11: and he works from 4.30 until 7.30am
column12: then goes to school

column1: I’m the child of a single mother who is an immigrant. My mom only got a middle school education
column2: and when she came to the US
column3: she got a job cleaning houses so I could pursue a better life. I always thought higher education wasn’t an option for me. But programs at school have made me realize it is possible. Right now
column4: I’m one of the 10 students sharing my input and my experiences within the public school system to help create an intensive
column5: one-year program for students at different high schools in San Francisco looking to get into Stem-focused careers called the Mission Bay Hub. We’re hoping it will offer tools and equipment that actual scientists use. I’ve told them that it’s really important to have a big open space
column6: because many of our classrooms are cramped. When volunteers come into the hub
column7: they should be a diverse and representative group – like us. Honestly
column8: being part of the program feels awesome – I feel like I’m doing something positive for my younger siblings and cousins in this system. I feel like I’m creating a change in our education. Schools should allow students to meet with the principal and board members
column9: instead of having one-minute
column10: once a month opportunities.

column1: Last year
column2: I started community college classes during high school. Next spring
column3: I’ll graduate from community college three weeks before I graduate from high school
column4: with 62 hours of college credit. The state of Oklahoma covers a lot of the tuition for concurrent enrollment students. And the Creek Nation
column5: which I’m a member of
column6: covered most of the rest. My mom estimates that my parents paid for the cost of a couple of books – that’s it. Everyone should have opportunity to study the same way I did. It helps students become familiar with the college application process
column7: how to navigate the different departments at college
column8: and the difference between high school and college classes. In high school
column9: you’re with this same group of kids
column10: and the teacher is pushing you to do your work. In college
column11: it’s all on you. I have a head start on my future. I should graduate in two and a half years – and save my parents about $50
column12: 000. It prepares students for college
column13: and is a huge self esteem booster. I look at it and think
column14: “I did that.”

column1: A lot of kids my age don’t even know how to sew on a button. If I were going to change high school
column2: I would make sure that students learn the basic life skills you need outside of school. Personally
column3: I don’t know anything about cars. Something happened to my tire when I was at school
column4: and my boyfriend and I had to call another friend to show us how to change it. So I’d make the first quarter of the class automotive – how to check your oil and your coolant
column5: change a tire – things like that. In the second quarter
column6: you could teach students how to cook from scratch. It’s cheaper than fast food
column7: healthier too. And I would know. One of my three jobs is working at McDonald’s as a shift leader. I’ve been a member of a youth organization called Future Farmers of America that prepares students for careers in agriculture since I was a freshman
column8: and it has had a huge impact on my life. Now
column9: I know different breeds of pigs and cattle
column10: and what they’re all for. The third quarter would focus on sewing. I only learned how to sew recently when I made masks with my grandma during the pandemic. I don’t want to have to pay a fee every time I want to get something fixed. The fourth quarter would be more about financial literacy
column11: and setting up a savings account. My freshman year
column12: a teacher taught us how to write a check. But here I am about to graduate
column13: and that’s as far as I’ve gotten.";https://www.theguardian.com/education/2022/jan/01/us-high-school-covid-pandemic-how-to-change
