column7: 'Northern Ireland'];"In a park opposite Belfast’s Saint Anne’s Cathedral
column8: Jamie-Lee O’Donnell is being photographed. It is a small
column9: unassuming shoot; she has only popped outside briefly
column10: catching a short spurt of sunshine on an otherwise gloomy Saturday. Yet within minutes
column11: passersby are stopping on surrounding streets: murmurs of excitement
column12: fingers pointing. A steady stream of selfie-hungry teenage girls muster up the courage to edge closer. “Oh feck
column13: ” I hear from behind me
column14: “that’s Michelle from Derry Girls!” Now filming its third and final series
column15: Derry Girls has proved popular beyond all expectations. Critical acclaim was matched by nationwide public adoration: the show was Channel 4’s biggest new comedy in five years. And in Northern Ireland
column16: the joyful sitcom set in 1990s Derry is a fully fledged sensation; the most watched series in the country since modern records began. Overnight
column17: its lead actors were elevated to national treasure status. En route to meet O’Donnell
column18: I had mentioned the purpose of my visit to my stoic
column19: middle-aged taxi driver and he immediately turned giddy. Later
column20: a mix-up over permissions to take pictures inside the gallery where we’re meeting was quickly resolved: one of the Derry Girls
column21: is it? No bother
column22: carry on.

column1: “It’s just so lovely
column2: ” O’Donnell says
column3: taking a seat opposite me back inside the city’s Metropolitan Arts Centre (the Mac). “When we film outside in Derry
column4: we often have to ask our audience to keep it down while we’re shooting a scene.” O’Donnell lived in the city for most of her life
column5: although recently she has moved to another part of the country. She would rather not say where exactly. “I had a wee bit of trouble with people finding out where we lived and coming to say: ‘Hello
column6: here’s my grandma.’” In Derry Girls
column7: the 34-year-old plays the much-loved Michelle
column8: a sexually liberated schoolgirl with a penchant for profanity. Her sharp one-liners are a series standout: “Do you think if I told him I had an incendiary device down my knickers he’d have a look?” she asks
column9: when armed soldiers board her bus unannounced. In person
column10: O’Donnell shares Michelle’s quick wit. She is also thoughtful and warm
column11: and if anything a little nervous
column12: a far cry from the abrasive over-confidence she exudes in the show as Michelle.

column1: We are here today to talk about her upcoming show
column2: Screw
column3: a gritty drama set in the wing of a men’s prison. O’Donnell takes on the part ofplays Rose
column4: a freshly hired trainee guard. “She’s a really strong
column5: tough young woman
column6: ” O’Donnell says of her character. “There’s something about her which just spoke to me: she undervalues herself a lot
column7: and doesn’t see the strength inside her.” In almost every way
column8: Michelle and Rose are polar opposites. “Although
column9: ” she adds
column10: straight-faced
column11: “they do happen to have the same curly hair.”

column1: O’Donnell is fiercely proud of being a true Derry girl. She grew up on the border between County Derry and Donegal; the north and the Republic. Despite being a generation on from the character she plays in Derry Girls
column2: set in the years before the Good Friday agreement was signed in 1998
column3: she too was raised in the shadows of the Troubles. “It’s such recent history
column4: and a vital part of who people in Derry are
column5: ” she says. “It shapes our outlooks
column6: our humour
column7: our personalities. How we feel things so strongly
column8: and love so fiercely.” Creating characters through her childhood allowed her to imagine other possibilities. “I was such a little weirdo
column9: ” she recalls with a grin. “I had so many outfits to dress up in. I’d make up these personas
column10: each with different hats. I’ve no idea where I got them.” Every evening
column11: she would come to dinner with a show to perform at the table. Drama school was never on the cards
column12: in part because of the cost
column13: but it also wasn’t on the family’s radar. That is not to say that her creative side wasn’t encouraged: she would write poetry
column14: plays and songs
column15: and stand in Derry city centre
column16: ready to perform intense immersive theatre to any unsuspecting shopper who would catch her eye.

column1: After a brief stint at Leicester’s De Montfort University
column2: O’Donnell dropped out and set about trying to find herself an agent. She found gigs as a self-taught nightclub dancer and performed in pantos. She moved around in search of work – London
column3: Belfast
column4: Manchester – taking on whatever she could
column5: be it retail or restaurant work
column6: or on-street promotions. “I managed a Santa’s grotto for a while
column7: ” she says. “I had to fire two elves for coming in drunk
column8: stinking of booze
column9: after clubbing all night at the Warehouse Project. I could hear them wobbling towards me because of the bells on their hats and shoes.” One of them threw up in a bin while Santa was with a group of toddlers.

column1: “Around then was the first time I really realised where I was from
column2: ” O’Donnell says. “I got a job working at a coffee shop in Manchester. I remember flicking through my contract and asking the other staff: why doesn’t it say whether you get paid for bomb scares? Back at home
column3: this was a standard question: will I lose wages if we’re forced to close for an evacuation? But they all looked back at me like I had two heads.” By 2017
column4: O’Donnell had returned to Derry and bought a corner shop. “It was good craic
column5: ” she says. “I was eating crisp sandwiches constantly. I didn’t make any money
column6: if anything I lost a bit.” It was then
column7: finally
column8: that acting work started to come in regularly. She shut up shop when she was cast in a touring production of I Told My Mum I Was Going on an RE Trip
column9: a play about young women’s abortion experiences. “We actually performed it right here at the Mac
column10: ” she says. “There were people protesting outside
column11: saying it was an abomination.” Access to abortion services remains difficult in Northern Ireland today
column12: but back then abortion rights were almost nonexistent in the country
column13: except in the most extreme of cases. “I’m very proud of that show
column14: ” O’Donnell says. “To have helped continue the conversation. In my opinion
column15: it’s healthcare for women. It’s really close to my heart. It affects me directly.”

column1: Around the same time
column2: O’Donnell read an article about a new Channel 4 sitcom written by the Derry-born writer Lisa McGee. “Right away I knew it would be hilarious
column3: ” she says. “I was desperate to be a part of it. As soon as I read the scenes
column4: I felt something. I knew every single one of these girls.” There were eight months between O’Donnell’s first audition and casting
column5: during which time she presumed it simply wouldn’t happen. When she got the call to say she had bagged the part
column6: the years of graft felt worth it. During filming – on intensive Belfast shoots
column7: and on location in Derry – cast and crew would laugh constantly. “We all had this feeling
column8: ” she adds
column9: “but we didn’t want to jinx it. Then the first episode came out
column10: and everything went crazy. It hasn’t stopped since.”

column1: There is magic
column2: certainly
column3: in the show’s performances and writing. But it’s the personal
column4: heartfelt portrait of a place so rarely seen or heard of outside the context of conflict and tension that truly casts a spell. “We’ve been able to show the world the real Derry
column5: ” O’Donnell says. “Not the one from the news
column6: but our one. Not a conflict zone
column7: but a community. It’s such a huge responsibility …” O’Donnell
column8: tears in her eyes
column9: takes a second. “Sorry
column10: ” she sniffs
column11: smiling. “It’s just nice to show the Derry we know. Why am I getting upset? This is ridiculous.”

column1: Saying goodbye to Michelle was always going to be sad. Derry Girls has changed her life for ever. “When you step on set as Michelle
column2: ” she says
column3: “the gloves are off and you can just go full-throttle ballistic. There’s this freedom whenever I’m playing her.” With Screw about to be released and Derry Girls ending
column4: O’Donnell is in a state of transition. On screen
column5: she is going from schoolgirl to working woman
column6: but her own life is also evolving. Initially
column7: when things took off
column8: she felt out of place at red-carpet events; enjoying her successes felt indulgent
column9: but that is changing. “It’s almost turning to guilt now
column10: ” O’Donnell says. “Maybe that’s too strong a word. It’s just my identity was shaped entirely by being a working-class woman focused on a single goal.” She is still that person
column11: she’s quick to add. “But once you start to achieve it
column12: then what happens? Being a struggling actor was a huge part of who I was. Now I’ve realised I’m not terrified of what comes next any more. And that’s great
column13: but in its own way
column14: scary
column15: too.” That is why
column16: even when Derry Girls wraps
column17: O’Donnell won’t say goodbye to Michelle completely. She will continue to channel her no-shits-given energy from time to time: “I hope Michelle will live on in me. Although
column18: only a wee bit. She’s totally nuts.” Screw starts Thursday
column19: 9pm
column20: Channel 4.";https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/01/jamie-lee-odonnell-weve-been-able-to-show-the-world-the-real-derry

column6: 'Inequality'];"I’m a literary agent and at the height of last year’s Black Lives Matter protests I was sent a list
column7: with accompanying photographs
column8: of the top editors working across the major publishing houses in the UK. When I read it I burst into tears. It showed a sea of almost totally white faces
column9: some of whom had been approaching retirement when I started out as an editorial assistant 20 years earlier. The stagnation in the industry was stark and filled me with despair. Analysis of the industry since then
column10: partly led by pressure from BLM and an open letter from the Black Writers Guild
column11: has only further highlighted this imbalance. Two of the biggest global publishers
column12: Penguin Random House and Hachette
column13: revealed that just 2.7% of their staff – in both cases – are black; and the Guardian reported that you are eight times more likely to see an animal as lead character in a children’s book than a person of colour. In a modern
column14: multicultural nation
column15: the whiteness of the industry matters. This summer
column16: the bestselling author Kate Clanchy chose to rewrite her memoir after an outcry over her portrayal of minority-ethnic children. Her book
column17: Some Kids I Taught and What They Taught Me
column18: used racialised terminology such as “chocolate-coloured skin”
column19: it referred to one student as “African Jonathon”
column20: a Somali child as having a “narrow skull” and described another as being “so small and square and Afghan with his big nose and premature moustache”. I’ve sat in weekly new business meetings across three of the five major publishing houses week in week out for decades
column21: invariably surrounded by all-white teams who between them not only decide what should and shouldn’t be published but also give final signoff to books before they’re printed. For me
column22: and other people of colour in the industry
column23: this was the moment we’ve been sounding the alarm bell about for years. The furore about Clanchy on social media left me astonished. I watched in horror as posters argued ferociously over whether it’s OK or not to comment on the shape of a black child’s skull. People raged
column24: asking how Clanchy’s use of language could have been published. For me
column25: the answer could be found easily in that white-dominated editors’ list
column26: and the fact that
column27: for years
column28: loud and growing calls to diversify its teams have been pretty much ignored. No wonder the industry today finds itself in a complete mess on race. There is a crippling and toxic silence around everyday racism and how it manifests in the media: erasure
column29: sidelining
column30: stunting of careers
column31: the sheer mental exhaustion of operating daily in a predominantly white space and the routine grind of being marginalised. A couple of years ago I left one of the major publishers and now work from my two-up two-down in Wales
column32: supporting talent behind the scenes. I focused instead on agenting David Harewood’s memoir and its important
column33: groundbreaking discussion of black mental health. And I worked with Lenny Henry on his first novel for children
column34: about a black child who is able to fly – helping to address that lack of black lead characters. I empathise with Vanessa Kingori
column35: the black chief business officer at Condé Nast
column36: who says that when she joined Vogue at the same time as editor-in-chief Edward Enninful
column37: their joint aspiration “was always to normalise the marginalised”. Meanwhile
column38: I’ve observed within publishing the increasing mention and use of “sensitivity readers”. What on earth are they
column39: you might ask. Essentially a little freelance cottage industry of marginalised folk has sprung up
column40: post-Clanchy
column41: to check that books aren’t racist
column42: disablist or any other -ist before they’re sent to print. What this means is that the predominantly white editors commissioning and publishing books featuring characters from diverse backgrounds are now checking these books with readers from these backgrounds in order to ensure publication does not cause accidental offence. And backlist titles
column43: too
column44: are being rethought – a recent example being that of an east Asian character from David Walliams’ The World’s Worst Children. It is now published without the character Brian Wong
column45: Who Was Never
column46: Ever Wrong
column47: following a complaint from a reader who had picked up on the way Brian had been illustrated
column48: wearing glasses and with “small eyes”. But
column49: for me
column50: “sensitivity readers” are an inadequate
column51: sticking-plaster solution. Why use freelancers when you could actually fully employ commissioning editors and publishers of all backgrounds? Shouldn’t there be enough diversity within the industry itself to ensure work can be properly checked for sensitivity? Given the industry seems incapable of this
column52: perhaps it needs an independent body to advise it on equality and monitor progress. As a black
column53: straight woman who commissioned and edited a memoir by a white
column54: gay man (that sold more than 450
column55: 000 copies with not a sensitivity reader in sight)
column56: I’d say that we have far more in common as human beings than differences. I don’t feel like a minority: there are lots of people around the world who look like me. Sharing all of our stories with respect and sensitivity really shouldn’t be this hard. Natalie Jerome is a literary agent
column57: deputy chair of Literature Wales
column58: and a former publisher";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/01/black-literary-agent-uk-publishing-diversity

column11: 'Law'];"A battle is brewing in SW19. Local residents
column12: environmental and heritage groups are preparing to launch a public relations and legal salvo against Wimbledon’s plans to develop historic Capability Brown parkland into 39 new tennis courts for the championships. The campaigners claim the All England Lawn Tennis Club’s (AELTC) designs for a new 8
column13: 000-seat show court and 38 other grass courts on a golf course next to the world-famous SW19 club breaches a covenant that prevents building on the Grade II* listed parkland. When it bought the freehold of the golf course from Merton borough council for £5.2m in 1993
column14: the All England club agreed to a legal covenant “preventing the use of the land otherwise than for leisure or recreation purposes or as an open space”.

column1: Despite the covenant
column2: the All England club has submitted plans to Merton and Wandsworth councils for a 95-metre long
column3: 28-metre high 8
column4: 000-seat “Parkland show court” on the land designed by Capability Brown for the first Earl Spencer in 1768. The club says it needs to build the new show court on the protected parkland because there is not enough space on its current site
column5: and it urgently requires higher capacity courts to compete with the other grand slam tournaments. The club has promised the campaigners
column6: who number in their thousands and include several prominent London lawyers
column7: that the show court will be “a world-class building matching the beauty of its surroundings and paying tribute to the site’s rich history”. The plans
column8: which the club said would enhance its “tennis in an English garden” image
column9: also include 38 ground courts
column10: several ancillary buildings and 9.4km of roads and paths. More than 1
column11: 200 people have submitted formal objections via the councils’ websites. Ahead of a planning decision expected in the spring
column12: several local residents associations
column13: heritage and environmental groups
column14: and local politicians are forming a “non-political umbrella group” to begin a public and legal fight against the All England club’s plan. Chris Baker
column15: director of the Capability Brown Society
column16: said the plans would “destroy forever” land laid out by Brown 240 years ago. “This act of desecration will be a savage act of vandalism by the All England – who claim to have ‘heritage is in our DNA’
column17: ” Baker said. Baker said the coalition of interest groups aimed to “first fight the All England in the court of public opinion”
column18: but has also asked lawyers to prepare for a legal battle over the status of the covenant if planning permission is granted. “The All England were good neighbours
column19: but local opinion is fast turning against them
column20: ” Baker said. “The great majority of locals are scared to death that they are going to wreck the park. They are interested in only one thing and that is revenue and the extra income their new developments on the golf course will generate.” Thelma Fry
column22: who has lived in a block of flats overlooking the park for 30 years
column23: said she was “devastated and heartbroken” by the proposals. “I am just one person against the endless wealth and influence of All England Tennis
column24: ” Fry said. “As I grow older
column25: my pleasure in life is ever more dependent on the view from my window. The trees
column26: grass and lake of Capability Brown’s landscape. I am devastated and heartbroken that it will be ruined by the All England plans. “They have assured me it will take years to build
column27: which means that for the remainder of my life
column28: instead of my present glorious view I will overlook a building site.”

column1: Iain Simpson
column2: chairman of Wimbledon Park Residents Association
column3: which represents more than 10
column4: 000 local households
column5: accused the All England club of deceiving local people by submitting plans that breach the covenant it signed promising not to build on the land when it bought it in 1993. Simpson dug out Merton’s minutes from when the council agreed to sell the golf club land on the condition that the All England signed a covenant promising “not to use it except for leisure or recreational purposes or as an open space and not to build on it”. At the time
column6: the then-chairman of the All England club
column7: John Curry
column8: said: “We completely understand and support everyone’s determination to keep the land open and we have purchased the land on that basis.” Tony Colman
column9: leader of Merton borough council
column10: said: “This council is resolute that the land will be retained as open space. All England has bought the land knowing this is our policy and is aware that we would not allow development of the site.” When Simpson recently wrote to Ian Hewitt
column11: the current All England chairman
column12: reminding him of the covenant and his predecessor’s promise
column13: Hewitt replied that: “I am sure you can appreciate that the requirements of the club and the community have developed in the resulting 28 years and that the AELTC has needed to work to ensure that the championships remain a pre-eminent tennis tournament and continue delivering significant and improved socioeconomic benefits to the local area.” “Residents and the public have been deceived about their intentions
column14: ” Simpson said in letter sent to thousands of local homes earlier this month. “Why should we believe anything they say?” In a statement
column15: Hewitt said: “Private land covenants do not form part of the public planning process but are to be dealt with outside that process. The AELTC’s view is that it would be appropriate for any discussion/consideration in relation to the covenants to take place once the planning application has been determined.”

column1: Hewitt said the proposed new courts were “vital to the future of Wimbledon – to the hampionships
column2: to the people of Wimbledon
column3: and to tennis in the UK and globally. We need to deliver on these aspirations in order to maintain Wimbledon’s position at the pinnacle of the sport.” A spokesperson for Merton borough council said: “A legal covenant is not a material planning consideration in a planning application assessment. “The All England Lawn Tennis Club’s application is currently under assessment and it will likely be decided by the planning committee: as yet we don’t have a committee date in mind as the application is still under assessment by officers.” The All England club rented the land to Wimbledon Park Golf Club on a lease due to expire in 2041. However
column4: eager to expand the championships and accommodate preliminary matches on site
column5: the tennis club offered the golf club members £65m to buy out the lease and expand its footprint. The golf club members
column6: who included Piers Morgan
column7: Ant McPartlin and Declan Donnelly
column8: and former cabinet secretary Lord O’Donnell
column9: voted in favour of the deal in 2018 and each collected a £85
column10: 000 windfall.";https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/jan/01/epic-match-beckons-as-wimbledon-locals-take-on-tennis-club-expansion

column6: 'Democrats'];"The debate was ostensibly over a stop-gap spending bill that would avert a government shutdown. But Chip Roy
column7: a Republican congressman from Texas
column8: seized the opportunity to accuse Democrats of supporting “unconstitutional” vaccine mandates
column9: critical race theory
column10: “woke gender ideology” and open borders. A vote to fund the federal government
column11: he warned

It’s insane.” Ryan’s frustration crystallized a dilemma for Democrats as they defend paper-thin majorities in Congress next year: how to talk about their legislative victories when Republicans are talking about everything else. Emboldened by a string of off-cycle electoral victories
column15: Republicans are embracing the culture war battles that Donald Trump waged from the White House as a strategy for winning back control of the House and Senate in the 2022 midterm elections. “Lean into the culture war
column16: ” was the title of a June memo from the leader of the House Republican Study Committee
column17: Indiana congressman Jim Banks. The “culture war” offensive comes as Democrats
column18: facing deep economic malaise and historical headwinds

column20: which includes an ambitious social policy package that faces serious legislative hurdles
column21: hampered by Democratic holdout senator Joe Manchin. “We have a plan to give you a better country

column24: chair of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. “We are tackling the tough problems of the economy and the pandemic. They seek only to win power and will say or do anything to achieve that.” The party controlling the White House typically loses seats in the first midterm elections of a new presidency. With Biden’s plunging poll numbers
column25: uncertainty over the centerpiece of his legislative agenda and Republicans’ redistricting edge
column26: Democrats are increasingly dour about their chances. In the House

column28: bipartisan infrastructure law and a poverty-reducing pandemic relief package – is critical for Democrats. But he said the party must also aggressively confront the Republican cultural assault. He urged Democrats to call out the opposition party’s embrace of “dangerous and reckless conduct”
column29: which includes amplifying Trump’s false claims of a stolen election and downplaying the seriousness of the 6 January attack on the US Capitol. On social issues
column30: he believes that Republicans have pushed too far
column31: particularly on the issue of abortion. As the supreme court considers whether to weaken or overturn the landmark Roe v Wade precedent
column32: Democrats are loudly trumpeting their support for women’s reproductive rights

column31: we created Haiti
column32: our language
column33: and with it goods
column34: ideas

column36: art and artefacts. What is soup joumou to me personally? I do not ask myself. The great poet René Philoctète wrote a beautiful poem about the questions he does not ask himself: “why I stay here

column1: “But reforms that helped to bring improvement have been poisoned by over-emphasis on autonomy and a devil-take-the-hindmost approach. column14: with global searches for the word increasing by 77% between March and May 2020
column15: when
column16: months later
column17: the fourth season of The Crown furthered the fervour with scenes of Diana
column18: Princess of Wales whizzing her way through Buckingham Palace. So when thinking about how to escape my comfort zone
column19: I plumped for the activity that had the potential to make me look the most stupid
column20: but also
column21: if I managed to pull it off
column22: the coolest. I arrive at Roller Nation in north London on a damp and dreary afternoon
column23: desperate to get my rollerskating lesson over and done with. Glimpsing knee pads on a table as I step inside
column24: I am struck with thoughts of how inevitable it is that I’ll fall over
column25: but my nerves are soon calmed by the venue’s sparkling disco balls and my unnaturally patient instructor
column26: Nele
column27: the founder of the rollerskating school Isle of Skating in London. My first topple comes about six minutes in and means Nele takes me back to basics
column28: teaching me how to fall correctly – which is harder than it sounds. The trick is to land on your knees
column29: rather than your bum. Having perfected the art of falling over
column30: I feel slightly less worried about the likelihood of having to leave the venue on a stretcher. I am ready for more. The second rule of skating
column31: it seems
column32: is multitasking: something else I’m notoriously bad at. Keeping your feet in
column33: knees low
column34: chest high
column35: bum low
column36: and arms in
column37: while propelling yourself forward by shifting your weight from side to side is … difficult. All the while
column38: you must avoid looking at your feet – Nele takes to asking me how many fingers she’s holding up
column39: in order to stop me gazing at the floor and
column40: ultimately
column41: falling towards it. After many unsteady laps around the rink
column42: walking like a penguin on my skates with Nele holding my hand
column43: I am surprised to see I am absentmindedly skating solo. Who would have thought the phrase “practice makes perfect” might have some truth to it? Leaving my comfort zone wasn’t exactly painless – I’m still nursing a bruised arm – but it was worth it. I probably won’t be signing up to a roller derby or showing off my moves at a roller disco just yet
column44: but I wholly intend to keep learning. I leave feeling buoyed up by the experience and hoping that
column45: next summer
column46: I might finally have the confidence to take on my lifelong enemy: the bicycle.;https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/escape-your-comfort-zone-i-cant-ride-a-bike-drive-a-car-or-swim-can-i-learn-to-rollerskate

column1: 6141;6141;Veganuary set to pass 2m milestone as more firms join movement;2022-01-01T09:00:44Z;['Zoe Wood'];['Veganism'
column2: 'Life and style'
column3: 'UK news'
column4: 'Business'];A record number of people are expected to try to eat only plant-based foods this month as growing concern about the climate crisis heightens interest in the Veganuary movement. The global campaign is gathering momentum as more large employers promote it internally. This year
column5: Harrods
column6: Superdrug and Volkswagen UK are among the big names taking part in the Veganuary “workplace challenge” for the first time. The corporate push involves making more vegan food available at work as well as running education and morale-boosting events to help participants keep going throughout the month. More than 500
column7: 000 people signed up to take part in last year’s Veganuary
column8: about a quarter of whom – 125
column9: 000 – were based in the UK. However
column10: the campaign’s research suggests that potentially 10 times as many people participate and a significant number continue with plant-based diets beyond the end of the month. By the end of January
column11: Veganuary expects to have reached the milestone of 2 million participants since its launch in 2014. It passed 1 million sign-ups in October 2020. A YouGov poll of 2
column12: 079 UK adults for Veganuary found 4% planned to participate. Extrapolated to all UK adults
column13: that would equate to 2.7 million people. The survey found that attitudes towards veganism had become more positive over the past two years
column14: with 36% describing it as an “admirable thing to do”. Veganuary’s Toni Vernelli said that 20 years ago if people said they were vegan
column15: others would think it was a “weird thing to do” or “quite extreme”. “Now the first thing people say is ‘oh
column16: I’m really cutting back on my meat and dairy consumption
column17: ’ and nine times out of 10 the reason is the environment.” At the same time
column18: going vegan is not the food-eliminating challenge it once was. There has been a gold rush in the food industry with investors pouring billions into alt-meat and dairy brands
column19: a trend that has resulted in thousands of new products including high-profile innovations such as plant-based bars of Cadbury Dairy Milk. With more than 50
column20: 000 products certified by the Vegan Society
column21: there has been no let-up before the 2022 campaign
column22: with a welter of treats arriving on supermarket shelves and menus in the coming days. A number of the most anticipated launches can be found in the cheese aisle. A vegan Babybel
column23: made out of coconut oil and starch and wrapped in green rather than the brand’s trademark red wax
column24: will make its debut. An almond- and oat-based Philadelphia spread is also coming. Forty-two companies in the UK have signed up to the workplace challenge this year
column25: including Marks & Spencer
column26: the professional services firms PwC and EY
column27: and the insurer Hastings Direct. Cian O’Brien
column28: the director of Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles UK
column29: said the company was focused on becoming more sustainable
column30: and that went beyond its work on electrification. “Sustainability is broader and the opportunity to make a personal contribution through changing our habits has to be explored
column31: ” he said. Vernelli said it was important for business leaders to “set the tone”. “Our meat and dairy consumption is not sustainable and the leaders in our society have to take action on this. By taking part in the workplace challenge
column32: they’re not only publicly showing their commitment to sustainability
column33: but also to their staff and leading by example
column34: ” she said. “I’m think it is incredible to have someone like Harrods taking part
column35: ” she added. “It shows that veganism cuts across all demographics. It isn’t a leftwing or rightwing thing or a class thing. We’ve got participants and businesses across all the whole spectrum.”;https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/veganuary-set-to-pass-2m-milestone-as-more-firms-join-movement

column1: 6143;6143;The Language of Love: the absurd dating show that will save your January;2022-01-01T08:00:45Z;['Joel Golby'];['Television & radio'
column2: 'Culture'
column3: 'Television'
column4: 'Davina McCall'];If you pay close enough attention you will notice that there are only three types of dating show: “laughs”
column5: “influence” and “genuinely wanting romance”. The first category
column6: laughs
column7: barely counts: participants on these one-episode dating shows are rarely in it for anything other than a story
column8: ironically enough to use as a conversation starter on subsequent
column9: untelevised dates – “An interesting fact about me? Oh
column10: uh: my episode of Dinner Date is still available on ITV Hub for the next 19 days”
column11: “Ah
column12: yeah? I got sent home after the penis round on Naked Attraction”. Second is the blockbuster dating format
column13: where everyone entering a villa half-hopes not for love but for a significant uptick in Instagram followers and the offer to open a shop in a local mall for a head-spinning amount of cash. These shows litter our screens in the summer months – a Love Island
column14: an Ex on the Beach
column15: a Ready to Mingle. (Play the game right and you can enter the Love Island villa at the start of the summer and leave the Celebs Go Dating villa at the end of the following winter.) Then you get what Channel 4 excels in: taking people who are 30 or almost 30 or a bit past 30
column16: and all emotionally damaged by something in their romantic history
column17: and throwing them into a speculative dating show that
column18: if sociologists enacted it in the 60s
column19: we’d be talking about now in the hushed tones we use when we mention the Stanford prison experiment. Anyway: welcome to The Language of Love (Channel 4
column20: Tuesday
column21: 10pm). It is exactly as ridiculous as it sounds: six lovelorn Brits do their little pre-roll interviews saying they’ve tried everything and they just can’t find the missing piece
column22: all they want is love
column23: and they’re willing to travel to the Costa del Sol to find it
column24: and blah blah blah blah blah. Then they get on a rickety coach and exchange tentative banter with each other (lads blasting the question “OI
column25: WHAT’S YOUR TYPE?” at each other like a football) as it winds up a hill. Then Davina McCall pops out
column26: the pedigree presenter to end all other presenters
column27: and tells them: you’ve all tried everything
column28: you all failed to find the missing piece
column29: you all want love and
column30: guess what
column31: today you’re going to find it. But guess what guess what: none of the sexy singles we’re going to introduce you to can speak English
column32: and none of you can speak Spanish. You have to negotiate heavy petting with the same staccato elan you use to order an omelette at a Tenerife hotel. Channel 4 more than any British channel understands the need to fill January
column33: the most miserable of months
column34: with a captivatingly absurd dating show. This is how they got me hooked on Married at First Sight: Australia last year. (What else was I going to do? I’d spent all my Christmas money and I wasn’t drinking.) The Language of Love seems similarly primed for an audience of people who can’t legally leave the house for whatever reason. As a result
column35: I’m already resigned to watching it to the bitter end. After the initial group meetings between the Spanish boys and the British girls
column36: you think: “How fun can this be
column37: really? They keep misunderstanding each other. Nobody knows how to count. This is stupid.” Then
column38: a banquet-style paella meal and some sangria jugs later
column39: and the electric crackle of human chemistry is somehow overriding the language barrier
column40: and you’re engrossed. Kimey
column41: a medical student
column42: is infatuated with Akonne
column43: a surprisingly sweethearted Brummie MMA fighter. Tracy and Thalia are squabbling over the same hotel worker. The whole thing seems to be filmed on the exact same hardware they use for the grainy interior shots of First Dates Hotel
column44: so you keep expecting Fred to turn up. Instead
column45: as Davina and co-host Ricky Merino watch from a distant balcony
column46: you actually spy something darker and more primal: the inherent human impulse to try to get off with someone even if you can’t confidently tell them where the library is. It doesn’t make sense that this show is as good as it is
column47: but then it doesn’t make sense that any human would spend a fortnight trying to forge a horny lingua franca just because Davina McCall told them to
column48: and yet here we are. This is what your January looks like. Staring into the abyss of the human condition and seeing just how deep it can go.;https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2022/jan/01/the-language-of-love-the-absurd-dating-show-that-will-save-your-january

column1: 6144;6144;Specs appeal: what’s the best way to apply make up as a glasses wearer?;2022-01-01T08:00:45Z;['Sali Hughes'];['Makeup'];"Like every other spectacles wearer I know
column2: I’m adamant that my prescription has deteriorated disproportionately during the pandemic. Where forgetting my glasses was once a mere inconvenience
column3: it’s now a crisis that forces me home to retrieve them. It’s been an interesting process
column4: beauty-wise – what one gains in not being able to see gaping pores
column5: one loses in the ability to apply a straight swoosh of liner. Sight isn’t the only consideration. Specs cast a shadow (anti-reflective coating helps)
column6: so concealer has to work harder to brighten dark circles (I use Dior Forever Correct
column8: and thick frames can obscure hard work done on eyeshadow
column9: which can be both a blessing and a curse
column10: depending on the application. For days when my glasses will be on and off as often as a teenage romance (I wear a librarian’s chain from Missoma)
column11: I want eye makeup to be simple but noticeable. The solution almost always comes via a crayon. By far the easiest eyeshadow with a tremendous effort/effect ratio
column12: crayons are a must for specs wearers. The bullet shape means that even an approximate aim lands on target. After drawing creamy colour on to the lid
column13: I simply take a clean
column14: fluffy brush and soften the edges. The technique is foolproof. For years
column15: Bobbi Brown made the only great crayons (Long-Wear Cream Shadow Sticks
column17: are still the longest-lasting)
column18: but I’ve diversified to include Vieve’s Eye Wands
column20: which fill some gaps in the Bobbi shade lineup. Vieve’s Sand
column21: a pale
column22: warm nude
column23: is a no-brainer lid colour on lighter skins
column24: and a terrific brow bone highlighter on darker tones. Camel and Hazelnut are warm
column25: neutral nudes that work on everyone (more shades coming this month).

column1: Perhaps prompted by the threat to its monopoly on crayons
column2: Bobbi Brown has introduced some delicious new shades
column3: too. Cashew and Shore are two endlessly useful neutrals (warm and cool
column4: respectively) and Skyward is a universally flattering metallic chartreuse for more playful looks. All can be swiped underneath the eye and smudged in the same way
column5: which helps enormously if your eyes appear to recede behind your glasses
column6: as mine do.

column1: What has become absolutely crucial over time is a SimpleHuman sensor mirror (£290). Illuminated
column2: mega magnifying and as pricey as it is indispensable
column3: it allows me to apply
column4: sans specs
column5: the complex makeup looks that I once took for granted. You won’t regret a penny of the considerable outlay.";https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2022/jan/01/specs-appeal-whats-the-best-way-to-apply-make-up-as-a-glasses-wearer

column1: 6145;6145;New year
column2: same old you! The secret to self-improvement is embracing your messy
column3: imperfect life;2022-01-01T08:00:45Z;['Oliver Burkeman'];['Health & wellbeing'
column4: 'Culture'
column5: 'Psychology'
column6: 'New year'
column7: 'Life and style'];"It’s the time of year for reinventions – or
column8: perhaps more accurately
column9: preparing for reinventions. For buying the diet book
column10: drawing up the new morning routine
column11: bookmarking the therapists’ websites or purchasing the storage cabinets for the soon-to-be-perfectly-organised house. As with all attempts at personal transformation
column12: at new year or otherwise
column13: this is the fun part. You get to experience all the excitement of becoming an entirely different person
column14: without having yet had to put in the effort – and without having failed. Like untrodden early morning snow
column15: the vision of who you’ll become remains pristine. Usually
column16: though
column17: something inside you knows the truth: in a few days’ time
column18: the whole thing will have turned into unpleasant grey slush. Personal reinventions fail partly for the obvious reasons: you set your goals too high; or your existing obligations at work or home get in the way; or you find (who could have imagined it?) that the unimpressive level of self-discipline you’ve demonstrated for your entire life until this moment can’t magically be tripled overnight. But there’s also a deeper problem with quests for wholesale transformation
column19: which explains why they rarely work as intended – and why
column20: as 2022 begins
column21: embracing the existing version of yourself
column22: with all its messiness and imperfections
column23: might be the most transformative thing you’ve ever done.

column1: The core of the trouble is that schemes for constructing a New You – whether in every area of life
column2: or just one major one
column3: such as your relationship with your children
column4: or your physical fitness – are always devised by the Old You
column5: who by their own admission has some pretty glaring issues. (Otherwise why would you bother to envision a new one?) You’ve got no good reason to trust this dubious character’s thoughts about reinvention; indeed
column6: it’s likely they’re using what looks like “reinvention” to reinforce old hang-ups instead. And so
column7: for example
column8: your vow to become more productive this year might just stem from your old belief that you’re obliged to fulfil every demand made by those around you
column9: when a better way forward might be to start strategically letting a few people down. Likewise
column10: your intention to make this the year you find your soulmate might simply represent your conviction that you don’t have what it takes to cope on your own. Even if it works
column11: the so-called reinvention will only end up entrenching the status quo. “No one awakens in the morning
column12: looks in the mirror and says

column1: Luck plays a big part in politics and the shadow chancellor took full advantage of her good fortune when Keir Starmer tested positive for Covid just before the October 2021 budget. According to parliamentary tradition
column2: the leader of the opposition responds to the chancellor’s budget speech
column3: but Starmer’s absence meant Reeves stepped in and
column4: by general consent
column5: delivered a polished reply to Rishi Sunak. No single speech
column6: no matter how widely praised
column7: will be enough to revive Labour’s fortunes after four successive election defeats
column8: and 2022 will be a crucial year for the party and for Reeves. Although the government has been floundering
column9: the message from byelections
column10: opinion polls and focus groups is that the public still have their doubts about Labour. The former Bank of England economist’s task as shadow chancellor is to come up with an approach to running the economy that is radical enough to be eye-catching yet also reassuring. She will need to do more than attack the Tories for higher taxes and rising inflation: she will need to start fleshing out Labour’s alternative. Larry Elliott Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala

column1: The task facing the World Trade Organization’s director general over the next 12 months is simple: to save it from irrelevance or – even worse – from falling apart completely
column2: When Okonjo-Iweala was appointed last year
column3: much was made of her being the first woman and first African in the role
column4: but it was her reputation as a political operator that decided the contest in her favour. She will need skills honed as finance minister in her native Nigeria and during 25 years spent at the World Bank to navigate her way through three big issues facing the WTO. The immediate task is to find agreement to waive patent rights on Covid vaccines so that developing countries can produce their own treatments for the pandemic. Success there would enhance Okonjo-Iweala’s reputation as a political fixer and give her a better chance of resolving two longer-running issues. When it was created in 1995
column5: the WTO had two core functions: to deliver multilateral trade deals and to settle trade disputes between member states. For the past few years it has struggled to do either under a succession of technocratic leaders. The next year will show whether Okonjo-Iweala can do better. LE Kristalina Georgieva

column1: When she was selected to succeed Christine Lagarde as the managing director of the International Monetary Fund
column2: Georgieva was seen as a safe pair of hands
column3: but it hasn’t quite turned out that way. She has become the latest occupant of her office to be afflicted by the curse of Washington’s 19th Street
column4: the home of the IMF. Like Lagarde and her predecessor
column5: Dominique Strauss-Kahn
column6: Georgieva has been touched by scandal and only just clung on to her job last year. The row over whether she tampered with a report to give a more favourable impression of China during her previous job at the World Bank was a distraction the IMF could have done without as it sought to deal with the economic fallout from the pandemic. A slowing global recovery
column7: upward pressure on inflation caused by supply bottlenecks
column8: the threat of financial crisis in two of the bigger middle-income countries – Turkey and Argentina – and the buildup of worrying levels of debt in many low-income states are all pressing issues. Georgieva will have her hands full in 2022 and must show she has put her personal troubles behind her. LE Emma Walmsley

column1: The chief executive of GSK was masterminding a bold revamp of Britain’s second-biggest drugmaker when the New York activist hedge fund Elliott Management emerged on the shareholder register in April. Since then
column2: Elliott has kept Walmsley – a former L’Oréal executive who took the helm at GSK in spring 2017 – on her toes. GSK has firmly resisted the hedge fund’s public demands that she reapply for her job before the demerger of its consumer healthcare division planned for the middle of next year. Walmsley has stuck to her plans
column3: and has received a boost lately from a spate of good news. GSK’s long-acting HIV treatment Vocabria
column4: which replaces daily tablets with an injection every two months
column5: was last month recommended by the UK’s National Institute for Health and Care Excellence
column6: which decides which drugs are available on the NHS. The company has also agreed a $1bn (£740m) contract with the US government to provide its Covid-19 treatment Sotrovimab
column7: which has been shown to reduce hospitalisation and deaths by 79%. Yet Walmsley probably needs more successes in the drugs pipeline to keep Elliott at bay and to prove to other investors that GSK’s turnaround is under way. It will be a tense six months until the split of the business is complete. Julia Kollewe Sharon White

column1: The chair of the John Lewis Partnership has been in her post for less than two years but has already caused quite a stir. The former Ofcom boss has already closed 16 loss-making John Lewis branches
column2: including major Birmingham and Sheffield outlets
column3: cut thousands of jobs and shelved the annual staff bonus for 2020. The staff-owned enterprise’s “partners” are now waiting to see if that bonus can be restored through stronger online sales and new avenues of business including financial services
column4: building homes for rent above some stores and widening distribution with outlets on local high streets. White is betting that retail alone will not deliver the kind of profit margins capable of keeping staff well remunerated
column5: but there is a fear that her team’s new ideas are riskier bets than shops and could be a distraction. Meanwhile
column6: back at the retail coalface there are plenty of challenges ahead. John Lewis
column7: under attack from cheaper rivals
column8: is expected to ditch the brand’s “never knowingly undersold” policy – a key part of its pitch to shoppers for almost a century. It’s not clear how shoppers will react. The first step towards that aim was the introduction of the cheaper Anyday range
column9: which some see as a misstep downmarket and others as vital in recalibrating its image for younger shoppers. Waitrose is also facing tricky times. Having cut ties with the online specialist Ocado
column10: giving new life to Marks & Spencer
column11: the supermarket faces a battalion of cheaper rivals during a period of high inflation. Finding cash to expand its newly independent online business could be a challenge. Sarah Butler Alex Mahon

column1: The chief executive of Channel 4 faces the biggest challenge of her tenure this year when the government’s push to privatise the broadcaster comes to a head. Nadine Dorries
column2: the culture secretary
column3: will publish her final decision on whether to sell off Channel 4 in the new year
column4: dampening its 40th anniversary of being set up as a publicly owned
column5: commercially funded alternative to the BBC and ITV. Mahon has her work cut out to fend off what looks to be a political fait accompli
column6: despite widespread criticism that any new owner would have to make large cuts to its programming budget and scrap much of its commercially unattractive content to boost profits. But Mahon may yet win the day
column7: with Channel 4 having survived about half a dozen attempts to push the privatisation agenda over the years. The most serious came under David Cameron’s government in 2016. Against what seemed insurmountable odds the broadcaster survived
column8: with the government able to save face in a “levelling up” deal that has resulted in significant operations and more than a third of staff moving out of London
column9: as well as the opening of a new national headquarters in Leeds and creative hubs in Bristol and Glasgow. Mahon appears to have no such sweeping strategy changes to offer that might appease ministers this time around. However
column10: with mounting opposition from TV producers in the nations and regions arguing that privatisation is diametrically opposed to the government’s agenda of spreading wealth across the country
column11: the battle is not over yet. Mark Sweney Debbie Crosbie

column1: Crosbie has become a dominant figure in the mid-tier banking sector
column2: becoming the first woman to lead for two major UK institutions: TSB and
column4: the UK’s largest mutual lender

column6: becoming its chief operating officer in 2015. Crosbie since led a turnaround at TSB
column7: after an IT meltdown in 2018 that left 1.9 million customers locked out of their accounts tarnished the bank’s reputation and led to the ousting of her predecessor
column8: Paul Pester. During her tenure
column9: Crosbie has cut nearly 1

column11: Crosbie leaves TSB in good stead

column13: which is still grappling with a male-dominated sector where men make up about 70% of senior management positions

column1: The appointment of the Indian-born executive as CEO of the luxury brand Chanel in December was greeted as a sign of much-needed diversity coming to fashion. The hope is that Nair’s appointment will provide an example for other brands in the industry. Nair moves to Chanel from Unilever where she was used to firsts – she was the company’s first Asian
column2: first female and youngest ever chief HR officer.

column7: Nair oversaw about 150

column6: 'UK news'];"The UK’s first specialist black bookshop is weighing up a move to new premises after a crowdfunding campaign to save it from closure raised £50
column7: 000 in just a few days. New Beacon Books was founded in 1966 and has been based in Stroud Green Road
column8: north London
column9: for all but one year of its existence. It announced in December that it would be forced to close its physical store in Finsbury Park due to competition from online retailers and the effects of the Covid pandemic
column10: prompting dismay at the potential loss of a “crucial cultural space”. Campaigners launched a crowdfunder in a bid to raise the cash to keep the shop open. Its £35
column11: 000 target was smashed within 48 hours. By Friday
column12: more than £50
column13: 000 had been raised in support of the shop. New Beacon Books’ director
column14: Michael La Rose
column15: said this week that the shop may have to find new premises so that it can scale up its publishing arm to avoid going online only.

column1: “In order to meet its financial commitments
column2: New Beacon Books must continue to do much more than just sell books
column3: ” he said in a statement. “The publishing arm … has been scaled down considerably
column4: but there are increasing calls for New Beacon Publications to commission and publish work by young creatives and provide a forum for the exchange of ideas. “For New Beacon Books to do this
column5: it must be able to make full use of its existing space and
column6: if necessary
column7: relocate to premises that will allow for the expansion of its publishing and public affairs programmes as well as for bookselling.” He added that an alternative premises may be needed “to accommodate publishing
column8: bookselling
column9: writers in residence [and] public programmes.” Francesca Gilbert
column10: a campaigner who helped to organise the campaign
column11: said: “The New Beacon bookshop exists as far more than just a bookshop. It is an invaluable institution of black history that is needed now more than ever. “It is a crucial cultural space rich with the affirmation
column12: validation and celebration of black literature
column13: culture and art that must be preserved.” She added: “As a young mixed-race Caribbean woman of colour
column14: I never feel more affirmed and held than I do when I spend an afternoon at the New Beacon bookshop surrounded by the work of writers who uplift black voices and stories. It is a second home
column15: a heartbeat and a legacy that we must protect now and in the years to come.”";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/01/uks-first-black-bookshop-weighs-move-to-new-site-after-50k-raised-to-save-it

column10: 'Museums'];"Simultaneous exhibitions to mark the 60th anniversary of Yves Saint Laurent’s first collection are to be held by six leading Paris museums in an unprecedented tribute from the art world to the late French fashion designer. The events at museums
column11: among them the Louvre and the Musée d’Orsay
column12: will reveal how the celebrated couturier was inspired by some of the 20th century’s greatest artists including Picasso
column13: Matisse and Mondrian. Mouna Mekouar
column14: who curated the multi-centre event that will feature the designer’s work placed in the context of each establishment’s permanent collections
column15: said the participation of some of France’s largest and most renowned museums was unprecedented. “I thought it would be impossible to get so many museums to agree to our idea
column16: but they were all very interested and hugely enthusiastic from the beginning. It is the first time they have all worked together on one project
column17: ” Mekouar said. “Saint Laurent was very much inspired by art and this shows the links and dialogue between his work and the museum exhibits. We didn’t want to put the clothes in a room
column18: we wanted them there among the permanent collections.

column1: “In this way visitors will rediscover those collections at the same time as paying homage to Yves Saint Laurent. It’s like a cultural archipelago.” Saint Laurent
column2: who died in 2008 aged 71
column3: was just 26 when he founded his haute couture house with the businessman Pierre Bergé in December 1961. He had moved to Paris nine years previously where his designs quickly gained notice and he was introduced to Christian Dior
column4: then a giant in the fashion world.

column1: Yves Saint Laurent presented his first haute couture show on 29 January 1962. “I believe the work of a couturier is very much like that of an artist. In fact
column2: I have constantly found inspiration in the work of contemporary painters: Picasso
column3: Matisse
column4: Mondrian
column5: ” Saint Laurent said later. “Always influenced by painting
column6: I owe my July 1966 collection to American painters like Wesselman
column7: Roy Lichtenstein. All my dresses were lit with landscapes
column8: moons and sunlight
column9: ” he added.

column1: “How could I resist pop art that was the expression of my youth.” The six museums taking part in Yves Saint Laurent Aux Musées
column2: which runs from 29 January to 15 May
column3: are the Centre Pompidou
column4: the Musée d’Art Moderne de Paris
column5: the Musée du Louvre
column6: Musée d’Orsay
column7: Musée Picasso and the Musée Yves Saint Laurent. Each will feature different aspects of Saint Laurent’s work. At the Louvre there will be some of his most exceptional garments
column8: including jackets embroidered with gold and crystals. At the Musée d’Art Moderne de Paris
column9: Saint Laurent designs will echo the colours of the artists Pierre Bonnard and Raoul Dufy. The Musée d’Orsay will feature some of the evening wear he created for the Proust Ball to mark the 100th birthday of the writer whose guests dressed by Saint Laurent included Baron Guy de Rothschild and Jane Birkin.

column1: A total of 50 Saint Laurent creations will be on display as part of the exhibition as well as about 300 designs. At the Yves Saint Laurent museum
column2: visitors will be taken through the creative process from sketch to finished garment. Mekouar spoke of the “dialogue” Saint Laurent created between “art and literature” and said the designer expressed “a whole artistic universe” through his creations. “It wasn’t just one collection but his whole life’s work that was linked to art. It’s about looking at Saint Laurent from the perspective of art. Both Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé were great collectors of art and this had a great influence on the fashion designs
column3: ” Mekouar said.

column1: “I think he would never had said he was an artist
column2: but today with the links between art and fashion I think we can see Saint Laurent as a creative artist.” Madison Cox
column3: an American garden designer who married Bergé shortly before the latter’s death in 2017 who is president of the Pierre Bergé – Yves Saint Laurent Foundation said the exhibition was an extraordinary showcase “of one of the greatest innovators of French fashion”. “For Yves Saint Laurent
column4: the fine arts were an inexhaustible source of inspiration
column5: embracing all cultures throughout history. This constant dialogue was a key element of the designer’s boundless ingenuity and creativity
column6: ” Cox wrote.";https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2022/jan/01/the-art-of-yves-saint-laurent-design-house-marks-60th-anniversary

column3: 'South and central Asia'];"At least 12 people have died and 13 were injured in a stampede at a religious shrine in Indian-administered Kashmir as thousands of pilgrims massed to offer prayers. The disaster happened around 3am on New Year’s Day while it was still dark on the route to the Vaishno Devi shrine
column4: one of the area’s most revered Hindu sites. “People fell over each other ... It was difficult to figure out whose leg or arms were tangled with whose
column5: ” witness Ravinder
column6: who gave only one name
column7: told AFP. “I helped pick up eight bodies by the time ambulances arrived after about half an hour. I feel lucky to be alive but am still shaking with memory of what I saw.”

column1: One official said that there was a rush to offer special prayers for the new year but this was not confirmed by others. Mahesh
column2: a devotee who gave only one name
column3: told Associated Press the stampede occurred near one of the gates where pilgrims entered and exited the route to the shrine. “Something happened near one of the gates and I found myself under a crush of people. I suffocated and fell but somehow managed to stand up
column4: ” he said. “I saw people moving over the bodies. It was a horrifying sight
column5: but I managed to help in rescuing some injured people.” Another devotee named Priyansh said he and 10 friends from New Delhi arrived on Friday night to visit the shrine and that two of his friends died in the incident. “I have never seen anything like this
column6: ” he said.

column1: The Indian prime minister
column2: Narendra Modi
column3: expressed his condolences on Twitter. “Extremely saddened by the loss of lives due to a stampede
column4: ” Modi wrote. Before the pandemic
column5: every day about 100
column6: 000 devotees would trek up a steep winding track to the narrow cave containing the shrine to Vaishno Devi
column7: about 60km from the city of Jammu. Authorities had capped the daily number to 25
column8: 000 but witnesses and press reports said that this may have been exceeded several times over. Two stampedes in as many months in 2008 – one in Rajasthan and one in Himachal Pradesh – left more than 370 people dead. Others in Kerala in 2011 and in Madhya Pradesh two years later each killed more than 100. In the latest incident
column9: other reports suggested an argument had broken out between devotees. Rescue operations started immediately and the injured – some of whom were reported to be in a serious condition – were taken to hospital. Video footage on social media showed small minivan ambulances with flashing lights rushing to hospitals while it was still dark
column10: as well as massive crowds.

column1: Access to the shrine was halted after the stampede but later resumed. Witness Ravinder said the crush happened at a point where huge crowds of people coming down from the shrine meet those going up. He estimated that there were at least 100
column2: 000 people. “No one was checking registration slips of the devotees. I have been there many times but never seen such a rush of people
column3: ” he said. “It was only when some of us managed to lift a dead body up with our hands that people could see [what was happening] and made space for moving the bodies out
column4: ” he said. With Agence France-Presse and Associated Press";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/01/kashmir-stampede-hindu-shrine-deaths-vaishno-devi

column3: 'Culture'];"It’s 2017 and Sam
column4: a middle-class
column5: perimenopausal wife and mother living in Syracuse
column6: NY
column7: is maddened by America. Who wouldn’t be? The US is both terrifying and electrifying in its inventiveness. In this
column8: her fifth novel
column9: Dana Spiotta is prepared to itemise her crazy country’s collapse. If her data collection effort ultimately becomes an exercise in passivity
column10: there are a few good “Whoa!” moments along the way. This is the first year of Donald Trump’s destabilising presidency. Innocence has been defiled. Unarmed Black teenagers are getting shot in the back by cops
column11: don’t-mess-with-me gun ownership is the prevailing ideal
column12: and everybody’s a tattletale. At the state fair
column13: which previously seemed innocuous to Sam
column14: even charming
column15: she now encounters T-shirts for sale that say things like “LGBT (Liberty
column16: Guns
column17: Beer
column18: Trump)”. Other slogans attack the liberally minded
column19: now derided as “snowflakes”. History is being obliterated
column20: along with art
column21: thought
column22: justice
column23: morality and landmark buildings. Sam seems almost alone in treasuring Arts and Crafts architecture and furniture
column24: peeling paintwork and antique tiling
column25: her daughter’s prepubescent years (now over)
column26: her mother’s perpetual love
column27: the mid 19th-century Oneida community (exultantly adventurous about sex
column28: but blemished by the practice of eugenics)
column29: and L Frank Baum
column30: who gets off very lightly here despite his genocidal attitude to Native Americans. Dissatisfied with her fellow menopausal Trump-resisters – all sauvignon blanc
column31: “landmine squats” and Hillary Clinton pantsuits – Sam leaves the comforts of suburbia for a solitary life in a crumbling house in downtown Syracuse that
column32: like Sam herself
column33: is “dirty
column34: falling apart
column35: empty too long”. There
column36: she relishes the freedom to stay up all night
column37: polish wooden floorboards and hardly ever eat. She even attends ghastly open-mic events at a local comedy club. She seems to be abandoning her self in order to study her society. Or she might just be unravelling. In place of old structures
column38: sincerity and taste
column39: online she discovers bizarre new allegiances that have emerged like fungi overnight
column40: groups for this
column41: groups for that. (For “group”
column42: you could substitute “hatred”.) She meets a few of these networkers in person
column43: but most of her investigations seem restricted to the stinky
column44: stagnant pond of the internet
column45: making the novel smell somewhat of the lamp. Still
column46: many of Sam’s findings are plausibly excruciating.

column1: Some of the off-gridders Spiotta catalogues advocate survivalism
column2: others are opposed to cosmetic surgery (yet make exceptions for stomach flab). There are witchcraft communities with sidelines in sundials
column3: and lots of Christians and dieters (anti-vaxxers haven’t yet hatched). A clandestine sorority of ageing women
column4: calling itself Hardcore Hags
column5: Harridans and Harpies
column6: is matched by another outfit: Men Going Their Own Way. Some renegades dress badly; others have superb teeth. Sam has pretty much left her real life behind
column7: including a husband – good in bed but offputtingly dependent on post-workout amino acid and whey protein shakes – and their teenage daughter Ally
column8: a straight-A student who’s into etymology
column9: dating older men and bearing grudges against her mother. Given Sam’s obsessive attitude towards Ally
column10: which has at times driven her to spy on her daughter’s online activities and fixate on her breasts
column11: this is probably just as well. To focus on a middle-aged woman is still an enterprising novelistic task. Alas
column12: the book is besotted with the kid. Why can’t an ageing female character exist on her own in a piece of fiction without being mirrored by a youthful one? Held in this Trumpian vice of desirability
column13: the younger contender (except maybe in the case of Bette Davis in All About Eve
column14: or Mrs Merdle in Little Dorrit) is pretty much bound to come out on top. Ally duly develops an air of moral superiority
column15: but she and her mother are so similar in outlook
column16: you really wonder why Spiotta felt she needed them both. It would have been better to concentrate on Sam’s psyche
column17: which wavers oddly between bewildered and smartass. Is she even likable? “Sam hated her own shallowness” … so do we.

column1: While everybody in Syracuse runs more and more (as ordered by their personal trainers)
column2: Wayward plods along. It can get preachy and pedantic
column3: too
column4: and overly medical. Spiotta tussles valiantly with serious things – human nature
column5: racial conflict
column6: cancel culture
column7: homelessness
column8: road rage and feminism – without reaching firm conclusions. A fairly touching soliloquy on menstruation comes out of nowhere
column9: then disappears as if ashamed of itself. Instead
column10: the normally staid narrative approach
column11: complete with loads of dutiful backgrounding and flurries of zeitgeist
column12: makes this feel at times like an up-to-the-minute Anne Tyler novel. Spiotta’s analogy between the Trump presidency and the menopause is apt: both cause fatigue
column13: anxiety
column14: insomnia
column15: sudden upsets
column16: fury
column17: revulsion
column18: ostracism and a lot of sadness. But on second thoughts
column19: this maligns the menopause
column20: which can be a real liberation for women; Trump is only about terror. It’s clear men should not be running the world
column21: but the wishy-washy women of Syracuse seem almost as untenable. • Lucy Ellmann’s Ducks
column22: Newburyport is published by Galley Beggar. Wayward by Dana Spiotta is published by Virago (£14.99). To support the Guardian and Observer order your copy at guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply.";https://www.theguardian.com/books/2022/jan/01/wayward-by-dana-spiotta-review-midlife-madness-in-a-mad-america

column10: 'World news'];"The piercing “crex crex” call of the male corncrake once kept country people awake at night. But its last breeding strongholds are falling silent as this elusive migratory bird teeters on the brink of extinction in Britain. Despite a successful rescue effort that led to its numbers rallying on the islands of north-west Scotland
column11: rising to 1
column12: 289 calling males in 2014
column13: the corncrake’s population has since fallen by more than 30%
column14: to just 850 calling birds in Scotland in 2021. A last-ditch effort to stop the corncrake vanishing is under way
column15: with the Corncrake Calling project in Scotland encouraging farmers to cut hay meadows later in the year and in a corncrake-friendly way. In England
column16: 100 corncrakes are being bred in captivity and released each year to re-establish them in the wild. The corncrake is an unusual species
column17: a long-distance flying machine that soars through the skies from the Congo before spending all summer on the ground
column18: eating insects and worms and rearing two broods of chicks hidden in long grass. The male’s repetitive
column19: mechanical-sounding calls – which bequeath the bird its scientific name – once resounded across the land
column20: day and night. But modern farming
column21: with meadows cut mechanically early and often for silage
column22: has led to corncrakes vanishing from most of Britain over one human lifetime. Populations have clung on in western Scotland
column23: where traditional crofting gives the birds the insect-rich long grass through the spring and summer it requires. The species has been revived since 1993
column24: when numbers fell to only 480 calling males in the UK. But a steady decline since 2014 is concerning conservationists who fear that there has been less uptake of government payments for corncrake-friendly farming in vital areas. Jane Shadforth
column25: project manager for Corncrake Calling
column26: an RSPB Scotland project to save the species supported by the National Lottery Heritage Fund
column27: said: “Most crofters and farmers want to support wildlife and help nature and help the corncrake but they can only do that if they are getting the support they need from the government. They need to make a living and they need to be rewarded for farming in these wildlife-friendly ways.” In England
column28: 97 corncrakes were this year bred in captivity by the Pensthorpe Conservation Trust and released on to the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust (WWT) reserve at Welney in the Fens
column29: as part of a Natural England-funded bid to restore the species that became extinct in England as a regular breeding bird in the 1970s.

column1: Birds have been bred in captivity and released for 16 years to restore wild populations
column2: which is particularly challenging with a migratory species. “There is no quick fix here
column3: ” said Chrissie Kelley
column4: the head of species management at Pensthorpe. “Captive breeding is a huge learning curve and it does take years but I’m really hopeful that the Welney trial is going to show some success. The main aim is to get a self-sustaining population of wild birds.” Calling males have been heard again on the Ouse Washes around Welney and on the Nene Washes in Cambridgeshire in recent years
column5: with wild birds successfully breeding at both locations. But another attempt to return the species to the Wensum valley in Norfolk has faltered because male returnees from Africa disperse too widely for their calls to be heard by females. Kelley said a good success rate for releasing a migratory bird is for more than 10% of the birds to return the following year. For the 97 released birds to produce seven or eight calling males next year would be a “good result”. “Captive breeding has its place – it can be a sticking plaster – but any reintroduction can only really work alongside habitat management
column6: ” said Kelley. “There’s no point releasing birds into habitat that can’t sustain them. These projects are long-term
column7: very expensive and well-managed habitat is what it’s all about in the end.” In Scotland
column8: Corncrake Calling is encouraging corncrake-friendly cutting. Traditional cutting from the field-edge inwards traps and kills corncrakes
column9: who will not run or fly across a mown field. But if mowing begins in the centre of a field and works outwards
column10: corncrakes and their chicks run to the safety of long grassy margins at the edge. RSPB Scotland’s annual survey has found that numbers have declined by more than 30% since 2014
column11: but with important regional differences. While the population in the Outer Hebrides has increased by 9.9% since 2019
column12: corncrakes on the Inner Hebrides have fallen by 12.2%. Since 2017
column13: corncrakes have disappeared from Mull and their number plummeted on Islay from 75 to 26. There was better news on Lewis
column14: where numbers increased from 75 to 89 while on South Uist they surged from 68 to 149. The reasons for these differences are likely to include changes in the uptake of agri-environment schemes. Managing land for corncrakes ideally requires farmers not to cut for silage or hay until 1 September to allow the birds to produce two broods in the long grass. A government scheme supporting corncrake-friendly farming
column15: the Agri-Environment Climate Scheme
column16: has been crucial in boosting corncrake populations in recent years but its future was in doubt until the Scottish government announced a three-year extension in autumn. But the climate emergency and more intensive farming in African wintering grounds are also challenging corncrakes. Many of Britain’s other long-distance migrants are also suffering drastic population declines
column17: including the turtle dove
column18: swift and willow warbler. “We don’t have the evidence at the moment to understand what might be occurring on that migratory route
column19: ” said Shadforth. “But we’re very keen to support the populations we have got in Scotland and enhance these by working with crofters and farmers here.”";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/jan/01/last-ditch-effort-stop-corncrake-extinction-britain
