column7: 'Mindfulness'];"We have the Babylonians to blame for making the new year a festival of self-flagellation – although their resolutions were more about appeasing gods than weight loss or cutting back on booze. (Sensibly
column8: they carried out their rituals in spring in the Middle East
column9: not the meteorological hellscape that is a British January.) John Wesley
column10: the founder of Methodism
column11: rekindled the idea in 1740
column12: with an annual new year’s service of resolution – his included a promise never to laugh
column13: which might explain why we also choose punishment over joy. But it doesn’t have to be this way. What if
column14: instead of being motivated by guilt and shame
column15: we leverage our worst habits to serve us better? By being intelligently
column16: purposely lazier; less mindful
column17: disorganised
column18: slower (and with a bit of self-compassion)
column19: we might actually be more successful
column20: productive and happier – but on our own terms. Here’s how. Make peace with your body Most of the body positivity movement is well intentioned – what’s not to like about being encouraged to love our bodies whatever they look like? “But body positivity was a movement created by fat and black women as a space to celebrate themselves because they didn’t see themselves represented
column21: ” says Chrissy King
column22: activist and founder of the Body Liberation project. “And it’s been co-opted by thinner
column23: straight white women emphasising a little bit of cellulite or fat rolls and saying
column24: ‘I love myself anyway’. That was never the point of the movement.” As well as marginalising the founders
column25: the visual dominance of women who are very close to the Europeanised beauty ideal can be painful and frustrating for those who live in bodies much further from it
column26: as well as for anyone with severe body image issues. “The idea that you’re going to love your body is too far of a place to jump to
column27: ” King says. “[Body positivity] is setting some people up for failure.” Body neutrality is more achievable. “I can look in the mirror and just be at peace with my body
column28: ” says King. “I can learn not to say I look gross
column29: or ugly. I can say this is the body I’m living in today
column30: and I’m going to work towards being neutral about it.” Body liberation takes things a step further: “If you live in a black body
column31: a trans body or a disabled body
column32: you can love yourself with all your heart
column33: but that doesn’t mean that you’re not going to face systemic oppression in the world because of your body. Body liberation is about asking: can I come to a place of acceptance and love for my own body
column34: and work towards dismantling the systems of oppression that make it difficult for all of us to be able to do so?”

column1: Be brilliantly lazy Kendra Adachi
column2: podcast host and author of The Lazy Genius Way
column3: is a productivity expert who isn’t necessarily into making people more productive. Instead
column4: she’s interested in helping us figure out exactly which things in our lives matter to us (rather than to anyone else)
column5: how to do them well
column6: and then being lazy (although cleverly so) about all the others – whether that’s laundry
column7: morning routines or cooking (her next book is The Lazy Genius Kitchen). We should organise our lives in ways that reflect what’s genuinely important to us
column8: she says – rather than to our parents
column9: colleagues friends or neighbours – and let other
column10: often very visible
column11: things go
column12: even when that’s socially uncomfortable. For example
column13: for Adachi
column14: it was accepting that she wouldn’t be the kind of mother who volunteered in her young children’s school
column15: but could be the kind who donated money and materials; and realising that was just as valid. Learn to love negative emotions When your cat dies and someone breezily says
column16: “Never mind
column17: you can get a new cat
column18: ” that’s toxic positivity. “Two things go wrong with toxic positivity
column19: ” says Robert Biswas-Diener
column20: positive psychologist and author of The Upside of Your Dark Side. “One is relational – when your friend comes to you wanting support
column21: what they want and what you offer has to match
column22: but often it doesn’t.” When we try to cheer someone up who actually just wants to be heard
column23: “toxic positivity feels invalidating”. We’ve all felt this – when a parent or partner wants to solve our problem instead of letting us talk about it. They want to fix things in part because they can’t bear being near difficult feelings
column24: and this is the second problem with toxic positivity: it often masks a distrust of uncomfortable or unpleasant emotions. “But there are a million good things about emotions – including negative ones such as fear
column25: jealousy
column26: anger
column27: guilt and sadness. They are how we navigate the social world. [But] because people don’t spend any time tolerating negative emotions – they turn on Netflix or grab a bottle of wine – they get out of touch with them
column28: and they parent their children to be out of touch with them
column29: too.

column1: “But if you suppress one emotion
column2: you suppress them all
column3: ” Biswas-Diener says. Learning to feel difficult emotions makes it easier when things go wrong in future; we won’t be blindsided by both events and our own reactions to them. If you’ve never had to navigate sadness
column4: anger or fear
column5: it’s almost impossible to be resilient. For Biswas-Diener
column6: this changed how he parented: instead of soothing and rescuing when things went wrong for his son
column7: he affirmed his son’s anger or disappointment
column8: meaning he grew up skilled at dealing with difficult feelings. We can do the same by giving ourselves permission to feel uncomfortable things such as sadness or anxiety
column9: giving them time and space to occur
column10: rather than always chasing them away with busyness
column11: booze or digital distraction. Be moderately disorganised According to the book A Perfect Mess: The Hidden Benefits of Disorder
column12: “neatness and organisation can exact a high price”. While absolute chaos isn’t helpful
column13: messy systems are often more robust and flexible
column14: according to authors David H Freedman and Eric Abrahamson
column15: who believe that constantly keeping everything shipshape can be an unnecessary waste of time or money. “Moderately disorganised people
column16: institutions and systems frequently turn out to be more efficient
column17: resilient
column18: creative and effective than highly organised ones
column19: ” they say. We’ve been socialised into thinking that being well organised is an unequivocal good
column20: without ever asking whether that’s really true. Freedman and Abrahamson point out that Albert Einstein’s desk – among many others – was always in “stupendous disarray”
column21: so next time someone officious tells you to tidy up your desk (or your sock drawer)
column22: remind them that if one of the greatest thinkers of all time thrived in a semi-shambles
column23: then so can you.

column1: Be less mindful “Traditionally
column2: meditation was never thought of as something to create a moment of calm in the middle of crisis
column3: ” says Dr Julieta Galante
column4: a neuroscience researcher at Cambridge University
column5: who studies the upsides and downsides of mindfulness and meditation. “That is a western repurposing of it.” Mindfulness is not a mental health panacea – despite new Nice guidance suggesting that mindfulness should be recommended before medication for depression. Research suggests up to 25% of meditators experience negative effects
column6: including anxiety
column7: panic attacks
column8: disrupted sleep and emotional or physical dissociation – exactly what we’re led to believe can be improved by mindfulness. Galante likens meditation to a drug with generally positive results for most people
column9: but for which potential side-effects and interactions should be listed
column10: rather than something anyone can start
column11: via an app
column12: with no trained support to fall back on if things go wrong. Which is not to say that mindfulness is bad
column13: but it won’t make life better for everyone who tries it.

column1: Instead
column2: be more mindless. “You don’t want to be mindful every single second
column3: ” says Biswas-Diener
column4: who also studies mindfulness. “Sometimes you want to jam out to some tunes while you’re driving
column5: rather than notice every colour and smell. Daydreams
column6: fantasies
column7: those insights that you get in the shower
column8: those are all from mindlessness.” Work less “We now have a century of research that shows overwork is counterproductive
column9: ” says Alex Soojung-Kim Pang
column10: a four-day week campaigner and author of Rest: Why You Get More Done When You Work Less. “It makes us less productive
column11: less happy
column12: increases the risks of burnout and of chronic disease; it negatively affects company performance
column13: whether you are working in a factory
column14: for the NHS or in a police station; you’re more likely to cut corners and to overlook small but crucial details that later on snowball into gigantic problems.” The only bits of the labour industry for which shorter working hours don’t make sense are
column15: he says
column16: “nonprofits trying to save the world or hedge funds trying to destroy the world
column17: who have an essentially infinite labour source of 22-year-olds whose greed you can satisfy
column18: whose idealism you can weaponise or whose ambition you can appeal to. For the rest of us
column19: working less
column20: but better
column21: makes an awful lot of sense for economies and societies generally.”

column1: Love your clutter “I’m someone who collects a lot of stuff
column2: ” says the maximalist designer Bethan Laura Wood
column3: who wears and makes fantastically layered and colourful patterns. “For some people
column4: my home
column5: which has a lot of objects in it
column6: feels uncomfortable. I find being in a space with less stuff in it uncomfortable – so it’s about what brings joy to you.” Wood believes we should declutter only if we really want to. “Don’t feel bad if you take all your stuff down
column7: dust it
column8: decide you like everything and put it all back.” In fact
column9: there’s even a branch of psychology that examines the connection between our stuff
column10: our identity and our sense of home. “Our possessions can take on a value that far exceeds their physical properties
column11: ” says psychologist Dr Christian Jarrett
column12: author of Be Who You Want – Unlocking the Science of Personality Change. “We imbue our belongings with meaning. They become extensions of ourselves
column13: or of the people who once owned them
column14: connecting us to our past or loved ones. It would be unfair to expect yourself to dispose of your stuff without incurring emotional cost.” In other words
column15: we don’t need to feel guilty about not doing a Marie Kondo and throwing our treasured clutter away. One of the pleasures of an invitation to someone’s home is seeing their mix of precious and incidental objects
column16: telling the story of their life. Abandon meaningfulness “The pursuit of meaning is not fundamentally a bad thing
column17: ” says Wendy Syfret
column18: author of The Sunny Nihilist: How a Meaningless Life Can Make You Truly Happy. “If you want to spend your whole life in a monastery
column19: or pursuing enlightenment
column20: good for you. But meaning has become so intensely commodified that now everything around us has to have meaning: your job has to be meaningful
column21: your relationship has to be groundbreaking and every single consumer product is presented as life-changing – I saw a pack of tampons the other day that said
column22: ‘This box is a revolution.’” When looked at this way
column23: it’s obvious that meaning is a construct – and if absolutely everything is meaningful
column24: then
column25: arguably
column26: nothing is. “[This] creates an incredible vortex of pressure that no one can live up to
column27: ” says Syfret
column28: who wants to help us realise our own insignificance
column29: but cheerfully. For Syfret and other optimistic nihilists
column30: nihilism is about being free from pressure rather than hopelessness or being selfish
column31: and actually powers her activism. “People tell us we should care about things to get us to invest ourselves in them – particularly work
column32: and often as a way to get us to work harder for less money. So when we’re offered meaning – which is not the same as quantifiable value [tampons are valuable
column33: not meaningful] – let’s ask: what is the intention of the person that’s giving me this message? Is this actually a message that’s trying to coercively control me?”

column1: Don’t diet “Before you try diets or gruelling exercise programmes
column2: spend one week treating yourself and your body the way that you would want the person you love most to speak to themselves
column3: ” says Shahroo Izadi
column4: a behaviour change expert and author of The Last Diet
column5: about how to improve our relationships with food and our body. “You may well notice that you are much softer with yourself
column6: you forgive yourself quickly
column7: you’re compassionate and you take a much more holistic approach to the way you treat your body.” Many of Izadi’s clients focus on the outcome – weight loss – as opposed to adjusting their behaviour. “People assume that the result will be enough to teach them a whole set of new skills. I often tell them to imagine they’ve already lost weight
column8: and that their task is keeping it off and still enjoying their life. That’s when they start realising that the way to keep off lost weight in the long term is to move away from the all-or-nothing
column9: I’ve-blown-it mentality and to not moralise their food choices. Because blame
column10: shame and guilt are so often the feelings that people need comfort from – and their comfort is food.” What can we do to create a healthier relationship with food? Have a conversation with yourself
column11: Izadi says. “For many of us
column12: it isn’t until we do some internal inquiry that we realise diets and other unhelpful nutritional ‘rules’ have left us feeling guilty after [eating] what we’ve been taught to consider are ‘bad’ food choices.” This is not how we deserve to experience food

column1: Embrace being single “Women get in touch with me every day saying
column2: ‘Oh
column3: you look so happy. Should I leave my husband?’” says Helen Thorn
column4: one half of the Scummy Mummies comedy duo and author of Get Divorced: Be Happy. “Now
column5: I can’t make that decision for you
column6: but I can tell you that divorce is the best thing that ever happened to me. I’m having a lovely time
column7: all of the time. I mean
column8: I wouldn’t recommend your husband having an affair
column9: but you know
column10: that’s OK.” Thorn is not against marriage. “And I’m not anti-love.” But now that’s she’s divorced and a single parent
column11: she is more clear-sighted about how
column12: sometimes
column13: people succumb to pressure to be in a couple
column14: or to stay in a relationship for the sake of children. “Being single was the thing that I feared the most. It was absolutely the thing that I thought would break me. But love comes in many forms. The happiness that I thought marriage would give me
column15: the completeness
column16: the satisfaction
column17: is what I’ve got from being single. I’ve got everything I need.” She says life (and parenting) is easier and involves less compromise than when she was married. “Romance is lovely when it works
column18: but it’s as hard as being single in many ways. I’ve created this life for myself where I’m happy – and now I don’t have to worry about someone complaining about how I cook my pasta.” Use your anger for good “In the next 365 days
column19: there will definitely be anger
column20: ” says Professor David Lebel
column21: who studies the effects of so-called negative emotions at the Joseph M Katz Graduate School of Business. “The question is how you’re going to handle it. There are times when anger is functional
column22: and there are times when it’s not. There’s a big difference between in-the-moment anger
column23: and using that anger at some future time. So
column24: do you explode at a work meeting? Or do you think
column25: ‘What that person said is upsetting. I’m going to address it
column26: but not now.’ You can’t really tell anger to go away
column27: because it’s too strong – it’s high energy
column28: it’s not comfortable and it’s going to take some time to be calm.”

column1: Anger is useful
column2: Lebel says. “Its function is to change a situation – something is disrupted
column3: that’s why you feel anger. So the first step is just labelling it: ‘I’m angry about this.’ If you don’t know what you’re angry about
column4: you can’t really make it functional. Then I tell people to draw on that anger in future – not to match the intensity
column5: but to supply energy [when you do speak up]
column6: moving away from reactionary blow-ups and towards more proactive responses.” Using anger positively means harnessing it for good
column7: such as improving diversity at work
column8: or helping your partner and child navigate the fallout from a nasty row
column9: rather than wading in while it’s happening
column10: taking sides and intensifying a conflict. Care less “I’m a very ambitious
column11: organised
column12: successful person
column13: ” says Sarah Knight
column14: author of the bestselling No Fucks Given books and You Do You
column15: an alternative self-help series about putting yourself first and giving less of a damn about other people’s expectations of your behaviour. Knight moved to the Dominican Republic after realising that her job in publishing was forcing her not to be herself
column16: and giving her severe panic attacks. “People look at what I do
column17: and the whole No Fucks Given ethos
column18: and they think
column19: ‘She has no direction
column20: no commitments
column21: no limitations.’ But that’s actually not true
column22: and part of the reason is that I don’t live the way culture and society tells me that I have to. A very big part of what I do is reminding people that it’s OK to pull back
column23: it’s OK to say no
column24: it’s OK to say that’s not important to me. You get to decide
column25: in your career
column26: in your marriage
column27: in your art
column28: as a parent. You’re allowed to decide that you don’t give a fuck about being organised
column29: you’re allowed to decide you don’t give a fuck about being slender
column30: you don’t give a fuck about getting a promotion. You don’t have to measure yourself against anybody else’s standards.” Rest better “Rest is good for us cognitively and physically
column31: ” says Claudia Hammond
column32: author of The Art of Rest
column33: psychology lecturer and presenter of All in the Mind
column34: on Radio 4. “The key is to find what feels truly restful to you
column35: and not feel guilty about it
column36: ” she says. “Many people find sitting on the sofa doing nothing quite hard. You don’t need to buy expensive candles to put around the bath before it can feel restful; you don’t have to have a spa weekend. Some find walking or even running restful – they can’t rest until they’ve exhausted their body
column37: they can’t clear their mind.” Hammond recommends activities that occupy your hands but let your mind wander
column38: such as jigsaws or gardening
column39: listening – really listening – to music
column40: spending empty time alone (by choice) and giving yourself permission to not achieve anything in particular. Why do we feel so bad about resting? “It’s a cultural issue – we’re taught at school not to doodle or stare out of the window
column41: and as adults busyness has status; there are experiments that demonstrate that we think busy people are more organised and more successful.”

column1: Read a book (and watch telly) Guardian TV critic Lucy Mangan has never been caught up in self-improvement. “I’m resistant and stubborn about people making me do stuff
column2: especially now I’m older
column3: ” says the writer
column4: whose new novel is called Are We Having Fun Yet? “I’m not about to give in to people who say I should have a side hustle or improve myself.” In the face of a million well-publicised hobby options – macrame! netball! pottery! – it’s easy to forget that you don’t have to have a skills-based sideline in order to be a fully realised human. You could just read a book. “All the reasons we encourage children to read don’t disappear as we get older. It still increases empathy and gives us the ability to recognise and articulate our own interior world (and television is in the same direction of travel
column5: even if it doesn’t go quite so far)
column6: ” Mangan says. What should we pick up
column7: if we’ve fallen out of the habit? “Something joyful such as Wodehouse
column8: or warm and lovely like Maeve Binchy. But don’t go looking for something you think you should read. If I catch you looking at the Booker long list
column9: I’ll smack you in the face.” Ignore people (for longer) Many of us already know we should use our phones less
column10: but the thing that sucks us back in is often what feels like an urgent need to reply to people. The pressure is all in our heads
column11: according to Emma Gannon
column12: whose new book is called (Dis)Connected: How to Stay Human in an Online World. “We think other people care more than they do
column13: ” she says. Many of the people she spoke to for the book were scared of turning off their notifications. “We’re frightened that we’re going to miss out
column14: and that no one will notice we’ve gone. We moan about notifications
column15: but [many of us] don’t turn them off because we like them and they make us feel busy and important.” And of course
column16: the more we respond
column17: the more we get back in response. Gannon recommends “retraining” the people in our texts
column18: DMs and inboxes not to expect quick responses. “We behave as if replying is a task we can complete
column19: but we can never
column20: ever
column21: ever finish it. So step away.” Stay away from resolutions “Approaching yourself with as much kindness as possible
column22: with as much love as possible
column23: is really
column24: as far as I can see
column25: our only choice
column26: especially now
column27: ” says Jeffrey Marsh. Marsh is an activist whose life-affirming videos have been watched over a billion times
column28: and author of the bestselling How to Be You
column29: part memoir of growing up non-binary in rural Pennsylvania
column30: part manifesto for global self-acceptance. “If you hate your guts into losing 20 pounds
column31: will you end up 20 pounds lighter? Maybe
column32: maybe not. But what you will have practised is hating your guts.” How do we learn self-kindness? “To me
column33: the essential question is: will I be able to be kind to myself? Self-hate is the engine that drives most people’s resolutions. It’s easy to say
column34: ‘I’m going to lose 20 pounds.’ It is unfamiliar to say
column35: ‘I’m going to deeply love myself
column36: no matter what.’ It may be the hardest thing to learn in one’s lifetime
column37: but it can also be the most loving
column38: beautiful
column39: fun and exciting process of one’s life.”";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/be-bad-better-from-anger-to-laziness-how-to-put-your-worst-habits-to-good-use

column5: 'UK news'];"The biggest shake-up to the insurance industry for decades takes place on New Year’s Day
column6: when insurers will be banned from quoting policyholders a higher price to renew their home or motor insurance than they would offer a new customer. The move will leave some customers better off
column7: but others look likely to pay more. What’s this all about? After years of complaints that customers who regularly switched insurer were paying significantly lower premiums than those that renewed automatically
column8: the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has said both sets of customers must now be offered the same price. The FCA had found evidence that insurers were attracting new customers with artificially low prices and then increasing premiums in subsequent years – a practice known in the trade as “price walking”. Insurers were also found to be cynically targeting customers who they thought were less likely to switch in future. This move is designed to end the two-tier insurance market that has grown up as a result. How will it work? If the regulations are applied as intended
column9: a car or home insurance customer receiving their renewal notice at the end of the year will be quoted the same premium as if they apply to switch to that company from a rival insurer. Until now
column10: insurers offered generous discounts in the first year – often at or below cost – to attract customers in the hope they would be able to increase their premiums in subsequent years. However
column11: it is a bit more complicated than it first appears. Insurers must prove
column12: on aggregate
column13: they charge new and existing customers getting insurance via the same “channel” at the same price. In effect
column14: this means that insurers can still charge different rates for customers who use different price comparison sites (channels) but they can’t favour new customers over existing ones.

column1: What does this mean for prices? The move looks likely to be bad news for households that switched their home and car insurers each year – chasing the lowest new-customer premiums. There was nothing to stop people switching suppliers each year taking advantage of the discounted deals – and that is what millions of people have been doing. This group will undoubtedly end up paying more each year to insure their homes and cars
column2: as those discounts will no longer be there. Conversely
column3: the FCA said it expects loyal customers who renew policies automatically to save £120 a year each. Martin Lewis
column4: the founder of the MoneySavingExpert website
column5: and one of those who helped to turn UK consumers into a nation of switchers
column6: said: “My best guess is firms won’t just cut renewal prices to match those for newbies. Rates will meet nearer the middle as happened in 2012
column7: when insurers were barred from gender price discrimination. This will mean savings from switching are likely to relatively reduce. “We’re still unsure of how this will work exactly
column8: but prices for switchers are very likely to be relatively higher for January.” Overall
column9: insurance prices will still rise (and sometimes fall as happened in the pandemic) but they should shift equally for all customers – rather than just those who switch regularly. Will it still be worth doing a price comparison at renewal? Yes and this is still the best advice. Insurers tend to target different segments of the market
column10: and some may still want to attract you as a customer and will quote accordingly. The big savings gained by switching will probably be a thing of the past
column11: but there will still be savings on offer. Expect insurers to continue to offer deals via the price comparison websites such as Moneysupermarket
column12: ComparetheMarket and so on. New entrants will still offer attractive prices to grab customers. It is worth noting that price walking has been particularly prevalent in the home insurance market where those renewing policies were often charged double or even triple what they would have paid as a new customer of the same firm. Anyone who has not swapped home insurance in recent years is advised to do a price comparison when they renew. Guardian Money is regularly contacted by people shocked having just discovered what their elderly parents or friends have been paying for their home insurance. Households have found themselves paying close to £1
column13: 000 a year for cover that could be bought elsewhere
column14: or even from the same provider
column15: for £250.";https://www.theguardian.com/money/2022/jan/01/uk-car-and-home-insurance-price-insurers-deals

column7: 'Health & wellbeing'];"A thumping headache
column8: a tongue that feels like a carpet and a strong sense of queasiness and regret – it is a condition with which many will be all too familiar on New Year’s Day. But while it may seem tempting to reach for a hangover “cure”
column9: researchers have chosen New Year’s Day to tell us that most will offer cold comfort. Scientists say they have evaluated studies looking at 23 different substances alleged to help prevent or treat a hangover
column10: but found all of the “remedies” had low-quality evidence for how well they worked. The study revealed only seven of the substances showed some sign of potential benefits for overall hangover symptoms
column11: with participants giving a lower hangover symptom score
column12: recorded as a percentage
column13: compared with a placebo. “A hundred percent is really bad. So they have the worst hangover known to mankind
column14: ” said Dr Emmert Roberts
column15: a co-author of the research based at the National Addiction Centre at King’s College London. Of these seven substances the largest and strongest effects were seen for clove extract
column16: the anti-inflammatory drug tolfenamic acid
column17: and pyritinol – a substance resembling two vitamin B6 molecules attached together. Participants taking a clove extract pill while drinking had
column18: on average
column19: a hangover symptom score of 19% compared with 43% for those who took a placebo pill. While the researchers said there would be limited harm in using such substances
column20: it seems much more research is needed to explore whether they actually help the morning after the night before. The clove extract study
column21: for instance
column22: involved just 16 participants. Writing in the journal Addiction
column23: Roberts and colleagues report how they looked at 21 studies
column24: all assessing different alleged hangover cures
column25: with 386 participants.

column1: Nevertheless the list has some surprising gaps. As Roberts notes
column2: while some may find painkillers such as aspirin or paracetamol help with a hangover
column3: neither has been studied for this purpose in randomised control trials. Among other limitations
column4: the team notes that eight of the studies only involved male participants
column5: while none involved adults over the age of 65. It is also not clear whether the findings of studies in one country would apply elsewhere. Furthermore
column6: the team points out many of the studies had “significant degrees of imprecision in outcome measures of treatment effect” while 16 of the 21 studies involved sample sizes of fewer than 30 participants. Roberts suggested when it comes to hangovers
column7: prevention is better than cure. “The most sensible thing to do is either to abstain from alcohol or drink in moderation
column8: ” he said. For those who are planning to drink more
column9: Roberts said staying hydrated was likely to help – although
column10: it was “not a surefire way to avoid a hangover”. Roberts has also stocked up on another option. “I have purchased a bottle of clove extract
column11: ” he said. Prof David Nutt
column12: of Imperial College London and the government’s former chief drug adviser – who was not involved in the work – said the only way to stop a hangover was to drink less or consume alcohol-free alternatives. Nutt has developed the alcohol-free spirit Sentia
column13: a drink that is claimed can make those who drink it feel “a mild sense of lightness and relaxation” without resulting in a hangover. “Hangover is probably the least researched major health impairment – costing the UK economy over £10bn a year
column14: ” he said.";https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2022/jan/01/most-hangover-cures-have-little-evidence-behind-them-study-finds

column4: who fed poor people at Christmas

For sure: he kept my glass full.
Best thing about Joe? His clear passion for everything he has done and wants to do.

column2: 'Food waste'

column6: fermenting and preserving'
column7: 'Beer'
column8: 'Cider'];"“Vinegar can be made from any fermented alcohol or solution of fermentable sugars
column9: ” says the fermentation expert and author Sandor Katz
column10: whose recipe in his book The Art of Fermentation I have adapted here. “The word vinegar comes from [the French] ‘vin-aigre’
column11: which means ‘sour wine’. That’s why people don’t like to drink the dregs of wine
column12: because after 24 hours they start to turn vinegary.” Katz explains how simple it is to make vinegar: “Take leftover wine
column13: and put it in a jar that gives it a high ratio of surface area to volume” – in other words
column14: in something that’s not full all the way to the top. “And make sure it has good access to oxygen: put a cloth over it and the process will just happen. It will happen faster if you add some sort of vinegar starter
column15: but you don’t really need to do that
column16: because the acidobacteria are everywhere.” Homemade vinegar from leftover alcohol Katz recently brought out a new book called Sandor Katz’s Fermentation Journeys that is full of wonderful stories and recipes from around the world
column17: as well as all sorts of traditional fermentation techniques. Fermentation is a vital tool that can help prevent food waste through preservation. For a better success rate
column18: I’ve included vinegar with its mother (AKA raw live vinegar) in today’s recipe
column19: but Katz assures me that it isn’t necessary and that vinegar can be made simply by leaving alcohol to oxidise. Dregs of leftover wine will make wine vinegar
column20: cider will make apple cider vinegar and beer malt vinegar; mixtures work
column21: too. Buy vinegar with the mother at big supermarkets or online
column22: and once you’ve made one batch
column23: keep some aside with the mother to seed your next batch of vinegar without any extra outlay at all. Live vinegar with the mother is a highly valued food product
column24: and
column25: considering how easy it is to make vinegar
column26: I’m going to start making a continuous batch at home using leftover wine. Katz told me how to do this: “I have an Italian-American friend called Ricky Boscarino
column27: who has a four- to six-litre cask with a little spigot and a hole at the top for making vinegar. If you have a bottle of wine at his house and there’s a bit left at the bottom at the end of the evening
column28: he pours it into the cask. Then
column29: when he’s making a salad dressing or whatever
column30: he’ll just open up the spigot
column31: release some vinegar and use that. He does this as a continuous process
column32: rather than making it in batches.” 300ml leftover alcohol (beer
column33: cider and/or wine diluted with the same amount of water) 100ml raw vinegar (ie with the mother) 1 x 500ml wide-mouthed jar (500ml or larger) Cheesecloth and a rubber band Narrow-neck bottles
column34: to store If you’re making wine vinegar
column35: dilute the wine with an equal volume of water first
column36: but cider and beer are fine just as they are. In a large
column37: wide-mouthed jar
column38: mix three parts beer
column39: cider or diluted wine with one part vinegar with its mother. Cover the top of the jar with a piece of cheesecloth
column40: seal in place with a rubber band
column41: then store in a warm place – in an airing cupboard or near a radiator
column42: say – and out of direct sunlight for a few weeks
column43: until the gluey smell dissipates and the contents taste properly acidic. A film
column44: or “mother”
column45: will form on the surface
column46: so once you’ve made your first batch
column47: save this mother and enough vinegar as the base for your next batch. As soon as the vinegar is ready
column48: decant into a sterilised bottle (or bottles)
column49: seal tightly and store in a cool place. Enjoy immediately
column50: or store for six months (or longer) for a superior taste.";https://www.theguardian.com/food/2022/jan/01/how-to-turn-leftover-alcohol-into-vinegar-recipe-zero-waste-cooking

column1: 6171;6171;I’ve been lied about and others get death threats. Covid has shown the power of misinformation | Devi Sridhar;2022-01-01T06:00:40Z;['Devi Sridhar'];['Coronavirus'
column2: 'Social media'
column3: 'Infectious diseases'
column4: 'Media'
column5: 'Digital media'
column6: 'UK news'
column7: 'Protest'];"Before the experience of the past two years of Covid-19
column8: I had assumed that a deadly viral outbreak would be quickly contained by governments. Especially in rich countries with good health systems
column9: public health infrastructure
column10: economic support packages and trust in public institutions. I thought there would be general consensus on what needed to be done
column11: and that people would get their information directly from experts working in universities and public health authorities. I mean
column12: who would want to risk getting a deadly infection? Now
column13: I wonder if an even more deadly virus – like a pandemic-ready version of Mers
column14: a coronavirus which killed 20% of those it infected in South Korea before being contained in 2015 – would be treated the same way as Covid-19. Would thousands of people show up at protests because theyhad read on Facebook that Mers was a hoax? Would there be similar scenarios at every pandemic after that? After my experience of actively working through the Covid-19 pandemic
column15: these possibilities seem horrifyingly possible. One of the most unpredictable aspects of the past two years
column16: and one of the most disheartening
column17: has been the rise of widespread misinformation. The line between facts and lies has disintegrated. Years of experience in infectious disease control and a doctorate or medical degree quickly became equivalent to the influencer on YouTube or Facebook who has garnered hundreds of thousands of followers by promoting exciting-but-untrue “facts”. You can see this clearly in the rise of anti-vaccine sentiment
column18: where popular conspiracists share stories about alleged side-effects such as how vaccines are microchipping our bodies
column19: or changing our DNA
column20: or poisoning us. This has gone far beyond social media chatter and personal resistance
column21: becoming an aggressive real-world campaign that has led to protests at hospitals
column22: health workers being attacked and scientists being mailed death threats. I’ve personally learned that lies spread faster than truth. People have written entire blogs attacking my expertise and sharing clear falsehoods – such as the claim that I have no published scientific papers
column23: or that I’m a global plant by the World Economic Forum or Gates Foundation
column24: or that I am a philosopher rather than a scientist (because I have a DPhil from Oxford). It’s easy to laugh at such obvious untruths
column25: until it sinks in that this clickbait gets shared thousands of times. People believe it
column26: and then they too share it. And there is no way to counter every single falsehood. These lies carry more weight among some internet communities than the fact that Edinburgh University evaluated my expertise and granted me a professorship. I always try to counter these claims by sharing my funding sources
column27: being transparent about what data I’m using for my analyses and advice
column28: and acknowledging that while I might get things wrong
column29: I always have tried to conduct myself with integrity and academic professionalism. But this isn’t always enough. There are many people voicing strong opinions who aren’t constrained the same way. Lots of politicians and leaders are seeking popularity
column30: often by actively opposing basic public health measures. There are social media celebrities who build followings by sharing emotionally appealing lies. There are even academics who staked a claim with a certain camp early in the pandemic
column31: and haven’t shifted their thinking despite new tools such as vaccines
column32: mass testing and antivirals becoming available.

column1: The power of misinformation can be seen in the number of people appearing in hospitals
column2: desperately sick with Covid-19 and struggling to breathe
column3: who still say it is a hoax
column4: and don’t believe that this is an actual virus (like many other viruses) that infects humans and makes us ill. A basic fact that somehow is harder for them to believe than the idea that this is a global conspiracy for government takeover of citizens. How is someone supposed to sift facts and real data from manufactured and glitzy stories on social media? There is little to no regulation of quality of data or sources on the internet. Some of the small lessons I’ve learned are to explain science clearly and simply so that it is comprehensible to everyone
column5: and to try to reach people in small groups or at an individual level; fighting misinformation on social media is a losing battle. Important too is for experts to engage with TV
column6: radio and newspapers
column7: as mass media still carries considerable influence. Now is the time to understand and address these problems. I’ve written a book – out next year – about the experience of advising government and trying to communicate the fast-moving science and policy of the pandemic to the public
column8: and hopefully how to do everything better next time. Reflecting and thinking ahead isn’t a theoretical exercise because we know that the next pandemic is coming – whether it is Mers or Sars or something else – and there may not be a quiet time to do it. Like everything else in the past two years
column9: we have to learn these lessons as we go. Prof Devi Sridhar is chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh";https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2022/jan/01/death-threats-covid-disinformation-public-health-expert-pandemic

column1: 6173;6173;Decision to exempt NSW health workers from Covid isolation reflects hospitals’ ‘desperate situation’;2022-01-01T06:00:08Z;['Donna Lu'];['Health'
column2: 'Coronavirus'
column3: 'New South Wales'
column4: 'Australia news'];"Doctors say a decision to exempt health workers in New South Wales from self-isolating if they are close contacts reflects an “extremely desperate situation”
column5: with warnings the policy change will increase the Covid risk to hospital patients. NSW Health announced late on Friday night that in “exceptional circumstances”
column6: frontline workers who are asymptomatic close contacts will be exempt from having to self-isolate for seven days
column7: to avoid disruption to key services. The exemption “allows these close contacts to leave self-isolation to attend their workplace
column8: provided they have been identified by their employer as critical to the service and cannot work from home.”

column1: Dr Chris Moy
column2: the vice-president of the Australian Medical Association
column3: said the policy change was indicative of the “enormous stress” the NSW health system was under “because of the increasing number of cases … Just as much
column4: it’s because of the number of staff who are having to be furloughed.” Covid hospitalisations in NSW were currently lower than at the peak of the Delta wave
column5: but had more than doubled in the last week. On Saturday
column6: there were 901 people in the state hospitalised with the virus
column7: compared to 388 on Christmas Day. The state now had one of the highest rates of Covid in the world. “It’s not just about the number of beds [taken]
column8: it’s about the number of staff to be able to safely provide healthcare
column9: ” Moy told Guardian Australia. “We’re having entire teams getting wiped out
column10: essentially.” As of 30 December
column12: 510 health workers across the state were self-isolating
column13: NSW Health confirmed to Guardian Australia. On Friday
column14: a leaked memo revealed St George hospital in Sydney’s south was already planning to fly in nurses in an attempt to deal with staffing shortages and surging Covid cases. Moy said that among medical professionals there was “a level of desperation which is not reflected in comments that the health system is holding up well”.

column1: Prof Nick Talley
column2: a physician and editor-in-chief of the Medical Journal of Australia
column3: agreed. “Obviously
column4: we’re in a very difficult
column5: perilous situation arguably
column6: despite all the assurances that the hospital system was robust and everything was going to be fine
column7: ” he said. Talley said the policy change was a means to “urgently deal with a major staffing matter which doesn’t seem to be fillable any other way”. “People will suffer or even die if we don’t have people caring for them in hospital
column8: but of course it will have some negative downsides that could be very serious as well
column9: ” he said. The self-isolation exemption would “put not only hospital workers at more risk from their colleagues
column10: but also patients in hospital will be at higher risk of catching Covid
column11: ” Talley said. “It’s a dreadful situation to have ended up in and it was potentially preventable if we hadn’t let go so early.”

column1: A senior doctor working in Sydney
column2: who spoke on the condition of anonymity
column3: described the situation in his health district as “at crisis point”. “Things are absolutely terrible
column4: with a combination of high numbers of patients and staff being off
column5: furloughed or sick
column6: ” he said
column7: adding there were high presentations to the emergency department and “ramping” – patients having to wait in ambulances because the department was full. He said though there were less Covid patients in the intensive care unit compared to the peak of the Delta wave
column8: staffing shortages meant the service had to “significantly cut back” on bed capacity. Omicron is linked to a substantially reduced risk of hospitalisation and admission into intensive care
column9: but experts said the variant’s transmissibility could still threaten to overwhelm the health system. “As cases rise massively
column10: there are still some people … who will need hospitalisation
column11: ” Talley said. “If you’ve got a huge number of people infected
column12: that’s a very significant load.” Moy said: “A large number [of people] are ending up in hospital at the same time
column13: but also a large number of staff are getting infected at the same time
column14: and they’ve been taken out of play.” To reduce the peak
column15: Moy said it was necessary to reconsider restrictions
column16: and to maximise TTIQ – test

column8: 'European Union']";"Six years ago on New Year’s Day
column9: an Iranian-Austrian IT businessman said goodbye to his wife and three children and boarded a flight from Vienna to Tehran via Istanbul. Kamran Ghaderi was due to return five to six days later
column10: but instead
column11: on 2 January 2016
column12: he was arrested and has now spent six years in Evin prison in Tehran. In October 2016
column13: he was sentenced to 10 years for spying for a foreign country at a trial in which neither he nor his lawyer were able to say more than two words. His sentencing was based on a confession he gave under what his wife
column14: Harika
column15: says was torture
column16: in the belief she might be in danger. No written judgment has ever been given to his family. “The effect on our three children – that is the most painful aspect of this story
column17: ” says Harika in an interview. “I cannot comfort them. My daughters were nine and 12 years old. Now they are 15 and 18. Our boy was two years old and now he is eight. He does not remember his father and he was asking every day
column18: ‘where is my father?’ I showed photos with him when he was a baby
column19: but he thought his father was dead. When he was four years old
column20: he asked whether his father was in prison. “The older children were scared they might be arrested too. They are still careful to see if anyone is following them.”

column1: Harika lost weight until she became “a skeleton”
column2: and despite taking pills found it difficult to sleep for more than two hours at a stretch. On this harrowing anniversary she recalls every aspect of his disappearance. In advance of his visit
column3: there had been no reason to be wary. Ghaderi – who had left Iran in 1983 to study electrical engineering in Vienna – was not a political activist. He had been on many business trips across the Middle East as an IT consultant
column4: and in 2015
column5: after the Iran nuclear deal
column6: he went on an official Austrian business delegation to Tehran led by the then Austrian president Heinz Fischer. Relations were on the up. Normally on his trips to Tehran he stayed with his elderly mother. Harika says: “On the first day I do not usually call him because he has a lot of meetings so I normally wait a day. This time when I spoke with his mother she said
column7: ‘No
column8: he is not here’
column9: so that was a big shock. “I first thought he might have had a heart attack on the plane. It was not a direct flight but there was a transit in Istanbul
column10: so I rang the airport in Istanbul and asked if he could be in a hospital. The airport said they had no such information. All I knew was that he had been onboard the flight from Vienna. It was a Sunday and all the travel agencies were closed so I drove to the airport
column11: and said I have to know whether he was on the flight from Istanbul or Tehran or not. They said they would not give information to a third party
column12: and I was screaming and shouting. I was not myself. “Next I thought a taxi driver had attacked him for his money – all kinds of things were in my mind
column13: but I never ever had the thought that he had been arrested by the government. The next day his brother went to Tehran airport and he was told he had been arrested and taken from there. We did not know who had arrested him
column14: or for what reason. One and a half months after his arrest
column15: the IRGC [the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps
column16: a branch of the Iranian armed forces] allowed him to call me
column17: and he was allowed to say
column18: ‘I am alive. Take care of yourself and the children.’ I asked him what had happened and – he was crying – he said he was not allowed to tell me.

column1: “Three months later his mother received a call and was told she could visit him. That visit so affected her that she had to be driven to hospital with high blood pressure. He had lost 16 kilos and he told her under pressure he had signed two confessions.” Ghaderi finds it painful that her husband is still in jail
column2: innocent
column3: and cut off from his family
column4: save a daily phone call
column5: while the Austrian foreign ministry has hosted since April an Iranian government delegation in Vienna to discuss the future of the country’s nuclear deal. It is perhaps not a coincidence that French
column6: German
column7: British and US dual nationals are held by Iran
column8: their countries being among the signatories to the stalled nuclear deal
column9: but the detention of Ghaderi and another dual national Massud Mossaheb
column10: the secretary of the Austro-Iranian Society
column11: is a puzzle. Ghaderi explains: “I have come to realise this was a business for Iran
column12: so my question to the Austrian ministry was ‘why him
column13: what do they want in return for Kamran?’ It may not be something directly from Austria but from the EU.” Either way
column14: the Austrian government has taken the softest of approaches to his plight
column15: insisting quiet diplomacy is the best solution. In an open letter to the ministry in April
column16: the two families begged to differ: “You do not publicly request their release
column17: nor do you publicly acknowledge the injustice
column18: torture and illegality of their imprisonment. After years of continuing to rely on ‘silent diplomacy’
column19: we interpret this either as a sign of resignation
column20: a lack of commitment or a lack of will to consider alternative strategies.” Looking through the public comments of the Austrian foreign ministry
column21: it is hard to know that two of its citizens have been arbitrarily detained. The foreign minister
column22: Alexander Schallenberg
column23: has met Harika only once
column24: when he was
column25: she says
column26: very kind
column27: but meetings between the hostage families and the ministry are rare. The greatest irony is that Iran is mounting a campaign asking Iranian citizens abroad to return to their country to work. Perhaps
column28: looking at Ghaderi’s family
column29: few in the diaspora will be rushing for a flight back to Tehran.";https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/01/kamran-ghaderi-why-does-austria-stay-silent-dual-nationals-arrest-six-years-ago-iran

column3: 'World news'];Residents of a town in north-west Spain have banded together to try to track down a convicted murderer – nicknamed the “Galician Rambo” for his multiple jailbreaks and extensive knowledge of survival techniques – who is believed to be living in a nearby wooded area. Alfredo Sánchez Chacón has been on the run since March when he failed to return to prison after being allowed out on a day pass. News that the 63-year-old was missing probably surprised few: Sánchez Chacón
column4: who is due to be in prison until 2025 for a murder in 1996
column5: was already notorious across Spain for slipping out of prison twice. His first escape was in 1999 when he reportedly strung together a series of sheets to shimmy down the walls of the Pontevedra prison as other inmates distracted the guards. For more than two years he remained on the run
column6: using his training as a former member of the Spanish Legion to hide out in the dense brush of northern Spain. In 2001 he managed to again break out of prison but his taste of freedom lasted just 25 minutes before he was caught
column7: according to the newspaper La Voz de Galicia. This time around it was months before alarm bells began to sound in the small town of Pontedeume
column8: in Galicia
column9: about 65 miles (105km) from the prison. At the end of summer
column10: the municipality’s 7
column11: 900 residents began trading stories of items that had mysteriously gone missing from their kitchens: packages of biscuits
column12: cans of beer and cold cuts. Others had closer calls: one person recounted how he had stumbled across a man in his kitchen
column13: peering into an open fridge
column14: in the middle of the night. Suspicions that it could be Sánchez Chacón intensified last week after a hunter stumbled upon a man who matched the fugitive’s description living in a makeshift camp in the dense woods of the Fragas do Eume park near the town. Desperate residents soon came together
column15: with eight of them announcing a patrol capable of combing the area for traces of Sánchez Chacón. “It’s outrageous that we’re caught in this
column16: ” one resident told La Voz de Galicia
column17: while another hinted that this might not be the residents’ first brush with the Galician Rambo. “He was already hiding in the Fragas do Eume [park] more than 20 years ago
column18: in another of his famous escapes.”;https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/01/spanish-town-comes-together-in-hunt-for-galician-rambo
